John Mayer's ''Born and Raised'' (Columbia) topped the Billboard album chart for a second week, but that was not a huge accomplishment, since sales were anemic all around. Mr. Mayer needed to sell only 65,000 copies to hold onto the top slot, the smallest number for a No. 1 album since Feb. 2011, when Nicki Minaj's ''Pink Friday'' was on top after selling only 45,000. Overall, album sales are down 3 percent since January compared to the same period last year. Adele's ''21'' (XL/Columbia) remained at No. 2, after a slight boost in sales from a prime-time special on NBC featuring the British soul singer. That album is turning into a juggernaut of historical weight. It has been in the Top 10 for 67 weeks and is closing in on 10 million in sales. Only six other albums have spent longer at the top of the Billboard 200.

At the end of 2007, Rajat K. Gupta had an investment in a Galleon Group fund worth $16.4 million. Less than a year later, his stake in the fund was wiped out. Mr. Gupta's lawyers have argued that he and Raj Rajaratnam, the former head of the now-defunct Galleon Group hedge fund, had a falling out over the fund's collapse and as a result, Mr. Gupta had no reason to leak corporate secrets to Mr. Rajaratnam.

During the last meeting of the She Owns It business group we introduced Deirdre Lord, an owner of The Megawatt Hour, and Beth Shaw, who owns YogaFit. Ms. Lord talked about a marketing opportunity that her company was scrambling to maximize, and Ms. Shaw shared her desire to get out of the apparel business and focus on education, her company's core competency. Ideally, she would like to license the apparel side of her business. We also caught up with the other members of the group. YogaFit's unsuccessful foray into the sale of nonbranded clothing has left it with $500,000 worth of unsold merchandise to unload. Susan Parker, who owns Bari Jay, said she could relate to that. With prom season ending she is also looking to get rid of inventory. ''Next year, these prom dresses will be worth less than they are right now,'' she said.

CLAIMING HIS NAMESAKE The board of Kenneth Cole Productions said Wednesday that it had accepted a takeover offer by Kenneth Cole, left, the company's founder, who plans to take it private. The announcement caps a lengthy review by a special board committee, which was tasked in February with evaluating Mr. Cole's proposal. The bid, which values the company at about $279 million, or $15.25 a share, represents a 17 percent premium to the clothing maker's stock price on the day before the management buyout proposal was disclosed. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

I have gained tremendous insight reading the comments on this blog. One in particular really struck me recently. It came in response to a post that I had written quite a while ago, ''The Dirty Little Secret of Successful Companies,'' and it illustrates the huge difference in perspective that can exist between the owners of companies and their employees. Here is the comment: There is nothing wrong with being an average (mediocre) employee. Not everyone aspires to be in management. If the person meets the requirements of their current job, and they like the job and want to stay in the job, so be it. Stop trying to force people to get to the next level. The reality is that work is not the most important thing in everyone's lives. People have more important things in their life than work. Work is simply a means to get the money we need to pay the mortgage and our other bills. Work is a low-priority event for most people. I'm only willing to do the bare minimum that it takes to get a paycheck every two weeks. As long as I am meeting the requirements of my job, than that is good enough. Don't expect any more of me because I will not be a slave to any company. -- Jo-Ann Youngblood, Tulsa, OK

An article on Tuesday about treatments for epilepsy that focus on the role of inflammation in the disease misidentified the drug regimen prescribed for William Moller, a Brooklyn boy whose seizures abated with steroid therapy. Q.I am going to Europe and plan to take my mobile phone. I looked on the power adapter and the label said it ranges from 100 to 240 volts. Does that mean I don't need to pack an electrical converter for the trip? A. Most consumer electronic devices like mobile phones, media players, cameras, laptops and e-book readers and so on come with power adapters that can handle a range of voltage and frequencies without an extra converter. If the label on your adapter says something like ''Input: 100-240VAC,'' with a reference to ''50-60 Hz,'' it should be fine operating in countries with electrical voltage running between 100 volts and 240 volts, and frequencies of 50 to 60 Hertz.

GUTIN--Marvin, artist, quintessential Upper Westsider, and owner of that neighborhood's institution, Marvin Gardens restaurant, died early Wednesday morning. His first one-man show was in 1966 at the Ward Eggleston Gallery in New York City and thereafter he never stopped painting. He served in the Navy during WWII, and leaves his wife, Sukey; children Charles, Elizabeth, Julia and Cris (who pre-deceased him); grandchildren Samuel, Sydney and Cary Gutin, Aimee and Valerie Nedo, and Lauren Masten.

OLTCHICK--Gertrude Thypin, passed away peacefully at home on Wednesday evening, surrounded by her family. She was a very young 96 years old. When asked her secret to good health and longevity her motto was "Everything in Moderation". Gert and her brother Dave Thypin were long time partners in Thypin Steel Co., founded in 1910 by their father Abraham. She was a modest woman, but received many awards that recognized her as a successful woman in a man's business environment. After retiring at age 87, she became very involved in her community of Rockaway Beach, as an active member of Temple Beth-El and a volunteer and champion fundraiser for Peninsula Hospital. A working woman who put family first, Gert was a role model to many. As the matriarch of a large and close family, she was an inspirational and adored "Aunt Gertie". Her legacy lives on in her children Stuart and Judi Oltchick, Arlene and Larry Gilbert, and Ellen and Howard Deixler, her grandchildren Amy, Peter and Amanda, Eric and Assunta, Jay, Avi, and Ben, and her great-grandchildren Marinda, Katherine, Zoe, and Andrew. In Gert's memory, donations may be made to The Thypin Oltchick Institute for Women's Entrepreneurship at FEGS or to your favorite charity. Funeral service Friday, June 8, 11:45am, at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Kimmel--Herbert D.,Ph.D. Originally from New York, died at home in Charleston, SC, June 5, 2012. He was 85. His loving wife, Barbara, was with him. From his humble Brooklyn beginnings, he joined the navy in WWII and later graduated from the University of Florida, earned a M.A. from NYU and a Ph.D. from USC. A Distinguished Research Professor of Psychology, Emeritus, of the University of South Florida, Herb was a man of boundless intellectual energy and a consummate scholar, well-known for his research in classical and instrumental conditioning, as well as the original studies of biofeedback. He exuded a passion for life that enveloped those around him. An athlete, an avid traveler and an artist who wrote poetry, fiction, lyrics and music, he founded Jazz West Records. The world is a better place because of his many scientific and artistic achievements and his profound personal relationships. He is survived by his devoted wife of 33 years, Barbara; four daughters, Ellie, Ann (Ritt Ritter), Jean, and Tracy (Jim Florack); and seven grand children. Colleagues, friends, and family are asked to celebrate his life in their own special ways. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to the MUSC Foundation for Internal Medicine Support Fund, 18 Bee Street, Charleston, SC 29425, 843-792-2677. "Each moment lived complete will always be, a lasting part of sweet eternity." (from "Embers Glow", Herbert Kimmel, 1956)

OLTCHICK--Gertrude Thypin. The Board of Directors and the Staff of FEGS Health & Human Services mourn with great sorrow the passing of Gertrude Thypin Oltchick, beloved mother of Stuart Oltchick, President of the FEGS Board of Directors. Gertrude Thypin Oltchick was an extraordinary woman - devoted mother, grandmother, aunt, friend, mentor and colleague; skilled and successful entrepreneur; activist who enjoyed and lived life to its fullest. FEGS is honored to continue her legacy through The Thypin Oltchick Institute for Women's Entrepreneurship, established by the generosity of her family in her honor, recognizing the extraordinary impact she made as one of the first women entrepreneurs in the steel industry. She leaves a legacy to all who strive for dignity and independence, the embodiment of FEGS's mission. Our deepest sympathies to Stuart (Judi), Ellen (Howard), Arlene (Larry), and the many adored grandchildren and family. Joseph Stein, Jr., Chairman Gail Magaliff, CEO

FORT WORTH, Tex. - More than four months after withdrawing from the Republican presidential race, Gov. Rick Perry addressed thousands of conservative Texans on Thursday here at the state Republican Party convention, poking fun at his own gaffe-filled campaign and throwing his support behind his onetime rival Mitt Romney. Last year, Mr. Perry soared to the top of the polls after announcing he was running for president, but then struggled to keep his early lead after a series of missteps, particularly during the debates. ''Oops,'' he famously uttered during a debate after failing to recall the name of one of the three federal agencies he said would eliminate if elected president.

An article last Friday about the money contributed by trial lawyers to Republican races in Texas misstated Steve Mostyn's title at the Texas Trial Lawyers Association. He is the immediate past president, not the president.

Every spring, corporate chieftains and their boards squash uprisings from a familiar batch of pugnacious investors, a ritual that shields many companies from major change. This proxy season was different. In recent weeks, chief executives and directors have gone up against a more formidable foe than the typical corporate gadfly: the mainstream investor.

And in the end, the profits you take are a function of the sales you make. But without enough paying visitors, a German museum dedicated to the memorabilia of the Beatles and situated on the Hamburg street where the band played some of its earliest shows is planning to close at the end of the month, The Guardian reported. The museum, called Beatlemania, opened in May 2009 and offered more than 1,000 Beatles-related items, exhibitions, listening stations and plenty of kitsch, including a life-size recreation of the Yellow Submarine. Its location on the Reeperbahn, a nightlife (and red-light) district in Hamburg, was meant to evoke connections to local clubs like Top Ten and the Kaiserkeller, where the Beatles first performed in the early 1960s.

When Kiva Ford returns from his job as a glass blower for a pharmaceutical company, he usually takes up his hobby: making creations to sell at art shows or online.

13P, a New York City collective of 13 writers who teamed to produce one play by each member, will mount its final show in July before disbanding after nearly nine years, the organization announced on Thursday. The last production will be a chamber music adaptation by the playwright Sarah Ruhl and the composer Todd Almond of Ms. Ruhl's 2001 farce, ''Melancholy Play,'' which will be performed July 18-27 at the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn. The director will be Davis McCallum (''February House''), and the actors will be David Greenspan, Erik Lochtefeld, April Matthis, Sarah Tolan-Mee, and Amy Warren. In its original form ''Melancholy Play'' included a cellist who performed through much of the show, which centers on a doleful young woman whose sudden turn toward happiness has strange effects on those around her. Ms. Ruhl, a Pulitzer Prize finalist and Tony nominee for her 2009 comedy ''In the Next Room, or the vibrator play,'' said in a statement that the play was always structured as a chamber piece and that the new production would shift from the single cello to an entire string quartet.

An article on Wednesday about the racehorse owner J. Paul Reddam, who was once a philosophy professor, misidentified the racing event where he quoted the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein saying, ''After all the philosophical problems have been solved, nothing of importance will have been accomplished.'' He said that after his horse I'll Have Another won the Kentucky Derby, not after the horse won the Preakness Stakes.

LINGERING SUIT SETTLED A group of Bear Stearns shareholders who claimed to have been hurt by the investment bank's deteriorating health agreed on Wednesday to settle its claims for $275 million, four years after the firm was sold to JPMorgan Chase. The pact, which still needs court approval, would end years of litigation. Former Bear Stearns executives, including James E. Cayne, left, the chief executive, were named in the suit. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

Federal prosecutors have charged the singer and actress Lauryn Hill with failing to file income tax returns for three years during which she earned more than $1.6 million. Prosecutors in New Jersey said in a court document that Ms. Hill, an eight-time Grammy Award winner, did not file tax returns in 2005, 2006, and 2007, even though she owns and operates four corporations, tours as a musician and earns royalties from recordings and films she has made. She is scheduled to appear before a magistrate in federal court in Newark on June 29 to answer the charges. Ms. Hill, 37, of South Orange, N.J., got her start in music as a singer with the Fugees in the early 1990s and started a solo career in 1998, releasing the critically acclaimed album, ''The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill.''

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about efforts to prevent abusive relationships with programs directed at middle school students omitted, at two points, part of the name of a foundation involved in the effort. It is the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation -- not the Johnson Foundation, an organization not connected to the project.

The High and Low Finance column on May 25, about federal government aid to for-profit colleges like ITT Technical Institute, misstated the number of states in which ITT has campuses. It is 39, not 48. (The institute has students in 48 states, but some of them take classes online rather than at campuses.)

In April Lincoln Center announced that Christian Marclay's much-loved ''The Clock'' -- a 24-hour montage of clips from movies and television that depict particular minutes in the day, synchronized with the moment they are shown -- is coming to Lincoln Center's David Rubenstein Atrium, on Broadway between 62nd and 63rd Streets, where it will be shown free. Now the dates and hours of the run have been announced: July 13 through Aug. 1, Tuesdays through Thursdays, 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. and continuously from Fridays at 8 a.m. through Sundays at 10 p.m. It will not be shown on Mondays.

DONHAUSER--Rathbun Paige 88, died peacefully on June 3, 2012, in New York City. He is survived by his beloved wife, Rosine (nee Lambiotte), daughter Caroline R. and son Peter L. Donhauser, son-in-law Victor Barall, daughter-in-law Whitney W. Donhauser, granddaughters Amelia W. and Cecile L. Donhauser, and devoted nieces and nephews. Born June 28, 1923, in Albany, NY, he graduated from the Albany Academy and the Taft School. He received a B.A. and Masters of Architecture from Yale University and served in the United States Army, European theater, during World War II. As an architect, he worked independently in Caracas, Venezuela, then as a senior associate for the firm of Edward Durell Stone and Associates. Among his numerous design contributions were those as project architect for the United States Pavilion at the 1958 Brussels World's Fair and for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Washington, D.C. Before retiring, he was in private practice. He resided in New York City and New Concord, NY, where he found joy in the beauty of the wildlife and the land and fulfilled his dream of creating a garden resplendent and delightful. Memorial service will be private.

Representative Ron Paul may be the most libertarian of the Republicans who ran in the 2012 primaries, but he is encouraging his supporters with delegate estimates that veer toward liberal. In a statement late last night, Mr. Paul suggested that, either officially or in spirit, his backers would represent ''just over 20 percent'' of the delegates at the Republican National Convention in August.

An iPad app by Inkle Studios and Profile Books based on Mary Shelley's ''Frankenstein'' drew some rave reviews for its sophisticated choose-your-own-adventure approach when it was released in April. Now a second ambitious interactive take on the classic monster novel has jolted to life in Apple's App Store, courtesy of the New York Public Library. ''Frankenstein: The Afterlife of Shelley's Circle,'' created with the developer Potion and downloadable free, is the second release in the library's Biblion: The Boundless Library series. Based on the library's Carl H. Pforzheimer Collection of Shelley and His Circle, it includes full digital scans of Mary Shelley's 1816-1817 handwritten manuscript, on loan from the Bodleian Libraries, her husband Percy Bysshe Shelley's Esdaile Notebook (containing his earliest known poems) and the stunning scrapbook-like ''friendship albums'' of two women from the larger social and literary circles surrounding the poet.

PETRUSKY--Susan Alane Maros, 47, of Bronxville, NY, passed away May 22, 2012 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Peter Petrusky and loving mother of Zachary and Samantha. Daughter of Frank G. Maros and Sally Engstrom, sister of Diane Lamb, Karen Maros and Lynne Kramer (deceased). Born in Park Ridge, NJ, and raised in Media, PA, Susan graduated with a BS in Finance at the University of Delaware. Susan was Managing Director at Bank of America in New York City. Susan was devoted to her two beautiful children, who were her greatest passion. A Funeral Mass will be held on June 9 at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville, NY at 10:45am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Susan's honor to St. Jude Hospital: www.stjude.org and to the Humane Society at: www.humanesociety.org.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Thursday about the weekly Billboard album chart misspelled part of the name of the band whose album ''Here'' ranked No. 5. The band is Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros, not Sharp.

KELLER--Seymour P. Seymour P.,Keller, 89, Physicist, Emeritus of IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, NY, and longtime resident of Chappaqua, NY, died June 6, 2012 in Brighton, MA. After earning a Ph.D. in Chemistry from the University of Chicago, Keller spent his entire research career at IBM, primarily at Yorktown Heights but also consulting at the Zurich and San Jose labs. During his tenure, Keller was the Director of the Physical Science Research Dept, and served as consultant to IBM's Director of Research. Editor of Handbook of Semiconductors: Materials (1980), Keller also taught at the Universities of Bochum, Grenoble, Stuttgart and Trieste. As a recruiter of research physicists and chemists, he made a lasting imprint on the scientific community with his uncanny ability to recognize promise and excellence. His no-nonsense advice and support, both personal and professional, resulted in significant advances in the field of solid state physics. Perhaps best remembered by family and friends as an informed cook and gourmet, he enjoyed travel and all things intellectual and cultural. Seymour is survived by his wife of 62 years, Pearl Josephson; children Jan (Howard Schultz), David (Mary Maxwell), Richard (Teruyo Shimazu), Lisa (Daniel Lee); grandchildren Peri (Joshua Zelig), Michael, Daniel, Saskia, Olivia, Jonathan; and great-grandson Benjamin. Memorial services will be held Sunday at 12 noon at Stanetsky Memorial Chapel, 1668 Beacon St., Brookline, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the University of Chicago or the Glaucoma Research Foundation. Stanetsky Memorial Chapel www.stanetskybrookline.com

GELLER--Jerome C.,"Jerry", June 6 at age 91 in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Formerly of New York. Harvard '42. Leaves behind his adoring and adored wife, Mitzi Edelberg, their son Seth and three sons by previous marriage; Anthony, Mitchell, Jeffrey. Enjoyed a long career in the fashion textile industry. Dedicated sponsor to recovering addicts. Loved the New York Jets, Knicks, tennis, chess, bridge. Always the optimist.

BILDNER--Albert. The leadership, staff, and worldwide community of the Weizmann Institute of Science deeply mourn the passing of our beloved friend and advocate, Albert Bildner. Al shared his devotion to many Israeli and American philanthropic causes with his late father, Benjamin Bildner, a long-time supporter of the Institute. Al served on the Institute's Board of Governors and Executive Council. He was Honorary Vice Chairman of the American Committee and a member of the Palm Beach Regional Board. Along with his wife Lin, Al was inducted as a member of the Weizmann Institute's President's Circle in recognition of their generous support. Al's significant gifts to advance Weizmann research over the years included the establishment of the Patricia Elman Bildner Professorial Chair of Solid State Chemistry, in honor of his late wife. We will always remember Al for his visionary leadership, generosity, and compassionate spirit. We extend heartfelt condolences to Lin and their son Max. May Al's memory be for a blessing. Lawrence S. Blumberg, Chairman American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Marshall S. Levin, Executive V.P. & C.E.O. American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President Weizmann Institute

An obituary last Friday about the Hall of Fame basketball player Jack Twyman included several errors. In the 1959-60 season, when Twyman averaged 31.2 points a game and he and Wilt Chamberlain became the first two N.B.A. players to average more than 30 in a season, Chamberlain's average was 37.6 points, not 32.1. When Twyman retired in 1966, a number of players -- not just Chamberlain -- had scored more points in their career than Twyman's 15,840. The University of Cincinnati, where Twyman played college basketball, and St. Francis College, where his future teammate Maurice Stokes played, met in the National Invitation Tournament in 1955, not in 1954, in a consolation game to determine the third-place finisher, not in the semifinals. And in that game, Stokes outscored Twyman, 31-29; Twyman did not outscore Stokes, 27-26.

Who will win the Belmont? A half-dozen New York Times staffers offer their thoughts, led by Joe Drape, who writes about racing and would love to see a Triple Crown winner. But he's not holding his breath. Seven times now I have headed out to Belmont Park on a Saturday in June hoping that I was about to see a horse capture the Triple Crown. Seven times I have been disappointed.

Cynthia von Buhler figured the simplest way to make sense of a Depression-era murder that intrigued her was to reconstruct the crime scene. She wanted to be able to look at it from every angle, to manipulate the lamp post on the corner or the sleek sedan parked at the curb. She hoped that recreating everything in minute detail would help her understand why the trigger had been pulled, not once but twice - and whether the racketeer known as Dutch Schultz was somehow behind the deed.

The Federal Reserve proposed on Thursday that the country's banks adopt a broad package of international regulations aimed at making the global financial system more resilient to shocks. The proposal, drafted by a group of central banks and national bank regulators, would require banks to hold sturdier buffers against losses. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision devised the rules, known as Basel III, after the 2008 financial crisis revealed the frailty of global banks.

A limited number of tickets to a memorial service next week for Maurice Sendak are being made available to the public. The service will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, June 12, in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. People interested in tickets can send an e-mail to Sendakmemorial@gmail.com. There is a limit of two per request, and those seeking tickets will be notified by e-mail. Mr. Sendak, the author of ''Where the Wild Things Are'' and many other children's books, died last month. The playwright Tony Kushner, a friend of Mr. Sendak, said several people who knew the author thought it was a good idea to reserve some seats for the public ''because his work meant so much to so many people, and it meant a lot to him that people loved'' his books. Approximately 100 tickets will be available.

FERKAUF--Eugene. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Eugene Ferkauf. Along with his wife, Estelle, Eugene was a dedicated philanthropist. His legacy lives on through the generosity of his loving family. We extend our condolences to Estelle; to their daughter, Lenore (Robert) Bronstein, a cherished colleague and friend; their two other children, Amy and Bobby; their grandchildren; their great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, is raising questions about Brett McGurk, President Obama's nominee for ambassador to Iraq, after leaked e-mails surfaced purporting to show that Mr. McGurk had a relationship with an Iraq correspondent for The Wall Street Journal while he was the Bush White House's top Iraq adviser. Mr. Inhofe has not yet put a hold on Mr. McGurk's nomination, an aide said. But the senator canceled a planned meeting with Mr. McGurk. ''I don't think we'd say we've reached the decision point yet,'' Jared Young, Mr. Inhofe's press secretary, said in an interview.

And though a recent federal appeals court ruling has provided some hope to gays and lesbians that their unions could potentially be recognized by the federal government, nothing has changed just yet. That means that same-sex couples, including those who live in states that recognize their unions, should take extra care when setting up their financial life with a partner or spouse. You can find some basic tool kits and resources on Web sites like Lambda Legal and the Human Rights Campaign. But if you want more tailored advice, you should try to seek out a professional who is well-versed in these issues.

Pete Cosey, a guitarist who played on many blues and R&B records in the 1960s but who became best known for his work in Miles Davis's electric band of 1973-75, contributing a sound drenched in distortion and punctuated by the wah-wah pedal, died on May 30 in Chicago. He was 68. The cause was complications of surgery, said his daughter Mariama Cosey.

Last fall, DC Comics reintroduced its heroes in 52 new series, all starting with issue No. 1. This September the publisher will be going even further back in time, with plans to unveil an issue No. 0 for each of those series. Last year's reboot left readers with a lot of questions on the back stories of Superman, Wonder Woman and their caped-and-colorful brethren, and executives at DC Comics said that these issues will tell a complete origin story or provide some detail of an hero's background. They'll also introduce some characters who still have not been seen in the ''New 52,'' which is what DC calls the initiative, as well as provide new complications for the heroes.

Many employers are clueless about the fees they and their employees pay for operation of their 401(k) plans, a recent report from the Government Accountability Office finds. Understanding 401(k) fees is important, because they can make a big difference in the amount workers eventually have available for retirement.

A federal judge indicated Thursday that the police did not adequately warn Occupy Wall Street protesters against walking on the roadway of the Brooklyn Bridge before arresting about 700 of them in October. The ruling, by Judge Jed S. Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, allows a class-action suit filed by protesters to proceed against police officers and commanders involved in the arrests. But the ruling dismissed the mayor, the police commissioner and the City of New York as defendants in the suit, saying that there was insufficient evidence that those parties were responsible for any misconduct by the police.

A small fire broke out Friday afternoon in an apartment building on Central Park West where Robert De Niro lives, according to Fire Department officials and residents of the building. The fire, which started on the fourth floor of the 12-story Brentmore at 88 Central Park West, was contained by 2:56 p.m., about an hour after a call was made to the Fire Department. Some residents said it started in the laundry room of Mr. De Niro's apartment; the apartment spans the fourth, fifth and sixth floors.

Ada María Isasi-Díaz would have become a Roman Catholic priest, she told friends, if not for the church's ban on ordaining women. Instead, she became a dissident theologian who spoke for those she considered the neglected spiritual core of the church's membership: Hispanic women like herself. Dr. Isasi-Díaz, who died of cancer in New York on May 13, was widely known in North and South America as the chief theorist behind Mujerista theology -- she published a book of the same name in 1996 -- which extols the role of Hispanic women, especially the poor, in personifying Christian faith in the everyday struggles of life. She was 69.

LIPTON--Harvey, former general counsel for Hearst Corporation, member of the Board of Directors and a trustee of the trust established under the Will of William Randolph Hearst, died suddenly June 8, 2012 at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, NY. He was 86. Lipton began his distinguished career at Hearst in 1950 as a law clerk. In 1951, he joined the Office of General Counsel as a lawyer. He was appointed general counsel and became secretary of Hearst Corporation in 1966, a post he held until his retirement in 1990. In 1975, Lipton was appointed to Hearst's Board of Directors. He continued to be a legal consultant to Hearst Corporation, member of the Board of Directors and a trustee of the trust established under the Will of William Randolph Hearst until his death. "Harvey was both a valued friend and a trusted colleague to all of us who had the pleasure of working with him," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., executive vice chairman and CEO of Hearst Corporation. "His service as general counsel for 24 years meant he was an important and effective player in Hearst's major changes and events during those years. We were also fortunate to have his good advice and engagement after his retirement in his capacity as a director of the Corporation and a trustee until his death. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family." Lipton graduated from New York University in 1948 and graduated summa cum laude from St. John's Law School in 1951, and thereafter was awarded a doctorate of law. He was a member of the New York County Lawyers Association. Lipton went to Far Rockaway High School and lived in East Rockaway for the majority of his life. Generous donations to a host of philanthropic organizations were his priority. Lipton is predeceased by his wife, the former Pearl Barsky, and survived by two children, Diane Gail Gollub and Charles Norman Lipton, and five grandchildren, Hayley and Ross Gollub, and Jonah, Samantha and Morgana Lipton. Services will be held Monday, June 11, 2012, at 2pm at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY, phone: 516-764-9400. Donations may be made to Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre, 295 Main Street, East Rockaway, NY, 11518, phone: 516-599-2634.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) BRIDESMAIDS (2011) A maid of honor (Kristen Wiig, far right, with, from left, Melissa McCarthy, Ellie Kemper, Rose Byrne, Wendi McLendon-Covey and Maya Rudolph) struggles with her financial and romantic woes as she tries to plan the perfect wedding for her best friend (Ms. Rudolph) in this comedy about women in love -- with men, and with one another. Ms. Wiig and Annie Mumolo wrote the script, and Paul Feig directed; Ms. McCarthy, who earned an Oscar nomination; Ms. Byrne; Ms. McLendon-Covey and Ms. Kemper play the bride's friends, who make it through a dress fitting, a bachelorette party and a bridal shower that go very, very wrong. Ms. Wiig and Ms. Mumolo, who also received an Oscar nod for best original screenplay, ''ask the question facing every modern woman who jumps at the chance to enact the latter-day equivalent of being passed from man to man, father to husband, if without a bushel of dowry corn and 12 goats: How do you survive getting down the aisle?'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''With a little, or rather a lot, of help from your friends, or so say the filmmakers, for better for worse, for richer for poorer, in sickness and in health, to love and to cherish, till misunderstanding, jealousy, other people or just life us do part.'' 8 P.M. (Discovery) STEPHEN HAWKING'S GRAND DESIGN In the first of two episodes based on ''The Grand Design,'' his 2010 book with Leonard Mlodinow, Mr. Hawking uses the writings of Descartes and advances in quantum physics to get at the meaning of life. He also answers questions like, ''Do we have free will, or are we just complex beings working within the laws of nature?'' and ''Who are we, and why are we here?'' In ''The Theory of Everything,'' at 9, he delves into the existence of the universe.

The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about the reaction to the hiring by Alcorn State, a historically black university, of a white football coach, misidentified the position of Ed Hill at Howard University, another historically black university. He is the sports information director, not the athletic director.

An article in some editions on Thursday about a settlement between the co-chief executives of Archie Comic Publications, of Mamaroneck, N.Y., included several errors. It was Richard Goldwater (not Michael) whose estate sold a 25 percent share of the business to one of the chief executives, Jon Goldwater. And Richard and Jon were half brothers, not brothers. The other chief executive, Nancy Silberkleit, is the trustee of the Silberkleit Trust, which holds 50 percent of Archie Comic Publications; Jon Goldwater owns 25 percent. They do not each control 50 percent of the business. (The other 25 percent is in a trust for Richard Goldwater's three daughters.) And the settlement was reached through court-recommended mediation, not through arbitration.

Eleven years ago this summer, Lt. Harry Wanamaker Jr., a 58-year-old veteran New York City firefighter assigned to Marine Company 1, posed proudly on a fireboat against the skyline of Lower Manhattan with Welles Remy Crowther, 24, an equities trader at Sandler O'Neill & Partners who worked on the 104th floor of 2 World Trade Center. On the face of it, they seemed to have little in common. But there was in fact a close bond. Both men were volunteer members of the Empire Hook and Ladder Company, No. 1, in Upper Nyack, N.Y., and Lieutenant Wanamaker was among the firefighters who had trained Mr. Crowther.

The wife of Al Qaeda's leader, Ayman al-Zawahri, has made a rare online appeal to Muslim women, praising their role in the Arab Spring uprisings and urging them to raise their children ''to love jihad and martyrdom.'' The Eisenhower Memorial planned for Washington's National Mall has encountered yet another hurdle. The secretary of the interior, Ken Salazar, has asked to see large models of the Frank Gehry-designed memorial to honor Dwight D. Eisenhower later this month, a Web site about Washington, dcist.com, reported on Thursday. ''Our priority must be to get it right,'' a spokesman for the department said in a statement. ''We will continue to work with the Eisenhower family'' and the Eisenhower Memorial Commission ''toward a plan that everyone can all be proud of and that will stand the test of time.''

5:05 p.m. | Updated Comcast is exploring whether the British Sky Broadcasting Group, Britain's largest satellite broadcaster and a lucrative pay TV asset 39 percent owned by News Corporation, could become available for purchase, according to several people briefed on the company's strategic thinking. Comcast's thinking about a possible deal is in the preliminary stages, and the company has not made a formal offer or even approached BSkyB or News Corporation about negotiations, said these people, who were not authorized to speak publicly about the company's strategy.

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about online services to substitute for features of Apple's soon-to-be-discontinued MobileMe, rendered incorrectly the name of a company that provides online backup storage. It is Dropbox, not DropBox. The column also misstated the maximum amount of storage available through upgrades to customers who refer friends to the services. It is 16 gigabytes, not 8 gigabytes.
An Op-Ed article on Thursday about counterinsurgency misstated the year President John F. Kennedy warned West Point graduates about the dangers of such warfare. It was 1962, not 1961.

There was I'll Have Another at one end of the leather tether, looking every bit the wonder horse, with his coat combed to a chestnut glow and his mane braided and glimmering. At the other was his trainer, Doug O'Neill, leading his colt out of Barn 2 at Belmont Park for a shockingly final bow before a battery of cameras on Friday. It was hardly the farewell anyone connected with the Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes champion - or for that matter anyone enamored of horse racing - had envisioned. The third act of the Triple Crown drama was supposed to play out on Saturday in the 144th running of the Belmont Stakes, with I'll Have Another having a chance to become the 12th horse to sweep America's three classic races and earn horse racing's most cherished title.

Kimmel--Herbert D.,Ph.D. Originally from New York, died at home in Charleston, SC, June 5, 2012. He was 85. His loving wife, Barbara, was with him. From his humble Brooklyn beginnings, he joined the navy in WWII and later graduated from the University of Florida, earned a M.A. from NYU and a Ph.D. from USC. A Distinguished Research Professor of Psychology, Emeritus, of the University of South Florida, Herb was a man of boundless intellectual energy and a consummate scholar, well-known for his research in classical and instrumental conditioning, as well as the original studies of biofeedback. He exuded a passion for life that enveloped those around him. An athlete, an avid traveler and an artist who wrote poetry, fiction, lyrics and music, he founded Jazz West Records. The world is a better place because of his many scientific and artistic achievements and his profound personal relationships. He is survived by his devoted wife of 33 years, Barbara; four daughters, Ellie, Ann (Ritt Ritter), Jean, and Tracy (Jim Florack); and seven grand children. Colleagues, friends, and family are asked to celebrate his life in their own special ways. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to the MUSC Foundation for Internal Medicine Support Fund, 18 Bee Street, Charleston, SC 29425, 843-792-2677. "Each moment lived complete will always be, a lasting part of sweet eternity." (from "Embers Glow", Herbert Kimmel, 1956)

The Wilson Quarterly, the 36-year-old general interest magazine published by the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington, has announced that it will put out its final print issue in July. ''We're not going on the Web per se,'' Steven Lagerfeld, the magazine's editor, said in an interview. ''We already have a Web site. The magazine will simply be published in a somewhat different form as an app,'' first in the iTunes store and later on the Android platform.

John Goberman, who created PBS's much-honored series ''Live From Lincoln Center'' more than three decades ago, is leaving as the show's executive producer at the end of the month, Lincoln Center said Friday. The program, which began on Jan. 30, 1976, has in more than 200 live telecasts given millions of viewers a front-row seat to opera, orchestra, dance and theater productions at Lincoln Center, brought to air under existing performance conditions without extra lights or overly intrusive cameras. After leaving Lincoln Center, Mr. Goberman, 71, will continue to stage concert galas, video productions and symphonic cinema events, in which orchestral scores are performed live to films, Lincoln Center said.

When Mario Gutierrez came from virtually nowhere to ride I'll Have Another to victory in the Kentucky Derby, Donna Barton Brothers was waiting just beyond the finish line to interview him in her role as analyst for NBC - on horseback. For Brothers, being on a horse comes more naturally than holding a microphone. Her mother, Patti Barton, was a trailblazer for women jockeys, and Brothers, her sister and her brother followed in her footsteps. When Brothers retired in 1998, she was the second-winningest female rider in the United States by money earned. But she never strayed too far away from the sport she loved. She is married to a horse trainer, Frank Brothers, and works as an analyst for NBC Sports and TVG. Q.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week's image. It is not often that I covet a fly's ensemble. Yet during my last visit to Corson's Brook Woods, I was wowed by a golden-backed snipe fly's all-black outfit, with its lavish gold midsection and smoky wing venation. The fashion house of Alexander McQueen couldn't have done much better.

OLTCHICK--Gertrude Thypin, passed away peacefully at home on Wednesday evening, surrounded by her family. She was a very young 96 years old. When asked her secret to good health and longevity her motto was "Everything in Moderation". Gert and her brother Dave Thypin were long time partners in Thypin Steel Co., founded in 1910 by their father Abraham. She was a modest woman, but received many awards that recognized her as a successful woman in a man's business environment. After retiring at age 87, she became very involved in her community of Rockaway Beach, as an active member of Temple Beth-El and a volunteer and champion fundraiser for Peninsula Hospital. A working woman who put family first, Gert was a role model to many. As the matriarch of a large and close family, she was an inspirational and adored "Aunt Gertie". Her legacy lives on in her children Stuart and Judi Oltchick, Arlene and Larry Gilbert, and Ellen and Howard Deixler, her grandchildren Amy, Peter and Amanda, Eric and Assunta, Jay, Avi, and Ben, and her great-grandchildren Marinda, Katherine, Zoe, and Andrew. In Gert's memory, donations may be made to The Thypin Oltchick Institute for Women's Entrepreneurship at FEGS or to your favorite charity. Funeral service Friday, June 8, 11:45am, at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the Sunken Garden Poetry Festival in Connecticut that is entering its 20th anniversary season misstated the surname of a poet who had previously read at the festival. He is Robert Hass, not Haas.

By the time we convene the next meeting of the Big City Book Club, it will officially be summer and well into baseball season. We'll honor the moment with a reading of a classic New York City ballpark novel, Mark Harris's ''Bang the Drum Slowly.'' Written in 1956, and a sequel to his ''Southpaw,'' the book revolves around a star pitcher for the New York Mammoths (based on the Yankees) and the illness of one of his teammates, the catcher Bruce Pearson. The book was adapted for television in the 1950s and then as a film in the '70s starring Michael Moriarty and Robert De Niro. Join us for the online conversation on June 27 from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. on the City Room blog. To become a member of the Book Club and receive updates about future chats, send an e-mail with the subject line ''Join'' to bigcity@nytimes.com.

HERMANN--Nancy Ruth, nee Nierdieck, died on June 3, 2012, age 72. Ms. Hermann was born in St. Louis, MO on May 28, 1940. She attended Lutheran schools in St. Louis and graduated from the University of Missouri in 1962. She was a member of the Delta Delta Delta sorority. Ms. Hermann moved to Manhattan in the mid-1960's, and had a deep love for the city and all of its cultural life. For over 15 years she worked as a special sales associate at Bergdorf Goodman. Ms. Hermann is survived by her brothers William Nierdieck (Carole) and John Northlake (Julie), and two nephews and a niece. A memorial gathering will be held at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home in New York City on Wednesday, June 13th, 12-3pm. Memorial donations may be made to either the Metropolitan Museum of Art or the Metropolitan Opera Company.

A chart last Sunday with an article about rising prices for town houses in brownstone Brooklyn misstated the listing and sales prices for a house at 124 Park Place in Park Slope. It was listed at $2,700,000, not $1,270,000; and it sold for $2,910,000, not $1,291,000.

This is a good article, but it strikes me as unfair to brand a given people as being without humor. Humor is as natural to human beings as sex, but it is culturally specific. So while Woody Allen has always struck me as hilarious, I have to understand that an Arab or a Zimbabwean may not catch his point, just as I don't always giggle with the Qataris. WILLIAM M. SHAW, Shreveport, La., posted on nytimes.com

PULLER--Dr. Leon S.,90, of Linden, NJ and Morgantown, WV, April 7, 1922 May 15, 2012. He served in the US Army and Air Force, earned his MD from Creighton School of Medicine, and practiced internal medicine devotedly for 50 years. A dedicated family man, his wit, honesty, kindness are legend. He and his wife were avid patrons of the "Met." Predeceased by parents Abraham and Anna Puller, brother Dr. Herbert Puller, sister-in-law Minnie Puller, and cherished wife of 54 years Sybil Holland Puller. Survived by loving daughter Dr. Elissa Hoffman, son-in-law Dr. Werner Pluhar, former son-in-law Dr. Donald Hoffman, and grandchildren Yonina Hoffman and Jarrett Hoffman. Funeral at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ, June 10, 11am; life celebration at Heritage Point, Morgantown, June 23, noon. In lieu of flowers, consider donation to Neuromuscular Disease Foundation.

LIPTON--Harvey, former general counsel for Hearst Corporation, member of the Board of Directors and a trustee of the trust established under the Will of William Randolph Hearst, died suddenly June 8, 2012 at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, NY. He was 86. Lipton began his distinguished career at Hearst in 1950 as a law clerk. In 1951, he joined the Office of General Counsel as a lawyer. He was appointed general counsel and became secretary of Hearst Corporation in 1966, a post he held until his retirement in 1990. In 1975, Lipton was appointed to Hearst's Board of Directors. He continued to be a legal consultant to Hearst Corporation, member of the Board of Directors and a trustee of the trust established under the Will of William Randolph Hearst until his death. "Harvey was both a valued friend and a trusted colleague to all of us who had the pleasure of working with him," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., executive vice chairman and CEO of Hearst Corporation. "His service as general counsel for 24 years meant he was an important and effective player in Hearst's major changes and events during those years. We were also fortunate to have his good advice and engagement after his retirement in his capacity as a director of the Corporation and a trustee until his death. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family." Lipton graduated from New York University in 1948 and graduated summa cum laude from St. John's Law School in 1951, and thereafter was awarded a doctorate of law. He was a member of the New York County Lawyers Association. Lipton went to Far Rockaway High School and lived in East Rockaway for the majority of his life. Generous donations to a host of philanthropic organizations were his priority. Lipton is predeceased by his wife, the former Pearl Barsky, and survived by two children, Diane Gail Gollub and Charles Norman Lipton, and five grandchildren, Hayley and Ross Gollub, and Jonah, Samantha and Morgana Lipton. Services will be held Monday, June 11, 2012, at 2pm at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY, phone: 516-764-9400. Donations may be made to Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre, 295 Main Street, East Rockaway, NY, 11518, phone: 516-599-2634.

Barack Obama won 52.9 percent of the popular vote in 2008 and 365 electoral votes, 95 more than he needed. Many naturally concluded that prejudice was not a major factor against a black presidential candidate in modern America. My research, a comparison of Americans' Google searches and their voting patterns, found otherwise. If my results are correct, racial animus cost Mr. Obama many more votes than we may have realized. Quantifying the effects of racial prejudice on voting is notoriously problematic. Few people admit bias in surveys. So I used a new tool, Google Insights, which tells researchers how often words are searched in different parts of the United States.

A news analysis article on June 3 about physical exams and other health screening tests that might not be medically necessary misspelled the given name of a professor of clinical internal medicine at the University of South Carolina. He is Allan S. Brett, not Alan. The article also paraphrased incorrectly from a comment by Dr. Brett. He estimated that 80 percent of urologists still believed prostate specific antigen tests to be beneficial or worthwhile, compared to only 20 percent of primary care doctors -- not that 80 percent of urologists still ordered the tests. The article also misspelled the surname of the president of the American Board of Internal Medicine and the ABIM Foundation. She is Christine K. Cassel, not Cassell.

JUNE has become a dependable time for grass-roots new-music initiatives. On Tuesday the East Village collective INCUBATOR ARTS PROJECT opens June Days, a five-concert series that offers familiar faces in novel settings. The series begins on Tuesday with two intrepid keyboardists, Kathleen Supové and Wil Smith, playing a Paula Matthusen piece for extracted piano frame. Chris McIntyre, a composer and trombonist, introduces a new project on Thursday. And on Saturday the guitarist James Moore plays John Zorn's compendium of fractious virtuosity, ''The Book of Heads.'' 8 p.m., Tuesday and Thursday through Sunday, Incubator Arts Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village, (866) 811-4111, incubatorarts.org; $12 in advance, $15 at door. Throughout his career the composer PHILIP GLASS has been an avid collaborator and an eager promoter of emerging artists. ''Philip Glass: Music With Friends,'' a three-evening series, finds him in both modes. Wednesday's collaboration with Stephin Merritt, a droll singer and songwriter, is a likely high point; Friday's meeting with Laurie Anderson, a sure bet. 8 p.m., Wednesday through Friday, Issue Project Room, 22 Boerum Place, Downtown Brooklyn, (718) 330-0313, issueprojectroom.org; $85 Wednesday and Thursday, $150 Friday.

The photographer Raphaël Dallaporta calls the MiKroKopter a ''magic flying tripod.'' In 2010, he bought his own for less than $7,000 -- a German-engineered self-stabilizing drone that can be set up to shoot digital still photos. ''The great thing is when you pilot it, you get some sensation of flight,'' says Dallaporta, who steers it from the ground. ''To keep the control from earth you must be in connection with the elements like the wind and the sun.'' He first took his drone to northern Afghanistan to photograph archaeological sites that had not been documented before. (The drone was briefly lost till he offered a reward of 5,000 afghanis, or about $115, for it.) In May, Dallaporta took another drone, a new, upgraded version of the MiKroKopter, to Worcester, Mass., the site of several collegiate championship regattas, to photograph crews from as high as 330 feet over Lake Quinsigamond. digital camera dallaporta installed on his Mikrokopter: ricoh 28 mmhis preferred operating altitude: 50 to 100 meters

NOURI--Edmond J.,died peacefully on June 1st in Glen Cove, NY. Known for his generosity and steadfastness, for his humor, candor and flair, he will be sorely missed by countless people with whom he interacted with warmth, kindness and verve. He will also be missed by crack rivals at the backgammon table. Mr. Nouri was born in Baghdad in 1918. His education at Jesuit Baghdad College won him an IBM scholarship to Georgetown University in 1938. In 1942, he enlisted in the US Army as an Iraqi national, and served in China and Burma, before becoming an American citizen in 1943. Shortly after, he worked as a staff writer for the Stars and Stripes and the New Yorker, and as a commodities trader at US Steel. Mr. Nouri was a General Agent for New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, with his own agency in New York City. Mr. Nouri leaves behind his wife of 41 years, the former Diana Crocker Redington of San Francisco; two sons, Michael Nouri of Los Angeles and Guy Nouri of Hillsdale, NY; a daughter Katherine Hughes Del Tufo of Princeton, NJ; and two step children: David Redington of Stamford, CT, and Ruth Redington of Cambridge, MA. He is also survived by six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A first marriage to the late Gloria Montgomery Nouri ended in divorce. A Memorial Service will be held on June 14th at 2pm at St. Thomas Church, 53rd and 5th Avenue, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Episcopal Social Services, 305 7th Ave., New York, NY 10001.
FINKELSTEIN--Bernard. Wherever I am you are never far from me, I carry your values, humor, and love in my heart always. Love, Alison

To the Sports Editor: Re ''For Mets and Santana, Wait for No-Hitter Is Over,'' June 2: In 1969, the Mets, a team that had previously never finished better than next to last in the National League, were 29-23 after an 11-game winning streak. After their first no-hitter, by Johan Santana in their 51st season, the Mets are 29-23.

The vacation rental company HomeAway joined with Priceline last week to allow customers to book plane tickets and car rentals in addition to homes. The partnership allows travelers who book a vacation rental through HomeAway.com or VRBO.com, part of the company's portfolio of Web sites, to complete their vacation planning on one site, using a search powered by Priceline Partner Network. After booking a vacation rental, travelers can buy tickets from most major airlines to the destination they are headed for and can customize their reservation by choosing seat classes and locations. Users can also rent a car and enter discount codes.

For aficionados of Frank Lloyd Wright, the new SC Johnson Gallery (scjohnson.com/visit) in Racine, Wis., offers another attraction on the fan circuit. The 2,000-square-foot gallery opened on June 2 in the SC Johnson Administration Building (above, with a Wright sculpture), designed by Wright in 1936. It focuses on Wright's residential designs with an inaugural exhibition, ''At Home With Frank Lloyd Wright,'' set to run for the next year.
TULCHIN--Toby. Retired English teacher and avid gardener, born January 24, 1931. Beloved wife of Jesse, mother of Deborah and Laurie, passed away June 4, 2012. You will always be in our hearts.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''When History Sneaks Up on You,'' June 3: This article reminded me of attending Carl Erskine's no-hitter on June 19, 1952. Thanks to a Sunday rainout, I traded two $3 rain checks for three better $2 weekday seats. Erskine would have had a perfect game, but in his haste to complete an inning before a rain delay, he walked the pitcher.

April 11, 2012, Natural Bridges National Monument, Utah My older son, William, 13, said he wanted to see the desert, so I took him and his brother, Rudy, 9, both city kids, to the Four Corners, where Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona and Utah meet. We began and ended our road trip in Durango, Colo., with stops in all four states. The distances are great enough for fraternal disputes to simmer down in the car before touring the parks, so our enjoyment of their natural wonders was never disrupted. I took this shot of the boys, deep in conversation about snakes, as we passed under Owachomo Bridge in Natural Bridges National Monument in Utah. ANDREW POPPER, New York

ON a recent Tuesday at noon, a dozen live-in home health aides -- all from the Bronx -- dialed a conference-call number. They phoned from their elderly patients' small apartments in Queens and from spacious houses in New Jersey and Connecticut. Within seconds, they were connected to their pastor, Benjamin Boakye, of Ebenezer Assembly of God Church on Jerome Avenue in the Bronx.

The current election is producing very few goose bumps, except perhaps among those who get all tingly when they view billionaire-financed attack ads. The incumbent, who drew adoring throngs last time, cannot always fill a room this time. The challenger's risk-averse, carefully plotted strategy is a business plan worthy of a Harvard M.B.A. - and consciously the antithesis of the improvisational, let's-take-a-shot style of the war hero Republican nominee of four years ago.

An article last Sunday about PTAs at New York City public schools that raise about $1 million annually referred incorrectly to extracurricular activities at P. S. 290, on the Upper East Side. It is not the case that the PTA there has ''treated'' each second grader in recent years to swimming lessons. And a fifth-grade trip to a horse ranch in Highland, N.Y., that the PTA has helped pay for is a day trip, not an overnight trip. (The PTA has also helped pay for an overnight trip to a Catskills nature center for fourth-graders at P. S. 290. )
To the Sports Editor: Re ''Molded for Success on Clay,'' June 8: Despite Rafael Nadal's dominance, I think there are ways for a big server to beat or at least seriously challenge him.

''Venom'' is not a word to use lightly. It is richly suggestive, conjuring thoughts of poisonous snakes like copperheads, water moccasins and rattlesnakes. So perhaps it is not surprising that my reference to eastern garter snakes as ''mildly venomous'' in a Spring Time post a few weeks ago troubled some readers. The post linked to a 2005 article in The New York Times that discussed the research of an Australian biologist, Bryan Fry, on the evolution of venom. He found that nearly all snakes - even ones considered nonvenomous - do actually produce these poison proteins.

''Timelessness'' is a compact, one-room exhibition of more than five decades of work by the designers Lella and Massimo Vignelli. On display are product designs like the elegant carafes (left) that were produced in the late '50s by the glassmaker Venini and the silversmith Christofle, or the designers' 1960s stacking plastic dinnerware for Heller. A slide show in the gallery illustrates the firm's interior, furniture and graphic designs, like the signage for New York's subway system or the iconic logos for American Airlines and Bloomingdale's. The exhibition conveys the couple's conviction that designers should produce things that last. ''We despise the culture of obsolescence, the culture of waste, the cult of the ephemeral,'' they wrote in their book ''The Vignelli Canon.'' Through July 15 at the Italian Cultural Institute, 686 Park Avenue. PILAR VILADAS

THE NORTHSIDE FESTIVALis building into something between South by Southwest -- daytime seminars about entrepreneurship and, next week, a film festival -- and a typical Brooklyn music weekend: bands playing all over. The bands are mostly local, including Caveman and Frankie Rose on Friday at Music Hall of Williamsburg, and Asobi Seksu on Saturday at Brooklyn Bowl. But the lineup boasts rarer events too. The rapper GZA of the Wu-Tang Clan brings two performances of his 1995 album, ''Liquid Swords,'' backed by a live band, Grupo Fantasma, to Music Hall of Williamsburg on Thursday. . On Friday two word-loving, style-hopping indie rockers -- Of Montreal and Jens Lekman -- headline at Williamsburg Park. The Tuareg rockers Tinariwen and the math-rock duo Buke and Gase share a bill on Friday night at Warsaw. The Olivia Tremor Control, whose wistfully psychedelic songs made them college-radio favorites in the 1990s, continue a leisurely reunion Saturday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg. A pass to visit multiple clubs (subject to capacity) is $86.64 until Wednesday and $102.47 once the festival starts on Thursday. Full information: northsidefestival.com.

SO many of the colors dominating the prefall collections, now arriving in stores, are almost exact matches to jewelers' gemstones. Amethyst, emerald and ruby were the favorites at Proenza Schouler, Vera Wang, the Row, Kenzo,J. Mendel ... the list goes on, leaving one to wonder: Is it acceptable to match dress and bijoux? ''It isn't traditionally perceived to be in good taste,'' said the J. Mendel designer Gilles Mendel, who has the reddest Hollywood-heartthrob dress in his collection. ''But there's a freshness and modernity to it if done right, with the jewels reinforcing the statement of the dress.'' Inspired by Mr. Mendel's remark, T went out and accessorized the season's gems with more gems. Hold that call to the fashion police. Matchy-matchy means no offense, after all. CHELSEA ZALOPANY Clockwise, from top: Proenza Schouler bustier, $995, and skirt, $2,250; go to proenzaschouler.com. Wilfredo Rosado ring, $14,900; go to bergdorfgoodman.com. The Row jacket, $2,290; pants, $1,290; and top, $1,890. For the jacket and pants, therow.com. For the top, bergdorfgoodman.com. Ippolita earrings, $625; go to ippolita.com. Narciso Rodriguez dress, $2,495; neimanmarcus.com. Hammerle bracelet, price on request; fd-inspired.com.

SANDS--Patricia H.,died in Los Angeles on May 14th, surrounded by her beloved family. She was 86. A native New Yorker, she was a popular lecturer in art history at the Pratt Institute and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Ms. Sands was also active in the fight to save the Beacon Theater. Her many family members and friends grieve her passing deeply. A Memorial Service will be held in Manhattan, details to be announced. Donations may be made in Pat's name to the National Wildlife Federation for wolf protection.

NICHOLS--Marguerite "Peggy" Prince Sykes, M.D.,Passed away on May 30th at her home in Manhattan in her 98th year. She was also a seasonal resident of Manchester, VT for 60 years. Peggy is survived by her stepsons Charles W. 3rd of Westport, MA and David H. of Dorset, VT and their spouses Helga and Christina, eleven grandchildren and sixteen great-grandchildren. Her husband Charles W. Jr. and stepdaughter Joan Nichols Rizzo predeceased her. Dr. Nichols graduated from New York University College of Medicine as a member of the class of 1948, only the second class to admit women. Following her internship at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan, she went on to enjoy a forty-year long career in chemotherapy at Memorial Sloan Kettering and James Ewing Hospitals. Dr. Nichols was also a Damon Runyon Fellow and an Assistant Professor at New York Hospital School of Medicine. During her long career she authored, co-authored, and presented around the globe many papers on her specialty of oncology -- specifically her research into effects of radiation on normal cells. She also led or contributed to seminal studies into leukemia, ovarian cancer, and endometriosis. Active for many years in several New York charities, Peggy was a founding member of the Women's Committee of the New York Zoological Society and served on its board for many years. She also served as a board member of the Nichols Foundation. An avid golfer, Peggy was Junior Ladies Champion in Long Island. Throughout her golfing career, she scored five holes in one. She was elected a Member of Distinction by the Colony Club in New York and also belonged to The Society of Mayflower Descendants, the River Club of New York and the Ekwanok Club of Manchester, VT. A memorial will be held on a later date. In lieu of flowers, as a great "Yorkie" lover it would have pleased her if her friends donated to the Animal Medical Center in New York City.

MORRIS--William (Bill) H. Died on June 7, 2012 from complications following a car accident. Bill graduated from Yale University in 1952 and served in the US Navy. He worked for the Bankers Trust Company in London and in New York until 1987. In retirement, he ran the family apple business in Rhinebeck, NY. Bill was a long time member of Alcoholics Anonymous and his volunteer work focused on helping people in times of trouble. He gave his time to Stay'N Out, an in-prison rehabilitation program and the Tuesday Lunch Program at St. James Church in New York. He enjoyed his friendships fostered at the University Club in New York and as class agent for Andover Phillips Academy. Bill is survived by his wife of 57 years, Arvia Crosby Morris, his three children, William Raymond Spencer Morris, Arvia Eleanor Morris, Adrienne Crosby Morris and four grandchildren, Arden Lee Morris, Owen Crosby Morris, Sonya Xiaoming Morris, and Lily Crosby Martin. In lieu flowers, please send contributions to the Tuesday Lunch Program at St. James Church 865 Madison Ave. New York, NY 10021 or a charity of your choice. www.dapsonchestney.com.

A picture on May 27 with an article about female film editors was published in error. The photograph was of a scene from the 1998 drama ''The Long Way Home,'' starring Jack Lemmon and Sarah Paulson. It was not a scene from a 1997 documentary by the same name edited by Kate Amend, one of the editors featured in the article and also shown in an accompanying picture.

In the sixth inning of the first game of the Subway Series, and with the Yankee Stadium crowd beginning to wonder whether Hiroki Kuroda could make a second consecutive New York Friday memorable, Omar Quintanilla knocked a 93-mile-per-hour sinker to left field. Quintanilla's double was notable for being the Mets' first hit all evening. Yet the hit also continued an unlikely string of production for an unlikely starting shortstop. In 10 games this season before a start Saturday against the Yankees, Quintanilla was batting .321 with a .457 on-base percentage. Four of his nine hits had been doubles, which is as many as he hit in all but one of the previous six seasons in which the 30-year-old Quintanilla has logged major league service time.

COHEN--Arthur, artist, died at home in Manhattan on June 4, 2012. He was 84 years old. He was well-known for his landscapes of New York and Provincetown, and his intimate interiors, mostly of musicians. He is survived by his wife, the pianist Elizabeth Rodgers and his son, Ezekiel Cohen. His loss will be mourned by friends and fellow artists in New York and Provincetown. Donations in his name may be made to VNSNY Hospice, 1250 Broadway, 7th floor, NY, NY 10001.

MILBRATH--Robert Henry. Robert Henry Milbrath died after a brief illness on May 30 with his loving family by his side in Gainesville, FL at the age of 100. Bob was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin in 1912. A graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy in 1934, Bob began his career in Buenos Aires, Argentina, as a sales engineer for Standard Oil Company of New Jersey (today Exxon Mobil). He married Margaret Ripperger of Brooklyn Heights in 1940. During World War II he served as Assistant Naval Attache in Buenos Aires and later with the Army-Navy Petroleum Board in Washington, DC. After the war, Bob rejoined Standard Oil holding a number of executive marketing positions in their Latin American affiliates. In 1961 he was named President of Esso International, the worldwide marketing and supply affiliate, and in 1969 he was appointed to the Board of Directors of Standard Oil of New Jersey as a Senior Vice President. During this period Bob headed the group charged with selecting the company's new name, Exxon. Bob retired in 1974. After retirement he and Margaret lived in Guilford, CT and Bob returned to his early love, sailing. At age 80 he gave up his 34-foot sailboat, Venture, and moved to Ponte Vedra, Beach, FL. In 2004, Bob and Margaret moved to Gainesville, FL where Margaret passed away after 68 years of marriage in 2008. He is survived by his three children Robert S. of Houston, Constance of Vancouver Island and Susan of Gainesville, his sister June Malen of Milwaukee, four grandchildren and one great-grandchild.

''IT'S all about comfort,'' Alber Elbaz said as he introduced his latest Lanvin collection to a small group of editors and retailers at Milk Studios. ''To me, that's the only definition of modernity.'' On Wednesday, Mr. Elbaz joined other designers in the long march that is resort, that in-between season that provides stores with clothes around the time you're carving the turkey. His collection tugged at two extremes: the silky tracksuit in bright solids or floral prints, and crisp-looking sportswear that included a cropped tuxedo jacket, tailored shorts and flared miniskirts. Many fabrics had a stretch element -- again, for comfort.

SENZER--Martin. 35 year resident of Great Neck, New York, died on June 7, 2012. Born June 12, 1931, in the Bronx, NY to Gussie Turkowitz Senzer and Irving Senzer. Loving husband to Carrie. Devoted father to Ernest Senzer, Gregory Senzer, Diana Sheedy (Nicholas), Deborah Kimes (Mark), J. Gregory Oreiro (Deirdre). Cherished grandfather to nine and great-grandfather to three. Beloved brother of the late Irwin Samuel Senzer. He was a graduate of N.Y.U. School of Commerce in June of 1966. Retired IRS Officer for 34 years. World traveler and connoisseur of classical music, sculpture, architecture and the fine arts. Donations in his memory may be made to the Friendship Circle at Sid Jacobson JCC. Graveside services Monday, June 11, 2012 at 1:30pm at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

A review on May 27 about ''The Last Englishman,'' Roland Chambers's biography of the journalist and children's author Arthur Ransome, misspelled the surname of the woman who became Ransome's second wife. She was Evgenia Shelepina, not Shlepina.

I have to comment on the perplexing point of view of Ina May Gaskin, the lay midwife featured in the article about home birth. Her first child was delivered in a hospital and survived. Her second child was delivered at home and did not. Yet she sees the hospital as a sinister place. She acknowledges at least one home breech delivery in which the child was neurologically damaged after becoming temporarily ''stuck,'' without acknowledging that this very likely would not have happened in a hospital. If you knew that your birthing experience was going to be completely normal from start to finish, arranging a home birth would make sense. But no woman knows that. KATHARINE WENSTROM, M.D., Providence, R.I.

Scott Walker has said that his strategy is to ''divide and conquer.'' What he doesn't realize is that those he has divided have found one another. Teachers have found the police. Small-business owners have found state workers whose incomes were docked. They have realized that their reduced revenues are the result of Walker's selective attack on some (but not all) state-worker unions. Walker, despite his number-juggling, has contracted rather than expanded the state's economy. LLYN, Wisconsin, posted on nytimes.com

Jerry Coleman has spent most of the last 70 years in professional baseball, but he has not been on the winning side of a no-hitter since Don Larsen's perfect game in the 1956 World Series. Coleman was an infielder for the Yankees. ''Frankly, winning the ballgame is the only thing that interests me,'' Coleman said last week, ''never mind what the individual did.''
BROWN--Venetia Arlen June 9, 1933-November 30, 2011 Happy Birthday, Venetia. We Miss you. Ronni and Cathy

McCULLY--Lucille M.,of New York City and Lake Tahoe, NV, died on April 24, 2012 in Roseville, CA. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th Street, on Thursday, June 21st at 10:30am.

GLADSTONE--Ruth Margolis, 100, on June 7, peacefully at her home on East 88 Street. Beloved wife of the late Bernard, dear sister of Karl Margolis and the late Betty, Nettie, Mona, and Ben, and treasured Aunt Ruth to two generations of nieces and nephews. She was one of a kind, elegant, particular and precise, not shy about expressing her opinion, and we loved her for it. A fierce competitor in bridge well into her nineties, she lived life on her own terms until the end. By default and by demand, she was the matriarch of a large and extended family, and she will live in our hearts forever.
