THIS week brings an exhibition that resembles few previously seen in New York in terms of size, scope and subject. ''CARIBBEAN: CROSSROADS OF THE WORLD'' will be spread among three museums: El Museo del Barrio (opening on Tuesday), which initiated its organization; the Studio Museum in Harlem (Thursday); and the Queens Museum of Art (next Sunday). It will present more than 400 works by some 350 artists, and will survey the cultural contribution of the Caribbean and its diaspora, from the Haitian Revolution of 1804 to the present in six thematic sections (two each museum) that weave together art and history. The artists include scores who were born and remained in the region, and others who relocated; European and Americans who emigrated there; others who visited; and still others for whom the Caribbean was an ancestral home or simply a place of the imagination. A mere sampling -- Camille Pissarro, William Blake, Winslow Homer, Hector Hyppolite, Wifredo Lam, Armando Reverón, Clementine Hunter, Felix Gonzalez-Torres and Jean-Michel Basquiat -- promises an ambitious effort that, regardless of any flaws, should astound. Information: elmuseo.org.

Talk about enchanted evenings. When Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''South Pacific'' (starring Paulo Szot and Kelli O'Hara) cleaned up at the 2008 Tony Awards with seven prizes, including those for best actor and best revival, it set a record for most awards by a musical revival. (''Kiss Me, Kate'' won five in 2000.)

Members of two Congressional committees investigating the drugging of racehorses have sent letters to racing regulators in 39 states seeking information on how trainers with multiple drug violations are disciplined and how often certain performance-enhancing treatments are used. The letter asks about the use of so-called milkshakes, alkalizing agents that help horses combat fatigue, as well as the use of shock-wave therapy, which supposedly promotes healing but also deadens pain.

IN ''First Point,'' his new short film, the artist Richard Phillips combines two of his current obsessions: surfing and Lindsay Lohan. But don't call Ms. Lohan, left, his muse. The actress, Mr. Phillips said, is as much his collaborator as anyone else in the cast and crew, including the surf filmmaker Taylor Steele; the professional surfer Kassia Meador, who performs mesmerizingly as Ms. Lohan's body double; the film editor Jay Rabinowitz; and Thomas Bangalter, half of the electro duo Daft Punk, who composed the ominously swelling score. ''First Point'' is at once a surf film and a film noir, an exploration of the California dream and the Hollywood nightmare. But no doubt the question on everyone's lips when ''First Point'' has its premiere this week at Art Unlimited, the curated section of the Art Basel fair, will be: ''Is it art?'' Fine by Mr. Phillips, who will also feature the piece in a solo show at Gagosian Gallery in September. ''It's just like in my paintings,'' he said. ''Because of the actor and the popular culture dimensions of the project, it will give people -- especially people in the art world -- a real sense of instability with regard to my intentions. Is it a film? Is it an art video? It refuses to announce itself as either.'' ALIX BROWNE

8 P.M. (CBS) THE 66TH ANNUAL TONY AWARDS Neil Patrick Harris, above, once again will sing and dance his way through the role of host for this ceremony honoring excellence on Broadway, to be broadcast live from the Beacon Theater in Manhattan. Performers include the casts of the nominees for best musical and musical revival -- ''Newsies,'' ''Nice Work if You Can Get It,'' ''Once,'' ''Evita,'' ''Follies,'' ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess,'' ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' ''Leap of Faith'' -- as well as ''End of the Rainbow,'' ''One Man, Two Guvnors,'' ''Peter and the Starcatcher,'' ''Ghost the Musical'' and ''Godspell.'' ''The Book of Mormon,'' last year's winner for best musical, will also be featured. Ellen Barkin, Candice Bergen, Jessica Chastain, Sheryl Crow, Nick Jonas, Angela Lansbury, James Marsden, Trey Parker, Jim Parsons, Mandy Patinkin, Tyler Perry, Bernadette Peters, Christopher Plummer, Paul Rudd, Amanda Seyfried and Matt Stone are among the presenters. 10 A.M. (Fox) FOX NEWS SUNDAY Chris Wallace interviews Gov. Mitch Daniels, Republican of Indiana; Dennis Van Roekel, president of the National Education Association; and Thea Lee, deputy chief of staff for the A.F.L.-C.I.O., about the effect of Wisconsin's recall election on the electoral map.

''Imagine it being one big insane frat party, like an over the top 'Animal House' toga party, but it happened all the time.'' BRET MICHAELS OF POISON, ON THE HARD-ROCK HEYDAY OF THE SUNSET STRIP, PAGE 18
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel previews his summer trip in Scandinavia, perhaps the ultimate frugal challenge.

A review last Sunday about a book by Paul Ingrassia that traces the intertwining of cars and culture during the past century misstated the book's title in some editions. As a subheading correctly noted, it is ''Engines of Change'' -- not ''Wheels of Change.''

MARCUS--Pearl, 97, of Manhattan and Boca Raton, FL died peacefully at home on April 30, 2012. She was the widow of Dr. Murray Marcus of Brooklyn, NY and is survived by her brother Stanley Winikoff; her sons Bruce, Michael, and Harvey; her daughter Andrea, and her grandchildren Zoe, Jared, and Shane. She was a graduate of NYU, had a successful career in publicity, and still found the time to be the consummate wife and mother. She is greatly mourned.

At the United States Open championship, the charm and the challenge for the world's best golfers is coping with a course many of them have not played for more than a decade, if at all. This year's site is the Lake Course of Olympic Club in San Francisco, a little bit of heaven with mostly sidehill fairways that drift down from the sandy cliffs above the Pacific Ocean through sentries of cypress trees and sloping target greens to the shore of Lake Merced. The club's name is derived from Olympia, the home of the mythical Greek gods, but at its four previous Opens over more than half a century, Olympic has treated human golf gods rudely. And what glorious gods they were. Ben Hogan, the only professional to win the Masters, the United States Open and the British Open in the same year (1953), after having survived a 1949 crash of his Cadillac with a bus.

An article on May 27 about the police detective Kurt Wallander, a character in novels and television shows, misstated the date the BBC and PBS series ''Wallander'' will begin its third season on ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' After the section had gone to press, the date was changed to Sept. 9, from July 1.

Noomi Rapace was exactly what I pictured when I read the Stieg Larsson series -- from the look right down to the personality. She wore Lisbeth Salander like a second skin, making it one of the most brilliant portrayals of a character based on a novel I've ever seen. That level of acting puts most of what we see in American movies to shame. MARK ROSENGARTEN, Newburgh, N.Y., posted on nytimes.com

''You can't keep flogging a dead horse.'' Harry Theoharis, a senior official in the Greek Finance Ministry who helps oversee the country's tax payment system, talking about the difficulty of raising revenue after two years of austerity.

Kimmel--Herbert D.,Ph.D. Originally from New York, died at home in Charleston, SC, June 5, 2012. He was 85. His loving wife, Barbara, was with him. From his humble Brooklyn beginnings, he joined the navy in WWII and later graduated from the University of Florida, earned a M.A. from NYU and a Ph.D. from USC. A Distinguished Research Professor of Psychology, Emeritus, of the University of South Florida, Herb was a man of boundless intellectual energy and a consummate scholar, well-known for his research in classical and instrumental conditioning, as well as the original studies of biofeedback. He exuded a passion for life that enveloped those around him. An athlete, an avid traveler and an artist who wrote poetry, fiction, lyrics and music, he founded Jazz West Records. The world is a better place because of his many scientific and artistic achievements and his profound personal relationships. He is survived by his devoted wife of 33 years, Barbara; four daughters, Ellie, Ann (Ritt Ritter), Jean, and Tracy (Jim Florack); and seven grand children. Colleagues, friends, and family are asked to celebrate his life in their own special ways. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to the MUSC Foundation for Internal Medicine Support Fund, 18 Bee Street, Charleston, SC 29425, 843-792-2677. "Each moment lived complete will always be, a lasting part of sweet eternity." (from "Embers Glow", Herbert Kimmel, 1956)

HAAS--Libby, passed away at age 101 on Thursday, June 7, 2012 in Westchester, NY. Cherished wife of the late Bernard A. Haas, devoted mother to Steven and Diane and mother-in-law to Roberta and Marc. Adoring grandmother of Jason, David and Penny and great-grandmother of Sarah, Michael, Juliette, Matthew, Bailey and Ella. Her memory will always be in our hearts and we will all miss her dearly.

An article last Sunday about rescue funds for artists misidentified the area in Maine where Stephen King, the author and founder of the Haven Foundation, was struck by a minivan in 1999. The accident was in North Lovell, not Lowell.

An article last Sunday about recent earthquake damage to historic buildings in the Emilia-Romagna region of Italy misidentified the school where Gian Michele Calvi is a professor of seismic engineering. It is the Institute for Advanced Study IUSS Pavia, not the University of Pavia.

OLTCHICK--Gertrude. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Gertrude Oltchick, a dedicated philanthropist who cared deeply for the Jewish community and for people in crisis around the world. Her generosity and leadership lives on through the efforts of her family. We extend our deepest sympathies to her children, Stuart, Arlene, and Ellen; her grandchildren; her great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

DRURY--Gilda "Jill" Gilda "Jill" Drury Parenteau Valvano passed away on Monday May 21, 2012. She was 84 years old. Jill was born in Queens, NY on April 17th, 1928. She attended Queens College in New York and was the daughter of the late Mario and Elvira Zaccaria. Jill was predeceased by her husbands John J. Drury, William Parenteau, John Valvano and her beloved son Keith. Jill is survived by her brothers, Arthur and Albert Zaccaria; three sons, Gary (Joan), Chris (Jill) and Paul (Mopry); four grandchildren, Jack, Mike, Kate Drury and Melissa (Andrew) Zinker; great-grandchildren Evan and Carly Zinker; niece Vicki (Gene) Zacharewicz; nephew Jeffrey Zaccaria and grandnephews Ian and Adam. Jill lived in Naples, FL and also had homes in Floral Park, NY and Westhampton, NY. Jill's first husband John J. Drury ran for Congress in 1960 in the 2nd Congressional District Nassau County, NY on John F. Kennedy's ticket. John went on to become District Attorney in Glen Cove, NY. Jill's second husband, William Parenteau was the Chief Air Traffic Controller at John F. Kennedy Airport in NY. Jill and Bill lived in Manhasset, NY. Jill was married a third time to John Valvano who was a commercial real estate developer. John and Jill lived in Naples, FL. After pursuing a career in modeling Jill became a housewife and raised four boys. She was very athletic and had a long career teaching tennis but her real passion was golf, which she played nearly every day. Jill was an adored friend who was kind, compassionate, humorous, giving and had a zest for life. Memorial Service is scheduled for her in NY on Wednesday, June 13th, from 5:00-7:30pm at North Shore Towers, Floral Park in the "Towers on the Green" room in Building 2. Donations may be given in her name to the Avow Hospice 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, FL 34105. http:/vowhospice.org. Online condolences, please visit www.fullerfuneralhome.com

The musical, ''If You Give a Mouse a Cookie,'' based on the book of the same name by Laura Numeroff, is scheduled for the summer of 2013; it does not run through July 14 of this year.

Before the Mayan calendar ends in December, travelers to Belize can pay homage to the indigenous culture in overnight stays at the Caracol archaeological site. Organized by Belize's National Institute of Culture and History (nichbelize.org), the sleepovers take place on solstice and equinox dates -- June 20, Sept. 21 and Dec. 20 -- at the site, in the country's Cayo district.

CORLISS--Ronni, born December 23, 1947, wife of William "Bill" Corliss; daughter of Joyce Lewin and the late Armand Lewin; step-daughter of Robert "Bob" Schwartz, WWII Veteran; sister Harley I. Lewin; mother of two fabulous loving sons Dustin Ross and Evan Ross. So many friends in Aspen, Carbondale, Roslyn and New York. She will be dearly missed.

HELPERN--David Moses Sr.,scholar, businessman, and philanthropist, died peacefully at age 94 on May 14th, 2012. Born on November 14, 1917, he was co-founder and Chairman of the eponymous Joan and David Inc., which grew from its start in 1967 to become a global fashion brand. David grew up in Brookline, MA and attended Boston Latin School. His mother, Rose, was a concert pianist turned music teacher, his father, Myron, a scientist and businessman. He was one of five children, with a brother, Saul, and three sisters, Miriam, Ruth, and Leah. He graduated from Harvard, where he studied European History, in 1938 and continued on to a Masters degree at the Harvard School of Education. He served proudly in World War II in the Philippines and Japan as a Sergeant in the radar corps. David believed strongly in the importance of education and equality. He was a supporter of Boston Latin School and Harvard School of Education, as well as civil rights causes, the arts and medical charities. David was a great lover of music, both classical and jazz. Most of all, he was kind and generous man. He was much loved by, and is survived by, his children, David Jr. and Elizabeth, their spouses, Ann Helpern and Adam Lass, his grandchildren, Noah, Jane, and Emily Helpern and many nieces and nephews. Please send donations in honor of David to the fund established in his father's name: The Myron E. Helpern (1905) Memorial Scholarship at MIT, payable to MIT and mailed to: Bonny Kellermann '72, MIT Director of Memorial Gifts, 600 Memorial Dr., MIT Room W98-516, Cambridge, MA 02139. Please note David Helpern in memo.

PARIS - The first time Max Mirnyi stepped to the line in the French Open men's doubles final on Saturday, the Bryan twins kept him serving for nearly four minutes, holding him hostage on three break points and numerous deuces. Mirnyi and his partner, Daniel Nestor, finally broke the spell and won the game to tie the score at 1-1. It seemed an omen. The Bryans were alert and combative, key qualities in the shootout world of doubles.

ROSS--Alice Plaut, of Larchmont, NY, died on June 7, 2012, at age 91. Adored wife of the late Morton S. Ross, loving mother of the late Stephen, Jim (and Anne), and Maggie. Known as "Mimi" to her beloved grandchildren, Samantha (and Andy) Saperstein, Scott (and Jennifer) Ross, Stephanie Ross, Gary (and Amy) Ross; and cherished great-grandchildren Charlie and P.J. Ross, and Jordan and Mia Saperstein. Mimi was sharp, intelligent, and engaging until the end. All who knew her will dearly miss her love, support, and world-class sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Arthritis Foundation, 1-800-283-7800.

''Light is my medium to be investigated,'' says the Japanese artist Hiroshi Sugimoto, who spent years chasing bands of prismatic color around his studio in Tokyo and capturing them, with what was for him rapid-fire succession, using a Polaroid camera. In collaboration with Hermès, 20 of the artist's abstract color studies have been translated into silk scarves in a signed, limited edition of 7 each. Couleurs de L'Ombre or Colors of Shadow, as the collection is called, is a moving tribute to the Polaroid, which faces imminent extinction. (Mr. Sugimoto, in fact, exhausted his last batch of the film to make the images.) Hermès, on the other hand, developed new inkjet technology to faithfully recreate the subtle gradations of intense color. Where the original Polaroids are small and precious, the scarves are large (just over 55 inches square) and dynamic, playing with light in ways the artist had never anticipated, though at around $10,000, you might think twice about actually wearing one. ''It's serious art for me,'' Mr. Sugimoto says, with a nod to Hermès. ''And if it's serious art, for me, it's also very reasonably priced.'' Available at hermes-editeur.com. ALIX BROWNE

DONHAUSER--Rathbun Paige 88, died peacefully on June 3, 2012, in New York City. He is survived by his beloved wife, Rosine (nee Lambiotte), daughter Caroline R. and son Peter L. Donhauser, son-in-law Victor Barall, daughter-in-law Whitney W. Donhauser, granddaughters Amelia W. and Cecile L. Donhauser, and devoted nieces and nephews. Born June 28, 1923, in Albany, NY, he graduated from the Albany Academy and the Taft School. He received a B.A. and Masters of Architecture from Yale University and served in the United States Army, European theater, during World War II. As an architect, he worked independently in Caracas, Venezuela, then as a senior associate for the firm of Edward Durell Stone and Associates. Among his numerous design contributions were those as project architect for the United States Pavilion at the 1958 Brussels World's Fair and for the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, Washington, D.C. Before retiring, he was in private practice. He resided in New York City and New Concord, NY, where he found joy in the beauty of the wildlife and the land and fulfilled his dream of creating a garden resplendent and delightful. Memorial service will be private.
'It's a bummer. It's not tragic, but it's a huge disappointment.' DOUG O'NEILL,

A NEIGHBORHOOD in Paris that has long been dismissed as seedy is slowly emerging from the shadow of the Père Lachaise. Situated at the southeast entrance of the famous cemetery, the Porte de Bagnolet area is becoming what the French would describe as bobo (bohemian-bourgeois). Bagnolet was originally a suburb of the French capital; when the city was enlarged in 1860, it became part of the 20th Arrondissement. Rue de Bagnolet, the area's main hub of activity, was lined with shuttered shops until around 1999, when the first wave of development brought a contemporary bookshop, Le Merle Moqueur, and a club, La Flèche d'Or, now renowned. And after the sleek hotel Mama Shelter, designed by Philippe Starck, opened in 2008, a second wave of creative and independent businesses began to emerge. ROOKSANA HOSSENALLY

WITH a new book out and her husband's re-election campaign under way MICHELLE OBAMA seems to be turning up a lot on television these days. But this week she makes one guy really work for the privilege of having her as a guest. He is the chef ROBERT IRVINE, and on Wednesday evening at 10, 9 Central time, his ''Restaurant: Impossible'' show on the Food Network offers a ''White House Edition.'' Mr. Irvine's usual job on the show is to give troubled restaurants a makeover, but he is not doing the same for the White House kitchen. His challenge, issued by Mrs. Obama, is to renovate a community center in Washington run by Horton's Kids, a nonprofit group whose services include tutoring and providing healthy meals to children. Before Mr. Irvine's arrival, those meals have to be eaten outside for lack of space. ''I need you to fix that,'' Mrs. Obama tells him. She also wants him to upgrade the kitchen and find somewhere to put a community garden. (Her new book is ''American Grown: The Story of the White House Kitchen Garden and Gardens Across America.'') Coolest touch: a kid-powered watering system for that garden using a rain barrel and a stationary bicycle.

JANOWITZ--Edward Roben, Edward Roben Janowitz, M.D. FACP: The last of a dying breed, a Jewish family physician making house calls in the tenements of the Lower East side of New York. On January 18, 2012, age 77, Dr. Edward Roben Janowitz died suddenly from cardiovascular complications at Dutchess County Hospital in Red Hook, New York. Ed was born to Rose and Benjamin Janowitz and grew up in suburban Paterson, NJ in a family of secular Jewish humanists. He graduated from Rutgers University in 1956 and went on to graduate from Chicago's Pritzker School of Medicine in 1960. Immediately thereafter he volunteered to join charity CARE and spent two years in Kuala Lipis, Malaysia manning a two-hundred bed hospital with another physician. Returning from Malaysia, he spent two years as a major in the US Army Medical Corp in Korea. The Surgeon General of Korea bestowed a special commendation to Edward for service to the poor, above and beyond the call of duty. The governor of Kangwon province Korea sent a letter of appreciation on behalf of the Korean people for Dr. Janowitz' personal efforts in promoting health and welfare. Upon his return from Korea, he completed graduate medical training in New York at the Montefiore Hospital and New York Medical Center. In 1970 he married Hong Cha Kim and established a medical practice on Grand Street on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. He was closely associated with Beth Israel Medical Center in New York, where he served as an attending physician and mentored many other physicians. He made house calls and saw patients in his office, often accepting haircuts, home-cooked food, and other bartered goods and services in lieu of payment. Often he sent patients on their way with a prescription and the $5 or $10 that they lacked to purchase the medication. He was a very caring Jewish family physician, making house calls in the teeming tenements of the lower East side of New York. Dr Edward Janowitz sought social justice, practiced kindness and served his patients and loved ones with humility. He is survived by his beloved wife, Hong Cha Janowitz, his proud son and daughter, Paul and Maia, his loving grandkids, Aidan and Blake, his loving siblings, Linda and Joel, and his daughter in-law Lin Dao. Contributions may be made in his memory to doctorswithoutborders.org

THE desire of the world's have-nots for a more prosperous and secure life in Western Europe informs two films -- Emanuele Cialese's ''Terraferma'' and the twin brothers Massimiliano and Gianluca De Serio's first feature, ''Seven Acts of Mercy'' -- in the Film Society of Lincoln Center's series OPEN ROADS: NEW ITALIAN CINEMA. The series, which began on Friday and continues through Thursday at the Walter Reade Theater, showcases the latest in contemporary Italian movies. In ''Terraferma,'' set on a small island off the coast of Sicily, a fisherman and his 20-year-old grandson violate directions from the coast guard and rescue an Ethiopian boy and his pregnant mother from drowning and give them shelter. But once they are safe and the mother has given birth, will they report them to authorities?

GINA GIONFRIDDO'S last Off Broadway outing, her witty dark comedy ''Becky Shaw,'' led to rave reviews and a Pulitzer Prize nomination in 2009. Happily, she's back, though she may be feeling even a tad darker. In Ms. Gionfriddo's latest play, ''Rapture, Blister, Burn,'' she considers the feelings of disillusionment that often afflict the post-40 set. As she put it in an essay on the Playwrights Horizons Web site, ''Rapture'' looks at a time in life when ''big, unfulfilled dreams are still possible, but they're statistically less likely.'' She added, ''If you're going to take a big leap and remake yourself, you have to do it now.'' (Another essay by Ms. Gionfriddo appears on Page 4.)

In ''Way Beyond Bake Sales: $1 Million PTAs,'' on the cover of last Sunday's Metropolitan section, Kyle Spencer wrote about New York City public schools where parents' groups raise amounts in the $1 million range annually. On NYTimes.com, readers debated the role of private wealth in a public education system. A selection of comments is below. Readers also responded to Ginia Bellafante's Big City column, which examined the word ''gay'' and its changing currency as an insult in light of a court ruling that a false accusation of homosexuality could no longer be considered slander. In a large public-school system where the city gives the same dollar amount for each child, this is how the class system stays maintained. The haves have more. The have-nots don't. How different is it from the suburbs where local taxes support local districts, where wealthy towns have well-provided successful schools and poor towns have poor, failing, underfunded schools?

The Pittsburgh Pirates drafted aggressively again last week, grabbing the Stanford right-hander Mark Appel, a Scott Boras client, when he fell to them with the No. 8 pick. Now the Pirates must decide how much of their allotted bonus pool of $6.56 million they should give him. The new spending limits, as mandated by the collective bargaining agreement, will almost certainly blunt the Pirates' recent strategy of spending heavily on multiple selections in each draft.

THE apartment on Park Avenue where Leon Hess, the oil magnate and New York Jets owner, lived until his death in 1999 sold for $17.25 million, the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. Mr. Hess's widow, Norma Wilentz Hess, continued to live in the 12-room ninth-floor apartment in the co-op building at 625 Park Avenue, at 65th Street, until her own death in 2010.

SUSLOW--Larry, passed away peacefully at 86, on June 1. Survived by his adoring wife of 50 years Kiki, devoted children Chris Aubert (Rhonda), Dany Papell (Lee), and Tracy Gold (David), 11 loving grandchildren, sister Eleanor Hope McCarthy and son Richard Rivman. A WWII veteran, accomplished lawyer, CPA and real estate developer, his kindness, love of life and generosity touched all who knew him. A memorial will be held in Mandeville, LA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Jude Children's Hospital.

HOLT--Dennis. Explainer and enthusiast of the new Brooklyn, died June 7 at 77 from injuries suffered at his Boerum Hill home May 14. A Kansas native reared in Indiana and a graduate of the University of Alabama, where he was a national debating champion, Dennis moved to New York and became a Brooklyn brownstone revivalist. His varied career included public relations for Union Carbide, a founding reporter for The Phoenix, chief of staff for Rep. Stephen Solarz. Since 1994 he was senior editor and columnist for the Brooklyn Eagle newspapers. Deeply mourned by family, colleagues and a host of friends, Dennis is survived by his wife Susan Benson Holt and their son Matthew, and by his daughter from an earlier marriage, Debbie Holt Taylor, and grandsons Graham and Cooper.

There is not a shadow of a doubt that the spotlight on dressing today is totally on men's wear. It has nothing to do with the general public, but it will in 10 years. What we are dealing with are the frontiers of a liberated generation that has in many parts of the country accepted gay marriage and the freedom of expression long associated with women's design. Many of these men have the highest antennas and they are transmitting thoughts about dress that are almost inconceivable, including the breaking of the last taboo: wearing clothes that Western civilization would consider women's. Don't jump to conclusions: this is not about drag. This is embracing the influences of ancient civilizations of Africa and Asian, where the caftan and sarong have long been worn by men. Granted these styles, far left, are most often seen here on men in creative fields, where they can get away with them without ridicule. Certainly Marc Jacobs's long lace shirt has caused an explosion equal to his first grunge collection 20 years ago. Less extreme but equally uncorralled are the clothes of Thom Browne, above left, he of the above-the-ankle trousers. And black contemporary music is a major influence. On a more traditional note: the man at top right, in the most punctiliously tailored and accessorized suits. Below left, a man artfully mixes color, classic shapes and bold accessories. For others, bottom right, it's the rustic look of Paul Bunyan.

IF LARRY KEIGWIN were a writer, it's easy to imagine him as a poet like Walt Whitman or Frank O'Hara, someone fond of wandering city streets, peering into windows, studying the gaits of passers-by, endlessly curious about the quirks of human behavior. Whitman and O'Hara might be inspired to write poems about city rambling. But Mr. Keigwin creates dances about urban life for his Keigwin + Company that fuse pop culture and high art. He'll be presenting four at the Joyce Theater, two of them world premieres. ''Twelve Chairs,'' which explores states of rejection and survival, is based on a simple but potent structural idea: the game of musical chairs. Competition is also a theme of the other premiere, ''Contact Sport,'' a male quartet that uses athletic movements to suggest the ever-changing relationships among four brothers. The program includes a revised version of the playful ''Trio,'' which received its premiere last fall, and a revival of ''Megalopolis'' (2009), a big work blending futuristic visions with nightclub camp, a mash-up of minimalism and hip-hop. 7:30 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, 8 p.m. Thursday to Saturday, 2 p.m. and 7:30 p.m. next Sunday, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea; (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; from $10.

The black labels that tell families what to expect from network television shows will start to appear on the Internet streams of those shows, too. The expansion of the TV content ratings system is expected to be announced by the major broadcast networks on Monday morning. The ratings will be included in all episodic streams on Web sites like ABC.com and Fox.com by December, according to people with knowledge of the plan, who insisted on anonymity because it had not yet been made public.

7 P.M. (Nickelodeon) FIGURE IT OUT The network updates its popular late '90s game show for the 21st century. Each week Jeff Sutphen, above, challenges four celebrity panelists -- among them, Victoria Justice, Jennette McCurdy, Cymphonique Miller and Rachel Crow -- to uncover the hidden talents or accomplishments of child contestants by bombarding them with questions. For each round in which the panelists fail to come up with the correct answer the contestant wins a prize. If, after three rounds, the panelists still can't figure it out, the player takes home the grand prize. Each game ends with a demonstration of the contestant's abilities. At 9, in a preview of ''Hollywood Heights,'' an adaptation of the Mexican telenovela ''Alcanzar una Estrella,'' Brittany Underwood plays Loren Tate, a shy high school senior who finds herself catapulted to superstardom when she wins a songwriting contest sponsored by her rock idol, Eddie Duran (Cody Longo) -- and, eventually, his love. The show, which also features a multiple-episode guest appearance by James Franco, has its official premiere next Monday. 7:30 A.M. (Fox Movie Channel) SONS AND LOVERS (1960) Jack Cardiff directed this adaptation of the D. H. Lawrence novel about the joy, sorrow and frustration that grow out of a strong bond between a mother (Wendy Hiller) and son (Dean Stockwell) in a northern England coal town, not unlike the one where Lawrence grew up. ''Oddly enough, the powerful passions that race and foam through the original tale, which shocked and dismayed a lot of people when it was published in 1913, do not surge up in the picture,'' Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. ''The strong possessiveness of a mother's love for a son, transferred to him from his father, comes through as a hot, but essentially lavalike, strain of attentiveness and jealous affection untouched by the thrust of Dr. Freud.'' The film received seven Oscar nominations, including best director for Mr. Cardiff and best actor for Trevor Howard as the discarded father, a miner who wed above his social class. Freddie Francis won for best cinematography, which Mr. Crowther called ''picture poetry.''

At an annual dinner on Thursday night the Japan Society will formally announce that Miwako Tezuka, the associate curator at the Asia Society, has been named the new director of the organization's gallery, making her its first Japanese chief. The current director, Joe Earle, is retiring in September. ''I am honored to join Japan Society and to work with its dedicated staff to create exciting exhibitions and related programming that stir the imaginations of the New York audience and people the world over,'' Dr. Tezuka said in a statement. Motoatsu Sakurai, the president of the society, said, ''Miwako is a well-regarded curator, who has an intimate knowledge of the New York art scene and a broad perspective of Japanese art in the global sphere.'' The nonprofit Japan Society was set up to encourage mutual understanding between the United States and Japan, and its gallery has been mounting exhibitions since 1971. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

After cutting the cable TV cord two years ago, I'm often a bit late to the conversations about hot new shows. So last week, after hearing friends rave incessantly about ''Game of Thrones,'' I gave it a try. Off I went to Apple iTunes, where I bought and downloaded the first season of the series for $29.

HERSKOWITZ--Dr. Irwin H.,92, died June 10, 2012 in Lake Worth, Florida. He leaves his beloved and loving wife of 67 years, Reida Postrel Herskowitz. He was father of the late Ira Herskowitz and leaves his children Joel, Mara, and Alan Herskowitz; Joel's wife, Roya Sayadi; and his grandchildren Laurel Dumont, Sylvan, Alexandra, Corey, and William Leo Herskowitz and Tara and Nika Makhmali. A 1940 graduate of Brooklyn College, he earned a masters degree from the University of Missouri in 1942, served with the U.S. Coast Guard during World War II, and received his Ph.D. from Columbia University in 1948. He taught for many years at Hunter College of the City University of New York. Through his scholarly teaching and writing and, upon retirement, through his artwork, he was an inspiration to his children, grandchildren, students, and colleagues. The funeral will be at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre at 10am, Wednesday, June 13.

Glenn Beck, who departed Fox News last year and started his own Internet television network, is sticking with his radio network partner. His company, Mercury Radio Arts, will announce on Monday that it has renewed its contract with Premiere Networks, keeping ''The Glenn Beck Program'' in syndication for five more years.
ROSE--Rosabianca. Congregation Shearith Israel mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her family. David J. Nathan, Parnas

If Microsoft couldn't find compelling enough reasons to release its Office applications for the iPad, Google just gave it one. On Tuesday, Google acquired Quickoffice, a start-up that makes a set of applications for iPads and Android tablets that let people open and edit Microsoft Word, Excel and PowerPoint files. Productivity apps are among the best sellers in the category of paid apps for the iPad. Quickoffice currently ranks seventh on that list in Apple's iPad App Store.

Rajat K. Gupta, a former director of Goldman Sachs accused of leaking secrets about the bank, will not testify at his insider trading trial, according to a letter from his lawyers that was filed with the court on Sunday. His lawyers' decision is something of an about-face. Late Friday, after the jury had gone home for the weekend, Gary P. Naftalis, a lawyer for Mr. Gupta, said it was said that it was ''highly likely'' that his client would testify in his own defense next week.

GREENBERG--Gloria. Passed peacefully in her sleep June 9. Devoted mother to Jay, Arthur, and the late Caren. Dear sister of Cecile Sanderman and Martin Jonas. Loving grandmother to Zack and Megan. She will be missed terribly. Services were held.

While the Masters in April heralds the flowering of another golf year, the United States Open lures Americans to the television for a midseason challenge more vicarious in character and charm. By mid-June, most golfers have hit some balls, played several rounds and secretly wondered if this will be the year they finally learn to hit a draw. Or a fade. Or something straight.

Just as print publications across North America are cutting newsroom staff and daily publication schedules, Politico is expanding. This week, the news outlet is starting to hire 20 more reporters and editors to help increase its coverage on the economy and military. Jim VandeHei, executive editor of Politico, said these journalists were being hired to expand its expensive subscription service, Politico Pro, which is often bought by lobbyists and trade associations. Politico is also adding 20 more employees to its business side. He wants to have this staff in place by September, well before the election and the lame-duck session of Congress.

Dear Diary: I often walk on the Long Beach boardwalk. This week two odd things occurred. Once there were three mirrors above three sinks in the ladies' room. No more. Nevertheless, after washing my hands, from habit I looked up where the mirror once was and saw on the blank wall ''YOU LOOK FINE,'' written where the mirror should have been.

TUCSON -- The contest to fill the Congressional seat vacated by Gabrielle Giffords, the Democrat who survived an assassination attempt last year, has been widely referred to as the race for ''Gabby's seat.'' Her chosen successor, Ron Barber, has tried to step out from her shadow, though, saying at campaign events and in interviews that the race is, in fact, for ''the people's seat.''

Bonnaroo's late-night surprise was a doozy: the return of D'Angelo, the all-around soul man who has not played a concert in the United States since the end of his 2001 tour for his album ''Voodoo,'' a masterpiece released the year before. R&B fans have been waiting for its successor ever since. On Saturday night, D'Angelo was in full voice, or, to be more precise, voices: the silken falsetto, the funk yowl, the love-man tenor, the full-throated shout. Playing keyboards and guitar, flaunting muscles and charisma, D'Angelo was intact.

Can the bottom of the world sustain one of Disney's megamusicals? ''Mary Poppins'' is about to find out. Disney's Broadway division has had hits like ''The Lion King'' and ''Beauty and the Beast'' crisscrossing the globe for nearly two decades now, but New Zealand has never made the cut - too expensive a trip for too limited an audience. Until now: ''Mary Poppins'' will open at Auckland's Civic Theater on Oct. 18, Disney said on Sunday (local time), and run for a hoped-for 10 weeks.

Dylan Ratigan, the opinionated and sometimes hotheaded television host, is leaving MSNBC, the cable channel where he has worked for the last three years. Mr. Ratigan, whose news analysis show is now broadcast at 4 p.m. Eastern time, said in a telephone interview that he was electing to leave cable so that he could put into practice what he has talked about on TV. Mr. Ratigan has attacked political systems, corporations and special interests on his show and promoted movements for job creation, bank reform and campaign finance reform in the past.

Dear Diary: It was so lovely on a Sunday afternoon to literally stumble upon a reminder of childhood as it was before every New York 10-year-old had a cellphone and Facebook became the default method of communication. As I was weeding my father's back garden on the Upper East Side, I found a tennis ball in a bed of pachysandra. No tennis court within blocks, nor a retriever nearby who might have missed a bounce.

Cellphone manufacturers are jostling for market share, one device at a time. Announcements last week included a no-contract iPhone plan from Cricket, and a summer release for new HTC models for T-Mobile and AT&T. Users increasingly turn to their devices for answering e-mails, posting to social Web sites and checking the weather, and the increase occurs across all ages. The percentage of users ages 13 to 17 who played a game on their device, for example, rose to 47 percent, from 41 percent a year ago. The percentage of those ages 55 to 64 rose, too, from 11 to 17 percent. SHELLY FREIERMAN

LIPTON--Harvey, former general counsel for Hearst Corporation, member of the Board of Directors and a trustee of the trust established under the Will of William Randolph Hearst, died suddenly June 8, 2012 at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, NY. He was 86. Lipton began his distinguished career at Hearst in 1950 as a law clerk. In 1951, he joined the Office of General Counsel as a lawyer. He was appointed general counsel and became secretary of Hearst Corporation in 1966, a post he held until his retirement in 1990. In 1975, Lipton was appointed to Hearst's Board of Directors. He continued to be a legal consultant to Hearst Corporation, member of the Board of Directors and a trustee of the trust established under the Will of William Randolph Hearst until his death. "Harvey was both a valued friend and a trusted colleague to all of us who had the pleasure of working with him," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., executive vice chairman and CEO of Hearst Corporation. "His service as general counsel for 24 years meant he was an important and effective player in Hearst's major changes and events during those years. We were also fortunate to have his good advice and engagement after his retirement in his capacity as a director of the Corporation and a trustee until his death. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family." Lipton graduated from New York University in 1948 and graduated summa cum laude from St. John's Law School in 1951, and thereafter was awarded a doctorate of law. He was a member of the New York County Lawyers Association. Lipton went to Far Rockaway High School and lived in East Rockaway for the majority of his life. Generous donations to a host of philanthropic organizations were his priority. Lipton is predeceased by his wife, the former Pearl Barsky, and survived by two children, Diane Gail Gollub and Charles Norman Lipton, and five grandchildren, Hayley and Ross Gollub, and Jonah, Samantha and Morgana Lipton. Services will be held Monday, June 11, 2012, at 2pm at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY, phone: 516-764-9400. Donations may be made to Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre, 295 Main Street, East Rockaway, NY, 11518, phone: 516-599-2634.

Some years ago, an engineer at Google told me why Google was not collecting information linked to people's names: ''We don't want the name. The name is noise.'' There was enough information in Google's large database of search queries, location and online behavior, he said, that a lot could be told about somebody through indirect means. The point was that actually finding out people's names is not necessary for sending them targeted ads. But increasingly, everything about you is out there. Whether and how you guard your privacy in an online world we are building up every day has become urgent.

Twitter knows when you nap. At least its engineers think they have a pretty good idea when you nap, because those are the few times when you're not pouring your heart out in 140-character bursts. Peering into its fire hose of tweets from four big cities around the world, a pair of Twitter engineers, Miguel Rios and Jimmy Lin, have discovered that the Twitter users in Istanbul don't sleep much in August -- and why would they, considering how many people are strolling along Istiklal Avenue on summer evenings. The denizens of Sao Paulo, Brazil, seem to take an afternoon siesta - tweets sharply drop off in the period after lunch.

The task forPresident Obama's campaign this week: turn things around. All presidential campaigns have bad weeks, and when they come in early June, it is hardly a disaster. But it is also important for campaigns to clean things up after they have gotten a bit messy, and that is what Mr. Obama's team will have to do after the week that ended with Friday's problematic news conference on the economy.

The special effects company that brought Tupac Shakur back to life in the form of a ghostly image on stage at the Coachella music festival says it has plans for a similar project with images of Elvis Presley, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The company, Digital Domain Media Group, has said it has entered a deal with Core Media Group to produce images of Presley for a range of entertainment projects on film, television and at live events. Core Media owns the rights to Presley's image. ''His lifelong fans will be thrilled all over again, and new audiences will discover the electric experience of Elvis the performer,'' said Jack Soden, a Core Media executive. ''These projects will help continue the growth of Elvis's rich legacy all over the world.'' He did not provide details about the projects.

Wired, a magazine that celebrates nerdiness with cover pieces like ''How to be a Geek Dad,'' has found a different audience of readers who are not coming from the programming circles of Silicon Valley. They are technology enthusiasts spread across military bases and mazelike corridors at the Pentagon. In the five years since Wired.com started its Danger Room blog, it has attracted a steady following in the national security community. The blog has 35,094 Twitter followers, makes up 10 percent of the traffic on Wired.com, and has broken stories as geeky and alarming as the one on a virus spreading through drone cockpits and ''burn pit'' trash disposal exposure in Afghanistan. Danger Room appears to be reaching readers the military sometimes has trouble connecting with in its own ranks.

Dear Diary: I was trying to get into the Holland Tunnel in the late afternoon during rush hour and was stuck on Varick Street, inching toward the entrance, when an attractive woman in her early 20s knocked on my passenger window. I was startled, but she seemed very interested in speaking to me, so I opened my car window, curious about what she might have in mind. To my astonishment, she scolded me for not being aggressive enough in my driving! She told me that I was being too submissive, allowing other cars and trucks to break into ''our lane.'' She told me to toughen up and keep the traffic moving in our lane.

In her final years she was surrounded by the love of her family and friends who will miss her dearly. Visitation is Tuesday from 6 to 9pm at Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY. Mass will be held at Church of the Resurrection on Wednesday 10am with interment following at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Giant aquariums now soothe pediatric patients at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. It has added welcome signs in 10 languages, a state-of-the-art cardiac operating room and programs to keep chronically ill adults safely at home. But as Pamela S. Brier, the chief executive, was walking to the main entrance last week, she spotted a rain-soaked plastic bag on the front steps. Millions of dollars in revenue now depend on improving patients' perceptions of the hospital. ''I can't stand it,'' Ms. Brier muttered, and she darted over, her cream chiffon dress fluttering, to scoop up the litter herself.

CHILL--Alfred, of Lake Worth, Florida died on June 9 at the age of 82. The loving husband of Marion for 58 years. Father of Steven Chill (Abbey), Debra Brown (Marc) and Lisa Stewart (Hal). Adored grandfather of Nicole, Danielle, Alana, Kimberly, Alexandra, Michael and Adam. His joyous life was a blessing to all of us. Funeral service 10am, Monday at I.J. Morris, Dix Hills, NY.

SENZER--Martin. 35 year resident of Great Neck, New York, died on June 7, 2012. Born June 12, 1931, in the Bronx, NY to Gussie Turkowitz Senzer and Irving Senzer. Loving husband to Carrie. Devoted father to Ernest Senzer, Gregory Senzer, Diana Sheedy (Nicholas), Deborah Kimes (Mark), J. Gregory Oreiro (Deirdre). Cherished grandfather to nine and great-grandfather to three. Beloved brother of the late Irwin Samuel Senzer. He was a graduate of N.Y.U. School of Commerce in June of 1966. Retired IRS Officer for 34 years. World traveler and connoisseur of classical music, sculpture, architecture and the fine arts. Donations in his memory may be made to the Friendship Circle at Sid Jacobson JCC. Graveside services Monday, June 11, 2012 at 1:30pm at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

SILVER--Judge Howard, 77, on May 10th. Son of the late Louis and Celia Silver, the life-long New Yorker graduated from DeWitt Clinton HS, CCNY and Brooklyn Law School. He married Beatrice and they lived in the Bronx with their sons, Lewis and Jeff. They were married for nearly 44 years at the time of her death in 2002. In 1975, Silver was named Deputy Commissioner, FDNY, in charge of the Legal Department. He was elected to the Bronx Civil Court in 1982, and to the state Supreme Court in 1990, serving until 2010. In "retirement" the well-liked and well-respected former judge continued to serve, as a judicial hearing officer in the Bronx court, and for Nat'l Arbitration & Mediation, Inc. Judge Silver is survived by his sons, daughters-in-law and his long-time companion, Jean Daniels, as well as four grandchildren and a great-grandchild. A funeral was held on May 14th. A Memorial Service is planned for June 21st at the Bronx County Courthouse. Donation suggestions: ALS Association of New York; or Hon. Howard R. Silver Memorial Scholarship Fund; c/o City College Fund, 160 Convent Avenue, Shepard Hall #

Dear Diary: Most of the winos on the Upper West Side have vanished. They have been replaced by financial consultants wearing jogging gear and carrying lap dogs. The wino I miss most had a working dog named Bill. -In the '70s, the wino's mission was to get drunk and stay drunk on a bum wine named Night Train. In the mid-'80s, Guns N' Roses paid homage to the grape-flavored, high-sugar, high-alcohol-content beverage that sold for $1.50 a bottle.

For some journalists, Syria has been one of the least hospitable countries in the Middle East, a place where reporters -- if they can get in -- are routinely harassed and threatened as they try to uncover the repression that has propped up the Assad government for decades. For other journalists, Syria has until recently been a country led by the cultivated, English-speaking President Bashar al-Assad who, along with his beautiful British-born wife, Asma, was helping usher in a new era of openness and prosperity.

Strong turnout for the latest ''Madagascar'' movie gave DreamWorks Animation a shot in the arm over the weekend, while Ridley Scott's ''Prometheus'' proved an R rating isn't always a ticket-selling handicap. ''Madagascar 3: Europe's Most Wanted'' took in an estimated $60.4 million in its first three days in theaters to become the No. 1 movie in North America, according to Paramount Pictures, which distributed the film. That result -- almost identical to the opening-weekend total for the last ''Madagascar'' movie in 2008 -- is better than what DreamWorks Animation movies like ''Puss in Boots'' have recently delivered. (''Kung Fu Panda 2'' notably disappointed last summer with $47.7 million in first-weekend ticket sales.)

The United Nations reported intense fighting between the Syrian military and opposition forces in multiple locations across Syria on Monday and expressed alarm about civilians trapped in besieged rebel strongholds in the central city of Homs and northwestern village of Al Heffa. United Nations cease-fire monitors reported artillery shelling and machine-gun fire in the Khaldiyeh section of Homs as well as the towns of Rastan and Talbiseh, to the north. The monitors also reported the military's use of helicopter gunships -- a relatively new tactic employed by the Syrian Army, first observed by antigovernment activists in attacks on armed rebels around the major port of Latakia a week ago. The helicopter attacks are regarded as a significant escalation by the government side in the conflict.

The basic idea of what would make a good sugar substitute is simple. On the surface of the tongue, certain proteins act as detectors for specific tastes. The sweetness receptor is made of two proteins in what is believed to be a structure like a Venus' flytrap. When a sugar molecule attaches to the receptor, the receptor jogs neurons that send a signal to the brain that says something sweet has just been tasted.

Robin Roberts, a co-host of ''Good Morning America,'' told viewers on Monday that she had a rare blood and bone marrow disorder called MDS. Ms. Roberts, left, will receive a bone-marrow transplant from her older sister Sally-Ann Roberts, a New Orleans television anchor. The transplant will occur this year and will probably require Ms. Roberts to be away from the show for a period of months. ''I am going to beat this,'' she said, clutching the hands of two other ''Good Morning America'' hosts, George Stephanopoulos and Josh Elliott. MDS, short for myelodysplastic syndromes, ''is a rare blood disorder that affects the bone marrow,'' Ms. Roberts told viewers. Dr. Richard Besser of ABC News said that the disorder occurred as a result of her treatment for breast cancer five years ago. Dr. Besser said that Ms. Roberts's doctors expected her to be cured. ''She is young and incredibly healthy,'' he wrote on abcnews.com. Ms. Roberts learned of the diagnosis on the same day that her show celebrated its first win over NBC's ''Today'' show in 16 years, a victory attributed in part to the popularity of Ms. Roberts and the chemistry she has with her co-hosts. ''Talk about your highs and lows!'' Ms. Roberts wrote in a message, also on abcnews.com.

ROBBINS--Edward E.,(82), died on June 9th in Fort Lauderdale, FL. Long-time resident of New York City. Devoted son of the late Sophie and Morris. Survived by sisters-in-law Rhona and Thelma, nieces Louise Edman (Win) and Risa Weinstock (Rob), their children, and his extended family of beloved friends. He was with the William Morris Agency, Inc. in New York for 43 years, retiring in April 1991. Burial was on June 11th on Long Island.

Like many other pediatricians, I do not wear a white coat. Many of us believe that babies and small children suffer from a special form of ''white coat syndrome,'' that mix of trepidation and anxiety that some adults experience - to the point of high blood pressure - in a medical setting. The pediatric version is easy to diagnose: Doctor in white coat walks into room, kid starts to cry. I worry that a child like this has recalled shots or an unpleasant ear check and has connected that memory to a particular garment, rather than to my face, or my exam room, or my stethoscope.

During Memorial Day weekend, I was listening to public radio en route to my daily swim when I heard ''A Child's Reliquary,'' a piano trio written by Richard Danielpour in memory of the 18-month-old son of the conductor Carl St. Clair. The child drowned in a pool in 1999 when his mother, who was in the pool with him, suffered a diabetic seizure. A day later I learned that a 17-year-old boy had drowned after being caught in a riptide off the coast of New Jersey. Soon after, I heard of yet another drowning off the Jersey Shore, this time a man in his 20s.

When Erika Royer's lupus led to kidney failure four years ago, her father, Radburn, was able to give her an extraordinary gift: a kidney. Ms. Royer, now 31, regained her kidney function, no longer needs dialysis and has been able to return to work. But because of his donation, her father, a physically active 53-year-old, has been unable to obtain private health insurance.
KLEIN--Bernard L. June 12, 2002. Nobody did it better. Love You Always, Alice and Family

LONDON - When Alex Ljung, a multilingual entrepreneur, co-founded the audio-sharing Web service SoundCloud in Stockholm in 2007, he knew the company needed an international expansion strategy right away. The company didn't have a big domestic market or access to a large pool of world-class developers. A few months after the company was started, Mr. Ljung and his business partner, Eric Wahlforss, moved to Berlin to be closer to many of the region's largest markets and tap into the city's booming start-up community. Earlier this year, he started breaking into the American market, securing $50 million of financing from Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the Silicon Valley venture capital giant, and other firms.

An Op-Ed essay on Friday about development around Theodore Roosevelt's Elkhorn ranch in North Dakota misstated an achievement of the Boone and Crockett Club, which Roosevelt founded. While the club lobbied for the creation of national parks, Yellowstone was not one of them. (The club lobbied to protect Yellowstone, which was created in 1872, from hunting and vandalism.)

GOCHBERG--Lawrence. SAR mourns the loss of Lawrence Gochberg, beloved father of longtime SAR supporters: Barbara Gochberg and Board Member, Steven Pretsfelder, grandfather of SAR students/ alumni - Talia and Maya. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack Bendheim, President

A popular class of drugs used to treat Type 2 diabetes may increase the risk of vision problems, a new study suggests, underlining the importance of regular eye exams for anyone with diabetes. The study is one of the largest to investigate vision loss associated with thiazolidinediones, a group of drugs that includes the medications Actos and Avandia. While the drugs can help to protect against complications of diabetes, small trials and case reports had suggested they may increase the risk of macular edema, or swelling in the central part of the retina, which can result in blindness in one or both eyes.

Since effectively nailing down the Republican nomination for president in mid-April, Mitt Romney has had to balance his time on campaign trail with jaunts to numerous fund-raising events across the country. But that is to change Friday, when Mr. Romney trades his jet for a bus for five days of barnstorming across six states that has all the appearances of an unofficial kickoff to the general election.

The Broadway musicals ''Once,'' ''Newsies,'' and ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'' all had stronger ticket sales than usual on Monday after their respective wins and televised performance numbers at the Tony Awards on Sunday night, according to publicists for the productions or theater executives familiar with the sales. ''Once,'' which won the best musical Tony and seven others, was on track to sell five times its usual number of tickets on Monday, by far its best day since performances began in February. ''Newsies,'' which won for best score and choreography, was selling almost twice as many tickets as usual. And ''Porgy and Bess,'' which won for best musical revival and best actress in a musical (Audra McDonald), had ''one of its best days since opening'' in January, Jeffrey Richards, a producer of the show, said. Other shows were hoping to rebound from shutouts at the Tonys. The revival of ''Godspell'' didn't have any Tony nominations but did get to stage a number on the CBS telecast, and the producer Ken Davenport said on Monday that he hoped that visibility would yield more ticket sales. ''Godspell'' has been struggling; last week the show grossed its lowest amount, $156,437, since performances began in October. Mr. Davenport, who had said he would close the musical on June 24 if ticket sales did not pick up, said on Monday that he would make a decision on a closing notice soon. Another play, Nicky Silver's comedy ''The Lyons,'' lost its one shot at a Tony on Sunday: best actress in a play for Linda Lavin. ''The Lyons'' has been among the lowest-grossing plays this spring, but a spokesman said on Monday that there were no plans to close it.

News that a Massachusetts man suffered severe burns while using a backyard grill -- just after applying sunscreen spray -- has raised new fears about sunscreen products. But dermatologists and burn experts called it a freak occurrence caused not by the sunscreen itself, but by the fact that the man was using an aerosol spray near an open flame. Sunscreen itself is not usually flammable. But like hairsprays, spray deodorants, insecticides, paints and other products that can be sprayed out of a can or bottle, sunscreen can become flammable when used in aerosol form, said Dr. Darrell Rigel, a clinical professor of dermatology at New York University.

The gap in life expectancy between whites and blacks in America has narrowed, reaching the lowest point ever recorded, a new study shows. White men and women born in the United States can still expect to outlive black men and women by about three to five years. But the new report shows that from 2003 to 2008, the gap declined by roughly a year for both men and women.

An article on Friday about Spain's latest government bond sale referred incorrectly to the owners of a majority of Spain's debt. Sixty-seven percent of Spain's bonds are owned by domestic investors, including banks, pension funds and insurance companies; banks alone do not own that much.

NOURI--Edmond J. Episcopal Social Services remembers Edmond J. Nouri, esteemed advocate and loyal supporter, for his dedication, commitment, and generosity to our mission of transforming the lives of New Yorkers in need. We are moved that he chose to encourage memorial contributions to ESS, a fitting tribute to honor his life's work and interest, and are eternally grateful for Mr. Nouri's unwavering support. www.essnyc.org.

Chinese archaeologists have unearthed 110 terra-cotta soldiers of the kind that stunned the world in the 1970s, when thousands of such figures were discovered at Xian in central China, part of a tomb army built to guard China's first emperor in the afterlife. Agence France-Presse reported that the newly excavated life-size warriors, like the one above, had been found near the Qin emperor Ying Zheng's mausoleum over three years and that archaeologists had also uncovered 12 pottery horses, parts of chariots and weapons and tools. ''The most significant discovery this time around is that the relics that were found were well preserved and colorfully painted,'' said Shen Maosheng, the deputy director of the archaeology department of the Qin Shihuang Terracotta Warriors and Horses Museum, which oversees the tomb. He added that archaeologists had pinpointed the location of 11 more warriors but had yet to unearth them. Nine of the estimated 8,000 figures discovered in the 1970s are on view in an exhibition ''Terracotta Warriors: Defenders of China's First Emperor'' at Discovery Times Square in Manhattan.

Playwrights, be fearless about what you put into your plays. But then be ruthless about what you cut out of them. Even your best lines can be lost if they're just tossed into an ocean of words. For proof of that you could see ''I Am a Tree,'' a solo play written and performed by Dulcy Rogers. Sprinkled throughout the show are several nice observations and clever moments. To get to them, however, you'll have to sit through a litany of action-stopping descriptions and digressions.

ATLANTA -- After an odd few weeks in the wilderness, when no one could get a clutch hit or pitch a dominant game, the Yankees finally got back to a place they always expected to be. With a 3-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves on Monday night, the Yankees were back in first place in the American League East for the first time since April 24. They took a meandering route, but after they fell into a tie for last place on May 21, when their record sagged to 21-21, the Yankees have won 14 of 18 games to catch the idle Tampa Bay Rays atop the division. At 35-25, the Yankees are a season-high 10 games over .500, tied with the Rays.

An article on Monday about a special election to fill the Arizona Congressional seat vacated by Gabrielle Giffords, who survived an assassination attempt last year, misstated the age of Jesse Kelly, the Republican candidate. He is 30, not 40. The article also misstated the number of terms served by Ms. Giffords, a Democrat. She was in her third term when she resigned in January, not her second.

McNAMARA--Francis J. Jr.,A prominent Connecticut trial attorney and philanthropist, passed away June 8th in Vero Beach, FL at the age of 84. During his illustrious 35-year career in litigation, he rose to managing partner of the law firm Cummings and Lockwood, Stamford, CT, and argued cases in courts from the Connecticut Supreme Court to the United States Supreme Court as well as in federal courts in many states. During the same time period, he also led the Charles E. Culpeper Foundation in New York City as it disbursed over one hundred million dollars in charitable funds to worthy health, educational and cultural institutions. Mr. McNamara was a voracious reader of history; as well as a passionate student of Irish genealogy, loved writing and had just recently completed a comprehensive memoir of the McNamara family. Mr. McNamara is survived by his loving wife of 26 years, Lois Magner; as well as his six children, three stepchildren and 20 grandchildren. Francis J. McNamara, Jr. was born in Boston, MA on November 30, 1927. He spent his early years in Washington, DC and graduated from Gonzaga High School in 1945. He served in the Navy as a seaman in 1946. He attended Georgetown University, receiving a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1949 and completing his college education in three years. Mr. McNamara considered pursuing a career in radio broadcasting, but at the urging of his father entered law school and subsequently received a Bachelor of Laws degree from Georgetown in 1951. Recalled to active duty as a Navy Lieutenant in early 1952, he served as a Communications Officer on a destroyer and later as Assistant Personnel Officer at the US Naval Station, Newport, RI, until late 1953. Mr. McNamara served as Assistant United States Attorney for the District of Connecticut from January, 1954 until December, 1956. In 1957 he joined the law firm of Cummings and Lockwood and became a partner of that firm in 1960. Mr. McNamara handled many important cases on behalf of Cummings and Lockwood in the Connecticut Supreme Court and Superior Court, the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut and the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit as well as a case before the U.S. Supreme Court. Prior to his retirement from Cummings and Lockwood in 1991 he was a managing partner in charge of the firm's litigation department and was a member of the Finance and Executive Committees of the firm. Mr. McNamara was a member of the bar of the United States District Courts for the District of Connecticut, the Southern and Eastern Districts of Virginia, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second and Fourth Circuits, the Supreme Court of the United States, the Tax Court of the United States and the United States Court of Military Appeals. He was a Fellow and former State Chairman of the American College of Trial Lawyers. A fellow of the American Bar Foundation and also past president of the Stamford Bar Association, Mr. McNamara lectured on legal matters in this country and in Europe. Mr. McNamara was elected Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Charles E. Culpeper Foundation in 1968 and remained in this position while maintaining an active law practice with Cummings and Lockwood until 1991 when he became President and Chief Executive Officer of the Foundation. He retired on July 1, 1999 and the Foundation was then merged with the Rockefeller Brothers Fund of New York City. During over three decades in active charge of the philanthropy of the Charles E. Culpeper Foundation Mr. McNamara had a major role in the disbursement of over $120,000,000 in charitable funds to undergraduate institutions of higher learning as well as hospitals, medical centers and medical schools, arts and culture activities and legal programs. A devout Catholic who attended daily Mass for many years, Mr. McNamara was a Knight of Malta and a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre in the Roman Catholic Church. In 1983 he was designated a Knight of St. Gregory the Great by Pope John Paul II. He received the Outstanding Philanthropic Service Award from the Fairfield Foundation of the Diocese of Bridgeport in 1984. Mr. McNamara was a Trustee of Fairfield University from 1969 to 1981 and was elected Trustee Emeritus. In May of 1983, an Honorary Doctor of Laws was conferred on Mr. McNamara by that University. A fan of horse racing since his early days in Washington, DC, Mr. McNamara bred and raced thoroughbred horses for many years. He was also a skier who enjoyed weekends with his children on the ski slopes in Vermont. In his later years, golf became a passion and he was a member of the Wee Burn Country Club in Darien, CT, and the Orchid Island Golf and Beach Club in Vero Beach, FL. Mr. McNamara's first wife, Noreen, died in 1984. He married Lois L. Magner of Norwalk, CT in 1986. In addition to his wife, Mr. McNamara leaves his six children: Francis J. III (and Lisa M. McNamara) of Wenham, MA; Moira P. (Mrs. Lance F. James) of Marblehead, MA; John A. (and Christa S. McNamara) of Darien, CT; Kathleen L. (Mrs. Robert J. Hugin) of Summit, NJ; Martha J. (Mrs. James Bordewick) of Boston, MA; Mark J. (and Karen Peterson McNamara) of League City, TX; three stepchildren: Michael J. (and Leslie) Magner of Weston, CT; Maribeth (and Joe) Hemingway of Sandy Hook, CT; Jay P. (and Lisa) Magner of Wilton, CT along with 20 grandchildren. He is also survived by his sisters: Jeanne E. (Mrs. Herman Eckrich) of New Canaan, CT and Lois A. (Mrs. Peter Driscoll), of Dataw Island, SC. The family will receive friends at The Magner Funeral home, 12 Mott Avenue, Norwalk, CT, 06850 on Wednesday, June 13 from 5-8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church, 21 Cherry Street, New Canaan, CT on Thursday, June 14 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Gonzaga College High School Annual Fund, 19 Eye Street, NW, Washington, DC 20001 or the Fairfield University Fairfield Fund, 1073 North Benson Road, Fairfield, CT 06824.

An article on Friday about malnourishment in India despite programs to distribute its bountiful grain crops misspelled the surname of a specialist on food policy and misidentified his profession. He is Biraj Patnaik, not Patniak, and while he advises the Indian Supreme Court on food issues, he is not a lawyer.

It was not enough. And it may never be enough. The euro zone's offer of $125 billion to bail out Spanish banks over the weekend was hailed by finance ministers and officials across Europe as a masterstroke. Germany's finance minister, Wolfgang Schäuble, suggested no further bailouts would be needed, saying, ''Spain is on the right track.'' On Sunday, some analysts and investors even applauded, with David R. Kotok, co-founder and chief investment officer of Cumberland Advisors, proclaiming: ''Euro zone leaders rose to the occasion.'' How wrong they were.

Another dispatch from the recent American Geriatrics Society scientific conference in Seattle: Caring for an elderly, ailing spouse is an unimaginably difficult task, especially when the caregivers are elderly themselves. But wives fare worse, physically and emotionally, than husbands, researchers at the University of California, San Francisco, have found.

The federal judge overseeing the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta made it clear from the outset that he would limit evidence related to the defendant's extensive charitable works and humanitarian acts. ''If Mother Teresa were here and charged with bank robbery, the jury would still have to determine whether or not she committed bank robbery,'' said Judge Jed S. Rakoff, the presiding judge, during a pretrial hearing last month.

This year's N.B.A. finals feature two strikingly different offenses. Over all, the Oklahoma City Thunder rely on penetration-and-pitch plays that create 3-point and close-range shots. The Miami Heat, in contrast, rely on strategic player positioning to create effective spacing for isolation plays that enable midrange and close-range scoring chances for their superstars. 3-Point Shooting

The Tony Award-winning musical ''Fela!,'' which ran 14 months on Broadway before closing last year, will return next month for a four-week engagement at the Al Hirschfeld Theater as part of the show's world tour, the producers confirmed on Monday. A biographical look at the Afrobeat musician Fela Kuti of Nigeria, the production will star the Tony nominee Sahr Ngaujah, above, at most performances, which are scheduled to run July 9 to Aug. 4, before the tour moves on to Australia and Japan. Such return engagements are relatively rare on Broadway, though Jujamcyn Theaters, which owns the Hirschfeld, arranged for a similar limited encore of ''Hair'' last summer at another of its theaters. As with ''Hair,'' which was also on tour, the ''Fela!'' producers -- who include Jay-Z and Will and Jada Pinkett Smith -- are capitalizing on an empty Broadway theater to try to make money and draw media coverage for the show's tour. ''Fela!'' won Tonys for the director Bill T. Jones's choreography and for costumes and sound design.

An article on Monday about efforts by President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his family, along with public relations advisers they have hired, to make the ruling family the face of a more Westernized and open Syria misidentified the organization with which Andrew Tabler, an expert on Syria who was quoted, is affiliated. It is the Washington Institute for Near East Policy -- not the Institute for Middle Eastern Studies.

NEWARK -- Mahler's Ninth Symphony is a brave undertaking for a smallish band. The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra ended its season, its second with Jacques Lacombe as music director, with performances of that work over the weekend. (Mr. Lacombe closed his first season, last year, with Mahler's Third Symphony, also a difficult but arguably less challenging assignment.) It has been an eventful spring for Mr. Lacombe and the orchestra. Last month they performed at Carnegie Hall as part of the Spring for Music festival. Mr. Lacombe, 48, who hails from Cap-de-la-Madeleine, Quebec, was knighted on Thursday by the National Order of Quebec (in absentia, occupied as he was with the orchestra). And now -- 100 years to the month after the work's premiere, 101 years after the composer's death -- here was Mahler's grand farewell symphony.

That David Robertson is a superb conductor of contemporary classical music hardly needs repeating. Evidence is everywhere in reviews worldwide and in the vivid memories of those who have heard concerts he has led. But what makes Mr. Robertson one of the most extraordinary musical advocates of our day has just as much to do with what he does off the podium. The latest demonstration came during the first of two concerts in the New York Philharmonic's Contact! series, presented in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday evening. In the context of an enticing program that included, miracle of continuing miracles, a premiere by the 103-year-old Elliott Carter, a single moment exemplified Mr. Robertson's gift.

An article on the Itineraries page last Tuesday about airports' experiments with tiered pricing for Wi-Fi service in the terminal misstated a provision of a contract between the Wi-Fi supplier Boingo Wireless and Denver International Airport. The airport will get a minimum of $500,000 a year for three years; it will not get a minimum of $500,000 over three years.

BEHIND SCHEDULE Despite fresh reminders of the fragility of the financial system, the United States, the European Union and Japan are behind schedule on executing measures that were adopted as part of an international effort to avert banking crises, a high-level panel said Monday. In a report to Group of 20 leaders ahead of their summit meeting in Mexico next week, regulators and central bankers from the world's largest countries gave poor marks to the regions that have been most vulnerable to banking crises in recent years. JACK EWING
