DIMOLEON--Paris Christian. American Thymele Theatre mourns the passing of its dramaturge P.C. Dimoleon, in Athens, on June 8. Before retiring in 2002, he appeared as actor in several major motion pictures and in classical stage repertory as well as in Greek State Television in early 70s series. As historian, he will be remembered for his extensive research in the history of Greek theatre in America and the Orthodox Church in America. Also, a musicologist and an original advocate in the creation of the Megaron Athens Music Hall, the capital city's only concert hall.

House Republicans on Monday signaled that they would take the first step toward citing Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. with contempt of Congress if he does not turn over more Justice Department documents related to the botched gun trafficking investigation known as Operation Fast and Furious. Representative Darrell Issa, chairman of the House oversight committee, announced on Monday that the committee would meet on June 20 to vote on whether to recommend that the full House hold Mr. Holder in contempt. The oversight committee approved a subpoena in October to the department for documents about Fast and Furious.

The Your Money column on Saturday, about setting aside a day each year to handle personal finance tasks, referred imprecisely to Vanguard's automatic rebalancing service for its customers' accounts. The service is offered only for 401(k) accounts; it is not available for all accounts.

8:25 P.M. (TV5Monde) À DOUBLE TOUR (1961) On a magnificent property near Aix-en-Provence in the south of France, the Marcoux family is living a seemingly respectable life. That is, until Léda (Antonella Lualdi), the mistress of the vintner Henri Marcoux (Jacques Dacqmine), is murdered -- placing him, his high-strung wife (Madeleine Robinson), their unstable son (André Jocelyn) and their heartsick daughter (Jeanne Valérie), who is in love with an unsavory sort (Jean-Paul Belmondo), under suspicion. Bernadette Lafont, above, plays the household's temptress maid. Claude Chabrol directed this psychological drama, his first use of color, for which he was nominated for the Golden Lion at the 1959 Venice Film Festival; Ms. Robinson won the Volpi Cup. ''M. Chabrol has captured visual beauties as exciting as anything else in the film,'' A. H. Weiler wrote in The New York Times about this movie, released in the United States as ''Leda.'' ''The scene in which his lovers wander hand in hand through a field of crimson poppies is truly picturesque, as are the views of the manor house, its formal gardens, skies, fields and the cool simplicity of Mlle. Lualdi's Japanese-like home. They need little explanation. Unfortunately, some actions of the principals in 'Leda' still do.'' In French, with English subtitles. 2:30 P.M. (Flix) THE ROMANTIC ENGLISHWOMAN (1975) Michael Caine and Glenda Jackson play Lewis and Elizabeth Fielding, a successful British writer and his bored wife, who become obsessed with each other's infidelities, imagined and otherwise. Helmut Berger is Thomas, the self-styled poet and gigolo Lewis invites to live with them while Lewis composes a screenplay about an unhappily married woman who runs off to the Continent to find herself. The director, Joseph Losey, and the screenwriters, Tom Stoppard and Thomas Wiseman, have ''attempted to make an intelligent film about intelligent people, and as long as Mr. Berger is kept off the screen, it is,'' Vincent Canby wrote in The Times. ''Mr. Caine and Miss Jackson are interesting performers.'' But Mr. Berger, he added, is ''a missing element, and the movie, unequally balanced, goes off into a wobbly, out-of-control orbit as a result.''

People take all sorts of things from the workplace: pens, paper, maybe a stapler now and again, but what about a grand piano? The principal of a city adult-education center in the Bronx admitted to doing just that.

RUHM--Wendy Sturges, peacefully at home after a brave battle with brain cancer. Born September 19, 1975 in Manhattan, Wendy attended the Bronxville School, Georgetown School of Foreign Service, the Sorbonne, Science Politique and London School of Economics. Acting in theatrical productions throughout her school years and Quogue summers, she joined The Blue Hill Troupe when she moved to New York. An active Troupe member, she particularly enjoyed designing the programs. She was an investment analyst at Bramwell Capital Management, part of Sentinel Management. A talented photographer she assembled a collection of extraordinary photographs from her many travels. She had a bubbling optimism, an infectious enthusiasm and an unparalleled gift for nurturing family and friends. She is survived by her parents, Michele and Thomas Ruhm, her brother Tom Ruhm and numerous family and friends. Funeral Service June 15th at 2pm at Christ Church, Bronxville.

For people who exercise but fret that they really should be working out more, new studies may be soothing. The amount of exercise needed to improve health and longevity, this new science shows, is modest, and more is not necessarily better. That is the message of the newest and perhaps most compelling of the studies, which was presented on Saturday at the annual meeting of the American College of Sports Medicine in San Francisco. For it, researchers at the University of South Carolina Arnold School of Public Health and other institutions combed through the health records of 52,656 American adults who'd undergone physicals between 1971 and 2002 as part of the Aerobics Center Longitudinal Study at the Cooper Institute in Dallas. Each participant completed physical testing and activity questionnaires and returned for at least one follow-up visit.

''We have 21 souls on board, 20 in the water,'' a man can be heard saying in part of a radio call released by the Coast Guard on Tuesday. ''I have three deceased on board, nine injured because of the explosion we've had. I'm in three feet of water on the bridge. I'm going to stay by the radio as long as I can before I have to go overboard.'' The call on Monday, calmly describing a scene of horror and panic at sea, prompted a major rescue response.

Hot Cup Chili Pepper 7 had just barreled through a tune called ''Turkey Foot Corner'' at the Red Hook Jazz Festival on Sunday afternoon when some outside noise piped up, distracting but altogether fitting. It was the rickety jingle of an ice cream truck parked next to the Urban Meadow community garden in Brooklyn, which adjoins a playground and serves as the festival site. Mister Softee, a familiar intruder, was easily silenced as the band played on. Still, the moment lingered in the mind awhile, an accidental reminder of what this festival means, and for whom.

ROSENTHAL--William S. New York Medical College mourns the passing of our colleague and benefactor, William S. Rosenthal, M.D., professor emeritus of medicine. For nearly 30 years, Dr. Rosenthal served as the Upham Professor of Gastroenterology and Director the Division of Gastroenterology. Throughout his long and distinguished career as a clinician, investigator and educator, he trained generations of physicians who have contributed to the field of gastroenterology. His humanitarian spirit and generosity will live on with the endowed chair in medicine that he and his wife Barbara bestowed on the College in 2001. The Barbara and William Rosenthal Chair of Medicine will contribute immeasurably to the training of many students, residents and faculty, and to the care of countless patients. We extend heartfelt condolences to his family and colleagues. Alan Kadish, M.D., President Edward C. Halperin, M.D., M.A. Chancellor for Health Affairs and CEO William H. Frishman, M.D. The Barbara and William Rosenthal Chair of Medicine Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D. Professor of Psychiatry

Whenever an artist produces something so boggling and so inexplicable as to defy more than a cursory understanding at first brush, I am reminded of the science-fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke's suggestion that ''any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic.'' There was magic in the air on Thursday evening at the Eyebeam Art and Technology Center in Chelsea, when a new piece by Eli Keszler, ''L-Carrier,'' was introduced before a rapt audience. Mr. Keszler's work presents several paradoxes. A percussionist with roots in punk rock and free improvisation, he fuses chaos and order in his drumming: a burble and clatter akin to what European drummers like Tony Oxley and Han Bennink invented in the late 1960s to distinguish their work from American free jazz. Mr. Keszler's penchant for pealing, ringing metal evokes another European percussionist, Eddie Prévost of the English collective AMM.

Geetanjali Gupta's education at Harvard Law School may not have included a class on how to testify, but she was poised and articulate in answering questions on the witness stand on Tuesday at her father's criminal trial. Ms. Gupta was among the final defense witnesses in the trial of Rajat K. Gupta, the onetime head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company. The government has accused Mr. Gupta, a former director of Goldman Sachs and Procter & Gamble, of leaking boardroom secrets from those two companies to Raj Rajaratnam, the fallen hedge fund titan convicted of insider trading last year.

NUSSBAUM--Jeremy, age 70. Cherished husband and life's love of Charline Spektor, loving and beloved father and best friend of Gabriel (Elizabeth) and Lily Claire, passed away at home on June 12th, 2012. One of the country's most distinguished intellectual property attorneys, and owner of the BookHampton bookstores. Words can't describe how he fulfilled our lives with his unstoppable curiosity, appetite for adventure (both literal and cultural), endless music, incomparable wit and the wildest laugh. He is ours forever and we are his. His memory will serve as a blessing. A funeral will be held on Thursday, June 14th at 11am at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons, 44 Woods Lane, East Hampton NY.

KONTES--Peter W. Principal of Greenwich Advisory Group, co-founder and former chief executive of Marakon Associates, and author of "The Value Imperative" and "The CEO, Strategy, and Shareholder Value," has died. He was sixty-five years old. He also served as an Executive in Residence and Distinguished Faculty Fellow at the Yale Graduate School of Management. He had a BA from Yale and an MBA from UC Berkeley. His family was the focal point of his life, and he enjoyed a strong bond with his Yale friends. He will be greatly missed.

NUSSBAUM--Jeremy. BookHampton mourns the death and celebrates the life of our loving and brilliant owner, His knowledge of books and music was unparalleled. His memory will continue to inspire all of us.

NUSSBAUM--Jeremy. We mourn the passing of our beloved colleague and friend Jeremy who led our firm's entertainment law practice for the past decade. Jeremy had a distinguished legal career spanning more than forty years of private practice counseling clients on copyright and entertainment matters in the publishing, theatrical, and music industries. Although his years with our firm represent only a brief part of his remarkable career, Jeremy made an indelible impression in our minds and hearts for the extraordinary quality of his legal mind, his dedication to his clients and his gracious manner. Jeremy brought class and sophistication to the practice of law that is rarely matched. We shall miss him very much. The law firm of Cowan, Liebowitz & Latman, P.C.

This season the Brooklyn Philharmonic, revived from the dead, traveled to three of the borough's communities with tailor-made concert series. In October the orchestra took Russian cartoon music to Brighton Beach and in March, an ambitious program full of premieres to Downtown Brooklyn, a new-music epicenter as of late. And on Saturday evening it closed the inaugural season of its new era under the artistic director Alan Pierson with a stimulating, entertaining outdoor concert at the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Plaza, an evening that connected the Philharmonic's origins to its future.

A good, old-fashioned consciousness-raising session flares into life in the first act of ''Rapture, Blister, Burn,'' the intensely smart, immensely funny new play by Gina Gionfriddo that opened Tuesday night at Playwrights Horizons. Over late afternoon martinis, four women representing three generations dive into a freewheeling conversation about how women's lives have and have not changed since the 1970s. The image of women rapping away about gender roles may hark back to that seemingly distant era, but the rap itself is rich in new perspectives. Consider this unlikely phenomenon: The ideas of Phyllis Schlafly, the anti-feminist scold of the ''me'' decade, are given about as much airtime as those of Betty Freidan, one of the movement's heroines.

Type the name Joe Walsh into any search engine, and two very different people pop up. The first, Representative Joe Walsh of Illinois, is a first-term Republican running for re-election. The second is a Rock and Roll Hall of Famer who endorsed the congressman's Democratic opponent on Tuesday. ''I'm the real Joe Walsh, and I'm proud to back a real American success story: Tammy Duckworth,'' the singer and guitarist for The Eagles said in a statement released by the campaign of Ms. Duckworth, a military veteran and former assistant secretary of veterans affairs. ''Tammy's story, her service to our nation and her continued commitment to working families (like the one I come from!) have convinced me that she's the right choice for Congress.''

5:53 p.m. | Updated Brett Anderson, the award-winning restaurant critic and food writer, was among more than 200 employees laid off on Tuesday by The Times-Picayune of New Orleans. He confirmed the decision in an interview, saying that New Orleans and its food community would remain central to his work as a writer.

POLEN--David Martin, 68, of Boca Raton, Florida died on June 11, 2012 after a heroic battle with cancer and with his family at his side. Born in Brooklyn, New York to Solomon and Estelle (Kimmel) Polen, David is survived by his mother Estelle Polen, his beloved children Carra, Solomon and Daniel, his long time partner and fiance Dr. Sherri Bluth, his sister Eileen Topper of New Jersey, his niece Elizabeth Topper Golub, Ph.D. of Baltimore, MD and his nephew Andrew Topper of New Jersey. David graduated from Brooklyn College with a Bachelor of Arts Degree. He was an entrepreneur and the visionary founder of Polen Capital Management (PCM). Over the past 23 years he built a successful money management firm along with an exceptional team. David's success stemmed not only from his intellect, work ethic and attention to detail, but also from his vision for successful investments in securities. He developed a proprietary investment methodology called the Systematic Valuation Discipline (SVD) that PCM continues to employ today. Using the SVD, David amassed one of the best track records in the investment business. David generously supported numerous charitable organizations. He held positions of leadership in many of these organizations, including the Jewish National Fund (JNF), Independent Group Home Living (IGHL), the YIVO Institute in New York City, The Florida Holocaust Museum in Tampa, Florida, Israel Bonds and the Jewish Federation. David was beloved and respected by his family and many friends and business associates. He will be sorely missed and remembered fondly by all those who had the good fortune to know him during his all too brief stay on earth. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations can be directed to the following charities that David was deeply committed to supporting: Jewish National Fund- www.jnf.org/; YIVO-www.yivoinstitute.org/; Tampa Holocaust Museum-www.flholocaustmuseum.org/; or IGHL Foundation- www.ighl.org/foundation.asp. Services will be held on Wednesday, June 13, 2012 at 1pm at Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, 7240 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL 33487, Telephone 1-800-992-9262 or 561-997-9900 with interment to follow at the Gardens Memorial Park at 4103 North Military Trail, in Boca Raton, Florida 33431, 561-989-9190. Shiva will be held at St. Andrew's Country Club in Boca Raton, FL following the funeral on Wednesday and on Thursday and Friday from 4:00pm- 7:00pm.

The owner of a Brooklyn tortilla factory where a worker died last year after falling into a mixing machine pleaded guilty on Tuesday to failing to pay adequate wages, the state attorney general's office said. The owner, Erasmo Ponce, also pleaded guilty on behalf of his company to failing to secure workers' compensation insurance for his employees.

PAY INCREASE Chief executives of Britain's 100 largest publicly traded companies received a median pay increase of 10 percent last year, according to a report released on Tuesday. That is higher than Britain's inflation rate of 3 percent, and the median executive package was about 200 times the average pay of employees in the private sector. Robert E. Diamond Jr. of Barclays, above, who made £21 million, was the highest-paid executive in the survey. JULIA WERDIGIER

A fleet of portable toilets has been booked, and they will be docked along 110th Street, at the north end of Central Park, where people will be mustering on Sunday afternoon. So far, at least 35 buses are expected. The subways will most likely carry the bulk of the crowd. A group of religious leaders from all five boroughs plan to meet on Wednesday to discuss the logistics of bringing their congregations. Training will be provided Thursday night for marshals who could not make a session that was held on Tuesday. ''Order and safety is the rule of the day,'' said Kyle Bragg, of Local 32BJ, a building workers union, who is organizing the training. ''The marshals will be there to help make sure we can offer our message in an orderly, peaceful way.''

When President Obama visits 1 World Trade Center on Thursday, he will find a tower that is undeniably impressive and - even a year and a half before its scheduled completion - unquestionably a landmark of 21st-century New York. But it is not exactly the tower New Yorkers were led to believe they would see when the plans were unveiled in 2006. Since the Durst Organization joined the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in 2010 as the effective codeveloper of the project, it has revised the design in a number of ways.

ORLANDO, Fla. - Mitt Romney understands the power of the verbal gaffe, real or perceived. During the Republican primaries, he offered up an all-you-can-eat buffet of them: his wife's ''Cadillacs,'' his friends' Nascar teams, how he liked being able to fire people. Every time, the Obama campaign and its Democratic allies were eager to pounce.

Coming soon to record stores both real-world and digital: a wave of Frank Zappa reissues. The Zappa Family Trust, which is controlled by Frank Zappa's widow, Gail, announced on Monday that it had regained control of his catalog and had struck a licensing and distribution deal with Universal Music Enterprises to release his entire catalog of some 60 recordings in coming years. The first batch of 12 albums -- including ''Freak Out!,'' ''We're Only in It for the Money'' and other classics by Zappa's 1960s band, the Mothers of Invention -- are due out on July 31, with another dozen to be released by the end of the year.

With four main actors scheduled to depart the show in July, the Broadway revival of ''Gore Vidal's The Best Man'' is turning to some notable television stars as replacements, in hopes they will help sell tickets to the tourists who dominate New York theater audiences in summertime. Two of the new cast members will also be making their Broadway debuts: The Emmy-nominated actress Cybill Shepherd (''Cybill,'' ''Moonlighting'') will succeed Candice Bergen as a frustrated political wife whose husband is vying for a presidential nomination, while Kristin Davis (Charlotte on ''Sex and the City'') will replace Kerry Butler as the southern belle married to a senator also seeking the nomination.

KHAYATT--Shaker A.,76, of New York City, passed away on June 10, 2012, surrounded by loved ones. Shaker is preceded in death by his parents Albert and Winifred Khayatt. He is survived by his wife, Edith Khayatt, by his children Samiha Khayatt (Thomas Blailock), Djenan Akel (Tarek Akel), Shaker A. Khayatt Jr. (Zoe Khayatt), and Shafika Khayatt, by his grandchildren, Zain, Aliaa and Mufleh Akel, and George, Daphne and Theodora Khayatt, by his sister, Samiha Melas, and by his nephew, George Melas. Shaker arrived in the United States from Egypt in 1957, received a Masters degree from MIT in 1959, and was a member of the Harvard Business School class of 1963. He loved to cook and entertain, enjoyed museums and theater, and was enamored of all things New York. Most of all, he loved to be surrounded by family and friends.The funeral service will be held on Thursday, June 14, at 10:30am at the Stanwich Congregational Church, 202 Taconic Road, Greenwich, CT 06831. Showtime's family of original programming has grown by two, with a little help from Masters and Johnson. The cable channel, already home to series including ''Homeland,'' ''Dexter'' and ''Shameless,'' announced that it was picking up two new shows including ''Masters of Sex,'' which dramatizes the lives of the sex researchers William Masters and Virginia Johnson. That series, whose pilot was announced in February and produced in March, casts Michael Sheen (of ''Frost/Nixon'' and ''The Queen'') as Masters and Lizzy Caplan (''Party Down'') as Johnson in a series that will chronicle their ''unusual lives, romance and pop culture trajectory'' from ''a mid-western teaching hospital in St. Louis to the cover of Time magazine and nearly a dozen appearances on Johnny Carson's couch,'' a news release said (they mean the one on the ''Tonight'' show).

One hundred and fourteen years ago, an experiment in a London laboratory helped shape the face of modern New York City. On June 12, 1898, two British chemists discovered neon. While New York's neon heyday is flickering off into extinction, visual artists with an eye toward preservation remain drawn to it like moths to a flame. Last fall, we showed you the photographer Kirsten Hively's Project Neon!, a salute to the city's illuminated history. It turns out Thomas Rinaldi, an architectural designer, has worked on a similar project since 2006.

White Light, Lincoln Center's fall festival dedicated to humanity's spiritual side, will present Esa-Pekka Salonen conducting Mahler's Symphony No. 9 with the Philharmonia Orchestra of London next season, the center said on Tuesday. The festival will feature the jaw-harp virtuoso Wang Li; the organist Cameron Carpenter playing Bach in Alice Tully Hall; and a Stockhausen program. The announcement of the new season, to run for a month starting on Oct. 18, said the series would also include the United States debut of the Latvian Radio Choir; a Charpentier program by William Christie and Les Arts Florissants; a music-theater work by Heiner Goebbels called ''I went to the house but did not enter,'' with the Hilliard Ensemble; and an appearance by the singer Mary Chapin Carpenter. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

When JPMorgan's chief executive, Jamie Dimon, appears Wednesday on Capitol Hill, he plans to play down the risky trading activities that have already prompted at least $3 billion in losses. In prepared testimony for a Senate hearing into the trading mess, Mr. Dimon called the losses an ''isolated event'' that would not hurt customers or taxpayers. While apologizing for various mistakes, he explained that risk was unavoidable in the banking business, and ultimately the firm's capital position and diversified model ''did what they were supposed to do'' and protected the company against unexpected losses in one area.

FREUDBERG--Judy. The Board of Trustees, staff of Sesame Workshop, and cast and crew of Sesame Street deeply mourn the loss of Judy Freudberg, show writer and co-creator of "Elmo's World." Her four decades with Sesame Street brought laughter, music and learning to children every day through Sesame Street, her work on the feature film "Sesame Street Presents: Follow That Bird," through books and so much more. Judy's words and stories will continue to entertain and bring joy to generations of young children to come throughout the world. We will all miss her.

The Advertising column on Tuesday, about advertisers' taking their brands on the road to interact with consumers at activities like music festivals and amusement parks, misidentified the headquarters city of the agency Beyond Traditional, which is collaborating on a campaign for Jack in the Box. Ravi Coltrane, Roy Hargrove and Vijay Iyer are among the jazz players who will perform at a benefit concert on Wednesday for the Jazz Gallery, a small nonprofit performance space in SoHo that has played an influential role in developing New York's jazz talent for the last 17 years. The concert will be held at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem at 6:30 p.m., and the tickets range from $45 to $250. The Jazz Gallery has been housed in a 2,000-square-foot loft at 290 Hudson Street since its founding but will lose its lease at the end of the year because the building has been rezoned and is being converted into residential lofts, the executive director, Deborah Steinglass, said. The organization has set out to raise $250,000 to pay for the move and retire its accumulated debt. A new space has yet to be found, and to remain in Manhattan, the nonprofit's rent -- now about $68,000 a year -- is likely to rise significantly, putting pressure on the group's $480,000 a year budget, Ms. Steinglass said.

A new Broadway revival of David Mamet's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' is in the works for the 2012-13 season with Al Pacino in line to play the desperate salesman Shelly ''The Machine'' Levene, according to two Broadway producers with knowledge of the plans. Playing Shelly Levene would be a reversal of roles for Mr. Pacino, who - in the 1992 film adaptation of ''Glengarry'' - played the hotshot in the Chicago real estate office where Mr. Mamet's searing comedy unfolds. Mr. Pacino was nominated for a best supporting actor Oscar for that performance, as Ricky Roma. It would also be the latest project for Mr. Pacino and the revival's director, Daniel Sullivan, who worked together on the 2010 Broadway outing of ''The Merchant of Venice.''

An article on May 28 about the Russian oil company Surgutneftegaz referred imprecisely to the overall value and sale of the oil it extracts. Surgutneftegaz produces oil valued at about $127 million a day; that is not the amount sold to an oil-trading firm, Gunvor. Although past reports have indicated that Gunvor is a primary purchaser of Surgutneftegaz's oil, Surgutneftegaz said in 2011 that about 9 percent of the oil it sold for export went to Gunvor.

TUCSON -- Ron Barber, whom former Representative Gabrielle Giffords picked as her successor, defeated his Republican rival on Tuesday in a closely followed special election seen by many political strategists as testing ground for the power of national issues in deciding competitive races. Mr. Barber's win over Jesse Kelly was largely secured by voters in Pima County, the largest of the four counties that make up the district and also home to Tucson, its base and Ms. Giffords's former hometown. Turnout there and in most others of the district was high for a special election, reflecting the significance of the race and Ms. Giffords's draw on voters.

Adele, Adele, Adele. Her album ''21'' (XL/Columbia) has broken seemingly every rule of the modern music business. Since ''21'' came out 68 weeks ago, it has never left the Billboard Top 10, indeed spending most of its time in the Top 5. It is closing in on 10 million sales, an achievement long assumed to no longer be possible. Its success has even warped the basic math of the industry.

ACNE, the Swedish cult label favored for killer denim and boots (its Pistol boots have been knocked off too many times to count), has grown out of its petite Greene Street boutique and moved to a space just up the street. Mazelike, with wall partitions dividing several rooms, the new shop has a Gustavian cast, with striped floor tiles and fur benches. The design was initially inspired by the 16th-century walls that Jonny Johansson, the company's co-founder and creative director (above), looks out on from his Stockholm offices. (''I didn't want to do a McDonald's concept where you see the same thing in Tokyo as you do in New York,'' he said.) What you will see is the familiar Acne aesthetic in apparel based on classic work styles. (A leather dress with star cutouts, $1,400, is a knockout.) You will also find a wall of denim and the coolest shoe closet in town. Acne, 33 Greene Street, (212) 334-8345; acnestudios.com.

V-Moda, a headphone maker known for its dramatic sounding headphones, is usually concerned with putting sound into your ears, but its Faders VIP hearing protectors are intended to keep sound out. V-Moda has updated last years Faders with ''Faders VIP,'' which protect hearing by reducing the volume of sound by 12 decibels. To put it more plainly, they are fancy earplugs.

S UMMERING city slickers have been transforming Montauk from a sleepy fishing village to a Hamptons party town. Despite protests from exasperated locals, the trend continued unabated this season, with new bars, new hotels, new owners and a new flock of house-sharing Jitney riders ready to keep the night going. Below, find out where to don your lavender slacks, how to relive a Murray Hill bar-crawl on the beach and what makes the natives the most restless. BEN DETRICK

Seagate, the hard drive maker, is redoing its consumer line-up with a new product that should make its mission crystal clear to shoppers. Named Backup Plus, the slim (14.5 millimeters) hard drive moves data from a computer for safe keeping. But it also will pull down photos from Facebook or Flickr too. The company says the device is pretty. True, and it comes in four colors: black, silver, red and blue.

The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency is so lenient on the banks it is supposed to regulate that it could be mistaken for a division of the United States Chamber of Commerce. Does its new head, Thomas J. Curry, have any hope of giving it a backbone? Mr. Curry, a former director of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a regulator that actually regulates, has been leading the O.C.C. for about six weeks. He made his debut in Congress last week, expressing contrition over his agency's failure to monitor JPMorgan Chase's trading that resulted in multibillion-dollar losses for the bank.

The Bronx Museum, which is celebrating its 40th anniversary, announced Wednesday that it had received $500,000 from the Ford Foundation, part of a campaign to raise $1 million for a new acquisitions fund that will focus on buying the works of contemporary artists with strong connections to the Bronx. The campaign's goal is to add 40 significant new works to the museum's permanent collection over the next year. ''These acquisitions will highlight the Bronx roots of many contemporary artists, illustrating how the borough has served as inspiration for a wide range of artists over the past 40 years,'' said Holly Block, the museum's executive director.

Political redemption, it seems, is almost never completely out of reach. Six years ago, after losing his Virginia Senate seat and handing control of the chamber to Democrats, George Allen hinted that he could see a day when the bitterness and embarrassment of his defeat would no longer loom so large.

As they do with many things, some parents worry disproportionately about ''summer slide.'' Children who don't read over the summer lose two to three months of reading development, while children who do read gain a month (though research shows that those who have access to reading material at home don't appear to be at much risk). But even if summer slide is something of a manufactured concern for the kind of parents who worry about these things, many of us want to keep our children engaged over the summer.

8:56 p.m. | Updated Another round is under way in the battle between established cable and Internet providers like Comcast and relative upstarts like Netflix. And the government is playing referee. The Justice Department is quietly investigating the cable industry's behavior toward nascent online video competitors as part of an inquiry into possible anticompetitive practices by cable companies.

ABRAM--Rachel. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the untimely death of our member, Rachel Abram. We will miss her integrity and courage, her devotion to family, friends and community. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her beloved Mike, their children, Sarah, Dan and Marina, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, DD, Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President

Q.One of my colleagues places way too many updates on Facebook about his church fund-raisers, his children's play dates, his wife's book, his trips to the park -- you get the point. I get annoying alerts every time he posts. How do I block the alerts, but not defriend him? A. Facebook includes a feature that lets you prune the content in your News Feed and filter out status updates from specific people. Just find an update from a person you would like to remove from your News Feed and click on the small arrow that appears when you pass the mouse cursor over the top right side of the update. From the menu, choose the Unsubscribe From Status Updates option for that person.

The annals of Broadway may have plenty of room for musicals with religious themes and stories inspired by the Gospels, but the summer season does not. The producers of the Broadway revival of ''Godspell,'' the pop musical loosely based on parables from the New Testament, said late Tuesday evening that the production will play its final performance at the Circle in the Square Theater on June 24. This revival of ''Godspell,'' which features a score by Stephen Schwartz (''Wicked,'' ''Pippin'') and a book by John-Michael Tebelak (who created the show as a master's thesis project for Carnegie Mellon University, and directed its Off Broadway, Broadway and other incarnations), began performances on Oct. 13 and officially opened on Nov. 7.

3:10 p.m. | Updated Showtime's supply of ''Weeds'' has been cashed: the coming eighth season of that cable network's original comedy series about a drug-dealing mom (played by Mary-Louise Parker) and her unconventional family will be its last, Showtime said on Wednesday.

SILVERMAN--Saul S. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and Past President, Saul S. Silverman. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Estelle and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President H. Lawrence Fein, Secretary

BANKER--Joel, 84, of Mamaroneck, NY passed away peacefully on June 12th. Loving husband of 57 years to Lucy, proud father of Stephen (Judy) and Caroline (Jeff). Devoted grandfather of Douglas, Russell, Katherine, Andrew and Marc. Joel had a long and productive career as a real estate developer and had served with distinction during World War II in the US Navy. He led a life that was rich in friendships, work, books, cycling and devotion to family. Contributions may be made in his name to the Alzheimers Association.

JENKINS--Paul. Abstract expressionist painter and most beloved husband, left this world June 9, 2012 leaving immense and inexpressible sorrow at his passing. A unique and extraordinary man, a great artist and friend whose devotion to his work transcended all boundaries, whose paintings brought joy as they explored the mysteries of color and light, who knew that beauty holds inherent danger and that life is full of wonder. A gifted writer and poet, generous and caring, a man for all seasons. His absence is profound. For contributions in his name: www.citta.org.

The On Hockey column on Monday, about the Los Angeles Kings' struggles in closing out the Stanley Cup finals against the Devils after taking a three-games-to-none lead, misstated the given name of the Kings defenseman who said: ''It's disappointing, but they don't hand this thing out. It's difficult to do; it's a test. You're going to lose two games in a row. You're going to lose on the road.'' He is Matt Greene, not Andy. (Andy Greene plays for the Devils.)

Game 1 of the N.B.A. finals Tuesday night proved that a small-market team like the Oklahoma City Thunder can resonate with fans beyond its region. The Thunder's 105-94 over the Miami Heat was seen by an average of 16.2 million viewers, the most for a Game 1 since ESPN/ABC acquired N.B.A. rights in 2002-03. The previous high was 15.3 million in 2004 for the Detroit Pistons-Los Angeles Lakers finals.

LONDON -- Manchester United may have fallen short of an English soccer championship last month, but the United States stock market is emerging as a new goal. The soccer club was considering an initial public offering in the United States instead of Singapore, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter. Several I.P.O.'s across Asia have recently been postponed or canceled.

PURSUING A SALE Dick Clark Productions, the 55-year-old company that produces the Golden Globe awards show and the New Year's Eve broadcast hosted by the company's late founder, left, is exploring a sale of itself, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday. The company has hired the Raine Group, a boutique investment bank, to run the sales process, these people said.

NUSSBAUM--Jeremy, age 70. Cherished husband and life's love of Charline Spektor, loving and beloved father and best friend of Gabriel (Elizabeth) and Lily Claire, passed away at home on June 12th, 2012. One of the country's most distinguished intellectual property attorneys, and owner of the BookHampton bookstores. Words can't describe how he fulfilled our lives with his unstoppable curiosity, appetite for adventure (both literal and cultural), endless music, incomparable wit and the wildest laugh. He is ours forever and we are his. His memory will serve as a blessing. A funeral will be held on Thursday, June 14th at 11am at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons, 44 Woods Lane, East Hampton NY.
JOHNSTON--Mary. A remarkable human being, friend and neighbor. Our sincere condolences to Michael, Ginny, Dan and the entire family. The world has lost a great humanitarian. The Bickell Family

GOLBY--Monique Poelman, of New York passed away April 6th. She will be missed by her husband Ralph Golby, daughter Alexandra Golby and son-in-law Chris Scovel, her son Wesley Golby and Kim Bucci, and grandchildren Phineas and Atticus Scovel and Adele Golby.

Who knew the ''Mad Men'' season would end -- spoilers ahead -- with Don Draper still happily married to Megan; Peggy Olson no longer working at Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce; Joan Harris a partner in the company; and Lane Pryce dead? Matthew Weiner, left, the creator and show runner of ''Mad Men,'' that's who. In conversations before and after the season finale was shown on AMC (and drew 2.7 million viewers), Mr. Weiner spoke about plot twists from throughout the year. These are edited excerpts from those conversations. DAVE ITZKOFF Q. We heard from Jared Harris [Lane Pryce] about how he dealt with his exit from the series. What was it like for you to have to let him go?

Google wants love. But so do six other companies. They are after .love, actually, a new ''top-level domain'' that could catch on as .com, .org and .net did. Love might not prevail, but chances are, at least one of the domains in 1,930 applications for new extensions will. The domains are the letters that follow the dot in Internet addresses, and the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, known as Icann, revealed the new requests on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON -President Obama presented Israel's president,Shimon Peres, with America's highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, calling Mr. Peres ''the essence of Israel itself - an indomitable spirit that will not be denied.'' The president praised Mr. Peres, 88, for helping to build the long-running alliance between the United States and Israel.

FRANKEL--Edith. The Art & Antique Dealers League of America sadly announces that Edith Frankel (73) died Tuesday, June 5, after battling pancreatic cancer. Edith was co-founder of E & J Frankel, Ltd., the renowned Asian art gallery in New York City. She was a lecturer and author on Asian art, and founder of the Far Eastern Art department at the New School. She served as a member of the League's Board of Directors since the mid-1980s. She is survived by her husband and business partner, Joel Frankel, her son James Frankel, her daughter Risa Swersey, and grandson Brandon Swersey. A memorial gathering will be held on Sunday, June 24, at 11a.m. at China Institute (125 E. 66 St., NYC, 10065). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation.

ZUCKERMAN--Joyce Lila Meisel, on June 11, at 81 in Hollywood, FL. Born in New York on August 13, 1930. Survived by her loving husband Larry of 61 years and her children Barbara, Elliot, and Robert. The memory of her will always be in our hearts.

LUNDBERG--Sara. The Contemporary Freudian Society mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague, Sara Lundberg who died on June 9. She was a gifted teacher, child and adult psychoanalyst, pianist and artist. We will miss her thoughtfulness and wisdom.

WASHINGTON -- JPMorgan Chase is ''likely'' to try to recover compensation from executives responsible for a recent multibillion-dollar trading blowup, according to Jamie Dimon, the bank's chief executive. In testimony on Wednesday before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Dimon assured lawmakers that the bank's board was investigating the trading losses at the chief investment office. Once the investigation is complete, he said, the bank will decide whose paychecks to pursue.

NUSSBAUM--Jeremy. BookHampton mourns the death and celebrates the life of our loving and brilliant owner, His knowledge of books and music was unparalleled. His memory will continue to inspire all of us.

KING--Norman. We will miss his brilliance, keen wit, fabulous sense of humor, but most of all his friendship. Len Isaacson and Sue

SIXTIES psychedelia was the starting point for the Creatures of the Wind capsule collection that Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters have designed for J. Crew. They are the latest CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund prizewinners to create products for J. Crew, a sponsor of the fund. Among the groovy items in the '60s-inflected collection are glittery multicolor patent leather oxfords, $295, and this kinetically striped cashmere cardigan, which also looks like a child's adorable construction-paper collage, $300. Creatures of the Wind collection at J. Crew, 91 Fifth Avenue, (212) 255-4848; jcrew.com.

In the summer of 1983, when an acting career was still just a dream, Woody Harrelson worked construction in Houston and met a play's worth of colorful characters, including an aspiring writer from Harlem named Frankie Hyman who became his best buddy on the scaffolding. That fall Mr. Harrelson headed for New York to try to break into theater, only to hit dead ends. As with many struggling actors, his thoughts turned to writing his own scripts, and he found himself thinking back to that summer in Houston - though it would take more than 25 years, and a collaboration with Mr. Hyman, to finish the play he had in mind. -Their dark comedy, ''Bullet for Adolf,'' which had its world premiere in Toronto last year, will begin performances Off Broadway at New World Stages on July 19 and run through Sept. 9. Mr. Harrelson, who went on to win an Emmy Award on ''Cheers'' and receive two Academy Award nominations, for ''The People vs. Larry Flynt'' (1996) and ''The Messenger'' (2009), will also direct the production.

FOR Humberto Leon and Carol Lim, the retail whizzes behind Opening Ceremony, this looks to be a gold-medal summer. They will mark the 10th anniversary of their store with a pop-up in London to coincide with the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games. And, in celebration of the Games, they will unveil a large-scale collaboration with Adidas Originals. The collection draws on classic Adidas swimming and cycling styles, now reimagined with '90s street-wear touches -- not designed for sport, but altogether functional nonetheless. ''Growing up not necessarily an athlete, I embrace the idea of sports-inspired clothing that you don't necessarily have to do sports in,'' Mr. Leon said, demonstrating, of course, that shopping is the sincerest form of flattery. Bandanna-print anoraks and swimsuits, sambas and sneakers in a mini-floral print (the sneakers are exceptional) and reflective bombers are a few highlights. The real triumph comes in wearing the sexy, sporty pieces on summer streets. Adidas Originals x Opening Ceremony, $75 to $630 for apparel and $140 to $275 for footwear, available later this month at Opening Ceremony (openingceremony.us) and Adidas Originals (adidas.com).

(ESPN) UNITED STATES OPEN CHAMPIONSHIP Fresh off his victory at the Memorial Tournament this month Tiger Woods, above, and 155 other golfers -- including last year's United States Open champion, Rory McIlroy -- tee off in the first round of this major championship at the Olympic Club in San Francisco. Coverage runs until 10. 6:30 P.M. (Showtime 2) AS GOOD AS IT GETS (1997) A successful author (Jack Nicholson) must overcome his obsessive-compulsive disorder and his general dislike of humanity to woo a waitress (Helen Hunt) who happens to be the only person who can tolerate him in return. Mr. Nicholson and Ms. Hunt each won Oscars for their performances. In her review in The New York Times, Janet Maslin wrote that this film, directed by James L. Brooks, ''echoes the quirky appeal of his 'Broadcast News,' and that's high praise.'' She added: ''Nobody does a better job of backing characters into happiness than Mr. Brooks, especially when those characters are high-strung enough to leave happiness practically out of the question. Though this is a looser and less even comedy, it shows off Mr. Brooks's gift for the right-on zinger.''

LANE--Dr. Frederick Martin, MD, of New York City. Born on May 27, 1928 and died June 12, 2012. Married to Evelyn Lane 1948-1973. Husband of Carol Feit Lane (deceased), survived by children Anne Lane, Elliot Lane, Roberta Lane and Carol Lane and by grandchildren Eleanor, Jacob and Joshua; and by stepchildren Wendy Zeifer and Laurie Feit. Yale University School of Medicine 1953; Cornell University 1949; Bronx High School of Science; Captain in the US Army; 50+ years of private practice in Psychiatry and Psychoanalysis; former Clinical Professor of Psychiatry, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons; Past President of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. Interests: writing, music, travel, movies. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel on Friday June 15th at 11:30. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Doctors Without Borders USA P.O. Box 5030, Hagerstown, MD 21741-5030.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Tuesday about the Los Angeles Kings' winning the Stanley Cup with a 6-1 victory over the Devils misstated, in some copies, the number of games the Kings won in the regular season. Of 82 games, they won 40, not 42.

HELLER--Peter E.,age 88, loving and devoted father, passed away June 11, 2012. Born August 25, 1923 in New York City, and raised in Chicago, he is remembered for his steadfastness and love to his family. He attended the Berkshire School receiving the Headmaster's Prize and went on to the Fifth and Second Marine Division in the Pacific 1942-45. A graduate of Northwestern University's Commerce School 1948, he became Senior VP, Director, Head of New York Office at Walter E. Heller & Company and was one of the early coordinators of facsimile transmission and non-impact printing with ensuing patent, licenses, and settlements. The owner of Faxon Communications/Accuscan, Inc., he was also President of Purchase, NY, spearheading the creation of the Public Park at Pepsico, Purchase, NY by rallying community effort against corporate environmental takeover and protecting green spaces. He invented and patented Logo Brake Light, a concept of automotive logo illumination and the center high mounted stop lamp in 2002 and was continuing his work until his very last weeks. He was also a member of the Board of Overseers for the Florence Heller Graduate School of Advanced Studies in Social Welfare at Brandeis University and past trustee of the Berkshire School. He is survived by his four daughters Darcy, Lisa, Dana, and Terry and three grandchildren.

A narrow majority of New York City voters oppose Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to restrict sales of big sugary beverages in city restaurants, movie theaters and street carts, according to a poll released on Wednesday. Opponents of the plan edged out supporters, 51 percent to 46 percent; opposition was strongest among older voters, white voters and voters on Staten Island. The poll, conducted by Quinnipiac University, found voters divided along political, educational and geographic lines over the proposal, which has attracted international interest and could become a major landmark of Mr. Bloomberg's public health initiatives.

KNAUSS--Jennifer, 75, former executive director of the Illinois Caucus for Adolescent Health, died of Alzheimers on Monday. Jenny's husband, Don Moyer of Chicago, survives her; as well as her two children, Orlando Knauss and Olivia Bukosky, from her previous marriage to the late Peter Knauss; and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held this summer. Donations can be made to Planned Parenthood.

During closing arguments in the insider trading trial of Rajat K. Gupta on Wednesday, a prosecutor distilled a dizzying number of exhibits - phone records, board minutes, trading logs and e-mails - into a cogent narrative of the government's case. But a defense lawyer for Mr. Gupta said that the reams of documents and nearly two dozen witnesses were a desperate attempt by the government to bolster a thin case that lacked any ''hard, real and direct'' evidence of wrongdoing.

Less than a year after writing a well-received memoir, Diane Keaton will follow it up with another book. Ms. Keaton, the Oscar-winning actress, is working on a book about ''beauty, aging and being a woman,'' her publisher, Random House, said on Monday. ''We're all obsessed with beauty, no matter who you are,'' Ms. Keaton said in a statement. ''I think most women are a little disappointed when they look in the mirror -- I know I am -- and this book is my way of asking why.''

Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers, the prominent Silicon Valley venture capital firm, filed its legal response Wednesday to the sex discrimination charges made last month by junior partner Ellen Pao. As expected, Kleiner sweepingly and specifically denied all the claims. ''KPCB vigorously denies that it discriminated against plaintiff, retaliated against plaintiff after she complained about harassment or discrimination, or that it violated its obligation to take reasonable steps to prevent discrimination from occurring,'' the response says.

A theater review on Wednesday about ''Rapture, Blister, Burn,'' at Playwrights Horizons in Manhattan, misspelled the surname of a prominent feminist whose ideas are discussed in the play. She was Betty Friedan, not Freidan.

There was an anniversary celebration at City Hall on Wednesday for something that happened 40 years ago, in June 1972. Cake with tasty white frosting was served. People swapped memories. And there was an official proclamation signed by the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, who was 5 years old back then, and Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer, who was 21.

SILVERMAN--Saul S. Beloved husband, devoted father, grandfather and great grandfather, respected legal advisor and trusted certified public accountant to so many, Saul Sonny S. Silverman, age 93, died June 12, 2012. Born in Brooklyn on April 18, 1919, to Jake and Minnie Silverman, Saul graduated from Lincoln High School at age 15, then from New York University School of Commerce at age 19. He received his JD degree from New York University Law School in 1941. His illustrious legal and accounting career began with his association with Mike Edelstein, which became Wright Long & Company and later merged with Clarence Rainess, where Saul was the managing partner. At the same time, he developed his legal practice as a tax specialist with his life-long cherished colleague Martin Weinraub, as Silverman & Weinraub. His long and distinguished career was not only based upon his tax law expertise, but also the universal trust in him held by all who sought his services. Never self-serving, he always put the interests of his clients first and was guided by the highest ethical standards. Saul was a respected community leader: honored and active in several Jewish charities, president of the Lake Success Civic Association, Lake Success Municipal Court Judge, president and long-time board member of Beach Point Condominium Association and High Ridge Country Club in Palm Beach, Florida. But the greatest achievement of his life was his long and endlessly happy marriage to Estelle, beautiful wife of 68 years, whom he married on Christmas day, 1943, while serving his country in the Air Force during World War II. Saul will be forever missed by his three loving daughters, Jill Cossman, Linda Sobo and Sheri Labovitz, their spouses David Cossman, Simon Sobo and Steve Labovitz, his grandchildren Joshua Cossman and wife Christy, Jim Cossman and wife Denise, Joanna Cossman, Daniel Sobo and wife Lisa, Michael Sobo and wife Mary Ellen, Andrew Labovitz and wife Allison and Laura Labovitz, and great grandchildren Lucas and Katie. Services will be held on Friday, June 15 at 11:00 a.m. Temple Bethel, 105 Old Mill Rd., Great Neck, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to cancercare.org.

CHICAGO - There may be an opening for least-hated banker in America, and Lloyd C. Blankfein seems interested in applying. On Wednesday, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase and long Wall Street's fair-haired boy, appeared before a Congressional panel to try to explain how his bank lost at least $3 billion on a trade he has admitted never should have been placed.

ROME -- On the steps of the Basilica di Sant'Agostino, a stone's throw from Piazza Navona and the famous Caravaggios in the Church of San Francese, four men waited for handouts on a summery afternoon last week. Only a priest and a few tourists passed by. Inside, soft scrims of white cloth scaffolding fluttered high over the marbled nave. The place was nearly empty. To the left of the entrance Caravaggio's ''Madonna di Loreto,'' the Madonna of the Pilgrims as it's called, hung in a narrow chapel. The pilgrims, a barefoot old man and an old woman, kneel before a sleepy Mary and the infant Jesus.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Tuesday about the Yankees' 3-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves the previous night misstated, in some copies, their position in the American League East standings. While the Yankees were in first place, they were tied with the Tampa Bay Rays, not a half-game ahead of them. The article also described incorrectly in some copies the performance of relief pitcher Boone Logan. While he recorded the game's final two outs, he did not earn a save.

The garment district is the new financial district. Fashion industry leaders are opening their wallets forPresident Obama, filling a crucial void in New York fund-raising circles left by Wall Street donors who remain leery of giving to the president.

KING--Norman, 86 years old, on June 12, 2012. Author, entrepreneur and media consultant, who founded the first independent media buying service, U.S. Media. His greatest loves were his wife of 56 years, Barbara, son Laurence, grandchildren Allison, Daniel and Nicholas, and The Friars Club. We were blessed to have you with us for 86 years, and we will love and miss you forever. Service Friday, June 15, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

ABRAM--Rachel F.,on June 12. Beloved wife of Michael. Loving mother of Daniel and Sarah. Doting grandmother of Yara and Kyra. Cherished mother-in-law of Marina. A gifted editor, avid reader, and proud co-creator of Face to Face/Faith to Faith. Donations in Rachel's memory to the Rachel Abram Fund for Face to Face, Auburn Seminary, 3041 Broadway, NY, NY 10027. Services Sunday June 17, 12 noon at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd Street.

An obituary and a headline on June 6 about the singer Herb Reed of the Platters erroneously attributed a distinction to him. While he was the last surviving member of the lineup that recorded the Platters' first hits, including ''The Great Pretender'' and ''Only You,'' he was not the last surviving original member of the Platters. (At least one other original member, Gaynel Hodge, who left before the Platters had their first hits, is still alive.)

Just a week after writing about the prepaid no-contract iPhone deal from mobile provider Cricket, Virgin Mobile announced it would also offer the iPhone 4 and 4S on a prepaid no-contract deal. Is it a better deal than Cricket's? To the calculator!

An article on Tuesday about the effect of budget cuts in Greece on ancient artifacts and historical scholarship misstated the name of a temple near a site where excavation has come to a halt. It is the Temple of Apollo Epicurius, not Epicurean Apollo. And in some editions, several paragraphs in the second column of type of the continuation of the article were out of order. The correct version can be found at nytimes.com/art.

The young people, all wearing green camouflage uniforms and standing attentively in two perfect lines, were reciting the Pledge of Allegiance with gusto and aplomb. But they were not in complete unison, and that made the tall man leaning against a wall unhappy. ''Y'all better act like there's a thousand of you in here! Again!'' the man, Sgt. Maj. Michael W. Tucker, yelled.

An article on Wednesday about a victory by Ron Barber, a Democrat, over his Republican rival, Jesse Kelly, in a special congressional election in Arizona on Tuesday to fill the rest of Gabrielle Giffords's term referred incorrectly to an election in November for the newly created Second Congressional District. While Mr. Barber and Mr. Kelly are expected to face each other in that election, they first must face primary challengers in August; it is not the case that they will indeed run against each other in November. The article also misstated the political makeup of Arizona's current Eighth Congressional District. While Republicans do hold a slight edge in registrations, they do not hold a majority.

BARNETT--Lawrence R. Executive, philanthropist and, foremost, beloved family patriarch, Lawrence Barnett passed away on June 11, 2012. Surrounded by family, Barnett died much as he had lived, with dignity and grace and with the adoration of all those he touched in his 98 years. From 1936 to 2000, Barnett was an executive and served on the boards of such organizations as Music Corporation of America (MCA) (1936 1963), General Artist Corporation (1963 1966), Piper Aircraft Corporation (1969 1977), Warner Communications Inc. (1984 1988), United Television, Inc. (1981 2000) and Chris-Craft Industries, Inc. (1967 2000). MCA founder Jules Stein hired and sent Barnett to MCA's West Coast offices where he handled the careers of many entertainers, including big band leaders Benny Goodman, Tommy Dorsey and Harry James; singers Tony Bennett, Lena Horne and Dinah Shore; and celebrities Jack Benny, George Burns, Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis and Marlon Brando. Barnett heard about a young American actress named Isabel Bigley, who was a big hit in the London production of "Oklahoma," and was featured on the cover of Time Magazine. Barnett met with her, convinced her to sign with MCA, and two years later he asked her to marry him. During her career, Bigley too was widely respected for her work in TV and the theatre. She won a "Tony Award" for her role as Sarah Brown in the original Broadway production of "Guys and Dolls." Lawrence Barnett's credo in life was to help people so that one day he could look back and say that he lived his life unselfishly and gave something back to society for all the good fortune that was bestowed upon him. Over the years, he shared his passion, dedication, generosity of spirit, leadership and philanthropy with many worthy causes, such as Hillside Hospital, the Adoption Society of Westchester, the Annenberg Center for Health Services and the Eisenhower Medical Center. Lawrence and Isabel Barnett established The Ohio State University Arts Administration Program and the "Public Policy and the Arts Symposium." In 1996, Lawrence Barnett was awarded an honorary doctorate of fine arts and received the 2004 Gerlach Outstanding Development Volunteer Award. In 2011, the Barnetts donated the funds to establish the multi-disciplinary "Lawrence and Isabel Barnett Center for Integrated Arts and Enterprise" at Ohio State and to support extensive building renovations for the College of Arts and Sciences. Barnett considered one of his greatest philanthropic accomplishments to be his work with The ALS Association to help find a cure and treatments for Lou Gehrig's Disease. ALS (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) is a devastating neuromuscular disease that robs its victims of the ability to walk, speak and, eventually, to breathe. Barnett served as the founding chair of The ALS Association; gave generously of his time, intellect and support; and became affectionately known as the "Grandfather" of the organization, a distinction of which he was especially proud. He and his wife helped fund research that eventually isolated the first gene associated with ALS and sponsored the inaugural Lawrence and Isabel Barnett Post-Doctoral Fellowship Award for ALS research. Barnett once shared, "I have always felt like I needed to help humanity as much as I can. And we are fortunate enough to be able to give back to the community and make a difference. Even as a child, I wanted to help others." Lawrence and Isabel Barnett shared 53 years of marriage, until her death in 2006, and leaves a large and loving family of six children: Robert, William, Claudia, Lawrence Jr., James, and Laurey; 16 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. For more information, visit www.alsa.org/news/lawrence-r-barnett-leaves-a.html. The family has indicated that anyone wishing to honor Lawrence Barnett's memory may make a contribution to The ALS Association, 1275 K Street NW., Suite 1050, Washington, DC, 20005, 202-407-8580. www.alsa.org/donate.

REMAINS OF THE BAILOUT The Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced on Thursday that it had been paid back for loans used to support the government bailouts of Bear Stearns and the American International Group. Even so, vestiges of the sweeping taxpayer support of 2008 remain. The New York Fed said two entities that held securities once owned by Bear Stearns and A.I.G. still hold assets that need to be sold. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

LONDON - Yasser el-Mallawany and Hassan Heikal are accustomed to turmoil. In recent years, they have steered EFG-Hermes through political upheaval, economic pain and market volatility, transforming the Egyptian financial firm into the leading investment bank in the Arab world. Now, the investment bankers face their own crisis. As deals dry up, Mr. Mallawany and Mr. Heikal are scrambling to sell a large piece of the business to a smaller rival in the gas-rich state of Qatar, which would give the firm capital to survive the current turbulence.

An article on Wednesday about the mobile phone app Skout described the abilities of some social networking apps incorrectly. Both Highlight and Circle show a user's location on a map; Skout and About.me give the location, but do not map it.

A picture caption on Thursday with the City Room column, about a 40th-anniversary celebration for Ms. magazine, misidentified the woman who was shown trying on a Wonder Woman outfit at a City Hall party. CROHN--George, Jr. Lifelong jewelry industry veteran, dedicated father of two sons, son of George Crohn Sr. and Eleanor Wohl of New York City, died June 12th, of a heart attack. His passions in life included boating, swimming, golf, the Boy Scouts of America and the National Foundation for Jewish Genetic Diseases which he founded in 1975. His younger son, Michael, was born with Dysautonomia, a Jewish genetic disease. Much of George's life was defined by his devotion to Michael and his tireless fund-raising efforts for all Jewish genetic diseases. A member of Sigma Alpha Mu, he graduated from Syracuse University in 1949 and prior to that attended the Horace Mann School in Riverdale. He is survived by his older brother Frank, his older son Jeffrey, two grandchildren, Nolan and Leah, and his loving companion of 20 years Angie Koo. Memorial/Funeral services will be held on Saturday June 16th at 11 o'clock at the Edwards Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that contributions be sent to Dysautonomia Foundation at www.familialdysautonomia.org. or Dysautonomia Foundationation, 315 W. 39th St. Suite 701 NY, NY 10018.

It hardly needs to be said that any armed force has the potential for internal as well as external violence. But ''The Invisible War,'' Kirby Dick's incendiary documentary about the epidemic of rape within the United States military, is a shocking and infuriating indictment of widespread sexual attacks on women. Such behavior, the film argues, is tacitly condoned and routinely covered up; the victims are often blamed and their reputations destroyed. This unsettling exposé, which won the audience award at the 2012 Sundance Film Festival, may be the most outraged film in the annual Human Rights Watch Film Festival, which opened on Thursday and continues at the Walter Reade Theater in Lincoln Center through June 28. It is likely to fuel a growing perception of the military as a broken institution, stretched beyond its limits and steeped in a belligerent, hypermasculine mystique that has gone unchecked.

A multiracial production of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' which opened to lukewarm reviews and middling box office on Broadway this spring, will close on July 22 after 23 previews and 104 performances. HECKMAN--Guy Carroll, of Newport, RI and Hobe Sound, FL died Sunday, June 3 at his home on Jupiter Island after a lengthy illness. He was 61. Mr. Heckman had a long career in finance, with a focus on energy, mining, and metals. He began his career at Chase Manhattan bank in 1974 in the Credit Audit Group. He went on to Mercantile Bank in St Louis and later returned to Chase Manhattan where he was a Vice President in the Petroleum and Mining Divisions. Mr. Heckman then joined American Bailey, a private equity venture capital firm, as a Principal, where he focused on the coal sector. Mr. Heckman, an avid sailor, was widely recognized for his accomplishments and contributions to the sport. He was the recipient of the inaugural Ted Turner Trophy awarded for an individual contribution to the 12 Meter Class of sailing on and off the water. Mr. Heckman was lauded for his efforts to sustain the 12 Meter Class, best known as the yachts in the America's Cup Races from 1958-1987. Initially a member of the syndicate for the 12 Meter yacht, "Courageous", which was a two time American's Cup winner, Mr. Heckman went on to be a member of the syndicate for the "USA", eventually taking over sole ownership of the "USA", a Grand Prix class 12 Meter design. He successfully campaigned the "USA", also known as "61", for the past several years. He was known as a sportsman dedicated to the highest level of the spirit of Corinthian, or non-professional, sailing. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club and served on the board of the International Yacht Restoration School and Museum of Yachting. Mr. Heckman attended St Louis Country Day School. He graduated from St. George's School in Newport, RI and Trinity College in Hartford, CT. He is survived by his wife Margaret Jenks Heckman: three sons: Drew Heckman of Atlanta; James Heckman of Washington, DC; Henry Heckman of Hong Kong; a grandson, Houston Heckman; and a sister, Lisa Hughes, of Washington, DC.; and daughters-in-law Allen Clare Heckman and Brooke Heckman.

Variations pose a challenge for a composer: take a theme -- a melody, bass line, whatever -- and progressively transform it, but never beyond recognition. It's harder than it sounds to change while staying the same. In a blog post about Bach's ''Goldberg Variations,'' the pianist Jeremy Denk writes, ''Think very similar thoughts for 79 more minutes, winding around the same basic themes, and then you will have some idea of what it's like to experience -- you might even say survive -- the 'Goldbergs.' ''

Mitt Romney steals a trick from an unlikely source for his latest ad: President Obama. But in this case, imitation is more mockery than the sincerest form of flattery. A new 30-second Romney campaign commercial called ''Doing Fine'' copies the music, pacing and script nearly verbatim from a 2008 Obama ad that took Senator John McCain to task for his well-known remark that ''the fundamentals of our economy are strong.''

Wayne Roberts was a pioneering 1970s graffiti writer known as ''Stay High 149'' who borrowed the haloed stick figure from the title sequence of the 1960s television series ''The Saint,'' put a joint in its mouth and turned it around. His ''Smoker'' tag, or signature, turned the heads of legions of imitators and admirers, including the anonymous teenagers who slipped into train yards at night to paint whole cars, as well as Norman Mailer, who featured him in his book ''The Faith of Graffiti.'' Mr. Roberts, who disappeared from the scene for some 25 years until he was rediscovered by a new generation of fans and artists in 2000, died on Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 61.

An Associated Press report in some copies on Wednesday about a 1-1 tie between the United States men's soccer team and Guatemala in a World Cup qualifier misstated the day of the game. It was Tuesday, not Thursday. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the day of the scoreless tie between Jamaica and Antigua. It was also Tuesday, not Friday.

JENKINS--Paul. Abstract expressionist painter and most beloved husband, left this world June 9, 2012 leaving immense and inexpressible sorrow at his passing. A unique and extraordinary man, a great artist and friend whose devotion to his work transcended all boundaries, whose paintings brought joy as they explored the mysteries of color and light, who knew that beauty holds inherent danger and that life is full of wonder. A gifted writer and poet, generous and caring, a man for all seasons. His absence is profound. For contributions in his name: www.citta.org.

Nick Watney holed out from the fairway for a double eagle at the par-5 17th. He hit a 5-iron from 190 yards to record the third double eagle in United States Open history. The other two were posted by T. C. Chen in the first round at Oakland Hills Country Club in 1985 and Shaun Micheel in the fourth round at Pebble Beach in 2010. ''Obviously the shot on 17 was something I'll always remember and I'm pleased with the round,'' said Watney, who carded a 69. He added: ''I can't really remember what I was feeling. It was kind of disbelief and joy, and it was really exciting.''

Countries with too much sovereign debt have increasingly found it difficult to raise the money they need at affordable rates in the financial markets. At the same time, banks in many of these countries have come under pressure as deposits have fled to countries with stronger economies. Because the banking systems are much larger than the economies of their home countries, the governments lack the ready resources to prop up banks in trouble. Until recently, Spain's sovereign debt was roughly the same as Germany's as a percentage of economic output, according to the International Monetary Fund. But Spain has Europe's highest unemployment rate and is once again in recession. As its banks have deteriorated, Spain has been forced to seek assistance for them from elsewhere in Europe. Many of Europe's Economies Are Weakening . . .

Updated, 4:21 p.m. | A third-grade teacher at a Harlem public school was arrested Wednesday on charges of sexually abusing an 8-year-old girl who goes to the school, the authorities said. The teacher, Rafael Sosa of Public School 208 on West 111th Street, is accused of touching the girl's genitals and kissing her on several occasions inside the school, according to a criminal complaint filed by a detective in the Police Department's Special Victims Squad. Mr. Sosa, who was the girl's third-grade teacher, also instructed her to log into his e-mail account and send him e-mails that said ''I love you,'' ''I miss you,'' and ''My heart belongs to you,'' the detective wrote.

The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed new national air quality standards that would significantly reduce levels of fine-particle soot. The rule, to be announced on Friday, would reduce the range of fine particulates allowed in the atmosphere by roughly 17 percent, according to an agency official who spoke on condition of anonymity, and Paul G. Billings, a vice president of the American Lung Association, who said he had been briefed on the standard by Obama administration officials.
Young immigrants who came to the United States illegally will be immune to deportation under a policy announced by the Obama administration.

9 P.M. (ABC) MEGASTUNTS: HIGHWIRE OVER NIAGARA FALLS -- LIVE! For the first time since stunts at Niagara Falls were banned a century ago, the high-wire artist Nik Wallenda, above, will attempt to walk roughly 1,550 feet on a two-inch-diameter steel cable suspended 173 feet above Horseshoe Falls, the largest of the area's three waterfalls. Mr. Wallenda is a seventh-generation member of the Flying Wallendas, a family circus troupe that dates itself to Austria-Hungary in 1780. Although he will wear a harness during his undertaking on Friday, he trained off site while being sprayed with heavy mist from a fire hose and jostled by a wind machine generating gusts up to 60 miles per hour. He is walking in honor of his great-grandfather Karl Wallenda, who fell to his death at the age of 73 in 1978 from a tightrope in San Juan, P.R. ''Countdown to Niagara: The Greatest Megastunts of All Time'' leads in at 8. 11:15 A.M. (TMC) LAST NIGHT (2011) Keira Knightley and Sam Worthington, below, portray Joanna and Michael, a married couple with a photogenic New York life undercut by a current of restlessness in this drama written and directed by Massy Tadjedin. Eva Mendes and Guillaume Canet are the outsiders -- Laura, a colleague, and Alex, a former lover -- who fuel distrust. Building on simple geometric coordinates, Ms. Tadjedin ''continues to draw lines and connect dots with near-Euclidean precision,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''As she increasingly switches between Joanna and Alex circling each other in one city, and Michael and Laura doing the same in another -- thereby leaching their individuality and emphasizing a parallelism already evident without the Ping-Pong edits -- you may wonder if Ms. Tadjedin wrote 'Last Night' with a ruler, compass and protractor.''

5:21 p.m. | Updated The New York City police are investigating a brawl that took place early Thursday morning at a SoHo nightclub where the rapper Drake and the R&B singer Chris Brown were socializing separately with friends. Bottles were thrown and at least eight people, including Mr. Brown, suffered cuts and minor injuries when the fight broke out at the W.i.P. club on Vandam Street shortly before 4 a.m., the authorities said. No arrests were made, nor complaints filed.

Thematic tightness is the name of the game in classical music these days. The onus is on artists to organize events that are as satisfying for the mind as for the ear. This has generally been a good thing, prompting audiences to think about the works they are hearing and make connections among them. But the premium placed on the concert-as-seminar can make less rigorously plotted shows seem somehow random, even dumb.

THE PRESENTING PROBLEM The 55-year-old woman barely recognized the face that stared back at her in the bathroom mirror of the emergency room. Her eyes were so swollen that she looked at her distorted reflection through tiny slits. Her skin was puffy and red. And her chest was dotted with several scarlet-colored blotches.

What is happening in New York City's job market is still a conundrum: The city gained more than 25,000 jobs in May but its unemployment rate rose to 9.7 percent, according to the State Labor Department. The latest numbers continued a pattern that has left economists scratching around for explanations. Once again, employers reported that they had increased their payrolls at a healthy clip but residents of the city said that they were struggling to find work.

When Leopold Stokowski formed the American Symphony Orchestra 50 years ago, he wanted to create, in part, a training ground for young musicians. Its ambition was to be second only to the New York Philharmonic in New York. Fifty years later, its ranks are dominated by veteran New York freelancers, and a claim on that No. 2 spot is unlikely. (The Met Orchestra? Orpheus? Orchestra of St. Luke's?) But the American Symphony is still around, again playing at Carnegie Hall, with a focus on less frequently performed works and a didactic mission. It has announced an ambitious season in the fall and spring to celebrate its 50th anniversary. Led by Leon Botstein, the music director for the last 20 years, the American Symphony will start its Carnegie season with a concert on Oct. 26. The program will open with Stokowski's arrangement of ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' which was played at the first concert, on Oct. 15, 1962. Mr. Botstein will also conduct Mahler's gigantic Symphony No. 8 and Ives's Symphony No. 4, which received its debut performance by the American Symphony, in 1965. Tickets will cost $1.50 to $7, a reflection of the era.
