-Several Broadway producers are in talks about a Broadway transfer this fall for the Nathan Lane-Brian Dennehy revival of Eugene O'Neill's ''Iceman Cometh,'' a nearly five-hour show now running the Goodman Theater in Chicago, according to theater executives with knowledge of the discussions. One of them, Roche Schulfer, the Goodman's executive director, said that producers interested in the transfer to New York were seeking the rights to ''Iceman'' from another producer, Scott Rudin, who now has the option to stage the play on Broadway. Mr. Schulfer declined to name those producers, noting the talks were confidential, but added, ''There's a lot of interest and a lot of conversation and we're hopeful - based on the level of interest - that this 'Iceman' will come to Broadway in the fall.''

The About New York column on Wednesday, about a silent protest planned against the New York Police Department's stop, question and frisk practices misidentified the location of a church where Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg addressed the issue on Sunday. He spoke in Brooklyn, not Queens.

There's a scene late in ''Murder in the First'' in which Willie, a prisoner at Alcatraz, recalls his grim and troubled life. Why have people been so cruel to me, he wonders aloud to his lawyer. It's a sad and tender moment, superbly played by Chad Kimball. Yet as the scene draws to a close the lighting shifts and cinematic music wells up, signaling the audience as to how they should feel. Those effects are superfluous, as are many others in a show that succeeds in spite of its slick production.

Confirming a Times report on Tuesday, Al Pacino will star as Shelly Levene, known as ''the Machine,'' in a Broadway revival of David Mamet's ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' the producers of the show announced on Thursday. Mr. Mamet's Pulitzer Prize-winning dark comedy about salesmen in a Chicago real estate office, is to begin previews on Oct. 16 at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on West 45th Street, with opening night scheduled for Nov. 11. Daniel Sullivan will direct the new production of Mr. Mamet's play, which had its premiere on Broadway in 1984; it will be produced by Jeffrey Richards, Jerry Frankel and Jam Theatricals, the same team behind its last Broadway run, in 2005, when it won a Tony Award for best play revival.

FRANKEL--Edith. The Art & Antique Dealers League of America sadly announces that Edith Frankel (73) died Tuesday, June 5, after battling pancreatic cancer. Edith was co-founder of E & J Frankel, Ltd., the renowned Asian art gallery in New York City. She was a lecturer and author on Asian art, and founder of the Far Eastern Art department at the New School. She served as a member of the League's Board of Directors since the mid-1980s. She is survived by her husband and business partner, Joel Frankel, her son James Frankel, her daughter Risa Swersey, and grandson Brandon Swersey. A memorial gathering will be held on Sunday, June 24, at 11a.m. at China Institute (125 E. 66 St., NYC, 10065). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation.

At a time when federal and state public works programs are stalled, the nation's biggest airports are in the midst of major renovations or expansions that, taken together, amount to some of the largest infrastructure projects in the country. New York's three major airports, as well as the airports in Los Angeles, Dallas, Atlanta and Chicago, are spending billions of dollars. Many of the airports have aging terminals, some built in the 1960s and 1970s, that are ill suited to the bigger planes, bigger security lanes and bigger crowds of modern-day air travel. They are replacing or improving existing terminals, updating food concessions and parking garages, or adding runways to keep up with growing demand.

Because of an editing error, the Saturday Profile article, about Geoffrey D. Langlands, a former British colonial officer and an educator who has lived in Pakistan since the country's birth 65 years ago and, at 94, is contemplating retirement, misstated Mr. Langlands's relationship to the Langlands School and College, an institution in Chital, Pakistan, that has become synonymous with excellence. He ran the school and was a major force in its development; he was not its founder. A picture caption with the continuation of the article repeated the error. The article also misstated the given name of a local development worker who called Mr. Langlands ''invaluable'' and someone who could not be replaced. He is Sultan Mehmood, not Multan.

The Weekend Miser column on Friday, about dance parties on the Hudson River and in Prospect Park, misstated the date for a performance by the Balkan Beat Box at Celebrate Brooklyn. The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption. The performance is tonight at 6:30, not Sunday. Because of an editing error, the article also misidentified the location of the GlobeSonic Sound System party on Saturday. It is at Pier i at 70th Street in Riverside Park South, not at Pier 1.

Any sentence that begins, ''Even for a small dinner for 100 guests -'' is bound to claim attention. That is how Feliberto Estévez, the chef at Gracie Mansion, describes his work day. And that helps explain why a kitchen that hasn't been renovated in 27 years no longer serves its purpose very well, especially since many more events are being held at the mansion now than when mayors and their families lived there.

Students, college graduates and their families have shared their personal struggles with education debt with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The bureau solicited the comments because it is studying whether there should be more regulation of so-called ''private'' student loans, those made by lenders outside the federal student loan programs. Private student loans are often more expensive than federal loans, and lack some of the borrower protections that federal loans carry.

The Tony Award-winning director and choreographer Susan Stroman (''The Producers'') will perform both duties for the Woody Allen musical ''Bullets Over Broadway,'' an adaptation of his 1994 film that is aiming to open on Broadway during the 2013-14 theater season, the show's producers said on Thursday. Ms. Stroman, who has also won Tonys for choreographing ''Contact,'' ''Show Boat,'' and ''Crazy for You,'' said in a telephone interview that Mr. Allen recently called her to talk about collaborating, and that they have had a couple of meetings so far as Mr. Allen boils down the film's Oscar-nominated screenplay (which he wrote with Douglas McGrath) into a libretto.

REICH--Joseph. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Lisa Messinger, President Jonathan Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor Dan Sklar, Rabbi/Cantor

6:34 p.m. | Updated The Tony-winning revival of ''Anything Goes'' will close on August 5, five weeks earlier than planned but after a twice-extended, 565-performance run. And ''The Lyons,'' Nicky Silver's caustic comedy of family dysfunction, will close at the Cort Theater on July 1. The Roundabout Theater Company production of ''Anything Goes'' earned Tonys last year for best musical revival, lead actress Sutton Foster, and choreographer Kathleen Marshall. Stephanie J. Block now plays the lead role of Reno Sweeney; she and Joel Grey, who has played the gangster Moonface Martin since the start, will finish out the run.

Senator John McCain of Arizona suggested in an interview posted online on Friday that a ''super PAC'' backing Mitt Romney, the Republican nominee, may have provided a conduit for foreign money to enter the presidential race. Mr. McCain, his party's 2008 presidential nominee and one of Mr. Romney's most prominent surrogates, was asked in the interview about recent contributions of $10 million to the super PAC, called Restore our Future, from Sheldon Adelson, a billionaire casino owner, and his wife, Miriam. Mr. McCain noted that Mr. Adelson's casino empire draws much of its revenue from overseas casinos, including major properties in Macau.

A lot is changing in daytime television, but this is not: teenage mothers, cheating spouses and sex addicts still have a forum on ''The Jerry Springer Show,'' and will for years to come. NBCUniversal said on Friday that it had reached new deals to sell ''Jerry'' and two similar shows, ''Maury'' and ''The Steve Wilkos Show,'' to local television stations through September 2016, a two-year extension to their current deals.

Even as we all pay greater attention to bank overdraft policies, some types of overdraft fees actually have increased, according to a new analysis from an arm of the Pew Charitable Trusts. Pew's Safe Checking in the Electronic Age project recently updated a study it published last year, in which it analyzed disclosures and fees for checking accounts at the nation's largest banks. The new report added two new banks and added an analysis of 12 big credit unions (we'll look at how credit unions fared in a separate post).

Nearly one month after its bungled initial public offering, Facebook is breaking its silence. The social network and its lead underwriters -- Morgan Stanley, J.P. Morgan and Goldman Sachs -- filed a motion on Friday in the Federal District Court in the Southern District of New York, requesting that all shareholder lawsuits be consolidated. The motion, an effort to streamline the legal process as Facebook sifts through dozens of shareholders lawsuits, also provides the first glimpse of Facebook's defense -- a defense built, in part, on Nasdaq's missteps.

They marched down Fifth Avenue on that summer Saturday without saying a word. They chanted no chants, sang no protest songs. The only sounds were the disconcertingly mournful thuds of muffled drums - and, of course, the marchers' footsteps on the hot pavement. It was a ''parade of silent protest,'' the organizers said, and that march in July 1917 is the inspiration for a silent protest planned for Sunday to protest the New York Police Department's stop, question and frisk policy, according to the main organizers of the new demonstration.

BERLIN -- America Movil, the Latin American phone carrier owned by billionaire Carlos Slim Helu, said on Friday that it had reached an agreement to increase its stake in Telekom Austria, the country's leading operator, to 23 percent, advancing the Mexican investor's push into the European telecommunications market. America Movil has agreed to acquire a 21 percent stake in the operator, based in Vienna, that is held by Ronny Pecik, an Austrian investor, for an undisclosed sum. The sale is expected to conclude by the end of this year, the company said.

Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky on Friday accused President Obama, his campaign and his administration of engaging in Nixonian dirty tricks, including keeping an enemies list, inciting ''mob'' attacks on its critics and leaking confidential tax information, in a concerted effort to curtail the free speech of his opponents. The same week that the casino magnate Sheldon Adelson contributed $10 million to an anti-Obama ''super PAC,'' Mr. McConnell went to the conservative American Enterprise Institute to defend what he called the right of free speech. He also delivered a broadside against a president he said is ''attempting to change the First Amendment.''

Having fallen from respected insider to convicted inside trader, Mr. Gupta has now exchanged the lofty board room for the prospect of a lowly jail cell. PREET BHARARA,the United States attorney in Manhattan, after Rajat K. Gupta, former head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company, was convicted of conspiracy and securities fraud. [A3]

Rajat K. Gupta, the retired head of the consulting firm McKinsey & Company and a former Goldman Sachs board member, was found guilty on Friday of conspiracy and securities fraud for leaking boardroom secrets to a billionaire hedge fund manager. He is the most prominent corporate executive convicted in the government's sweeping investigation into insider trading.

The Postcards column on Thursday, about Caravaggio's ''Madonna di Loreto'' in the Basilica di Sant'Agostino in Rome, misstated the name of a nearby church where there are other Caravaggios. It is the Church of San Luigi dei Francesi, not the Church of San Francese.

An article on Friday about renovations and expansions at many American airports misstated the role of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey at five airports in the region. It is the operator, not the owner. The article also misstated the timing of United Airlines' decision to cut 1,300 jobs at George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Texas. The layoffs followed the Houston city council's approval of an expansion for Southwest Airlines at nearby William P. Hobby Airport; they were not planned ''long before the city vote.''

Judi Dench, Jude Law and Daniel Radcliffe will play major characters in the inaugural season of London theater from a new producing company formed by the Tony Award-wining director Michael Grandage (''Red'') and his business partner, James Bierman, who together ran the Donmar Warehouse from 2006 to 2011, according to an announcement from the two men on Thursday night. The season will include a new play, ''Peter and Alice'' by John Logan, the Tony-winning author of ''Red,'' with Ms. Dench and the actor Ben Whishaw playing the two real-life figures who inspired ''Alice in Wonderland'' and ''Peter Pan.'' The new venture, the Michael Grandage Company, is notable for not only the talent and ambitions -- the Donmar exported five shows to Broadway under the two men -- but also its plan to keep ticket prices low. The company's announcement said more than 200 tickets for each performance would be sold for £10 (about $16) during the first season, which will include five plays between December 2012 and February 2014.

LANE--Frederick, M.D. The Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research and the Asso-ciation for Psychoanalytic Medicine mourn the loss of our distinguished colleague. He was a valued supervisor and teacher who delivered his expertise with gentleness and wisdom. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children and grandchildren. Eric R. Marcus, M.D. Director CU Psychoanalytic Center Henry P. Schwartz, M.D. President, APM

An article on Wednesday about laser technology used to engrave a microscopic numeric code on the firing pin and breech face of a firearm that is then transferred to ammunition described incorrectly the way in which a stamped code appears after the gun is fired. It is imprinted on the shell casing and on the primer, not just on the casing. A picture caption also described incorrectly the transfer of the numeric code from the firing pin. It is transferred to the primer, not to the casing.

It has not been a particularly warm spring so far, but there have been some days when the students and teachers at a Brooklyn middle school might have better enjoyed their studies in an air-conditioned climate. After all, the elementary school that the school shares its building with is air-conditioned. But while the classrooms at New Horizons Middle School do not have air-conditioners, the school's storage room does.

8 P.M. (HBO) CRAZY, STUPID, LOVE (2011) Steve Carell portrays Cal Weaver, an everyman with a family, a nice suburban house and an office job, whose wife of two decades (Julianne Moore) has just revealed that she cheated on him with a co-worker (Kevin Bacon) and wants a divorce. Ryan Gosling (above, with Emma Stone) is Jacob, the pickup artist who helps Cal overcome his bad haircut and terrible fashion sense and tutors him in the art of seduction so he can even the score with his spouse. And Ms. Stone is the recent law school graduate (with a useless boyfriend played by Josh Groban) who catches -- and holds -- Jacob's wandering eye. ''It is possible to wish that 'Crazy, Stupid, Love' were sharper and also to admire its decency and its unshowy skill,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Instead, he added, this romantic comedy, directed by Glenn Ficarra and John Requa, ''opts for mildness, modesty and chastened optimism. At the same time, though, it seems to know that a crueler, more cynical rendering of its story -- a 'Bitter, Hopeless, Love' -- lurks between the lines. What makes it worth watching, and worth liking, is the sense that it arrives at its warm and comforting view of things not by default but by choice.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Judy Valente reports on Healthy Visions, a program in Ohio and Kentucky public schools that helps teenagers with low self-esteem. Kim Lawton interviews Nicholas Vreeland, the American Buddhist monk recently appointed by the Dalai Lama to be the abbot of the Rato monastery in India.

The banks are on high alert. Hundreds of employees at big firms, some part of special teams, will be on standby this Sunday, awaiting the results of Greece's pivotal election. They are preparing for the worst case. The fear is that the vote will heighten the chances of Greece exiting the euro and the global financial system will be shaken when the markets open on Monday.
MORELAND--Larry D.,age 57. Memorial Service Saturday, June 23rd at 10:30am, Crestwood Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleecker St., New York.

Phil Jackson, an 11-time N.B.A. champion as a coach, views the Knicks as a flawed team and says he would have turned down the franchise had it offered him the head coaching job, according to a transcript of a coming segment on the HBO program ''Real Sports.'' ''There's just too much work that has to be done with that team,'' Jackson said in the interview with Andrea Kremer, which is to be broadcast on Tuesday. He added, ''It's a little bit of a clumsy team.'' But there was never a decision to make because the Knicks ''never called,'' he said.

A music review on Friday about ''Philip Glass: Music With Friends,'' at the Issue Project Room in Brooklyn, misspelled the given name of a singer-songwriter who performed with Mr. Glass. He is Stephin Merritt, not Stephen.

Weeks before the Summer Olympics in London and the start of the National Football League's training camps, Sports Illustrated is cutting editorial staff through buyouts and possible layoffs. Terry McDonell, editor of the Time Inc. Sports Group, has asked reporters and editors to volunteer for buyout packages by June 21. Depending on the number of people who volunteer, he will decide whether he has to lay off any of the magazine's 210 editorial employees.
SEVIN--Malvin Peace. Our anniversary - miss you; your love, extraordinary support and guidance. Love always, Audrey

ROSENTHAL--William S. The Alumni Association-College of Medicine, SUNY Downstate Medical Center, mourns the passing of our colleague and benefactor, William S. Rosenthal, MD (Class of 1950). He was a distinguished physician, professor, scientist and researcher and in 2010 received our Special Recognition Award in Gastroenterology. He endowed "The Barbara and William S. Rosenthal, MD 50 Fund" to support student research in gastroenterology. We remember Dr Rosenthal with great respect and affection and extend heartfelt condolences to his wife and family. James W. Ferguson, MD (President) Alumni Association- College of Medicine SUNY Downstate Medical Center

1:57 p.m. | Updated Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing agreed on Friday to buy the London Metal Exchange for £1.38 billion, or $2.14 billion, in another sign of Asia's importance to the world's commodities industry. The Asian bourse, one of the world's biggest financial exchanges based on market capitalization, outbid several American rivals for control of the 135-year-old London firm.

The Bologna Journal article on June 8, about Italy's baseball league for the blind, misstated the given name of an infielder for the Seattle Mariners who, as the first Italian-born-and-bred player in Major League Baseball, is popular among Italians. He is Alex Liddi, not Alessandro. (He is not blind.)

RUDD--Ethel, 86 years old, on June 14, 2012. Special Ethel was truly special. Successful businesswoman and proud matriarch, she was the devoted wife of Malvin Schultz, loving mother of Mark and Fred, cherished grandmother of Erica, Lily, Audrey and Parker and great-granddog Zoe. Funeral service Monday, June 18th at 10:15am, Congregation Rodelph Sholom. 7 West 83 St., NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to: The American Heart Association.

The architect David Rockwell has designed a pavilion for the Southampton Center, a new cultural and artistic organization that will occupy the Parrish Art Museum's former site on Jobs Lane in Southampton Village, N.Y. (The Parrish is moving to a building designed by Herzog & de Meuron in Watermill that is due to open in November.) On Thursday, Rockwell Group is to unveil to the Southampton Village Board of Trustees the design for the pavilion, a multi-use, open-air structure that features an elevated stage and seating. In the winter it will be used as an ice rink.

Extra, extra! Hey, look at the headline! By night (and on matinee days), Jeremy Jordan is a Broadway star playing the leader of a feisty gang of turn-of-the-20th-century newspaper boys. Now, by day and in whatever free time he has left, he'll be playing one of the aspiring Broadway stars hoping to hit it big in a developing musical about the life of Marilyn Monroe on ''Smash.'' Mr. Jordan, a Tony Award nominee for his lead role in ''Newsies the Musical,'' will join the ever-evolving roster of performers on that NBC series in its second season, a person with direct knowledge of plans for ''Smash'' said on Thursday night. (The person spoke on condition of anonymity because the series has not officially announced its casting decisions.) A casting breakdown for Mr. Jordan's character on ''Smash'' describes him as: ''Straight, working class from Brooklyn. Sexy, charismatic, musically gifted, but also self-destructive and remote.'' (The breakdown adds that the performer ''Must be able to sing in a rock and/or soul voice'' and that ''Ability to play an instrument and dance a plus, but not essential,'' which we think Mr. Jordan has down.)

In this weekend's Your Money column, I encourage readers to take a day to do a financial tuneup and cross off as many things as possible from their money to-do lists. This year, I rebalanced my workplace retirement account, got new keys for my unlocked filing cabinets, cashed in some credit card rewards and saved some of the money, signed up for time-saving rental car loyalty programs and tried (and failed, so far) to persuade American Express to automate the last bill in my life that I still have to remember to pay.

Gordon Lightfoot, Bob Seger and Jim Steinman - who wrote the songs on Meatloaf's ''Bat Out of Hell'' album - were among the tunesmiths inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame on Thursday at a ceremony in New York. Also given a place in the hall were the country songwriter Don Schlitz, a Nashville hit writer who came to prominence when he won a Grammy in 1978 for ''The Gambler,'' and the Broadway team of Harvey Schmidt and Tom Jones, best known for writing the 1960 hit musical ''The Fantasticks.''

The Romneys face a different sort of fierce competition this weekend: a horse co-owned by Ann Romney will compete for a berth at the London Olympic Games. In Gladstone, N.J., the United States Equestrian Federation will hold its dressage selection trials for the Summer Games. Dressage, a sort of ballet for horses, has long been a passion of Ann Romney. She took it up as therapy for multiple sclerosis and has been heavily involved in the sport for years.

4:40 p.m. | Updated The interruption stunned White House correspondents and television viewers. And it clearly surprised President Obama, too. As Mr. Obama was making a statement from the Rose Garden about a new immigration policy on Friday afternoon, a reporter from The Daily Caller, a conservative news Web site, repeatedly raised his voice and tried to interrupt. The reporter, Neil Munro, tried to ask whether the policy -- intended to help young illegal immigrants get work -- was good for legal American workers.

With the conviction of Rajat K. Gupta, the United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, has now secured the biggest scalp yet in the government's broad campaign against insider trading on Wall Street. A victory in a case that relied almost entirely on circumstantial evidence is sure to embolden prosecutors in their pursuit of hedge fund traders and their tippers.

WEINSTEIN--William A.,87, of Hartsdale, NY passed away peacefully on June 14. Loving husband of the late Harriet (Kolbert), devoted father of Robyn Cimbol (William) and Emily Davis (Elliot), adored grandfather of Andrew and Michael Davis and Michelle and Lauren Cimbol. The last surviving of the four sons of Lillian and Hyman. Proud alum of DeWitt Clinton High School and CCNY, distinguished veteran of WWII and respected proprietor of Weinstein's Shoe Shop in the Bronx. Despite health challenges, he remained a true inspiration, a caring man of deep integrity and unfailing good humor. Funeral will take place at 11:30am on Sunday, June 17 at Edwards and Dowdle in Dobbs Ferry. Donations in his memory may be made to Greenburgh Hebrew Center or to the synagogue of your choice.

Ruth L. Sims, a Democrat who in 1977 became the first woman elected to lead historically Republican Greenwich, Conn., in a race that required two recounts and a second vote, died on June 7. She was 92. Her son, Christopher, said she died at an assisted living facility in Skillman, N.J.

In all its forms, the Avanti still turns heads, but its value as a collectible has never equaled its stature as a design icon. Here are a few examples.

Studebaker hired Raymond Loewy in 1936, who then brought in other talent like Virgil Exner from Pontiac and later, Gordon Buehrig, a designer for Auburn, Cord and Duesenburg, and the promising Robert Bourke.
The Avanti began as a rakish grand touring car, the result of a whirlwind design program in 1961.
The Studebaker Avanti was a striking design introduced 50 years ago in an attempt to save the company. Studebaker was gone just a few years later, but the car lived on.

The Avanti was one of those rare cars whose design seemed to arrive fully formed — and without precedent. The legend of the car and the man credited with the design, Raymond Loewy, is both dramatic and true.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Dickey's Latest Work Is Close to Perfect,'' June 14: The Mets' R. A. Dickey is 10-1 and probably the most dominant pitcher in the major leagues right now. Consider that in his last six starts, Dickey has 58 strikeouts and only 4 bases on balls. For a knuckleball pitcher, such control is incredible, and few pitchers have ever had such a strikeout-to-walk ratio.

The South African Charl Schwartzel grimaced after almost every swing on the practice range on Saturday at the United States Open. A few times, he clutched his stomach. Somehow, he kept going. Schwartzel, the 2011 Masters champion, was three over par in the first 36 holes of the United State Open despite playing with an abdominal tear. At one point on Thursday, he said before his third round, he was not sure he'd be able to compete. He had the same thought after Friday's round. ''I figured I'm still in a good position,'' Schwartzel said. ''I'm not going to pull out.''

An article in some editions on June 3 about the Prefontaine Classic, a track and field event that offers a preview of the possible competitors at the Olympics, misidentified the home country of Sally Kipyego, who finished second in the 3,000 meters. Kipyego is from Kenya, not from Ethiopia.

SCHWARTZ--Dr. Harvey N. June 14, 2012. Born August 27, 1927. Beloved husband of the late Carol Schwartz. Husband of Arlene Schwartz. Adored father of Jimmy Schwartz (Jamie), and Jane (Steve Kantor). Loving grandfather to Chloe, Caroline, Ben, Emma, Carly, Juliet and Tyler. Graduated from U-Penn. Dental School at the age of 17 and served as a captain in the Air Force. He practiced dentistry in Manhattan for over 50 years and was loved by his patients. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to The Jewish Home at Rockleigh, 10 Link Drive, Rockleigh, NJ 07647.

Cost of wigs: about $150cost of hairbands and tiaras: about $150Cost of dresses: $1,500 to $4,000cost of socks: $5 (plain) or $15 (sparkly) The all-natural look did not win any prizes this year at the nine-day World Irish Dancing Championships in Belfast. The young girls among the dancers -- who came from as far away as China, South Africa, Australia and Canada -- applied spray-tanner and wore purple eyeshadow and pink lipstick and sparkly dresses and wigs with long ringlets. As the story goes among dancers, the curly wigs derive from the tradition of Irish girls dressing up for Sunday Mass. ''When they were going to church, they would curl their hair or put a bow in it,'' says Julie Showalter, who is a co-chairwoman of the North American Nationals, another major competition, which will take place in Chicago in July. ''And afterward they would gather just to be with their friends and family, and they would get up and dance.''

A picture caption on June 10 with an article about the return of the television show ''Dallas'' misstated the given name of the actress who plays Patrick Duffy's wife on the new show. She is Brenda Strong, not Barbara.

ADLER--Edward, 91, of NYC, June 8. Beloved husband of late Elaine, Father of Tony and Joe, brother of Pearl, grandpa of Chelsea, Logan, Zoe and Sophie. Former novelist, President/Councilman of WGAE. A true New Yorker, baseball man and James Joyce expert. Mentor and inspiration to many. Memorial donations can be made to Abramson Center, Weiss Day Program, 1425 Horsham Rd., North Wales, PA. 19454.

Credits with the Ethicist columns on May 27 and June 3 misidentified the illustrators of the authors' silhouettes. They were done by the magazine's art staff, not by Matthew Woodson (a regular illustrator of the column).

COLORFUL and raucous, the annual Electronic Entertainment Expo, or E3, attracted tens of thousands of video game aficionados at the Los Angeles Convention Center this month. The big talk of the convention was the Wii U game system, which met with mixed reviews. The Wii U is expected to be introduced by Nintendo late this year, while Microsoft and Sony are holding back on new game consoles. Beyond the hardware, there was a profusion of new video games to check out, including titles like Call of Duty: Black Ops II, Halo 4 and Watch Dogs. Attendees could also burn some calories with the help of the Just Dance 4 game or channel their inner Captain Kirk with a new ''Star Trek'' game.

MARCUS--Honnie (Hannah), on June 13, at age 93. Predeceased by husband Sam; son Charles; sister Clara; and brother Hy. Loving mother of Ken (Lisa) and Steve (Karl). Proud grandmother of Sara (Emm) and Katie (Guy). Cherished aunt and great aunt. A truly remarkable woman whose legacy of love was felt by all and will live forever. Donations may be made to "Frank Spencer Philanthropy," NYU Medical Center, 550 First Avenue, MSB #

NEW YORK has had a surge in the building of new theaters, at least Off Broadway. The Pershing Square Signature Center came online this spring, with three new spaces. Now Lincoln Center Theater opens its own new space, perched atop the Vivian Beaumont. The first tenant of the 112-seat Claire Tow Theater, which becomes the permanent home to the company's LCT3 program, devoted to nurturing new theater talent, is ''SLOWGIRL,'' a play by Greg Pierce about a teenage girl who descends upon her uncle in his Costa Rican retreat after a traumatic accident. (Theater trivia note: Mr. Pierce's uncle is the actor David Hyde Pierce.) In outline Mr. Pierce's drama sounds not unlike the company's current ''4000 Miles,'' Amy Herzog's play about a grandmother coaxing her grandson back to engagement with the world. The biggest success to emerge from the LCT3 program, Ms. Herzog's play moved to the larger Mitzi Newhouse this spring. Anne Kauffman, a gifted shepherd of new writing who directed Ms. Herzog's ''Belleville,'' coming to New York Theater Workshop this fall, is staging ''Slowgirl,'' which stars Zeljko Ivanek and Sarah Steele. Opens Monday; (212) 239-6200, telecharge.com; $20.

ONLY John Jay Park can rightfully claim an address on Cherokee Place, a blocklong strip west of the F.D.R. Drive between 77th and 78th Streets. But for some residents of Cherokee Apartments, a complex with a long and moving history, the street is literally their backyard. A cluster of four tan-brick buildings marking its centennial this year, Cherokee Apartments was built to house tuberculosis patients in a setting that, it was hoped, would help them recover. Within each building is a European-style courtyard from which four open spiral stairways wind up six stories, complete with resting areas so tubercular patients could make the climb in leisurely fashion. Floor-to-ceiling windows open onto wrought-iron balconies on which patients sometimes used to sleep.

For the next installment of the Big City Book Club, we will read a classic New York City ballpark novel, Mark Harris's ''Bang the Drum Slowly.'' Written in 1956, and a sequel to his ''Southpaw,'' the book revolves around a star pitcher for the New York Mammoths (based on the Yankees) and the illness of one of his teammates, the catcher Bruce Pearson. The book was adapted for television in the 1950s and then as a film in the '70s starring Michael Moriarty and Robert De Niro. Join us for the online conversation on June 27 from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. on the City Room blog. To become a member of the Book Club and receive updates about future chats, send an e-mail with

Co-Founder/Past President, National Association for Advancement of Psychoanalysis (NAAP); Faculty, Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies, New York/ Boston; Senior Member/ Chair of Legislation, National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis; Founder/ Chair, Joint Council for Mental Health Services. Loving husband of Eleanor, father of Jennifer and Michael, grandfather of Olivia and Ginevra. Memorial contributions to Union of Concerned Scientists (ucsusa.org/memorial) and NAAP (naap.org/donate). Memorial services to be held June 24th, 2pm, at 3 Rutherford Place, New York, NY.

UNTERMAN--Semah Zinsher, 92, died June 12, 2012, wife of Milton, mother of Sandra and Ronald (Dottie), Sisters, Jean Kurnit and Rebecca Solomon.

The neighborhood is known for its Italianate brownstones with spacious front yards, a civilized buffer between home and sidewalk. These are planted in various styles -- from garden-club meticulous to near-jungle -- but there are recurring plants and flowers, creating a floral theme. The following are especially lovely on President and Carroll Streets:

ON Beekman Place, two blocks between 49th and 51st Streets east of First Avenue, residents greet one another and even strangers with a smile and a wave. You notice a profusion of greenery, from evergreen trees to ivy trailing up handsome town houses. You also see an inordinate number of dog walkers, attracted perhaps by the popular dog run nearby. This sense of small-town charm appealed to Mitchell Crawford, 26, a transplant from small-town Virginia who moved to New York to study the organ at Juilliard. After graduation, Mr. Crawford lived in various apartments in Hell's Kitchen, and in January he moved to a one-bedroom at 34 Beekman Place.

GRIMM--C. Peter. A retired business executive, a certified fundraising executive and an inventor, died peacefully at his home in Friendship, Maine on April 28, 2012. He was 82 and is survived by his brother John E. Grimm III of Southampton, NY; a sister Nan Freeman of Norwalk, CT, and his loving wife Gloria M. Grimm. He is also survived by four children from a previous marriage, Carl H. Grimm of Rehoboth Beach, DE, N. Ellen Eifert of Woodstock, GA., Dr. Laurie Steelsmith of Honolulu, HI, and Susan K. Wilmot of New South Wales, Australia; and five grandchildren. Peter graduated from Deerfield Academy in 1947 and received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Hamilton Collage in 1951 when he captained the varsity tennis team to an undefeated season. In 1952 he graduated from the Newport, RI U.S. Naval Officer Candidate School and from 1953 to 1955 served in the U.S. Navy as a gunnery officer on a destroyer escort during and following the Korean War. From 1955 to 1983, Peter pursued a packaged goods and marketing career with such firms as General Foods, Sterling Drugs, Revlon, and American Home Products. In 1965, Peter co-invented and marketed Count-Down, a dial cigarette holder that reduced the health hazard of cigarette smoking. In 1968 he designed and invented the child protection safety cap that remains in widespread use today. In 1984, Peter became a fundraising consultant to nonprofit organizations such as Citizens Committee for New York City, City Harvest, Holy Trinity Orthodox Church and Montpelier, the General Henry Knox Museum. The family asks that remembrances in Peter's name be made to The National Parkinson Foundation.

THANKS to the ever-expanding Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, -- which spread to two weekends for the first time in its 13-year history, with regular band reunions and superstar appearances (this year the late Tupac Shakur showed up as a hologram) -- nearby Palm Springs, Calif., has gotten a shot of youthful energy, with several new hotels and restaurants hoping to sustain the party all season long. South Palm Springs, a formerly dreary retail corridor, has been livened up with a crop of new hotels and other venues that fill with music lovers looking for a chic weekend retreat. CARRIE NIEMAN CULPEPPER

11 P.M. (13) FLORENT: QUEEN OF THE MEAT MARKET (2011) David Sigal traces the trajectory of Restaurant Florent, a 24-hour diner-cum-bistro on Gansevoort Street in Manhattan's meatpacking district, from 1985, when it was the lone eatery in a shadowy industrial area, to 2008 when, after a successful run, it became a relic of a bohemian utopia in a quickly changing neighborhood. The film also chronicles the life of the restaurant's owner, Florent Morellet, above, a French expatriate, artist-cartographer and political activist who, after learning in 1987 that he was H.I.V. positive, disregarded the advice of friends and revealed his status, even keeping a running tabulation of his T-cell count on the restaurant's menu board. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden called this film, which features appearances by Julianne Moore, Diane von Furstenberg, Isaac Mizrahi and Michael Musto, ''a touching, elegiac tale of the rise (and some would say fall) of a colorful New York neighborhood under the relentless march of gentrification.'' 9 A.M. (CNN) STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY Ms. Crowley interviews David Plouffe, a senior adviser to President Obama, about the administration's plan to turn around the economy. She also speaks with Rick Santorum, a former Republican presidential candidate, about the conservative agenda. Later in the morning, Mr. Plouffe appears on ''Fox News Sunday With Chris Wallace,'' at 10; on ''This Week With George Stephanopoulos,'' at 10 on ABC; and on ''Meet the Press,'' on NBC at 10:30.

Several players early in Saturday's third round remarked how much slower the greens at the Olympic Club were compared to the first two rounds. Customarily, the greens at the United States Open get quicker as they dry out. But shots to the greens that in other days were running several yards after they landed were instead stopping after only a short release. This seemed to confuse the players, not just because it was different than in other days but because it was the opposite of what was happening on the fairways where shots were bounding and running out in what seemed like dry conditions.

THE celebrated photographer Bruce Weber has always used his home bases -- in Montana, the Adirondacks, Montauk and Miami -- as settings for his distinctly American fashion shoots. On Saturday, the Bellport-Brookhaven Historical Society on Long Island unveiled ''A Bellport Tale,'' an exhibition of photos that Mr. Weber took when he lived in Bellport in the 1970s and '80s. ''Everyone knew each other,'' he said of the bay-side village. ''You could knock on any door and just invite a neighbor over to be part of a photography sitting. It was as easy as borrowing a cup of sugar.'' The images in the exhibition come from a shoot that appeared in British Vogue in 1982 called ''Under Weston Eyes.'' Starring Talisa Soto and the male model of the moment, Bruce Hulse, that story was styled by Grace Coddington and inspired by the work of another photographer, Edward Weston. ''He took things that were very personal to him and let us see into that world,'' Mr. Weber said. ''I thought it would be interesting to do a series of pictures of my own imaginary family, living together in the dysfunctional, neurotic, beautiful way that families do.'' The exhibition (on view through Sept. 3) includes many memorable images, but perhaps none is more evocative of a quiet life on the bay than that of a shirtless Mr. Hulse, sitting on the stern of a boat, cigarette in hand, wearing calf-revealing baggy trousers, rumpled socks and dress shoes. Bellport-Brookhaven Historical Society, 12 Bell Street, Bellport, N.Y. Go to bbhsmuseum.org. BRUCE PASK

SHELDON--Helen B.,93, of NYC, died on June 3, 2012. Helen was the daughter of Maximum and Gertrude Butler, sister of the late Roselyn Butler, and loving spouse of the late Lewis P. Sheldon. She is survived by cousins Sarah (Matthew) Dahl, Marc (Vickie) Rosen, Andrew (Michele) Rosen and Karen Anderson-McCarthy and their children. Helen, a 1937 graduate of Hunter College and long-time resident of Greenwich Village, was an avid supporter of education, museums and libraries in her community. She loved traveling the world with Lewis and with friends. Contributions in recognition of Helen's commitment to social justice may be made to the Brennan Ctr for Justice, 161 Ave. of the Americas, NY NY 10013, MADRE, 121 W. 27th St, NY NY 10001, or Doctors w/o Borders, 333 7th Ave. NY NY 10001.

''A numerous and enthusiastic audience assembled in Chickering Hall last evening to listen to readings from the writings of Mr. Samuel L. Clemens -- who prefers to be known as 'Mark Twain' -- and Mr. George W. Cable. . . . The management, in its newspaper advertisements, spoke of the entertainment as a 'combination of genius and versatility,' but neglected to say which of the gentlemen had the genius and which the versatility. Some of those who were present last evening may have felt justified in coming to the conclusion that Mr. Cable represented both these elements. . . . Mr. Cable was humorous, pathetic, weird, grotesque, tender and melodramatic by turns, while Mr. Clemens confined his efforts to the ridicule of such ridiculous matters as aged colored gentlemen, the German language and himself. . . . ''The first selection was from [Cable's] 'Dr. Sevier,' the interesting scene in which Narcisse thinks he can 'baw that fifty dolla' himself. Then Mr. Clemens recited a selection from 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,' which will be continued in Mr. Clemens's next book. . . . Mr. Cable's last selection from 'Dr. Sevier' was 'Mary's Night Ride,' in which weirdness, tenderness and melodramatic force were joined with a rare skill that evoked hearty and continued applause.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the elusive director and actor Vincent Gallo misidentified a movie that he starred in. It is Francis Ford Coppola's ''Tetro'' (2009) -- not Mr. Gallo's own ''Promises Written in Water'' (2010), which has not been publicly screened since being shown at the Venice and Toronto film festivals the year it was completed.

MORE than five million Jeep vehicles are under federal scrutiny after a preliminary investigation revealed an uncommonly high occurrence of fires when the vehicles were rear-ended in crashes. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration upgraded its investigation of the Jeep Grand Cherokee from the 1993 to 2004 model years. The upgrade was prompted by a preliminary investigation that found the vehicles' fuel tanks were more susceptible to rupturing in rear impacts relative to other vehicles in the S.U.V.'s peer group.

TRAPPED with a Fox News big screen in my stable of trotters at the gym a few weeks ago, I took in the worldview that may give the White House to Republicans this year. After burning 400 calories, I was ready to torch the capital. For almost half an hour I heard another rehash of how my tax dollars were spent on a clown, a comic and a mind reader at a retreat for government workers outside Las Vegas in 2010. Those tin-eared bureaucrats in the General Services Administration spent a total of $835,000. An outrage, of course, and it was typical, I was informed, of runaway government spending under Barack Obama.

The Surfacing column on June 3, about Atwater Village in Los Angeles, located the neighborhood incorrectly. It is in northeast Los Angeles -- not East Los Angeles, which is an unincorporated community east of the City of Los Angeles.

HELLER--Peter E.,age 88, loving and devoted father, passed away June 11, 2012. Born August 25, 1923 in New York City, and raised in Chicago, he is remembered for his steadfastness and love to his family. He attended the Berkshire School receiving the Headmaster's Prize and went on to the Fifth and Second Marine Division in the Pacific 1942-45. A graduate of Northwestern University's Commerce School 1948, he became Senior VP, Director, Head of New York Office at Walter E. Heller & Company and was one of the early coordinators of facsimile transmission and non-impact printing with ensuing patent, licenses, and settlements. The owner of Faxon Communications/Accuscan, Inc., he was also President of Purchase, NY, spearheading the creation of the Public Park at Pepsico, Purchase, NY by rallying community effort against corporate environmental takeover and protecting green spaces. He invented and patented Logo Brake Light, a concept of automotive logo illumination and the center high mounted stop lamp in 2002 and was continuing his work until his very last weeks. He was also a member of the Board of Overseers for the Florence Heller Graduate School of Advanced Studies in Social Welfare at Brandeis University and past trustee of the Berkshire School. He is survived by his four daughters Darcy, Lisa, Dana, and Terry and three grandchildren.

Last Sunday morning, at the Phoenix Communications office in South Hackensack, N.J., Steve Insler spotted Warner Fusselle with a stack of newspapers, pens and a pair of scissors. ''He was doing what he always did, clipping and highlighting,'' said Insler, a senior producer. ''I used to tell him, 'We can find all this in a matter of seconds now,' but he didn't want to hear it. He wanted to do it the old-fashioned way. That's the way he was.''

LIBERATORE--Marianne Westpalm van Hoorn, died peacefully in her Weston, CT home on June 1, 2012. She will be sorely missed by many and her work in the cause of humanity through the promotion of the arts and music will be long remembered. She leaves behind two sons, Joseph of Northampton, MA and Willem of Ripton, VT and their families: Joe's wife Kira, daughter Aislyn and son Rainier and Willem's wife, Jean Cherouny and their daughters Anneke and Abigail as well as cousins Nico, Magteld, Reinier and Cordula of Holland and cousin Carolyn Lester of Andover, CT and several stepchildren: George, Virginia, Nick, Elliott, and Mark. She was predeceased by her husband of thirty-eight years, Nicholas Liberatore. Marianne was born in Wilmington, DE on September 30, 1928 to Helen Renner of Sandusky OH, a teacher, and Albert Willem Westpalm van Hoorn of Java, Indonesia, a naval architect. She graduated from Wilmington High School at 16 and Oberlin College at age 20 with a double major in History and Art History and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Marianne worked in New York City as a buyer for Macy's and later as a Lecturer in Retailing at Tobe-Coburn School. She married Joseph Jewett on February 16 1957. After living briefly in Larchmont, NY they settled in Westport, CT in 1965. In Westport Marianne promoted arts and musical events in local schools as a member of the Westport PTA. She produced a show of "Westport Artists of the Past" to commemorate the American Bicentennial at the Westport Public Library. After Joe's death in 1972, Marianne worked for Famous Schools, Sandak Inc. and Garden Way Associates. She married Nicholas Liberatore in 1973 and while living with him in San Francisco, worked at Macy's as Manager of the Direct Mail Division and started her own business there, Shop Work Inc. Nicholas and Marianne lived briefly in Orr's Island, ME in a house she designed but were drawn back to the cultural activity of Westport and its proximity to New York City. Returning to Weston, she became programming director and then President of the South Shore Music Club, leading a resurgence in the popularity and quality of its concerts and making it a major stop for up-and-coming as well as established artists. In the mid-90s, moved by the plight of musicians in besieged Sarajevo, she threw her energy into rebuilding the Sarajevo Philharmonic. Charitable contributions funded the purchase of new instruments and a repair mission with violin maker Phillip Injeian to Farfa, Italy, where the orchestra had found a temporary refuge from the war. Phillip fixed all of the string instruments including one cello with a bullet hole, allowing the orchestra to resume concert activities with a refurbished string sound. After the Sarajevo project she continued creating connections with the international music community by promoting a series of summer musical Odyssey excursions, bringing local music lovers to different culturally rich locations around the world to sample recitals, concerts and operas. In 1995 Marianne founded the Free Young Persons' Concert Series at Pequot Library and in 2002 re-made these concerts under a new entity, Music for Youth (MFY). MFY's mission of musical enrichment has been both innovative and successful. In addition to the Free Young Persons concerts, MFY funds residencies by professional musicians in the Fairfield and Bridgeport schools and an annual scholarship for local graduates continuing their musical education. Her awards include the Ruth Steinkraus Cohen Memorial Outstanding Women of Connecticut Award and the Connecticut Commission on the Arts Distinguished Advocate for the Arts, both in 2003 and the Westport Arts Advisory Council Champion of the Arts Award in 2010. A service and concert of remembrance including the Enso Quartet, a regular participant in Music for Youth programming, will be held at 5pm on June 23 at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport. Charitable donations can be made in her name to Music for Youth, Inc., P.O. Box 403, Westport, CT 06881. 413-582-0346 for information.

REUTER--Madalynne, died of natural causes on May 3, 2012 in Manhattan, NY. She was 90 years old. Madalynne Mathilda was the daughter of Hazel Flower and Herman Augustus Reuter. Her brother Herman Ruggles died in 2006. She is survived by her son, John Kurtz. Her journey from the orange groves of Southern California to the concrete canyons of New York City was a rich and full one. One filled with dear friends, much art and many, many words. The printed word was one of her great loves. She was an avid reader, a published writer, a reporter and an editor. She had the style and grace that accompany dignity with a respect for others. With a keen eye for fashion, she wore pants at a time when good girls didn't. She was a feminist, humanist and a preservationist who abhorred war and greed and celebrated non-violence and community. In keeping with her belief in the importance of being an active member of an active community she has donated her remains towards the advancement of research and education. She will be sorely missed by those of us who have loved her.

Richard F. Stolz, a career intelligence officer who was called out of retirement in 1987 to run the Central Intelligence Agency's spying operations and cleanse its image after the Iran-contra scandal, died on June 9 in Williamsburg, Va. He was 86. The cause was complications from a fall at his home in Williamsburg, said his daughter, Sarah Sullivan.

An article in some copies on June 3 about the Detroit Tigers' 4-3 victory over the Yankees the previous day misidentified the Tigers reliever who gave up back-to-back singles to Andruw Jones and Russell Martin to open the seventh inning. It was Phil Coke, not Joaquin Benoit. (Benoit replaced Coke after those two hits.)
'It's something I always wanted to do since I was little, but it's kind of a blur when it actually happens.'

Johnny Bench played his way into the Hall of Fame with power hitting and defense during a 17-year-career as a catcher with the Cincinnati Reds. In addition to his 389 home runs and 1,376 runs batted in, Bench won 10 Gold Glove awards and led the National League three times in percentage of runners caught stealing. He had a .990 fielding percentage as a catcher. Bench, 64, recently recovered from basal cell carcinoma and is now committed to raising awareness about skin cancer. He is a spokesman for the Play Sun Smart program, a joint effort by Major League Baseball, the players association and the American Academy of Dermatology.
DORFMAN--Dan. We mourn the passing of a loving and generous man, whose courage and fortitude touched all who knew him. Lynne & Burt Manning

WINOKER--David, 49, of Chappaqua, NY died Friday, June 15th. Adored husband of Jillian, devoted father of Jared, Hillary, and Allyson. Beloved son of Irma and Sidney Winoker and brother of Gail, son-in-law of Gale Spitalnik, brother-in-law of Gary and Jody, uncle to Brianna and Rebecca. President of Winoker Realty, a second-generation business founded by his father. David served as Co-chairman of The State of Israel's Bond Real Estate New Leadership Division. He was honored by the MANN Foundation and the Starlight Children's Foundation. After his family, his passions were his friends and golf. He will be most remembered for his smile, his kind heart and soul. He will be terribly missed by all who knew him. Services to be held at Shaaray Tefila, Bedford Corners, NY at 11:30am, Sunday, June 17.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Rachel L. Swarns on her book, ''American Tapestry: The Story of the Black, White, and Multi/racial Ancestors of Michelle Obama''; David Maraniss on his new biography of Barack Obama; Dexter Filkins on ''The Syrian Rebellion,'' by Fouad Ajami; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. By the BookAn expanded version of our interview with Elizabeth Gilbert, the author of ''Eat, Pray, Love,'' ''Committed'' and other books.
FRUGAL TRAVELER An exploration of ''real,'' and affordable, Danish food.

ARCANA Books on the Arts, long the go-to source in Los Angeles for rare and out-of-print books on art, photography, architecture, fashion and music, has moved from its cramped space in Santa Monica to a much larger, airier home in the Helms Bakery complex, in the heart of Culver City's Arts District. Lee Kaplan, who founded Arcana in 1984, has always worked with local architects; for this incarnation of the store, he turned to Sharon Johnston and Mark Lee of Johnston Marklee, and Brock Mayeux of Landlocd, a design/build firm. The 4,500-square-foot-space is now filled with rows of black powder-coated metal shelves that create what Mr. Lee calls a ''forest of books.'' In a nod to the store's history, Johnston Marklee reused pieces by previous Arcana architects, including plywood bookshelves by Gary Paige and a table by Robert Mangurian and Mary-Ann Ray, creating what Mr. Lee called ''a palimpsest of the former store designs.'' Arcana: 8675 Washington Boulevard, Culver City, Calif. BROOKE HODGE

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports from June 8 to 14. 1. LANCE ARMSTRONG FACES NEW DOPING CHARGES He will not face criminal charges but could be stripped of his seven Tour de France titles and barred from competing in triathlon events. (Published June 13)

An article on May 20 about the musician Regina Spektor referred imprecisely to a scale she played on the piano during one of her recording sessions, and a correction in this space on June 3 gave another imprecise reference to it. The scale was E-flat major -- not D-sharp, as the article noted, or D-sharp major, as the correction said. (The latter is the enharmonic equivalent of E-flat major.)

GREENHALL--Irene L.,78, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY died on June 12, 2012. Wife of Donald A. Greenhall, mother of Diana G. Newby (David) and Audrey L. Greenhall (George Chressanthis), sister of Richard Leav (Ann), grandmother of four. A Memorial Celebration of her life will be held on a later date. Memorial contributions to honor Irene's life may be sent to: Women's Medical Fund, PO Box 40748, Philadelphia, PA 19107 or, Adelphi University, Speech-Language Pathology Scholarships, Office of University Advancement, 1 South Avenue, Garden City, NY 11530. Online condolences may be made by visiting: www.paganofuneralhome. com

WISE--Don devoted family man, artist, curator, long-distance cyclist, raconteur and farmer, died after a brief illness on May 3, in New York City. He was 87 years old. He leaves his loving wife of 45 years, Taki, daughters Alexandra and Anouche and husband, Eric Zuehlke, grandson Leo, brothers Robert Wise of London and Herbert Wise of Los Angeles. Donald was the son of the late Alexander and Dorothy Wise of Flatbush, Brooklyn, who founded the music publishing firm now called Music Sales/G.Schirmer. After graduation from The Cooper Union, he began his business career as an art director at Conde Nast Publications, Inc. He went on to establish Don Wise & Co. in 1952, specializing in fashion and home furnishings. George Jensen, Anne Klein, Charlie's Girls, Hang Ten, The Herbal Newsletter, Paul Stuart, Vanity Fair, Yves Gonnet Fabrics, Gracious Home and Ethan Allen were among his clients. Don designed and curated exhibitions of photography for 30 years for the Staley-Wise Gallery beginning with the work of Horst P. Horst. A lifelong love affair with cycling and travel took him around the world, beginning with a bicycle trip at 17 from Brooklyn to Lexington, Kentucky to see the Thoroughbred racehorse, Man of War. In 1950, he boarded a freighter and traveled on an around the world trip for a year with a three month layover in Paris to work at Publicis. His passion for biking led to his 2,000 mile journey from North to South Vietnam and rides in Bhutan, Burma, Cuba, France and Italy. His keen interest in nature began in 1938 at the family home in Red Hook, in the Hudson Valley, and continued to the present. He raised sheep and chickens and had the pleasure of turning his eye for architecture to restoring and designing a number of buildings in the city and country . Don will be remembered fondly for the whimsical illustrations he drew as notes on envelopes, diaries and wrappings. They have been collected and treasured. His humorous stories delighted his family and many friends. He always gave his time and talent to good causes. In lieu of flowers please send donations in Don's name to: The Cooper Union at www.cooper.edu/give

The Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama was a central figure in the New York avant-garde art scene of the 1960s and today is considered one of Japan's most prominent contemporary artists. A full retrospective of her career opens at the Whitney Museum of American Art on July 12. Pictured above is ''I Want to Live Honestly, Like the Eye in the Picture,'' a work of synthetic polymer on canvas from 2009 (whitney.org).

TOKYO -- In a deal that could lead to Japan's first substantial steps toward reducing its burgeoning debt burden, Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda agreed with the country's two largest opposition parties Friday on legislation to double the country's consumption tax. Mr. Noda has staked the fate of his administration on the bill, which would double Japan's five-percent sales tax by 2015, hinting that he could call a general election if the plan fails to pass parliament before the current session ends next week.

LEWIS--Edward H. Retired President/C.E.O. of E. de Grandmont, Inc, died on June 11 at age 102. Mr. Lewis was the husband of the late Frieda S. Lewis, a former National President of Hadassah. He is survived by his sons, Dr. Jeffrey Lewis (wife Judith), Dr. Michael Lewis (wife Betsy), his companion May Golden, nine Grandchildren, and four Great-grandchildren. Contributions may be made to the Frieda S. Lewis Scholarship Fund at Hadassah.

An article last Sunday about the growing violence among indigenous tribes in Brazil over the struggle for ancestral land misstated the relationship between those people now struggling to recover tribal terrain and Brazil's original inhabitants. They are the descendants, not the ancestors.
PERLSTEIN--Harvey L. You are always thought of with love. Audrey and Suzanne

In all the pitching excitement last Wednesday, when the Giants' Matt Cain fired a perfect game and the Mets' R. A. Dickey tossed a one-hitter, it was easy to miss Lance Lynn of the St. Louis Cardinals. Lynn struck out 12 White Sox while allowing three hits in seven and a third shutout innings, matching Dickey for the National League lead in victories, with 10. Lynn has capably filled the void in the Cardinals' rotation left by Chris Carpenter's shoulder injury in the spring. Had Carpenter been healthy, Lynn might not have had a spot. He came to camp behind the veterans Kyle Lohse, Jaime Garcia, Adam Wainwright and Jake Westbrook.

HARDING--Dorothy M.,88, of Airmont, NY passed away June 13, 2012. Dorothy was born March 14, 1924 in Brooklyn, NY to Patrick and Brigid (Bowen) Maloney. Dorothy grew up in the Parkchester section of the Bronx with her sister Mary and brother Philip, who died in infancy. Dorothy graduated from the Holy Family School in Parkchester and Cathedral High School in Manhattan. From 1942 to 1944, Dorothy worked for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, aiding the Bureau's wartime efforts. On August 12, 1944, Dorothy married the late Thomas J. Harding, Jr., who was deployed with the US Army in the Alaska Territory. After the war, Thomas and Dorothy raised their family, first in the Bronx and then in Manhattan, until moving in 1954 to Suffern, NY, where for many years Dorothy worked as a nurse at Good Samaritan Hospital. Dorothy is survived by her sister, Mary McGillycuddy of Airmont, NY; six children: Patricia Hallowell, of Ashton, MD; Nancy Harding- Badewitz of San Diego, CA; Thomas of Suffern, NY; Philip of Midlothian, VA; Michael of Pompano Beach, FL; and Carol Martin of Metuchen, NJ; 12 grandchildren; and 10 great grandchildren.

NUSSBAUM--Jeremy, age 70. Cherished husband and life's love of Charline Spektor, loving and beloved father and best friend of Gabriel (Elizabeth) and Lily Claire, passed away at home on June 12th, 2012. One of the country's most distinguished intellectual property attorneys, and owner of the BookHampton bookstores. Words can't describe how he fulfilled our lives with his unstoppable curiosity, appetite for adventure (both literal and cultural), endless music, incomparable wit and the wildest laugh. He is ours forever and we are his. His memory will serve as a blessing.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Steve Schmidt, the senior adviser to Senator John S. McCain's presidential campaign, misstated the year of midterm elections in which Republicans gained Congressional seats with Mr. Schmidt as a key strategist. They occurred in 2002, not 2000.

Adam Davidson's column on the record prices in the contemporary art market supplies more evidence, as if it were needed, that rarefied prices have little to do with much of anything that makes sense. The art world is just a microcosm of the way the elite economy operates. MICHAEL JOHNSTON, Hamilton, N.Y., posted on nytimes.com
The byline for the Novelties column on May 20 misspelled the writer's surname. She is Anne Eisenberg, not Eisenberrg.

BRADLEY--Robert James, born in New Britain, CT, on January 2, 1938 to Francis Patrick Bradley and Anna McCabe Bradley, died peacefully on June 12, 2012, after a brief illness. Bob spent his youth in Old Wethersfield, CT. He joined the Marines in 1956 and was stationed in Camp Lejeune, NC. After two years in the Marines, he worked for Northeast Utilities in Stamford, CT, from 1960-1971. In 1971 he joined the printing company of Kurt H. Volk, Inc. in sales and marketing. He worked on national credit marketing plans for Sears Roebuck and American Express Company as well as direct marketing plans for Conde Nast Publications, McGraw Hill, Dow Jones and General Electric Credit. He retired on September 8, 1988. He lived and raised his children in Weston, CT, later becoming a resident of Vero Beach Florida and summering in Sunapee, NH. He was a member of Hawk's Nest Golf Club and John's Island Club in Vero Beach. Kathleen Baratuck Bradley, his wife of 39 years, died in 1996. His son, Jeffrey, and daughter, Stacy, also predeceased him. He is survived by his loving wife, Jacqueline Colgan Bradley, whom he married in 1998, and granddaughters Caitlin Bradley and Kristen Bradley and great-granddaughter, Londyn Faiella. He is also survived by nephews, Robert, Jay and Joseph Bradley and niece, Marcy Bradley Light. A memorial mass will take place on July 13, 2012 at 11:00am at St. Aloysius Catholic Church, 21 Cherry Street, New Canaan, CT. Memorial donations may be made to the Marine Corps Scholarship Foundation (Please note: The Robert J. Bradley Scholarship Fund), 909 N. Washington St., Suite 400, Alexandria, VA 22314 (www.MCSF.Org) or the Indian River Medical Center Foundation, 1000 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960.

SIMON--Jacques R.,formerly of Rockville Centre, NY, died June 9 at age 92 at home in Solana Beach, Calif. He attended USC, served in the Army Air Corps in WWII and worked in sales. He is survived by his wife Claire, daughter Nancy, sons Lloyd and Richard, daughter-in-law Susan and grandchildren Andrew, Claire and Zachary.
A picture caption on June 3 with an article about the Costa Chica in Oaxaca, Mexico, misidentified a bird in the mangroves at Ventanilla. It is a snowy egret, not an ibis.

What Craig Venter is doing isn't all that radical. Humans have been meddling with plants and animals since the dawn of time. Just look at dogs, cows, pigs, wheat, corn, apples -- none of these things would exist in their current form without a domesticating human hand. QED, New York, posted on nytimes.com

A news analysis article last Sunday about the legal difficulty of prosecuting people who leak classified information misstated part of the name a statute intended to allow them to be tried without revealing secrets in court. It is the Classified Information Procedures Act, not the Classified Information Protection Act.
WEEHAWKEN, N.J. THE drive to my dentist's office will never be the same. And it's all Sebastian Vettel's fault.

Philip Levine has written the funniest Ethicist column in years. And there were no punches pulled either. Before seeing the author's name, I found myself wondering if Studs Terkel were not really dead. TOM THEL, Clearwater, Fla., posted on nytimes.com

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about state and local governments that are aiming to refinance bonds containing interest rate swaps, misidentified the recipients of fixed rates of interest in these instruments. The issuer pays a fixed rate to banks involved in the transaction, not to bond holders.

A map on June 3 with the 36 Hours column, about Oxford, England, located Wellington Square incorrectly. It is the square to the northwest of the Ashmolean, not the square south of the Bodleian Library. (That square is Radcliffe Square.) A corrected map can be found at nytimes.com/travel.

KONTES--Peter W. Principal of Greenwich Advisory Group, co-founder and former chief executive of Marakon Associates, and author of "The Value Imperative" and "The CEO, Strategy, and Shareholder Value," has died. He was sixty-five years old. He also served as an Executive in Residence and Distinguished Faculty Fellow at the Yale Graduate School of Management. He had a BA from Yale and an MBA from UC Berkeley. His family was the focal point of his life, and he enjoyed a strong bond with his Yale friends. He will be greatly missed.

POHL--Aaron J. Cherished husband, son, brother, uncle, friend and gifted educator. Aaron passed peacefully on June 15, 2012, at the age of 62. Services 12 Noon Sunday at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. www.boulevardriversidechapel.com.

IT seems that New York City abounds with free summer outdoor movie screenings nowadays, but perhaps the daddy of them all is the HBO BRYANT PARK SUMMER FILM FESTIVAL, which celebrates its 20th anniversary this year with some of its biggest hits from the past. It starts Monday with ''Psycho'' and concludes Aug. 20 with ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' and on Mondays in between are heavyweights like ''On the Waterfront'' (July 9), ''All About Eve'' (Aug. 13) and ''The Wizard of Oz'' (July 2), which, weather permitting, may well generate the season's biggest turnout. (I remember when ''Casablanca'' closed the festival a few years back. Some viewers reverently whispered famous lines a moment before they were uttered on screen.) Of course there are traditions to be observed, namely a trailer or two, the presentation of a vintage Looney Tunes short and (fanfare please) the ritual crowd dance to the quasi-disco, 1980s-era HBO theme music, a 60-second revel to shed workday stress before the feature. Shake your booty, relax and enjoy the show. Avenue of the Americas between 40th and 42nd Streets; lawn opens at 5 p.m., movie after sunset; (212) 512-5700, hbo.com/hbobryantparkfilmfestival.

See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week's image. There was no rain forecast for our last visit to Corson's Brook Woods, but the dark gray sky augured precipitation. The dim early morning light put everything in soft focus.

BRUSTEIN--Jeffrey, 60, of Ocean Township, NJ died Wednesday June 13, 2012. He was Physiatrist at Community Medical Center in Toms River and a member of Congregation Torat El. Jeffrey enjoyed bicycle riding and was an accomplished pianist. He is survived by his wife Ina and his daughter Rebecca of Neptune. Jeff also leaves behind his two brothers and sisters-in-law, Fred and Marsha of Ocean Township, Scott and Lenore of Highland Park, and his mother Lillian of Eatontown. He will be fondly remembered by all.

DISCOVERING Mimi Weddell, the gauntly stylish actress who, at 90, was the subject of a 2009 documentary, was a turning point for Ari Seth Cohen. Mr. Cohen, a 20-something photographer living in Seattle at the time, quickly decamped for Manhattan in pursuit of his new fashion idol. A doting Harold to her Maude, he tracked her down, picked up his trusty Canon and began shooting Ms. Weddell, who was the first in a stately parade of New Yorkers, ages 60 to 100, whose images he began posting on Advanced Style, his blog.

One of the prettiest sights of the spring benefit season, which just came to a close, is the New York Botanical Garden dinner dance in the Bronx. The conservatories, transformed to look like the Impressionist Claude Monet's gardens, will be open until Oct. 21, with flowers changing all summer. When guests in floral dresses paused on the Japanese bridge over the lily pond, the full force of Monet's vision was recreated in the Bronx.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the Yankees' 4-2 victory over the Mets the night before misstated the pitching count when the Yankees' Mark Teixeira hit a home run in the sixth inning. It was 2-2; he did not hit it on ''the first pitch he saw.''

The United States women's national team began a two-game trip to Sweden on Saturday with a 3-1 victory over the host country. Alex Morgan scored in the first half and Tobin Heath in the second, but the goal of the day -- and that includes the Euro 2012 action -- was the 35-yard, first-touch half-volley scored by Abby Wambach in the eighth minute. Morgan's goal, a muscular effort after a turnover, was her 15th this year and solidified her place in Coach Pia Sundhage's starting lineup and as the Americans' key player to watch heading to the London Games.

EISENSTEIN--Enid RosalindeJune 17, 1953 - May 12, 1977 Beloved Daughter Without you No rose can grow No leaf be green If never seen Your sweetest face, No bird have grace Or pow'r to sing Or anything Be kind or fair And you nowhere Rebe Eisenstein, loving family and friends

Canyon Ranch, the upscale spa that usually caters to adults, is dedicating two weeks this summer to a weight-loss program for parents and teenagers 14 to 17 years old. The seven-night program, held at the Tucson spa on July 8 and again starting Aug. 12, offers participants group and individual sessions with a nutritionist who instructs them on how to prepare healthy meals together, and with an exercise physiologist who gives guidance on incorporating fitness into their lives. The program also offers exercise classes and a meeting with a life coach. Every participant goes home with a customized plan and receives nine 50-minute follow-up sessions with his or her choice of specialist. The program was created to help counter the rise in childhood obesity and to instill healthy habits in an impressionable age group, said Sheryl Press, a spokeswoman for Canyon Ranch. Rates start at $5,500 for one parent and one child.

THE unbleached canvas beach tote with contrast trim is an icon of summer style, a simple yet effective object that designers mess with at their peril. One who's taken it on and come out ahead is Sydney Weinger of Morton & Hudson, whose linen-lined Tropez tote takes the utilitarian nature of the original and Gallicizes it (hence the reference to the French resort). Diagonal pleats in the canvas give the Tropez texture. Leather trim in blue, moss or neon yellow provides a tiny splash of color, and the attached change purse has a practical life beyond towel-and-sunscreen duty. In short, a bag for all summers. Morton & Hudson Tropez Tote, $435. Go to morton-hudson.myspotify.com. NANCY MacDONELL

For more than four decades most Americans identified the Democratic Party with a social contract and safety net, equality of justice and opportunity, and progressive -- yes, even liberal -- causes. Sometime in the last 30 years the party of progress and change -- Emerson's ''party of hope'' -- became the party of reactionary liberalism. The 1970s brought revolutions: globalization and foreign competition; the decline of the manufacturing base; petroleum-producing nations controlling the price of oil; and the unsustainable costs of cold war military deployments.

FONTANILLS--George, world leader in options trading, passed away on June 2, 2012 in Singapore. George graduated with honors from NYU with a B.A. in accounting. He received an M.B.A. from the prestigious Harvard Business School. George co-founded a company called "Optionetics." George's reputation as the "Dean of Options Trading" led to numerous television and radio shows across the country. He has written and co-written many books on trading, all of which have been translated into multiple languages and distributed across the world. George had just completed a new suite of products which is now scheduled to be released worldwide under the brand name RoboTrader, focused on what he firmly believed was the new frontier of trading using powerful algorithms. George will be missed by his beloved wife Charlene Fontanills, his parents Philip and Lugui, and his brother Luis. A memorial service will be held on June 29th, 2012 at 2:00pm at the First United Methodist Church of Boulder. Please visit: www.greenwoodmyersfuneral.com to offer condolences.

No matter how many escaped, no matter how many were caught, no matter how many committed heinous acts while they were on the run, they still kept releasing more guys into the halfway houses. THADDEUS B. CALDWELL, who spent four years tracking down fugitives in New Jersey. [16]

LENT--Norman F. Age 81, on Monday, June 11, 2012, of Arlington, VA and West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Barbara Morris-Lent; loving father of Norman F. (Susan) Lent, III, Barbara Ann (Geoff) Roberts, and the late Thomas B. (Shari) Lent; devoted grandfather of Elizabeth and Abigail Roberts, Mollye and Ryan Lent, and Andrew Lent. He is also survived by a brother, Robert (Patricia) Lent, one niece and one nephew. A retired member of the United States House of Representatives, Mr. Lent represented the South Shore of Long Island, NY for 22 years from 1971 to 1993, rising to the position of Ranking Republican of the Energy and Commerce Committee. He previously was elected to five terms in the New York State Senate from 1962 to 1970, where he was Chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Public Health and Medicare. Prior to his elective offices, Mr. Lent was appointed law clerk to New York State Supreme Court Justice Thomas P. Farley. He also served as Police Justice for the Village of East Rockaway, NY. Mr. Lent served in the U.S. Navy during and immediately after the Korean War, achieving the rank of Lieutenant. He was a graduate of Hofstra University and Cornell Law School. Visitation June 19 at Everly-Wheatley Funeral Home, Alexandria, VA, everlyfuneralhomes.com. Funeral services, 11am the next day at Fairlington United Methodist Church, Alexandria, VA. Interment at a future date at Arlington National Cemetery.

SAN FRANCISCO - The United States Open falls on Father's Day weekend, a quirk in the calendar that's seen as serendipitous since fathers and sons often treat golf as a bonding exercise. A dozen times in Phil Mickelson's playing career the tournament has fallen on his birthday, a scheduling oddity that is beginning to feel more like a barb than a bonus for Mickelson, whose struggles continued on Saturday at the event he most wants to win. On his 42nd birthday, Mickelson teed off with the stated goal of going low in his third round and putting himself back into contention. An opening six-over 76 has made the rest of the week a steep climb for Mickelson, but his swing felt good and he was confident the putts would begin to fall.
