SOPHIE ALBOU MECHALY, the designer for the French clothing label Paul & Joe, doesn't claim to be an avid chef, but delights in collecting china (including the high-end Hungarian manufacturer Herend and kitsch treasures like Ridgewood) at the Paris flea markets. ''I love to dress a dinner table in colorful prints the way I dress myself,'' said Ms. Albou Mechaly, who is expanding the brand to include home goods. ''My idea of fashion is not to be only about clothes but about living well.'' Paul & Joe La Maison is making its first foray into design with a three-print collection of kitchenware: cherry blossoms, kittens and Asian-inspired koi motifs. ''The brand's DNA is all about the happiness in colors and prints, so this feels like a natural extension,'' she said, which is another way of saying that La Maison's prints are derived from the current season and past collection hit-makers. The collection includes everything from porcelain dinner plates and linen dishcloths to butter dishes, egg cups and even charming lunchboxes. And, with everything priced between $30 and $150 (similar to their sold-out 2006 Target collaboration), customers can afford the luxury of changing their home décor as often as they change their mood and clothes. ''There's no trend to it,'' Ms. Albou Mechaly said. ''Mixing pieces and decorating your kitchen with them is fun.'' CHELSEA ZALOPANY

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Armstrong Faces New Doping Charges,'' June 14: The United States Anti-Doping Agency's threat to suspend Lance Armstrong that could lead to his being stripped of his seven Tour de France titles is ridiculous. What are they going to do? Hand the titles to the second-place finishers, most of whom were guilty of doping? And how far back will the agency go?

KIERNAN--Hayes Anthony Hayes Anthony Kiernan, 66, Vietnam Air Force Captain and successful telecommunications salesman, who above all "enjoyed life," died Saturday June 2nd with his family in Denver, Colorado, after a nine year fight against cancer. He is survived by wife Barbara, daughters Jennifer and Catherine, grandchildren Ethan, Andrew, Tyler, Kiernan and brother Howard. A private family mass was held June 5th, and a celebration of Hayes's life is planned. Donations marked 'in memory of Hayes Kiernan' may be made to University of Colorado Hospital Foundation, 12401 East 17th Avenue, Mail Stop F485, Aurora, CO 80045.
The Tonys are over, and summer in the park with Shakespeare looms, but The Times's theater critic Ben Brantley is in London. Follow his London Theater Journal online: nytimes.com/artsbeat.

The first two games of the 2012 N.B.A. finals played out like repeats of the same horse race. The Miami Heat ran to an early lead, looking nearly invincible, then the Oklahoma City Thunder stormed from behind. In Game 1, that was enough for the Thunder, and they won easily. In Game 2, the Heat's lead was too large to overcome. But in each case the Thunder seemed to control the second half.

FLENDER--Norma Fast. Dear Norma passed June 14, 2012 at the age of 81. A Memorial will be held on Friday, June 22 at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, NY at 1:00pm with a reception following.

NEPON--Claudine. Education Legacy Fund mourns the death of our long-time member, friend and colleague.

WORDS do not fail the performance artist and activist SHARON HAYES. She has stood on city sidewalks and cried out plaintive letters to an unspecified lover. Indoors she has recited transcripts of audiotapes made by Patty Hearst when she was with the Symbionese Liberation Army. For ''There's so much I want to say to you,'' a selection of her projects at the Whitney Museum of American Art, she has been commissioned to produce, in collaboration with the feminist firebrand Kate Millett, an installation featuring vintage film footage of women's liberation marches from the 1960s. Thursday to Sept. 9, (212) 570-3600, whitney.org. Traditionalists may prefer the 17th-century Dutch painter WILLEM VAN AELST, who specialized in pictures of dead birds, rabbits and other game animals and the gear hunters used to bag them along with fruit, flowers and sumptuous fabrics. He was much admired for the meticulous craft by which he rendered fur, glass, satin and other textures. ''Elegance and Refinement: The Still-Life Paintings of Willem van Aelst'' at the National Gallery of Art in Washington brings together 28 of his feats of painterly technique and his only known drawing. Next Sunday to Oct. 14, National Mall between Third and Seventh Streets, at Constitution Avenue NW, (202) 737-4215, nga.org.

April 6, 2012, Trinidad, Cuba My wife and I passed through Trinidad, a small town in Sancti Spíritus Province, while on a trip organized by People to People Cultural Exchange through National Geographic Expeditions. Trinidad is one of the best-preserved colonial cities in Cuba. It's like time travel in other ways, too. Many people still use mules and horses for transportation. The few cars they do have are American models from the 1950s like Buicks, Dodges and DeSotos. I took this photo from the bell tower of Antiguo Convento de San Francisco de Asís. It captures the beauty of the countryside, but it also serves as a reminder that we only view new places through our own experience. LOUIS RANA, Biddeford, Me.

To the Sports Editor Re ''Mayweather Seeks Jail Move,'' June 13: I used to think that nothing looked more natural than boxing gloves on Floyd Mayweather until I saw the handcuffs on his wrists. For advice on managing his discomfort in jail, he may wish to consult the victims of his domestic abuse and various battered parking attendants.

An article on June 3 about rescue funds for artists misidentified a group that provides financial aid to individuals and referred incorrectly to its aid amounts and to its president. It is the Mayer Foundation, not the Haven Foundation, that aims to disburse grants totaling $50,000 to $75,000 a year. (The Haven Foundation also provides such grants, in amounts up to $25,000 per applicant.) And Charles Mayer is president of the Mayer Foundation, not a spokesman for the Haven Foundation.

In advance of TNT's reboot of the television series ''Dallas,'' Southfork Ranch, a private home turned conference and event center used as the exterior for the Ewings' mansion, has been welcoming more visitors than ever. Since opening to the public in 1992, the 340-acre ranch in Parker, Tex., has attracted 400,000 visitors a year. Daily tours at Southfork (southfork.com; $10.75) exhibit rooms modeled after sets like Jock's living room and Lucy's ''Yellow Rose of Texas'' suite, and iconic props like the gun that shot J. R. and Lucy's frills-and-lace wedding dress are on display in the museum. Visitors can also walk the grounds, which are featured prominently in the wedding scene that opens the pilot of the new series. Sally Peavy, who has been giving tours of the ranch for 15 years, said that though there has been a recent uptick in visits, the ranch has always been popular with visitors to Dallas.

An article on June 3 about the different logos commissioned by the magazine for its cover misidentified the typeface of one. The typeface used by the design firm Helmo was AG Schoolbook, not Helvetica.

LEWIS--Barbara M.,81, died on June 13, 2012. Devoted wife of Bob Lewis, mother of Peter and Jim. Accomplished speech and language pathologist in New York City and Westchester. Memorial Service at 1:00pm on June 23 at 2801 New Mexico Ave., NW, Washington, DC.

RUDD--Ethel, 86 years old, on June 14, 2012. Special Ethel was truly special. Successful businesswoman and proud matriarch, she was the devoted wife of Malvin Schultz, loving mother of Mark and Fred, cherished grandmother of Erica, Lily, Audrey and Parker and great-granddog Zoe. Funeral service Monday, June 18th at 10:15am, Congregation Rodelph Sholom. 7 West 83 St., NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to: The American Heart Association.

How much does it cost to gather more than 25,000 artists from the around the world and to stage 12,000 cultural attractions? The equivalent of $85.6 million. That's the total figure for the London 2012 Festival, which opens in Britain on June 21 and runs for 12 weeks. But helicopters don't come cheap -- in one of the more unusual events a string quartet will play live from four flying choppers in a performance of Stockhausen's opera ''Mittwoch aus Licht.'' Expect plenty of premieres and a whole lot of Shakespeare (festival.london2012.com).

STUYVESANT STREET, a sliver of the East Village that crosses Ninth Street between Second and Third Avenues, is distinctive in several ways. Along with being only a block and a half long, it represents a powerful link to old New York. The tree-lined stretch is a truncated remnant of an artery that ran through the old Stuyvesant estate; the Astors used the street to visit St. Mark's Church, whose silvery bells still toll the half-hour. Perhaps most interesting, Stuyvesant Street runs at an angle to the grid system, thereby offering a subtle but distinct experience for Manhattanites used to conducting their lives in a checkerboard metropolis. ''There's something rakish about a diagonal,'' said Alan Good, 58, who has lived on Stuyvesant Street since 1976. ''It's like a surprise.''

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Rodriguez Ties Gehrig for No. 1 in Grand Slams,'' June 13: Alex Rodriguez used steroids for part of his career, and it took a fatal disease to stop Lou Gehrig, who was almost Rodriguez's age (36) when he retired from the game. To equate them in any way is a disservice to Gehrig.

The first time he saw Jose Altuve, in the summer of 2006, Omar Lopez liked almost everything. Altuve was 16 years old and ripped line drives from gap to gap. He showed good range and hands at second base. He always hustled. To Lopez, a scout and minor league manager for the Houston Astros, there was only one problem: Altuve was very, very small. At first, Lopez hoped he was wrong about Altuve's height, reasoning that his seat at the field in Lara, Venezuela, was too high off the ground, creating an unnatural vantage point for scouting. Lopez moved closer to the action, but, alas, Altuve was indeed tiny.

IT has been more than two decades since Natalie Weiss attended college, and more than a decade since she became a real estate broker. But on Pomander Walk, the patch of old England between West 94th and 95th Streets west of Broadway, where she was raised, residents still call her Little Natalie. The affectionate name reflects a salient quality of Pomander Walk -- the closeness its residents tend to feel toward one another. In the case of Ms. Weiss, whose mother still lives in the house to which she moved in the late 1960s, this closeness continues, so much so that when she became engaged, there was no question of where her wedding would take place. ''You're getting married here,'' announced her friend Verna Pierce, whom she had known her entire life.
Manhattan

JOHNSTON--Mary, of Gladstone, NJ, passed away peacefully surrounded by her family on June 12th at the age of 72. She grew up in Missouri, where she met and married her high school sweetheart, Mike. Mary had a lifelong love of music and earned a degree in harp and music education from the University of Kansas. After moving to New Jersey, Mary performed as a free-lance harpist and founded First Strings, a harp and string rental business. She was president of the family ranching business, MJ Ranch Corp, and oversaw the construction of three family houses. Mary was active on the boards of the Raritan Headwaters Association, LifeCamp Inc., and the Truman Library Institute at the time of her death. She loved nature and birds and was previously on the board of the Cornell Ornithology Laboratory. She was also one of the founders of the New Jersey Youth Symphony, where she also served as president. Mary is survived by her husband Michael Johnston, daughter Virginia Johnston Crisci, son Dan Johnston, brother David Bennett and five grandchildren. Donations may be made to: Raritan Headwaters Association, PO Box 273, Gladstone, NJ 07934, www.raritanheadwaters.org; BGCN LifeCamp, Inc., PO Box 1975, Morristown, NJ 07962-1975; and The Truman Library Institute, 500 U.S. West Highway 24, Independence, MO 64050-1798, www.trumanlibrary.org. For a complete obituary, visit www.baileyfuneralhomes.com

TRENT--Richard D.,died on June 9, 2012, age 86. He is survived by his wife, Cynthia, his children, Giselle, Stephen and Bradley, daughter-in-law, Kenia and grand-children. A WWII Veteran, Richard received his Doctorate from Columbia University in 1955. He was the founding President of Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn. He returned to teaching at Brooklyn College, as Professor Emeritus, retiring in 1992. He will be dearly missed.

PARADISE--Jean V.,of Manhattan, June 12, at 97. Beloved wife of the late John Paradise, mother of Emily, mother-in-law of Ben, grandmother of Jesse Achtenberg. Former Vice-President of Macmillan Publishing Company, novelist, dedicated student at the IRP/New School University, life-long learner and trailblazer.

IF you missed ALEXEI RATMANSKY'S new ''Firebird'' last week -- the subject of fervent balletomane speculation since its premiere in California in March -- you can catch his reworking of the Fokine/Stravinsky classic this week with Frederick Ashton's poetic masterpiece ''The Dream.'' If ever there was a ballerina born to dance the Firebird, it's Natalia Osipova -- she of the spectacular jump and sizzling stage presence -- who will perform on Thursday. But there are no spots on the other casts, which feature the wonderful Isabella Boylston and Misty Copeland in the title role of this American Ballet Theater production. 7:30 p.m. Thursday and Friday, 2 p.m. and 8 p.m. Saturday, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; (212) 362-6000, abt.org; $20 to $210. The Montreal choreographer SYLVAIN ÉMARD began staging his ''Grand Continental'' -- huge groups of dancers, both trained and not, doing a contemporary version of line dancing -- in his hometown. Now he brings it to the River to River festival. 7 p.m. Friday and Saturday, 2 p.m. next Sunday, Piers 16 and 17, South Street Seaport, Lower Manhattan; rivertorivernyc.com; free.

I GREW up in West Palm Beach, Fla. My dad took me hunting, trapping and fishing when I was a kid. Years later, when I was working for I.B.M. in the Midwest, a customer invited me to go pheasant hunting in South Dakota. I haven't missed a season there in 20 years. During my senior year at Florida A&M University, I worked in a stereo store. A fraternity brother who headed job-placement services on campus encouraged me to interview with I.B.M. He said I was a natural salesman. I had an 800-pound Afro, a big beard and mustache and wore bell bottoms and a flowered shirt.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Black and White Women Far From Equal Under Title IX,'' June 12: Statistics in this article demonstrate a low percentage of African-American women in lacrosse, swimming and soccer. Is it possible to describe the low participation without suspecting racism? Yes. A more plausible explanation is that African-American women choose not to participate in those sports in favor of basketball and track.

A chart last Sunday with an article about the abuse of prescription stimulants by high school students referred incorrectly to the availability of a generic equivalent of one drug, Concerta. A generic form of the drug has been available since 2011; it is not the case that it is not available and that therefore Concerta could be more expensive. The article also referred incorrectly to Nan Radulovic, a health care worker in Santa Monica, Calif., who said students had asked her for Adderall prescriptions. She is a social worker, not a Ph.D. and psychotherapist and therefore is not a ''Dr.''
SMITH--Philip. Dear Dad, always in our hearts and thoughts. We love you. Happy Father's Day. Michael and Jeffrey
MELSON--Helene, aka Helene Forbes. Arts consultant who passionately engaged artists through Chelsea Gallery walks and Le Petit Salon. We mourn your sudden passing.

A 14-ROOM duplex penthouse apartment above the Ritz-Carlton that sold for $70 million to the casino magnate Steve Wynn was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. It was also the second-highest price ever paid for an apartment in New York City. Having made his fortune in the gambling business, Mr. Wynn must see luxury real estate in Manhattan as a good bet.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Extra Bases baseball notebook last Sunday, about the San Diego Padres' distinction as the only major league franchise without a no-hitter, misstated the number of World Series appearances by the Padres. They have played in two World Series, not one.

NUSSBAUM--Jeremy. We mourn the death of our beloved friend Jeremy Nussbaum, the extraordinary, brilliant, spirited and wise husband of our cherished founding supporter Charline Spektor. Susan L. Solomon, Paul Goldberger, and the entire board and staff at The New York Stem Cell Foundation.

NUSSBAUM--Jeremy. BookHampton mourns the death and celebrates the life of our loving and brilliant owner, His knowledge of books and music was unparalleled. His memory will continue to inspire all of us.

AS the election season simmers, those waxing nostalgic for that flag-waving, gun-toting mama bear from Wasilla, Alaska, known as Sarah Palin need look no further than Lifetime. In ''BRISTOL PALIN: LIFE'S A TRIPP,'' Tuesday at 10 p.m., Sarah Palin -- cheerfully apolitical in jeans and goose-down vest, her hair loose -- sends her two eldest female cubs skedaddling off to Los Angeles with the advice that life's an adventure. Bristol, now 20, is a single mother to the toddler Tripp, the blond cherub with whom she was pregnant in September 2008 when Sarah Palin, then a vice-presidential candidate, brought Bristol and her boyfriend, Levi Johnston, onstage at the Republican National Convention. But it is Bristol's sister Willow, a sullen 17-year-old, with whom Tripp will frolic in a borrowed Beverly Hills mansion while Bristol toils for the charity Help the Children.

WHEN people step onto Rutherford Place, the first thing they notice is the blast of bird song. That is not surprising because the street fronts a square rich with trees whose leaves create a vast canopy much of the year. Rutherford Place is a two-block strip just west of Stuyvesant Square between Second and Third Avenues and 15th and 17th Streets. Though tiny, it is home to two architecturally impressive institutions that date to the mid-1800s -- the Friends Meeting House and St. George's Episcopal Church, a Romanesque Revival building of chocolaty brownstone that was J. P. Morgan's house of worship.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Growing Up Bubba,'' June 11: In a world of seemingly interchangeable golfbots on the PGA Tour, we fans are extremely fortunate to have one truly unique character in Bubba Watson.
LORCH--Ernest, passed away peacefully on May 13. A memorial service will be held on June 23, 11am at the Church of the Intercession, 550 West 155th St, New York.

An essay in some editions last Sunday about riding in a car with the Stanley Cup as it traveled from Montreal to Chicago during the 1973 Stanley Cup finals misstated part of the name of the location where the Cup was housed at the time. It was at the Canadian National Exhibition grounds in Toronto, not the Canadian National Exposition grounds. And an accompanying picture caption misidentified the Montreal Canadiens player who was shown kissing the Cup while it was being held by Henri Richard. He is Larry Robinson, not Guy Lafleur.

RUDD--Ethel. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our member, Ethel Rudd, devoted wife of Malvin Schultz, beloved mother of Mark and Frederick, Tracy and the late Jean. We will miss her indomitable spirit, passionate love of life and devotion to family, friends and community. Our deepest condolences are extended to Erica, Lily, Audrey and Parker. She will be deeply mourned, missed and forever loved. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President
Can you create the perfect day by taking advice from a perfect stranger? The author chose five virtual hosts to find out.

WEINSTEIN--William A.,87, of Hartsdale, NY passed away peacefully on June 14. Loving husband of the late Harriet (Kolbert), devoted father of Robyn Cimbol (William) and Emily Davis (Elliot), adored grandfather of Andrew and Michael Davis and Michelle and Lauren Cimbol. The last surviving of the four sons of Lillian and Hyman. Proud alum of DeWitt Clinton High School and CCNY, distinguished veteran of WWII and respected proprietor of Weinstein's Shoe Shop in the Bronx. Despite health challenges, he remained a true inspiration, a caring man of deep integrity and unfailing good humor. Funeral will take place at 11:30am on Sunday, June 17 at Edwards and Dowdle in Dobbs Ferry. Donations in his memory may be made to Greenburgh Hebrew Center or to the synagogue of your choice.

DORFMAN--Dan, 82 years old, died peacefully at New York Hospital on June 16, 2012. Beloved husband of Harriet and devoted father of the late Leah. The quintessential financial reporter whose beat was the world. Despite severe health challenges, he remained active in his career until the very end. He brought joy and humor to his family and many friends. In lieu of mourning, please enjoy a glass of Petrus and drink a toast to Dan, remembering all the good times. Services will be held on Monday, June 18th, 11:00am, at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Shiva Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, 4-7pm, at the home of Burt Manning, 655 Park Ave., NYC.

In last Sunday's Big City column, Ginia Bellafante examined the controversy over the New York Public Library's plan to add a circulating collection to its flagship Fifth Avenue branch and move two million research volumes to off-site storage. On NYTimes.com, readers criticized the plan; a selection of their comments is below. Those who enthuse over the plan -- or at least pooh-pooh its critics -- cannot be current users of the main research library. The fact is the facility is already overcrowded, notably with tourists coming into the building to photograph the ceiling murals and gawk open-mouthed at the architecture. Moreover, as I can attest, a great many books are already in storage, and after you have waited two or three days for the book to be transported from Princeton, N.J., you stand a good chance of having to request it all over again: ''The request must not have gone through,'' you are told, or perhaps ''the book must be lost.''

BANCROFT--Francis S. The Reverend Canon Francis S. Bancroft, III, 77, of Wellfleet, MA died June 3, 2012. Born in Nyack, NY, he was a son of the late Reverend Francis S. Bancroft, Jr. and the late Sylvia (Stainton) Bancroft. He was the husband of the late Janet (Currey) Bancroft. Father Bancroft leaves one son, Wayne Currey and his wife Laura Currey, along with a sister, Ann Bancroft, grandchildren Justin Notaro and Briana Notaro, nieces Diane McHale, Judith Sabati, Alice Fredericksen, nephew Victor Fredericksen, and Laura's mother Audrey Brown. Father Bancroft graduated from Wesleyan University and The General Theological Seminary and was ordained a priest in the Episcopal Church in 1959. After serving as vicar and later rector of St. James Episcopal Church, Ridgefield, NJ he retired in 2000 to his home in Wellfleet, MA. Visitation open to all will be held at St. James Episcopal Church, 514 Abbott Ave., Ridgefield, NJ on Wednesday, June 20, 2012 from 2:00-7:30PM with a Service of Remembrance with Congregational Sharing on Wednesday, June 20, 2012 from 7:30-9:00PM. A Funeral Service with Holy Eucharist in the Episcopal Tradition is to be held at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church, 555 Prospect Ave., Ridgefield, NJ on Thursday, June 21, 2012 at 9:30AM. Final prayers at the crematory will be private for family only. Blackley Funeral Home and Cremation Services, Ridgefield, NJ have been entrusted with Father Bancroft's funeral arrangements.

Beloved husband of the late Faye Steiner, father of Barbara, grandfather of Eric and Scott, grandfather-in-law of Marni and Jessica and great- grandfather of E.J. and Michael. He will be sorely missed by all. Service Monday, June 18th, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

THE musculature is thick and extravagant on ''WIXIW'' (Mute), the sixth full-length album by Liars in just over a decade. That's remarkably productive compared with other Brooklyn bands of the early 21st century, especially given this one's peripatetic nature. For much of the last decade the group -- with Angus Andrew, Aaron Hemphill and Julian Gross as its steady members -- has been changing direction so often and with such vigor that it often appeared to be working against its own best interests. The band has carved out an erratic path that's found it recording in New Jersey, Berlin and now Los Angeles, making songs that were sometimes moist and human and sometimes frigid and electronic, lately interested in traditional structure but only after ignoring it altogether. ''WIXIW'' feels like a reconciliation of many of those directions. Mr. Andrew sings with feeling and integrity, and the band returns to its earliest rhythmic impulses, making for some beautiful art-soul that sometimes recalls early Depeche Mode and other chilly romantics of the early 1980s, and sometimes the bands that dismantled their beauty but kept the pulse. This week Liars play their first New York show since the album's release. 7 p.m. Wednesday, Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 353-1600, websterhall.com; $20.
FORT GREENE TOWN HOUSE $3,050,000

BROOK--Claire, of New York City and Hillsdale, NY, former music editor at W.W. Norton Co., died on June 8, 2012 at the age of 87. She was born in New York City to immigrant parents Sonya and Frank Kessler, and distinguished herself early in the field of music as a pianist and composer. She attended the High School of Music and Art, graduated from Queens College and got a Masters degree in music from Columbia University, which she followed with a year of composition studies with the pre-eminent teacher Nadia Boulanger. She was married for 35 years to the love of her life, Barry S. Brook, head of the doctoral program in musicology at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. They traveled the world together and always considered Paris their second home. After her retirement from W.W. Norton, she was Executive Editor at Pendragon Press, a musicological publisher she and her husband founded with her brother. She was an active member of the Century Club, as well as many other organizations. Her husband, Barry Brook, and her son, Jonathan Mann, predeceased her. She is survived by her daughter Lisa Mann, her brother Robert Kessler and his wife Janet Lincoln, her niece Amanda Udis-Kessler, step-son Randy Brook and step-daughter Brook Avidon, and her devoted grandchildren Mallery Avidon, Joshua Burke, Justin Mann, Zachary Burke, Sonya Burke, and Carey Mann, as well as her grand-daughters-in-law Emily Baum and McCann Lefevre. Her thorough enjoyment of life, and especially all things musical, will be missed by her family and her friends all over the world. A memorial service will be planned. Photo taken by Christian Steiner.
OCHS--David 6.17.52 - 4.24.09 Beloved son, brother, uncle, friend, on your 60th - and the beat goes on.

JUNE is typically a slow period for classical music in New York, a timeout before the summer festivals. The exception among major institutions is the NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, which works the whole month. This week Alan Gilbert conducts the Season Finale concert at Avery Fisher Hall, a substantive Mozart program. The pianist Emanuel Ax performs the Concerto No. 22 in E flat, K. 482, Mozart's biggest piano concerto, written in 1785 while he was also immersed in work on ''Le Nozze di Figaro.'' After intermission Mr. Gilbert conducts the Mass in C minor (''Great''), with the New York Choral Artists as well as the soprano Jennifer Zetlan, the mezzo-soprano Jennifer Johnson Cano, the tenor Paul Appleby and the baritone Joshua Hopkins, who won many fans in 2010 for his touching portrayal of Junior in the New York City Opera's production of Bernstein's ''Quiet Place.'' 7:30 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday, 8 p.m. Friday and Saturday, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center; (212) 875-5656, nyphil.org; $45 to $132.(The Philharmonic appears at the Park Avenue Armory for ''Spatial Music,'' with works by Mozart, Boulez, Ives and Stockhausen on June 29 and 30.)

The innovative French pastry chef Pierre Hermé, one of the world's most famous pâtissiers, has enjoyed a long love affair with Japan. In 1998, he introduced the first outpost of his Pierre Hermé Paris pastry boutique in Tokyo, three years before opening one in Paris. Now, Mr. Hermé has created a dessert menu for the Japanese airlines All Nippon Airways. ''I now can indulge myself on an airplane,'' Mr. Hermé said.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the vanishing community of Americans on Chichi Jima, a remote Pacific island that was founded by an American sailor but turned over to the Japanese in 1968, misstated the given name of a Westerner who served in the American Navy and now runs a bar in the island. He is Rance Ohira, not Lance.

Dear Diary: Not long ago, I got off the express bus at Madison Square Park with a friend to attend a business dinner at a smart restaurant nearby. A young man holding an instrument case rushed over to my friend and asked if he would sell the black shirt that he was wearing. The young man explained that he desperately needed the shirt: he was late to play a gig and had no luck finding a black shirt at nearby stores. My friend could name his price and he would gladly pay it. After a moment's hesitation, my friend took off his sport jacket, removed his shirt and handed it over, saying, ''Fifty dollars!''

Apple announced an expansion of Siri at the opening of its developers' conference on Monday; new devices and apps will work with the voice-command service. One of the more intriguing areas of that expansion was the addition of automakers to Siri's roster of partners. Apple announced that Audi, BMW, Chrysler, General Motors, Honda, Land Rover/Jaguar, Mercedes-Benz and Toyota would all have ''Eyes Free'' buttons in their cockpits starting in the next 12 months or so. It's a fairly impressive list of automakers. Taken all together, they have sold 58.4 percent of all the cars in the United States so far this year.

If you're an experienced computer user, you probably remember explaining to newbies how a desktop computer worked: Your photos should go in this folder; your documents in that one. You will need to use this application to open that image; that application to open this document. It was all pretty confusing, to say the least. That is, until Apple's mobile interface came along.

The reRun Gastropub, a movie theater and bar in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, is to close for an unspecified period of time, the site's programmer, Aaron Hillis, announced in an email this week. With the subject line ''Farewell to reRun Gastropub Theater,'' Mr. Hillis wrote that he would be stepping down from curating films there and that the owner, Jason Stevens, would temporarily shut the space to revamp it for ''whatever its next incarnation will be.'' The theater, along with indieScreen and Nitehawk Cinema in Williamsburg, increased screening options in New York by combining the cinema and bar experience. The reRun also gave the public a way to see independent films that emerged from festivals like Sundance and South by Southwest without traditional distribution.

Dear Diary: As a very tired floor nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital in Harlem, I often took a cab home after work to my apartment in Inwood. Over the course of two years, a particular livery cab driver began to anticipate my schedule and would often wait for me outside the hospital around the end of my shift. I appreciated this, as it meant I did not have to haggle over the price of my ride with a different driver every night. One night, I walked outside and I did not see my friend the driver. Instead, another cab pulled up and we quickly agreed on a price. He drove up the Harlem River Drive chatting energetically over his headset in his native language. Suddenly, as we exited onto Dyckman Street, he looked at me in the rearview mirror and said, ''Is your name Rachel?''

The live telecast of a tightrope walk over Niagara Falls on Friday night did exactly what ABC hoped: it lifted the network to a first-place finish for the night and provided evidence that there's an audience out there hungry for big television stunts. ABC easily surpassed NBC, CBS and the other broadcasters for the night. From 10:30 to 11 p.m., when the daredevil Nik Wallenda finished his walk, ABC netted 13.1 million viewers, according to preliminary Nielsen ratings.

An article in the Square Feet pages on June 6 about riverfront development in Cincinnati described incorrectly the recent opening of a 41-story skyscraper. The article also misstated the year Mayor Mark Mallory was elected and the number of terms he has served. Mr. Mallory was elected in 2005, not 2006, and is in his second term, not his third.

Dear Diary: My meeting included a small setup of waters and soft drinks and ended at about 5:30 on a hot afternoon. I had to get across town, and walked down Fifth Avenue and then west on 42nd alongside Bryant Park. As I headed west, I saw a panhandler eyeing me up and down and assessing his chances. Typically he would have none. (My straight-ahead stare is honed from years of preventing cut-ins in Midtown traffic.) Today, however, it was hot and I felt some sympathy.

You can learn a lot about the world from Wikipedia, sometimes without reading the articles. Kalev Leetaru, a researcher at the University of Illinois, has been looking at the capacious volunteer-written encyclopedia as a Big Data resource, concentrating on the connections between cities around the globe over time. To understand these connections, he focuses on the type of language used to talk about a particular place, to see whether the writers have a generally positive or negative sentiment toward the place at that time.

Audrey Meadows worked there in ''That Touch of Mink.'' Marlo Thomas met a photographer there in an episode of ''That Girl.'' Joan Crawford longs for a fellow patron's pie in ''Sadie McKee.'' In ''Easy Living,'' Jean Arthur calmly digests her beef potpie while cafeteria chaos ensues. Neeley ate there in ''A Tree Grows in Brooklyn.'' An Irving Berlin ditty evokes the place (''let's have another cup of coffee'') as do the lyrics of ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes.'' The advertising slogan ''Less work for mother'' became a middle-class mantra. The place was the Automat, which in New York first opened July 2, 1912, in Times Square. The gleaming machines were successfully marketed as gleaming, newfangled gadgets that dispensed fresh food barely touched by human hands. Eventually, more than 40 Automats and cafeterias opened in New York.

Pity the poor flight attendant. They didn't sign up for this: millions of petulant airline passengers surreptitiously reading digital books and magazines on their iPads or Kindles during takeoff and landing. The flight attendants' job was never easy. Glamorous once, at times rewarding. But now they have to stroll the aisles of a plane while it lingers at the gate or on the runway to ensure that people turn off their smartphones, computers or tablets - yes, ''Off, not in Airplane Mode.''

Retail sales rose only 0.1 percent in May, excluding gas purchases, which fell 2.2 percent. Sales of big-ticket items, like cars, furniture and appliances, rose in May, but declined in the general merchandise category (like Target and Walmart) and at building supply stores. Teasing out the relationship between online visitors and sales is tricky, since people use the Web for window shopping and for buying, and because categories blur across retailers. Perhaps visitors to Lowes, Sears and Walmart were shopping for a refrigerator or couch, not shoes, flooring or new bicycles. SHELLY FREIERMAN

LOS ANGELES - The weekend's two new wide-release movies -- ''Rock of Ages'' and Adam Sandler's ultracrude ''That's My Boy'' -- both flopped, continuing Hollywood's boom-or-bust summer. The two movies, while dramatically different, simply appeared to underwhelm audiences, as signaled by lackluster exit poll scores. That allowed ''Madagascar 3: Escape to Europe'' (DreamWorks Animation via Paramount) to finish No. 1 for a second weekend, taking in about $35.5 million for a new domestic total of $120.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. ''Prometheus'' (20th Century Fox) repeated as the second most popular movie, selling about $20.2 million in tickets for a two-week total of $88.9 million.

(MoreMax) OUT OF AFRICA (1985) Meryl Streep (right) earned her fourth best-actress Oscar nomination as the Danish writer Karen Blixen, who later published under the name Isak Dinesen, in this sweeping drama -- and best picture winner -- about her life on a coffee plantation in British East Africa, now Kenya. Klaus Maria Brandauer was also nominated for his role as Baron Bror Blixen, her Swedish-born cousin and philandering husband. Robert Redford plays Denys Finch Hatton, the love of her life. And Sydney Pollack took home the Oscar for best director.

The issue of mammoth ''super PAC'' spending on political advertising has already dominated the election cycle. On Monday, Aristotle, a company that provides data for online political advertising, and Intermarkets, a digital advertising company that works with sites like Drudge Report and anncoulter.com, will announce an exclusive partnership.

Responding to the challenge that President Obama posed in his order last week to stop deporting some illegal immigrants, Mitt Romney declined to say on Sunday whether he would reverse the president's decision if he takes up occupancy of the White House. Although Mr. Romney said during the Republican primary debates that he would veto the Dream Act, which would provide a path to citizenship for some illegal immigrants, he was more equivocal about Mr. Obama's order last week. It allows work permits and prevents deportation for as many as 1.4 million undocumented immigrants under the age of 30 who were brought to the United States as children.

For most of its deliriously odd 75 minutes ''Space//Space,'' a mythic and slyly theatrical production by the experimental company Banana Bag & Bodice, seems like some kind of cosmic joke. It's about brothers in space, bored out of their minds. This trip has the trademarks of dark science fiction, but it's more silly than sinister. The siblings' every move is recorded, but no one is watching. They eat ''emergency sandwiches'' even though the term seems designed to make the meal seem less ordinary. If they meet aliens, what they have to offer from the human race's creations are a couple of greatest-hits albums.

Roth, chairman and chief executive of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is to deliver the commencement speech.

Out in the Mojave Desert in California, a power plant that could eventually generate enough electricity for 140,000 homes hopes to get its moment in the sun soon. When the $2.2 billion solar thermal plant known as Ivanpah is completed -- sometime next year, if all goes according to plan -- nearly 350,000 mirrors on 3,600 acres will reflect light onto boilers. Steam will power turbines, which will generate electricity that flows to California homes. It will be the largest such plant in the world. These ''solar workhorses of the desert,'' says V. John White, an analyst in Sacramento and an advocate for renewable energy, ''can produce a lot of high-quality energy in the way that other renewable energies can't do. And there are only a handful of places on the planet that have solar radiation that good.'' But some opponents have criticized the Obama administration for pushing solar projects that don't pan out. The solar-panel maker Solyndra declared bankruptcy last year despite receiving $528 million in federally guaranteed loans, while BrightSource Energy, one of Ivanpah's developers, has benefited from a similar $1.6 billion government loan. It's expensive harnessing the sun. And the costs go beyond construction. BrightSource says that it has spent more than $56 million relocating desert tortoises. Dear Diary: I am walking down Lexington Avenue on the Upper East Side. I have missed lunch and am late for a meeting when I pass a store handing out free samples. I grab three pieces, say a quick thank you, thrust the nourishment into my mouth and keeping moving. The cheese tastes awful, but maybe it is an acquired taste. The more I chew, the worse it tastes, and my mouth is now full of a horrible, dreadfully unpleasant concoction. Since I am walking on Lexington Avenue, it is not appropriate to spit up on the sidewalk or the curb, so I have to keep chewing.

GRAYSON--William. The staff of Thirteen mourns the passing of longtime Great Performances publicist Bill Grayson, who died June 14 after a brief hospitalization. A devotee of all performance, Bill brought passion, humor, vast knowledge and a gentleman's class to his work. We miss him deeply.

WINOKER--David. Your premature demise has left us stunned and saddened. You have long been a cherished friend and business partner. We will miss you so much. Our thoughts and prayers are with Jillian, the kids, your parents and sister. Steve, Elisa, Samantha & Olivia

A massive rooflike structure collapsed onto a temporary stage for a Radiohead concert in Toronto on Saturday afternoon, hours before the band was supposed to go on, killing a stagehand and injuring at least three other workers, CNN and the CBC reported. Radiohead, a British alternative rock band, canceled the concert. No band members were on stage at the time of the collapse, but members of concert crew were working in the area. A 30-year-old stagehand was found dead at the scene, while a second worker, 45, suffered a head injury and was taken to Sunnybrook Hospital, said Ian McClelland, the deputy commander of Toronto Emergency Medical Services.

A critic's notebook article on Friday about the Human Rights Watch Film Festival at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, which includes the film ''The Invisible War,'' about rape in the United States military, misstated the military's procedures for reporting rape. A victim can report a rape to a number of people including a commander; a commander is not the only person to whom it can be reported. In describing another film in the festival, ''Call Me Kuchu,'' which centers on a Ugandan gay-rights activist who was killed, the article referred incorrectly to the term ''kuchu.'' Lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender Ugandans use it to refer to themselves; it is not derogatory slang for ''homosexual.''

KALOW--Samuel Jay, 82, of Sarasota, FL, passed away on June 10. Loving husband of the late Joan (Peirce). Cherished father of David, Mark, Bruce, and Nancy, grandfather of eleven, and beloved brother of Syril Morss and Henry Kalow. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to TideWell Hospice of Sarasota.

Even as Best Buy insists it can get out of its current predicament, competitors are circling, as everyone tries to prove one point: that electronics stores can thrive. Best Buy is closing 50 of its big-box stores, and its sales at stores open at least a year are falling. Brian J. Dunn, its chief executive, recently resigned after the board found he was having an inappropriate relationship with a subordinate. Richard Schulze, who founded the company in 1966, said this month that he would leave the board immediately, a year ahead of schedule, and is trying to sell his 20.1 percent stake in the company.

On Tuesday, Mitt Romney will wrap up his ''Every Town Counts'' bus tour through small towns in six states. The thematic barnstormer-via-motorcoach might be quaint in the days of Twitter and microtargeting, but such bus tours are actually a somewhat recent phenomenon. Bill Clinton and Al Gore discovered that the news media, especially television, loved the predictable, highly visual nature of their 1,240-mile, six-day odyssey. ''Amid the networks' excitement over the Democrats' road trip,'' The Times's Richard L. Berke wrote in a 1992 report, ''President Bush has been practically ignored.''

The latest relief rally in European financial markets was over almost before it began. The market's tepid response on Monday to Greece's supposedly momentous election of a pro-bailout party points to a hard truth. Investors will not stop punishing Europe until its leaders devise a comprehensive program with a lot more money to backstop the Continent's banks and governments.

A world traveler, he was President of Universal Licensing Ltd. and retired Sr. Vice President, Kaiser Roth International.

A trove of interviews with more than 200 giants of the music industry including Ella Fitzgerald, Ray Charles, Barbra Streisand, Little Richard, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, Elton John, Paul Simon, David Bowie, Billy Joel, Tony Bennett, Joan Baez and Tina Turner has been donated to the Library of Congress by Joe Smith, the former president of Capitol Records/EMI. The recorded recollections include Les Paul's description of how he created a prototype of the electric guitar in 1929, Steven Tyler's discussion of his drug addiction, David Bowie's description of Mick Jagger as conservative, Paul McCartney's talking about his professional superiority and Herb Jeffries and Dave Brubeck's recollections of working in segregated clubs.

JENKINS--Paul. Abstract expressionist painter and most beloved husband, left this world June 9, 2012 leaving immense and inexpressible sorrow at his passing. A unique and extraordinary man, a great artist and friend whose devotion to his work transcended all boundaries, whose paintings brought joy as they explored the mysteries of color and light, who knew that beauty holds inherent danger and that life is full of wonder. A gifted writer and poet, generous and caring, a man for all seasons. His absence is profound. For contributions in his name: www.citta.org.
SEGALL--Robert L. Two Years, Gone Too Soon. Missed Always. Loved Forever. Mom, Dad, Debbie, Jesse

An article on Monday about a Pennsylvania man who says he went AWOL from the United States Air Force in 1984 and hitchhiked from his base in Germany to Sweden misstated, in some editions, the status of the extradition policies between Sweden and the United States. While Sweden has an extradition treaty with the United States, it does not cover military or political offenses. It is not the case that Sweden has no extradition treaty with the United States.

In the third inning of the New York Gothams' first game on Governors Island on Saturday, a batter hit a towering fly ball to shallow left field. The outfielder followed its arc, jogged into position - and let the ball drop in front of him, catching it on one hop.

A large trial has found that supplements of omega-3 fatty acid do nothing to prevent cardiovascular problems or death in people with Type 2 diabetes. Diabetes greatly increases the risk of heart attack, stroke and other cardiovascular ailments. Researchers randomized 12,536 people with Type 2 diabetes or pre-diabetes to receive either a placebo or a daily dose of at least 900 milligrams of omega-3 fatty acid.

A central goal of the inaugural Queer New York International Arts Festival was to posit a more expansive notion of queerness. Yet in several solo performances offered last week at Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side, one of the most striking through-lines was the way these works dealt with various ideas of confinement and were themselves confined. In ''2-Dimensional,'' the Macedonian artist Igor Josifov lay face up in a coffinlike box with a plexiglass top, placed in the entryway so that visitors had to walk over him.

An editorial on Saturday of endorsements for the June 26 primaries improperly described the new 13th Congressional district of New York. It covers northern Manhattan, Harlem, Fort George and parts of Morningside Heights and the northwest Bronx. It does not include the South Bronx or all of Morningside Heights.

(BBC America) DISCOVERING LENNON The musician and producer Mark Ronson, the artist Damien Hirst, the photographer Rankin and the actor John Simm are among the British creative types offering their perspectives on the ideas of John Lennon (above, in 1975) and his effect on society in this documentary, part of the network's Summer of London programming. ''The Brit List: 20 Coolest,'' a look at people who define the style, grace, energy and irreverence that is distinctly British, like the fashion designer Vivienne Westwood and the actor Idris Elba, follows at 10. 1:15 P.M. (MTV) CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY (2005) Tim Burton's sugar rush, based on Roald Dahl's book, stars Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka, an oddly sinister candy maker, and Freddie Highmore as Charlie, a boy who wants nothing more than to swim in chocolate. Well, who wouldn't? Despite burdening Wonka with a psychological back story and forcing a redemptive father-son reconciliation onto Dahl's tale, ''the sumptuous, eerie look and mood of the movie make it possible to ignore this dispiriting and superfluous adherence to convention,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. He added: ''There is simply too much pleasure to be found in Wonka's world to get too hung up about his relationship with his dad. The real lesson of 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' is -- or should be -- that pleasure and curiosity are their own rewards.''

Drinking, smoking and using recreational drugs probably will not reduce a man's fertility, a new study suggests - but working on a road crew might. British researchers studied 2,249 men who visited fertility clinics after a year of trying unsuccessfully to impregnate a partner. The men completed detailed health and behavioral questionnaires and each provided a semen sample for analysis. The scientists categorized 939 of the men as having abnormally low sperm count or motility. Some unalterable factors were associated with reduced fertility: nonwhite race, testicular surgery, older age, a mumps infection after age 13 and a two-week fever within the last three months.

Paul Jenkins, a colorful Abstract Expressionist who came of age during the heyday of the New York School and for several decades carried on its highly physical tradition of manipulating paint and canvas, died on June 9 in Manhattan, where he lived and had continued to paint until recently. He was 88. He died after a short illness, said his wife, Suzanne.

For Goldman Sachs, the insider trading case against a former board member, Rajat K. Gupta, which ended in a conviction on Friday, was distracting and discomforting. At least until now, it has also been very expensive.

A new musical version of Roald Dahl's beloved children's book ''Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,'' directed by Sam Mendes, will open at the London Palladium in June 2013, according to a news release. The ubiquitous Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman, who co-wrote the lyrics for the Tony-winning musical ''Hairspray'' (Mr. Shaiman wrote the music) and created the music for the NBC series about Broadway, ''Smash,'' will be writing songs for the show. Dahl's 1964 book has been made into two big-budget Hollywood films, the most recent being in 2005 and starring Johnny Depp as the eccentric candy-maker Willy Wonka, who opens his factory for a day to five contest winners.

Jamie Dimon, the outspoken chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, is returning to Washington to face another round of questions about his bank's multibillion-dollar trading loss. Less than a week after he appeared at a relatively tame hearing of the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Dimon is set to testify on Tuesday before the House Financial Services Committee. He is sticking to the same script. Once again, he will apologize for the misstep while playing down its effect on the bank and the broader financial system.

Many observational reports have suggested that statin drugs cause fatigue in some people, and now a randomized trial has found further evidence for the effect. The experiment, published online June 11 in Archives of Internal Medicine, included 1,016 healthy men and women over age 20 with levels of LDL, or ''bad'' cholesterol, ranging from 115 to 190 milligrams per deciliter of blood (around 100 milligrams per deciliter is generally considered optimal). A third of them took 20 milligrams of simvastatin, a third 40 milligrams of pravastatin, and a third took a placebo daily for six months. They rated themselves for ''energy'' and ''fatigue with exertion'' on 5-point and 10-point scales.
The Watch List column on Monday, about the Internet series ''Burning Love'' on Yahoo! Screen, misstated the number of episodes planned for the series. It is 14, not 12.

An article in some editions on Saturday about updates to the kitchen at Gracie Mansion referred incorrectly to the financing for the renovation and may have left an incorrect impression that Mayor Michael R. The money did not come ''several sources, none of them disclosed.'' (The error was repeated in a subheading.)

Robert H. Laws, a retired judge in San Francisco, and his wife, Beatrice, knew it was important to have health care directives in place to help their doctors and their two sons make wise medical decisions should they ever be unable to speak for themselves. With forms from their lawyer, they completed living wills and assigned each other as health care agents. They dutifully checked off various boxes about not wanting artificial ventilation, tube feeding and the like. But what they did not know was how limiting and confusing those directions could be.

POZNAN, Poland -- On a night of high temperatures, and even higher drama, Spain and Italy confirmed themselves as the two qualifiers from Group C Monday night in the European soccer championships. Spain's was a tough grind to break down a Croatian side in Gdansk, until Jesus Navas scored the late winner.

For hard-core Justin Bieber fans it was an opportunity not to be missed. The pop star put out the word over Twitter on Sunday that there were 500 tickets available for an unannounced show Monday night at the Apollo Theater. All one had to do to get two of them was to buy $168 (plus tax) worth of his new fragrance at Macy's in Herald Square. By the time the stores doors opened on Monday morning, there were more than 200 fans, mostly teenage girls, crowded outside, and some had been waiting overnight, clerks at the store said. They streamed into a special promotional counter surrounded by live-size cutouts of Mr. Bieber, jostling for position and laying down the money they had borrowed from relatives or somehow scraped together.

RILEY--Rev. C. Ronald, 73, of Charlotte, NC passed away Sunday, June 17th. Rev. Riley had worked as an Actuary for MetLife and Royal Insurance. At the time of his retirement, he served as CFO for Royal. He entered the ministry following his retirement and became an ordained minister in the United Methodist church. He earned his Doctorate in Ministry on May 19, 2012. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 21st at 11am at Memorial United Methodist Church, 4012 Central Ave., Charlotte, NC. Ron is survived by his wife Rosalie, son Michael and daughter Laura, as well as his sister Suzanne R. Wilson. Online condolences may be addressed to: www.carolinafuneral.com.

A conventional piston-driven internal-combustion engine functions by performing a cycle with four main steps: Air intake, air compression, combustion and exhaust. An engine is referred to as a “four-" or “two-stroke” model according to the number of movements the piston makes to perform one cycle. The Scuderi split-cycle engine and EcoMotor OPOC engine are both departures from the four-stroke engine most commonly found in automobiles. By revisiting and perfecting existing technologies, the companies say their motors provide more power, lower emissions and significantly better fuel efficiency.

KIEV, Ukraine -- Wayne Rooney had completed a two-match suspension and was scheduled to return to a thin spot atop England's attack, soccer's version of a comb-over for a guy who had hair plugs installed last summer. But Rooney had played little in the previous month. Would he be fresh or rusty Tuesday in England's final group match at the European Championships? Calm and resolute? Or ill-tempered and underachieving, as he had sometimes been at major tournaments?

LEVY--Ira M.,97, of Ardsley, NY, passed away on June 14th. He was predeceased by his beloved May, his wife of 70 years who passed away on March 26, 2012 and his son Jonathan who passed away in 1986. Ira is survived by his son Hal and his wife Barbara of Westport, CT and his grandchildren, Ginny and Jon. Ira grew up in the Bronx and later moved with his wife and children to Yonkers, NY in 1952. Ira was an Army veteran who served in Europe in World War II. He received a Bachelors degree from City College of New York and a Law degree from NYU. He was a principal and CEO of the manufacturing company G. & G. Instrument Corp. of Ardsley, NY for over 60 years. Ira was also a professional singer and musician and in the late 1930's, had his own radio shows on WNBC and WMCA in New York City, using the stage name Bert Manning. Ira was a Board member of the Greenburgh and Peoples Westchester Savings Banks and a longtime active member of Elmwood Country Club in White Plains, NY. Ira was a compassionate and generous man who was loved by the many people whose lives he touched over his long lifetime. Mr. Levy will be privately interred beside his wife and son at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY. A memorial service will be held in a celebration of his life and many accomplishments on June 28th at the G. & G. Building in Ardsley. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of May and Ira Levy to the Hospice & Palliative Care of Westchester 311 North St., Suite 204, White Plains, NY 10605.

Companies have been slowly adding workers for more than two years. But pink slips are still going out in a crucial area: government. In California, the governor is threatening to eliminate 15,000 state jobs. When school begins in Cleveland this fall, more than 500 teachers probably will be out of work. And in Trenton -- which has already cut a third of its police force, hundreds of school district employees and at least 150 other public workers -- the only way the city will forestall the loss of 60 more firefighters is if a federal grant comes through.

Tanglewood, the summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Lenox, Mass., is celebrating its 75th anniversary this summer in several big ways. The two-month Boston Symphony season doesn't begin until July 6, when Christoph von Dohnanyi conducts the orchestra in a program of Beethoven. And the anniversary concert is the centerpiece of the second weekend, on July 14, with the orchestra conducted by Andris Nelsons, John Williams and Keith Lockhart, and guests soloists including the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the pianists Emanuel Ax and Peter Serkin.

WASHINGTON - Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, tussled with lawmakers on Tuesday in his second showdown in Washington since JPMorgan, the nation's largest bank, disclosed a multibillion-dollar trading loss. At a hearing of the House Financial Services Committee, members peppered Mr. Dimon, once considered Washington's favorite banker, with pointed questions about the bank's aggressive lobbying, its failures in risk management and its focus on complex bets in the credit markets instead of lending.

6:29 p.m. | Updated The lawyer for President Obama demanded on Tuesday that Crossroads GPS disclose its donors, saying in a complaint to the Federal Election Commission that the group is plainly a ''political committee'' subject to federal reporting requirements. In the complaint, obtained by The New York Times, Robert F. Bauer, the campaign's chief counsel, writes that the group - founded by Karl Rove, among others - can no longer shield the identity of its donors by defining itself as a ''social welfare'' organization.

As the school year ends, Marin Acevedo, 14, is already looking ahead to September, but the view is hazy. In January, city officials announced that they intended to shut the charter school Marin attends, Williamsburg Charter High School in Brooklyn, because of concerns about its management. Court proceedings have stalled the city's efforts, and the freshmen, sophomores and juniors who intended to stay on at the school still have no idea whether it will be open in the fall.

IRISH SKIES Ryanair, Europe's biggest budget airline, has offered 694 million euros ($883 million) to buy the Irish airline Aer Lingus. Ryanair, which already owns a 28.9 percent stake, said its bid would help the carriers compete with larger rivals. ''This offer represents a significant opportunity to combine Aer Lingus with Ryanair to form one strong Irish airline group capable of competing with Europe's other major airline groups,'' Ryanair's chief executive, Michael O'Leary, said in a statement.

A picture caption with the On Par column in some editions on Monday, about the final round of the United States Open, misidentified the hole at which Tiger Woods was shown hitting a bunker shot. It was the second hole, not the first.

SCHULTE--Tony. The New Press Board of Directors and staff mourn the loss of founding board member and stalwart supporter Tony Schulte. Tony's dedication, expertise, and loyalty have guided us for two decades and his faith in the mission of the Press never wavered. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Liz, Peter, and Lucy as well as to his beloved grandchildren and many friends.

LEBOY-NATHANSON--Phoebe Starfield, died peacefully at her home on Saturday June 16, 2012 at age 75, of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Beloved wife of Neal Nathanson, loving step-mother of Kate, John, and Daniel, and adored step-grandmother to their six children, Leah Ochroch, Claire Ochroch, Alexander Nathanson, Sophia Nathanson, Olivia Nathanson, and Jack Nathanson. She was a retired Professor of Biochemistry at the School of Dental Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, where she was the first female Professor. As the President of the Association for Women in Science (AWIS), she devoted her last years to her passion, equal opportunities for women in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. The family requests that donations be made in her memory to either the Starfield fund at Swarthmore College or AWlS.

The Phys Ed column on June 12, about the effects of moderate exercise on health and longevity, misstated a measure of time in a study that found a plateau effect associated with prolonged exercise. In the study, involving 416,175 Taiwanese adults, 92 minutes a week of moderate exercise was seen as a ''sweet spot,'' decreasing the risk of mortality by 14 percent. For each additional 15 minutes of exercise per day -- not per week -- mortality risk fell further, but by only about 4 percent.
LEVIN--Vivian. You were our sunshine. We miss you and honor your memory every day. Jan & David

The man accused of killing a Chinese student in Montreal, dismembering his body and mailing parts of it to Canadian political parties and two schools pleaded not guilty to murder on Tuesday. The suspect, Luka Rocco Magnotta, was returned to Montreal on Monday from Berlin, where he was captured two weeks ago. He appeared in court by way of a video link from an undisclosed police detention center. His lawyer said he would ask the court on Thursday to order a psychiatric evaluation to determine if his client could be held criminally responsible.

The grief of our dear friends is unimaginable, and we are mourning with his parents, his wife and children. Our hearts go out to you at this time of deep sorrow, and we send you our love and our most compassionate condolences. The Weiler Arnow Families

Survived by husband Massimo Teresi, children Jamie and Jessica Wax; sisters Peri Wolfman, Bonnie Golden, Cathy Levine. Memorial Sunday, June 24, 11am, Portland, OR. For full obituary, go to: holmansfuneralhome.com

When Seth MacFarlane calls to talk about his directorial debut, ''Ted,'' he's multitasking, of course. He's just finished another day of work overseeing the three Fox animated comedies he produces - ''Family Guy,'' ''The Cleveland Show'' and ''American Dad'' - and is preparing to attend a benefit that night. ''It's a little crazy,'' Mr. MacFarlane said. ''But I can shower and get dressed while we're on the phone.'' ''Ted,'' due June 29 from Universal, stars Mark Wahlberg as a man still living with the toy bear he wished to life when he was a boy. Mr. MacFarlane, 38, not only directed the movie (on a reported budget of $65 million) and wrote the screenplay (with ''Family Guy'' collaborators Alec Sulkin and Wellesley Wild), he plays the title character: a living, talking, cursing, pot-smoking teddy bear that he portrayed using motion-capture technology.

10 P.M. (TV Land) THE SOUL MAN In this spinoff of ''Hot in Cleveland,'' Cedric the Entertainer, above with Jazz Raycole, stars as the Rev. Boyce Ballentine, otherwise known as the Voice, who was living the high life as an R&B superstar in Las Vegas -- his big '80s hit: ''Sex Wichoo'' -- when he got the calling to save souls. But his wife, Lolli (Niecy Nash), and his daughter, Lyric (Ms. Raycole), aren't exactly thrilled about moving to St. Louis so that he can take over the preaching duties in his father's church. In this series premiere the Ballentines discover that not all of their belongings have arrived at their new home. A second season of ''The Exes'' begins at 10:30, as Holly (Kristen Johnston) persuades the guys (David Alan Basche, Donald Faison and Wayne Knight) to go to therapy to settle their differences. Then they realize that she is the cause of their problems. 9 A.M. (CUNY) ELDRIDGE & CO. Joel Berg, the executive director of the New York City Coalition Against Hunger, discusses the benefits of food stamps and the 1.5 million residents of the city who do not always have enough to eat. On ''BrianLehrer.tv,'' at 7:30 p.m., Donna Lieberman, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, talks about the ''Stop and Frisk Watch'' app for Android phones designed by Jason Van Anden, also a guest, that allows people to record and report actions by the New York Police Department.

Times Square dazzles, but it is short on pure delight. That is why the entrances of the Hilton Times Square on West 42nd Street and West 41st Street were such a treat: a small army of imaginative bronze figures by the sculptor Tom Otterness clambered over the canopies, under the columns and around the facade.

On the southern shore of Queens, away from scolding lifeguards and crowded boardwalks, a former military base has become one of New York's great hidden beaches. There at Fort Tilden, some beachgoers go topless and some forage the dunes for driftwood with which to build makeshift shelters with sheets and blankets. Mariana Garay, her husband and their two sons (one of whom is in the center picture on the next page) have driven down to Fort Tilden from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on summer weekends for the past three years. ''You're not surrounded by people selling things and eating hot dogs or lifeguards who are always blowing their whistles,'' Garay says. ''It's a different vibe, more lonely and quiet.'' But it isn't flawless. ''It's not the cleanest ocean,'' she adds. ''It's still New York, you know.'' Beach at Coney Island: 107 acres

The London auction season kicked off on Tuesday night at Sotheby's, where a 1927 painting by Joan Miró, ''Blue Star,'' brought nearly $37 million, more than twice what it had sold for at a Paris auction in 2007 and a record price for the artist at auction. It was one of the few high points in an otherwise bumpy sale where Impressionist and modern paintings by Léger, Delvaux, Pissarro and Kandinsky often failed to elicit as much as a bid.

Because of an editing error, a music review on Saturday about the New York Philharmonic, at Avery Fisher Hall, referred incorrectly to the concert. It opened the penultimate subscription series program of the season, not the last one.

WINOKER--David. ABS Partners Real Estate mourns the untimely passing of David Winoker a true gentleman, consummate professional, highly regarded and ethical businessman and our long time friend. Our sincere condolences to the family at this most difficult time.

The next major theater project by Diane Paulus, the director of the Tony Award-winning musical ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess,'' is already attracting Broadway attention. Barry and Fran Weissler, veteran Broadway producers, are considering signing on as backers of Ms. Paulus's revival of the 1972 musical ''Pippin'' that is scheduled to run this winter at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., a spokesman for Mr. Weissler confirmed on Tuesday. While the spokesman, Clint Bond Jr., said any talk of a Broadway move for ''Pippin'' was premature, such a transfer would become a possibility if the Weisslers, who have produced musical revivals like the long-running ''Chicago,'' come on board and the show draws strong reviews in Cambridge, where it is scheduled to run Dec. 5-Jan. 20, 2013. Referring to Ms. Paulus's ''Pippin,'' Mr. Bond said, ''It's a project that Barry and Fran are very interested in. They're huge fans of Diane. Right now they're just supporting the project.'' Asked if supporting the project meant providing money to enhance the production beyond the budget of the non-profit A.R.T., Mr. Bond said Mr. Weissler was ''still working out details of the support,'' and declined further comment about any financial dimensions of the producers' involvement.

Eugene Selznick, a celebrated volleyball innovator who helped raise American players' game to international caliber in the 1960s, and whose shrewdness in drafting Wilt Chamberlain for a 1970s exhibition of beach volleyball helped make Californians' beach-party game an Olympic sport, died on June 11 in Los Angeles. He was 82. The cause was pneumonia after a series of illnesses, according to USA Volleyball, the sport's governing body.

Barnes & Noble reported a fourth-quarter loss of $57.7 million on Tuesday, falling short of market expectations, even though sales of the popular ''The Hunger Games'' and ''Fifty Shades of Grey'' and the liquidation of Borders lifted same-store sales by 4.5 percent in the period. The company reported sales of $1.38 billion for the three months that ended April 28, which was lower than expected and flat compared with the same quarter last year.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption on Tuesday with an article about the difficulties facing brick-and-mortar electronics stores misstated the name of the town in Illinois where the Abt Electronics store was shown. It is in Glenview, not Glenville.

DOESCHER--Gregory. Died June 15 of cancer. He was a raised in Rochester, NY, received a BA from Bucknell University, where he served as a trustee, and an MBA from NYU. He spent his career at the First Boston Corporation, eventually becoming Chairman of the Management Committee. He retired in Gig Harbor, WA. He was preceded in death by his daughter Anne Doescher and is survived by a son, Eric Doescher, of Providence RI, and his former wife, Patricia McElroy, of NYC.

An article on June 5 about a promise by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to increase efforts to deter, detain and deport illegal migrants misstated the status of Israel's mechanism for registering legitimate refugees. Such a system was set up in 2009, under the country's interior ministry; it is not the case that Israel has no such refugee approval program. (Since the system began, 16 of 7,000 applications have been approved, officials said.)

An article on June 6 about the recent deterioration in the tense relationship between Iran and Azerbaijan because of the expanding military cooperation between Azerbaijan and Israel misidentified the area controlled by Armenia that causes the Azerbaijan exclave of Nakhichevan to be cut off from the rest of that country and accessible only through Iran. It is the province of Zangezur, not Nagorno-Karabakh.

BRONSTEIN--Edythe (Katler), age 88, on Saturday, June 16 of Laguna Woods, CA formerly of New York City, NY and Boston. Devoted daughter of the late Benjamin and Betty (Eiseman) Katler. Loving mother of Dr. Mark Alan Bronstein and his wife Christine (Schafer) of Irvine, CA and Dr. Scott W. Bronstein of Long Beach, CA. Cherished grandmother of Benjamin, Arden, Michael and Rebecca. She taught elementary school in Huntington, NY for 38 years. A member of SAG and AFTRA, she was an actress with many leading roles in community theatre, soap operas, commercials and movies, Services at Schlossberg Solomon Memorial Chapel, Canton, MA on Friday, June 22 at 11:00am.
Jacobs--Julia. September 5, 1923--June 17, 2012. Wife of Nathan, sister of Ruthie Schockett, friend, and grandmother to all. We will miss her fiesty personality.

The weather report on Monday misidentified, in some editions, the moment that marks the beginning of summer in the Northern Hemisphere. It begins when the sun is directly over the Tropic of Cancer, not the Tropic of Capricorn.

3:42 p.m. | Updated The author Alice Walker has told an Israeli publisher that she will not permit it to release a Hebrew-language translation of her Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, ''The Color Purple,'' as a protest of Israel's treatment of Palestinians.

In 1972, I was in Eugene, Ore., photographing my first United States Olympic track and field trials. I was 23. The events at Eugene, the site of this year's trials, were timed with handheld stop watches, giving times in tenths of a second, rather than the thousandths of a second achieved by today's automatic electronic digital timers. The finish line was a thin piece of string; anything thicker interfered with the photo-finish picture and the revolutionary automatic timing being tested.

An article on Tuesday about the response of global stock markets to the results of the Greek election misstated the surname of the chief executive of Macro Risk Advisors, who commented on efforts to resolve Europe's financial crisis. He is Dean Curnutt, not Churnutt.

It knows who you are. It knows what you like. Now it wants to make it easier for you to buy things, in your own currency. Facebook on Tuesday signaled its ambitions to grow as a payment platform, with changes to how its users can buy goods and services without leaving its site. It is also a clear indication to Wall Street that the company is pushing to make more money. Concerns about the company's revenue prospects have held back its shares since its public offering last month.

Ryan Lochte, who is expected to challenge Michael Phelps for swimming supremacy in London, is entered in eight events at the United States Olympic trials, which begin Monday in Omaha. Phelps, an eight-time gold medalist in Beijing, has signed up to swim seven events. There are six events in which they are both entered: the 200- and 400-meter individual medleys; 100 and 200 freestyle; 200 backstroke and 100 butterfly.

SCHULTE--Anthony M. The Keewaydin Foundation mourns the passing of former camper, parent and board member, Tony Schulte '40. Tony was one of Keewaydin's greatest promoters: his leadership and generosity helped make a summer at Keewaydin possible for dozens of children. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Liz, son Peter, daughter Lucy, and the entire Schulte family. Stuart Fraser, Board President Peter Hare, Executive Director

A campaign notebook article on Tuesday about a bus tour by Mitt Romney and his efforts to brush up on his sometimes awkward banter with voters referred incorrectly to the role of Naomi Wolf in the 2000 presidential campaign of Al Gore, who was also criticized for his stilted campaign style. Ms. Wolf advised Mr. Gore on women's issues and on outreach to young voters; she was not paid to be Mr. Gore's image consultant and offer sartorial advice, such as wearing earth tones.

When a man has lost the woman he loved, seen the near-annihilation of the human race, been stabbed to death, resurrected as a lumbering corpse and shot and killed again, where does he go next? To the stage, of course. With his ''Walking Dead'' character returned to the soil (presumably), Jon Bernthal, who in March concluded his two-season run on that hit AMC horror series in spectacularly grisly fashion, will return to his roots as a classically trained stage actor: he will star in MCC Theater's production of ''Small Engine Repair,'' alongside its author, John Pollono, that theater company said on Tuesday.

Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana is a candidate again. Not for president of the United States - he declined to run for that post last year. And not for governor - term limits prevent him from seeking re-election. Instead, Mr. Daniels is likely to be named the next president of Purdue University when trustees gather to choose a new leader on Thursday, according to a Republican close to Mr. Daniels.
GROGAN--Aloysius Anthony. Beloved husband, father, and Poppy. Our gentleman, inspiration, and hero. Happy Birthday in heaven. Love you always!

After an absence longer than many careers in show business, Arsenio Hall will be attempting a comeback in late-night television when a new syndicated show begins in over a year. Mr. Hall and partners that include CBS Television Distribution and stations owned by the Tribune Company announced on Monday that they had agreed to introduce a late-night show starring Mr. Hall in the fall of 2013.

SCHULTE--Anthony. The Board and staff of the Scherman Foundation mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague. For the past 36 years, Tony brought warmth, intelligence and good humor to our shared work. His commitment to social justice, particularly for incarcerated individuals and their families, was profound, as was his passion for the arts. Our former chair, Axel Rosin, introduced Tony to our Board in 1976 as "one of the most capable and attractive men in publishing today." And so he remained in so many ways. Our condolences go out to his wife Liz and their family.
