7:20 p.m. | Updated Two big retail chains on opposite sides of the Atlantic are betting that prescriptions, paper towels and nail polish are global goods.

Language does not come naturally to machines. Unlike humans, computers cannot easily distinguish between, say, a river bank and a savings bank. Satire and jokes? Algorithms have great trouble with that. Irony? Wordplay? Cultural context? Forget it. That human edge in decoding what things mean is what a computer scientist turned entrepreneur, Luis von Ahn, is betting on. His start-up, Duolingo, which opened to the public on Tuesday, proposes to put armies of language learners to work translating text on the Web.

The ''Conversation With'' article on Tuesday, about Dr. Avram Hershko, a biochemist whose focus is protein degradation, quoted incorrectly from his comment that his grandchildren are the most important fact of his life. Dr. Hershko cited his close relationship with his six grandchildren, not ''my three grandchildren.''

The fallout from this month's Tony Awards at the Broadway box office - good and bad - came into sharper relief last week, with the musicals ''Once,'' ''Newsies,'' and ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'' and the plays ''One Man, Two Guvnors'' and ''Gore Vidal's The Best Man'' in the strongest shape among new productions as the summer tourist season begins, according to the weekly ticket sales data compiled by the Broadway League. Moving swiftly after winning the best musical Tony and seven others on June 10, ''Once'' raised ticket prices for swaths of seats last week and also increased its top price for so-called premium tickets to $275 (from $225 a week earlier). The show grossed $955,362 last week, an increase of 13 percent and its largest haul since performances began in February.

After the financial crisis and the recent insider trading convictions of Raj Rajaratnam and Rajat Gupta, perhaps it is time to reconsider the plight of Jeffrey K. Skilling. The former chief executive is serving a 24-year sentence arising from his conviction in a Houston trial of 19 counts after the stunning 2001 collapse of Enron. Until the financial crisis, Enron's bankruptcy was viewed as Exhibit A of corporate crime and executives run amok. After trial that lasted months, Mr. Skilling was convicted of securities fraud, among other crimes. Judge Sim Lake sentenced him to the low end of the recommended sentencing range after Mr. Skilling expressed remorse, asserting that he was ''innocent of these charges.''

At Harvard Law School in 1990, President Obama found himself lovingly mocked by his peers for relentlessly promoting the exotic story of a search for racial identity that later became the theme of his best-selling book, ''Dreams From My Father.'' ''My mother was a backup singer for Abba. They were good folks,'' a student parody of Mr. Obama joked. In Chicago, ''I discovered I was black, and I have remained so ever since.''

That human edge in decoding what things mean is what a computer scientist turned entrepreneur, Luis von Ahn, is betting on. His start-up, Duolingo, which opened to the public on Tuesday, proposes to put armies of language learners to work translating text on the Web.

CAIRO -- Former President Hosni Mubarak's health deteriorated rapidly and he was rushed to a military hospital on Tuesday, adding to the uncertainty gripping the nation as the ousted strongman's longtime opponents, the Muslim Brotherhood, battled his onetime allies in the military for political power. There were conflicting reports about Mr. Mubarak's condition. Government officials and the state news agency initially said that Mr. Mubarak, 84, had suffered cardiac arrest and a stroke in prison and had been declared ''clinically dead'' after being taken to a military hospital overlooking the Nile. Other reports said he had been placed on life support. But by early Wednesday, an Interior Ministry spokesman said he was in critical condition but alive.

GEORGIS--Mitzie, of La Jolla, CA, 80, died on June 19, 2012. Mitzie was born on July 8, 1931 in Chicago, IL to Peter and Chrisoula (Ganas) Chronos. She was the beloved wife of the late Ted W. Georgis, mother of Demi Bowles Lathrop (Thomas N. Lathrop), Ted Georgis, Jr. and William T. Georgis (Richard D. Marshall) and grandmother to Henry M. Bowles, III, Nellie C. Bowles, Matthew T. Georgis, Kelly E. Georgis and Jessica K. Georgis. She is also survived by brothers; George P. Chronos and Harry P. Chronos. Mitzie was an inspired gardener, hostess extraordinaire, bon vivant, and life force. She leaves a veritable legacy of love and laughter. Her spirit carries on in the lives of those she touched. Mitzie loved life! The following services will be held at Sts. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church, 3459 Manchester Ave., Cardiff by the Sea, CA 92007. Trisagion will be at 6:30pm., Friday, June 22, 2012. Funeral Service at 10:00am., Saturday, June 23, 2012 with burial immediately following at El Camino Memorial Park. Services under the direction of El Camino Memorial 5600 Carroll Canyon Rd., San Diego, CA 92121 www.elcaminomemorial.com.

Beloved Father of Deborah (Todd) Cortese, Sharon Catapano, Jeanette Zuaro, Patricia (Douglas) Marciel, Robert (Mary Ann), and the late Steven. Devoted Brother of the late Mildred Clark and Lloyd. Reposing Moloney's Lake Funeral Home and Cremation Center, 132 Ronkonkoma Ave., Lake Ronkonkoma Thursday from 6-9pm. Funeral Friday at 10am. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. www.moloneyfh.com.

This month, as Bernard L. Madoff completes the third year of a 150-year sentence for masterminding his global Ponzi scheme, the top courts in the United States and Britain are tackling issues that could have a multibillion-dollar impact on thousands of his victims. On Thursday, the United States Supreme Court justices will confer on whether to take up the fiercely disputed issue of how victim losses in the Madoff scheme should be calculated.

I went in wanting to be an I-beam. I settled for being a brick in the foundation, way down at the base: solid, sturdy, dependable. And oblivious to what was going on above me, which was a ''human tower'' seven levels high, being assembled on a rooftop near Madison Square Park, with two people on each level, standing on the shoulders of the people below. I fretted: Would it lean like the famous one in Pisa? Would it fall to the ground like the 13th-century tower clock in Finale Emilia, Italy, that was done in a few weeks ago by earthquakes and aftershocks? (No, and no.)

The four remaining members of the Jackson Five are starting a tour on Wednesday, just days before the third anniversary of their brother Michael's death, The Associated Press reported. The ''Unity'' tour will begin at Casino Rama in Ontario and will finish up on July 29 at a casino in Snoqualmie, Wash., hitting 14 other cities along the way. They will play the Apollo Theater in Harlem on June 28. Various combinations of the brothers - Marlon, Jermaine, Tito and Jackie - have performed over the years, including an appearance at last year's ''Michael Forever'' concert in Wales, but this tour will be the first time all four have toured together since 1985. After Michael Jackson's death the four did a reality show on A&E called ''The Jacksons: A Family Dynasty,'' which explored their attempts to stage a comeback before their brother died.

''How is June going for you?'' a friend asked via e-mail. ''Hate the transition from the school schedule devil-we-know to camp and the devil-we-don't.'' Picking up the pieces of three workweeks shattered by midday school events, early dismissals and half-days, I could send only a quick, impassioned agreement. June, as no general ever said but every mother knows, is hell. It's hard not to love summer, what with fresh tomatoes, sunny days and the aura of freedom. But that freedom for children comes at a high price for working parents: even the most free-range young children cannot be left to roam the house and the neighborhood unsupervised. Every week of camp, grandparent care or summer school presents an opportunity to sort out and bungle a new schedule of pickups, drop-offs, lunches and sunscreen. The need to manage a different structure is as oppressive as a string of 90-degree days.

PODGORSKI--Richard. The Pace Community mourns the loss of Richard Podgorski, PhD, Provost from 1993-1997, and a Professor of English at Pace University for 41 years. He received numerous awards and citations for his achievements in advancing the University and mentorship of students and faculty. Dr. Podgorski was born in New York and attended Xavier High School in Manhattan. He was a graduate of St. John's University in Queens receiving bachelors, masters, and doctoral degrees. We extend deepest condolences to the Podgorski family. Donations: International Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia Foundaton. www.iwmf.com

(FX) ADVENTURELAND (2009) It's the summer of 1987, and James Brennan (Jesse Eisenberg) is dreaming of a post-college trek across Europe, followed by graduate school. But his father has been demoted, so James will have to settle for working at a rundown amusement park. Kristen Stewart plays James's crush, a moody N.Y.U. student secretly involved with a married maintenance man (Ryan Reynolds). Writing in The New York Times about this film from Greg Mottola, A. O. Scott said, ''The smart, slightly depressive vibe feels just right-- for James's era and for our own as well.''

Ever had to ignore a call because you were in a meeting or other situation that made answering not an option? Smartphones running the Android 4.0 software (also known as the Ice Cream Sandwich update, in accordance with Google's dessert-themed nicknaming scheme) offer a convenient feature that lets you respond to the caller with a text message. When a phone rings (or vibrates) and the incoming-call screen appears, swipe your finger up to the message icon to open a menu of canned responses like ''I'll call you later.'' You can also tap out a custom message on the spot or compose your own response for the menu -- just press the Menu icon, choose Settings and, in the Call Settings area, tap Quick Responses. On the Edit Quick Responses screen, tap a response in the list to edit it.

On the first truly sunny afternoon on offer since I arrived in London, I chose to descend into a deep American fog. Oh, I knew that light-starved, water-logged people were out there romping around Piccadilly Circus like newly escaped captives of a crypt. Yet there I was, some feet below street level in the Apollo Theater, grinning away at a fine, murky spectacle of unhappiness like a member of the Addams Family in a torture chamber. What can I say? Whenever the Tyrones are willing to share their misery with me in style, I'm on board. This self-devouring clan, which Eugene O'Neill modeled closely on his own family, has been reassembled to revelatory effect in Anthony Page's excellent revival of ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' which runs through Aug. 18. The play's characters - portrayed by a cast that includes Laurie Metcalf and David Suchet - may be trying to hide from themselves in the literal and metaphoric fog that enshrouds their home. But clarity, cruel clarity, keeps piercing through to their sorrow and our edification.

Rodney Alcala, a photographer and onetime contestant on ''The Dating Game'' who is on death row in California for killing a 12-year-old girl and four women in the late 1970s, was flown to New York City on Wednesday to face charges of murdering two other women. The Manhattan district attorney's office announced in the morning that Mr. Alcala, 68, was on an airplane with federal marshals. A person briefed on the case said he arrived in Newburgh, N.Y., in the afternoon and was brought to the city for fingerprinting by the police. After processing, he is to be arraigned in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, possibly on Thursday.

The New York Times Company announced on Wednesday that two main members of its advertising department would take on expanded responsibilities as group vice presidents. Todd Haskell, who interned at The Times in 1989 and officially joined the paper in 2004, will assume a new role focused on enhancing the company's digital advertising strategy. In the past, Mr. Haskell has been responsible for advertising for luxury, fashion and retail brands. He also handled digital advertising sales for nytimes.com. Mr. Haskell said his new responsibilities would include overseeing advertising for entertainment and culture categories like movie studios, live entertainment, books and travel.

As a founding member of the British Invasion band the Hollies and then a crucial constituent in Crosby, Stills & Nash (and sometimes Young), Graham Nash would seem to have accumulated enough experiences and anecdotes for two memoirs. But he'll have to fit them all into one, for now: a book that Mr. Nash will write about his life and rock-music career has been acquired by Crown Archetype, an imprint of Random House's Crown Publishing Group, the publisher is expected to announce on Wednesday. ''I've had an incredible ringside seat to the last 50-odd years of rock 'n' roll,'' Mr. Nash said in a telephone interview. ''I think people will be very interested to know what the British Invasion was like, what Woodstock was like, what my friends are like, what trouble we got into, what heights we scaled. I think they'll be interested in all of it.''

A caption on Wednesday with a picture essay about the 1972 United States Olympic track and field trials in Eugene, Ore., misidentified the runner shown with Dave Wottle, who equaled the world record in the 800 meters at the trials. He is Lowell Paul, not Rick Wohlhuter. (Paul and Wohlhuter were teammates on the University of Chicago Track Club.)

The vessel-in-distress calls, placed to the Coast Guard three weeks and half a continent apart, were strangely similar. The boat captains reaching out for help used Coast Guard terminology - referring to passengers as ''souls'' and talking of ''taking on water.'' They both contacted the Coast Guard's Vessel Traffic Service, something else that civilian boaters do not typically do. The men's voices even sounded a bit alike.

BURGER KING FLIP Formerly privately held, Burger King returned to the public markets on Wednesday after closing a deal to merge with an investment vehicle whose backers include the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman. The fast-food chain has gone public through a combination with Justice Holdings, a so-called blank-check company run by Nicolas Berggruen and Martin Franklin. A blank-check company is essentially a shell company with a stock listing that aims to find and merge with a privately held corporation.

Janet Maslin recently reviewed two novels that each featured fictional movies. Jess Walter's ''Beautiful Ruins'' includes the idea for a movie called ''Donner!'' about the Donner party, which, Ms. Maslin writes, ''might just be the worst screenplay idea Hollywood has ever known.'' And in Alan Furst's new novel, ''Mission to Paris,'' an actor stars in a movie about World War I called ''Après la Guerre,'' or ''After the War,'' which begins filming at the dawn of World War II. This spurred thoughts about other movies invented by novelists. (Cousins to the fictional books in literature collected by a blog called The Invisible Library.)

While his animated comedy ''The Simpsons'' has been on the air a mere 22 seasons and counting, series creator Matt Groening has spent those years - and then some - drawing his syndicated comic strip ''Life in Hell.'' But soon that streak and the comic itself, which ran more than 30 years and played a crucial role in the creation of ''The Simpsons,'' will be no more: Mr. Groening has said he is ending the strip. ''I've had great fun, in a Sisyphean kind of way,'' Mr. Groening said in an e-mail to the Web site Poynter.org, ''but the time has come to let Binky and Sheba and Bongo and Akbar and Jeff take some time off.''

An article on Wednesday about increasing layoffs in local government misstated the number of government jobs lost since the postrecession peak in April 2009. It was 706,000 -- not 657,000, the number of jobs lost since May 2009.

An article on Wednesday about England's 1-0 victory over Ukraine at the European soccer championships, in which the sport's lack of goal-line technology became a factor when Ukraine seemed to tie the score, misidentified the English player who appeared to score a goal in a similar situation in a 2010 World Cup game against Germany. He is Frank Lampard, not John Terry.

DARE to bare a little extra skin this season. The hint-of-midriff crop tops we're seeing, when worn with navel-covering knee-length skirts, look altogether tasteful. At Cannes, Freida Pinto (near right) was typically effervescent in a two-piece Ferragamo look. At the CFDA awards, Karen Elson (center) was dishy in Proenza Schouler's bustier and high-waist skirt. And the model Dree Hemingway (far right) was the picture of summer fun in Dolce & Gabbana's chile-print two-piece. The look doesn't have to be matchy, though. At the recent 2013 resort shows, the photographer and fashion blogger Hanneli Mustaparta looked chic and modern in a minimalist cropped tee top and knee-length skirt. The key to pulling off the look is in the proportions. And a healthy dose of confidence.

A picture caption on May 31 with an article about TV remote controls referred imprecisely to the remote created by the Art. Lebedev Studio in Russia. It has 108 buttons and can be programmed for 399 channels; it does not have 399 separate buttons.

Fans of James Joyce who were unable to attend the annual ''Bloomsday on Broadway'' readings at Symphony Space on Saturday - along with anyone who appreciates the sound of famous literature read aloud by trained actors - will want to sample the BBC Radio 4 production ''James Joyce's Ulysses,'' currently accessible to American listeners on the BBC Web site. Broadcast on Saturday - June 16 being the day when the action of ''Ulysses'' takes place - this new radio adaptation consisted of segments scattered across the day's schedule, at times roughly corresponding to the movements of Leopold Bloom and Stephen Dedalus across Dublin in the novel. The high-profile cast includes Stephen Rea as narrator, Andrew Scott (Moriarty in the BBC ''Sherlock'') as Dedalus and Henry Goodman (''The Damned United,'' ''Notting Hill'') as Bloom. The nine segments totaling five and a half hours, available free on the BBC iPlayer site for two weeks, include the dramatization (with songs and sound effects) as well as radio chit-chat and live commentary by the journalist and writer Mark Lawson, introduced by the BBC host J.P. Devlin in Joycean terms as ''the stately, plump Mark Lawson.''

LONDON - Britain will make shareholder votes on executive pay binding next year as part of a set of measures announced by the government on Wednesday to rein in excessive remuneration. Vince Cable, the business secretary, presented the measures to Parliament on Wednesday, saying they would provide shareholders with new powers to hold companies accountable on their pay practices and increase transparency. The rules are expected to be approved by Parliament and then become law in October 2013.

As audiophiles go mobile and take their music with them on their travels, device makers are trying to keep up by offering headphones and portable speakers to enhance the sound during playback on the go. Unfortunately, the music stored on a portable device is compressed, making it sound flat and dull. Leave it to a D.J. to come up with a way to enrich that experience.

GRAIVIER--Leonard, MD. The Board of Trustees, staff, and volunteers of the March of Dimes mourn the passing of our esteemed volunteer, noted pediatric surgeon Leonard Graivier, MD. Dr. Graivier was a long-time volunteer leader of our foundation, serving since 1964 in our chapters in Oklahoma, New Mexico, Missouri, Kansas, and Texas, and chairing the Medical Advisory Board. He and his wife, Pauline Pierce Graivier worked tirelessly to recruit new volunteers for the March of Dimes, and in 1993 they received the national March of Dimes Elaine Whitelaw Award for Outstanding Volunteers. Dr. Graivier's loving care for the health of babies and his guidance to the March of Dimes will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Pauline and the entire family. Jennifer L. Howse, Ph.D., President

Two theater actors who know their way around moody, macabre musicals have been cast as the main characters in another one: the Broadway musical ''Rebecca,'' which lost its original leading lady and man this winter when producers were unable to raise the show's $12 million budget to open as initially planned in April. With producers now confident that all the money will be in place, ''Rebecca'' - an adaptation of the Daphne du Maurier mystery novel - is set to begin preview performances on Oct. 30 starring Jill Paice (''The Woman in White'') as a new wife simply known as I, and Ryan Silverman (who has played Raoul in ''The Phantom of the Opera'' on Broadway) as her husband, the wealthy Englishman Maxim de Winter.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about a significant deterioration in the health of former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and its impact on his country's uncertain political situation misidentified, in some editions, the photographer and the news organization for whom the photograph was taken. The picture of crowds of protesters in Tahrir Square was by Adam Ferguson for The New York Times, not by Amr Nabil for The Associated Press.

A wave of new releases took over the top rungs of the Billboard chart this week, with Usher reaching No. 1 for the fourth time and new albums by Rush, the country singer Josh Turner and the British singer Ed Sheeran also scoring high. Usher's latest album, ''Looking 4 Myself'' (RCA), opened at No. 1 with 128,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The venerable Canadian rock band Rush had its best sales week in 10 years, landing at No. 2 with 103,000 sales of its 20th studio album, ''Clockwork Angels'' (Roadrunner). It is Rush's second No. 2, after ''Counterparts'' in 1993; despite more than 25 million album sales, according to the Recording Industry Association of America, the band has never hit No. 1.

One of the biggest banks in the world wants the president's favorite banker muzzled. The banker, Robert Wolf, a top UBS executive in New York, is amongPresident Obama's leading fund-raisers, building more than more than $500,000 for his re-election so far this year.

SHELDON--Edward R.,77 of Westport, CT. Beloved son of Bernice and the late Max, devoted husband of 50 years of Barbara; adored father of Amy, Wendy and Spencer; proud grandfather of Maggie and Nicholas; loving brother of Robert. You were truly the kindest and most gentle man, involved with every member of your extended family. We thank you for loving each of us so completely and teaching us so well the most important lessons of life. Services will be held June 22 at 11am at Temple Israel, Westport.

June hasn't been kind to Broadway shows with religious themes. The producers of the musical ''Sister Act,'' about a singer-on-the-lam who finds happiness hiding in a convent of nuns, announced on Wednesday that it will close Aug. 26 after a 16-month run, having played 28 previews and 561 performances. The $10 million show, which has had uneven ticket sales since January, will close without recouping its full capitalization. But the producers hope to eventually turn a profit on the show from its North American tour that begins in Toronto on Oct. 2; other productions of ''Sister Act'' are now running in Hamburg and Vienna and on tour in the United Kingdom. Productions are set for Paris, Moscow, Sao Paolo, Seoul and elsewhere.

Cambell Funeral Home, Madison Ave. at 81st St., NYC Wednesday 7-9pm, Thursday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass Friday 10:30am, St. Vincent Ferrer Lex. Ave., 66th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Kennedy Child Study Center, 151 East 67th St., 10065.

An article on Monday about the group Artists Wanted, which held an online contest for people to select artists to have work displayed on electronic billboards in Times Square, misidentified the group that has donated some of the billboard space for the project. It is the Times Square Advertising Coalition, not the Times Square Alliance.

There are things in the United States Senate that are regular and expected: steamed fish served on Tuesdays for partisan lunches; fulminating conference calls hosted by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York; and amendments to bills that point out embarrassing government expenditures, offered by Senator Tom Coburn, often bound for failure. So it was Wednesday, during a monster session of amendment votes on the farm bill, that Mr. Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, offered a measure that would prohibit taxpayer dollars from enriching some programs in the Market Access Program, which is designed to help American agriculture entities market their brands overseas and conduct research.

Jittergram is a nifty free app that helps you make and share simple stop-motion animations using an iPhone. It's pretty easy to use, but not so easy that it couldn't benefit from some instructions. The app was built in a weekend for Photo Hack Day in New York, said Andy Mangold, a co-founder of Friends of the Web, which created the app. ''We didn't have time to do instructions over the weekend, and we didn't want to invest the time in making the instructions afterward,'' he said.

Jim Wilson, whose cross-country travels in a GM pickup festooned with giant Romney for President signs and stickers earned the admiration and enmity of strangers, reported that his truck was badly burned on Interstate 70 in Pennsylvania on Wednesday afternoon. Mr. Wilson, Mitt Romney's most loyal, visible and assiduous supporter, was not injured in the fire, but his truck was destroyed.

An article on Tuesday about Italy's 2-0 victory over Ireland at the European soccer championships on Monday referred incorrectly to a game between the teams 18 years ago during which six people in Loughinisland, Northern Ireland, were shot and killed while watching in a pub, an event the teams recognized with black armbands on Monday. It was a World Cup game, not a World Cup qualification game.

NBC executives are making a plan to replace Ann Curry on the ''Today'' show, only a year after she became the co-host of the newly vulnerable morning television franchise. The planning - which is taking place in secret and has not been completed - is effectively an admission that all is not well at ''Today,'' the show that invented morning television 60 years ago and inspired countless lower-rated competitors since. ''Today'' consistently ranked No. 1 in the morning ratings until this spring, when ABC's ''Good Morning America'' beat it in the ratings for several weeks.

Kortick, devoted mother of Nancy Dagostino and her husband Michael, cherished and proud grandmother of Brian Dagostino, dear sister of Robert Mensch and his wife Dorothy and the late Bernice Gedal. Services 10:45am, Friday at Sanctuary of Abraham & Sarah, 735 Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

If the names Monogram, Aurora and Revell instantly summon memories of ''put tab A in slot B,'' then you'll recognize the design behind the iPhone covers from KitcaseUSA. The injection molded plastic cases are sold as three separate parts attached to a frame (called the sprue, if you really want to know) like scale model airplanes and cars of yore. They are assembled just like those plastic model kits, but without that glue with those heady fumes.

A hearing to determine whether the man who confessed to killing Etan Patz is mentally fit to stand trial will be pushed back until Oct. 1, people briefed on the case said on Wednesday. The man, Pedro Hernandez, 51, was scheduled to appear in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Monday, when the results of a psychiatric evaluation were to be filed with the court. But Mr. Hernandez's lawyer, Harvey Fishbein, and the office of the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., agreed to the delay.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the City Council, announced on Wednesday that they intended to file a legal brief arguing that the federal government's Defense of Marriage Act is unconstitutional. The friend-of-the-court brief will be included in the lawsuit of Edith Windsor, an 83-year old widow in Greenwich Village who has paid more than $500,000 in inheritance taxes since her spouse, Thea Spyer, died in 2009, two years after the couple married in Canada.

A critic's notebook article on Tuesday about the Queer New York International Arts Festival, at the Abrons Art Center in Manhattan, included an erroneous description of part of a public round table at the festival. When the discussion's moderator asked if there is anything that could not be framed as queer art, one of the curators, André von Ah, did in fact answer the question, citing works that do not deal with aesthetic or social norms. It was not the case that neither curator answered.

An article on June 7 about edible weeds misstated the name of the hometown of Tama Matsuoka Wong, a New Jersey resident who grows such weeds. It is Flemington -- not North Flemington, which is not an official municipality.

A picture caption last Thursday with an article about crops that rural African-Americans relied on for survival referred incorrectly to Vincent Mills Jr., who was shown holding an ear of corn at the River Road African American Museum in Donaldsonville, La. He is the grandson of Janice Linton, a museum staff member; he is not the grandson of Kathe Hambrick-Jackson, the museum's executive director. And because of an editing error, the article misspelled the name of a type of pea. They are crowder peas, not chowder peas.

The emotional toll of a heart attack can be so severe that an estimated 1 in 8 patients who survive the experience develop post-traumatic stress disorder, a condition that doubles the risk of dying of a second heart attack, according to new research. While it has long been known that a heart attack affects both physical and mental health, most doctors and patients are not aware that the emotional stress of a life-threatening heart event can develop into full-blown post-traumatic stress disorder, or P.T.S.D. The disorder, which more typically affects combat veterans and victims of violent crime, can be particularly insidious in heart patients, who live with constant trepidation about their own bodies, frequently paying anxious attention to each heartbeat or twinge of chest discomfort.

A dance review on Monday about Wind-Up Dances at the Baryshnikov Arts Center in Manhattan, using information from a publicist, misidentified the dancer who walked off wearing a table in ''Wind-Up Circus.'' She is Sarah Chien -- not Emily Giovine, another member of the company.

Will Michael O'Leary get lucky on his third try? Shares of Aer Lingus, Ireland's flag airline, leapt by as much as 25 percent Wednesday after news that Ryanair, the Irish low-cost airline Mr. O'Leary runs, had made yet another hostile bid for it.

KOERNER--Ira. Passed away in his sleep on June 10 just shy of his 88th birthday. He suffered quite a bit but now he is at peace. We were only two weeks apart in age but he always told everyone he was much younger. Ira was my first cousin and we grew up in Brookline, MA. We were childhood friends since the age of three and maintained a very close relationship all of our lives. He started out in real estate with Brown Harris Stevens under the VP of John Capon in the Wall Street area. As young men we would double date and when I met my wife for the first time, he dated her roommate. He was the best man at my wedding, had a great sense of humor and was always the life of the party. Ira loved the beach and especially Jones Beach which he called his own. We would all meet there early on Sunday mornings and enjoy the day. He was a wonderful man and I will miss my friend. Robert Arnow
WEISMAN--Ceil, on June 20, 2012. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Elinor Goodman and the late Harvey Weisman. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

SMITH--David Schlemmer. Lawyer, writer, photographer, died unexpectedly on Saturday, June 16, 2012 at the age of 56. David was a graduate of Poly Prep Country Day School and attended Stanford University, serving as editor of the Stanford Daily and graduating Phi Beta Kappa in English. He entered publishing and worked as assistant editor of the Columbia University Press for several years, then attended Harvard Law School. He worked as an associate at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, then as vice president at Citibank for fifteen years. David was an ardent camper and naturalist. David is fondly remembered as favorite uncle to Andrew, Katherine, Benjamin and Audrey, wonderful brother to Peggy and Peter, and loving son of Alan and Joyce Smith, who survive him. Contributions in David's name may be made to the Brooklyn Public Library.

On doctor's orders, Tony-winning actress Audra McDonald will be out of ''The Gershwins' Porgy and Bess'' until July 3. ''As a result of performing with a respiratory infection last week, her vocal cords have become inflamed to a point where she cannot sing,'' the show's producers said in a statement released late Wednesday.

SCHULTE--Tony. The New Press Board of Directors and staff mourn the loss of founding board member and stalwart supporter Tony Schulte. Since 1973, Congregation Beit Simchat Torah has tried to reconcile traditions transmitted across the millenniums with traditions that its members - gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender Jews - have often had to make up on the fly, battling hostility, indifference and the AIDS epidemic at the same time. ''Radical traditionalism'' is the phrase used by Sharon Kleinbaum, the senior rabbi, to describe the philosophical arc of the 1,100-member congregation. Fine words. But what does ''radical traditionalism'' look like in three-dimensional volumes, in concrete and glass and wood?

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about Erica Kennedy, the author of the 2004 novel ''Bling,'' omitted a paragraph, leaving the impression that Ms. Kennedy was talking about her novel when she said, ''Everybody kept talking about how scandalous that book was.'' In fact she was referring to another novel, ''The Nanny Diaries.'' Her comment should have been preceded by this passage: ''Ms. Kennedy was moved to start work on the book, she later said, by the hoopla surrounding 'The Nanny Diaries,' the 2002 novel by Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus that lampooned Manhattan's elite.''

It is called a friendly, but usually it is everything but when the United States and Mexico take up occupancy on the same soccer field. And so it is likely to be on Aug. 15, when Coach Jurgen Klinsmann takes his American team to Azteca Stadium in Mexico City for a exhibition match only a few weeks before the next round of World Cup qualifying matches in the Concacaf region. It will be the first friendly between the countries on Mexican soil since 1984.

LONDON - Depictions of two women - one, by Picasso, seated and pregnant, and another, by Magritte, of a woman being raped - were the top two sellers at Christie's auction of Impressionist and Modern art here on Wednesday night. Seventy works, including paintings and sculptures by Monet, Renoir and Degas, were for sale and the auction brought in $145.5 million. By contrast, Sotheby's smaller auction Tuesday night of 48 works from the same period brought in $117.7 million.

Merger talks between two of New York City's biggest hospital systems -- NYU Langone Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners -- broke down abruptly on Thursday after Continuum got a competing offer, officials said. The offer came from Mount Sinai Medical Center, which, like NYU, is an academic medical center with a prestigious medical school.

(ABC) 20/20 Rielle Hunter speaks with Chris Cuomo, above, about her relationship with John Edwards; their 4-year-old daughter, Quinn; and the trial that ended in Mr. Edwards's acquittal on a charge of accepting illegal campaign contributions and a mistrial on five other counts. She also discusses her new book, ''What Really Happened: John Edwards, Our Daughter, and Me,'' which is due out on Tuesday. 8:40 A.M. (Cinemax) IN AMERICA (2003) Johnny (Paddy Considine), an Irish actor, and his wife, Sarah (Samantha Morton, who earned an Oscar nomination for best actress), try to start over in New York after the death of their young son in this modest but sincere drama from Jim Sheridan. Djimon Hounsou (nominated for best supporting actor) is Mateo, a reclusive painter dying of what seems to be AIDS who is befriended by Johnny and Sarah's daughters. Mr. Sheridan (''My Left Foot'') wrote the film with his own two daughters; the three earned a nomination for best original screenplay. ''This movie, from moment to moment, feels small, almost anecdotal,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It is only afterward that, like Mr. Sheridan's other films, it starts to grow into something at once unassuming and in its own way grand.''

He was preceded in death by his daughter Anne Doescher and is survived by a son, Eric Doescher, of Providence RI, and his former wife, Patricia McElroy, of NYC.

10:33 p.m. | Updated Already grappling with weak profits and global economic turmoil, 15 major banks were hit with credit downgrades on Thursday that could do more damage to their bottom lines and further unsettle equity markets. The credit agency, Moody's Investors Service, which warned banks in February that a downgrade was possible, cut the credit scores of banks to new lows to reflect new risks that the industry has encountered since the financial crisis.

A man believed to be the son of Mexico's most-wanted drug trafficker has been detained by the Mexican Navy, officials said Thursday. Naval officials said they had arrested Jesús Aflredo Guzmán Salazar, 26, ''the presumed son'' of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, better known by his nickname, El Chapo, or Shorty. The Mexican Navy said in a statement that Mr. Guzmán Salazar was detained Thursday in Jalisco State, on the central Pacific Coast. Mr. Guzmán Salazar, officials said, managed his father's real estate holdings and coordinated most of the Sinaloa drug organization's shipments of cocaine and marijuana to the United States. American drug agents, Mexican officials said, assisted in providing information leading to his arrest. Mr. Guzmán Salazar was indicted in 2009 on several drug-related charges in a federal court in Illinois, making it possible that he could be extradited to the United States.

Nasdaq has blamed Facebook's botched debut last month on flawed computers and ''technical errors.'' Regulators suspect it may be something more. The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened an investigation into the exchange for its role in the initial public offering of Facebook, according to people briefed on the inquiry. Regulators are examining whether Nasdaq failed to properly test its trading systems, which broke down during the I.P.O., and whether the exchange violated rules when it rewrote computer code to jump-start trading.

A picture caption on June 1 with an article about the opposition to intervention in Syria by the Russian Orthodox Church misidentified the position held within the church hierarchy of the clergymen shown. They are bishops, not priests. The article also misidentified the president of Ukraine in 2009. The post was held by Viktor A. Yushchenko -- not Viktor F. Yanukovich. who is the current president.

An obituary on Tuesday about the artist Barton Lidice Benes misstated the cause of his death. Mr. Benes died of acute kidney failure, not complications of AIDS.

As Moody's Investors Service prepared to cut the ratings of some of the world's biggest financial firms on Thursday, Morgan Stanley's chief executive, James P. Gorman, was in St. Petersburg, Russia. He spoke to a group of business and economic leaders about how banks would have rethink their roles in an environment characterized by more regulation and falling profits. It is a topic Mr. Gorman knows all too well.

SCHULTE--Anthony Martin, passed away suddenly on June 17 at his summer home in Maine at the age of 82. Son of Luise Meyer and Arthur Schulte, he is survived by his wife, Liz Darhansoff; his daughter, Lucy Schulte Danziger, her husband, James, and their children, Julian and Josie; his son, Peter Schulte, and his children, Revell and Dashiell; his sister- and brother-in-law, Pat and Bob Levinson, their children, Margot, Andrew, and John and his brother and sister-in law, Bonnie and David Kanfer and their children, Alexis Wellman and Jordan Kanfer. An article on Saturday about the Obama administration's new policy allowing some younger immigrants to avoid deportation and obtain work permits misstated part of the age qualifications established by the new rule. It applies to people who came to the United States as children and were no more than 30 years old -- not ''under 30 years old'' -- at the time the policy was changed by the administrative action last week. The error also appeared on Sunday and on Monday in articles about the new policy.

Coffee's for closers only, as a great man once said. So hoist a mug of joe for Bobby Cannavale, who has closed on a role in the coming Broadway revival of ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' its producers said on Thursday, and will join Al Pacino in that David Mamet play. Mr. Cannavale, a Tony Award nominee for ''The ---------------------- With the Hat,'' has been cast in the ''Glengarry'' revival as Ricky Roma, the real estate salesman who is proudly enjoying a hot streak while his office mates struggle through dry spells. He inherits the role, as it were, from Mr. Pacino, who topped the sales charts as Roma in James Foley's 1992 film adaptation of the play. On Broadway, Mr. Pacino (who never did get that new Cadillac his character was entitled to in the movie) will be playing the role of Levene, an older and less successful salesman known by the nickname ''the Machine.''

An article in some editions on June 7 about the Yankees' 4-1 victory over the Tampa Bay Rays the previous night misidentified, in some copies, the player who scored on Nick Swisher's double in the eighth inning. It was Dewayne Wise, not Raul Ibanez. (Wise had replaced Ibanez as a pinch-runner earlier in the inning.)

Sonny Rollins, the veteran saxophonist, was the big winner on Wednesday night at the annual Jazz Awards in New York, taking home three trophies. He was named musician of the year for the second year in a row and won for best record and best tenor saxophonist to boot. He won the best-record trophy for his latest album, ''Road Shows, Vol. 2'' (Emarcy/Umgd), which consists of live recordings from concerts in Japan as well as a concert he gave on his 80th birthday in New York with Ornette Coleman. Mr. Rollins could not attend the awards dinner at the Blue Note because he was moving to a new home, in upstate New York, but sent a letter that was read by the master of ceremonies, Josh Jackson, who hosts a jazz show on WBGO (88.3 FM), The Associated Press reported.

Forty-seven pit bulls, bred for fighting, lived crammed in a basement-level apartment in the Bronx, the police said. They stayed in cages, some two to a cage, and, the police said, some of them might never have seen the sun before Thursday afternoon. It was then that police officers and workers from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, surrounded by curious neighbors, carried the dogs, one by one, out of 1254 Sherman Avenue, near the Grand Concourse. They were to be collared, photographed and registered into evidence.

At Columbus Circle, top, Caitlin LaPera, 20, sunbathed Thursday and Christian Gunn, 6, scampered in the fountain. Tourists, left, shielded themselves from the sun, while Sam, above, enjoyed a water blast at the Bronx Equestrian Center. The high temperature in Central Park was 94 degrees; at Kennedy and La Guardia Airports, it was 97, according to the National Weather Service. The temperature at Kennedy broke the record for the date of 95.

SOMMER-PORTNOY--Elaine Ruth (nee Woronoff), Age 89, widow of the late Bernard Sommer, her devoted husband of 45 years, and the late Hal Portnoy, died peacefully on June 20, 2012 in Boca Raton, Florida. Funeral services will be held Sunday, June 24, at 11:30am at Temple Beth-El, 333 S.W. 4th Ave., Boca Raton, Florida.

One of the most famous Monty Python sketches, featured on the Goal blog earlier this week is a simple soccer match between Germany and Greece entitled ''International Philosophy.'' The twist in this timeless gag is that the two squads are built with classical thinkers from both nations' illustrious cultural past, as they do their best to not only beat each other at in the game, but to outwit and out think their opponents. Coincidentally, Friday's match in Gdansk, Poland, between Greece and Germany not only offers a game of soccer in much the same fashion as that of the Python farce -- albeit of a slightly higher standard -- but a battle of intellect and a study between two coaches who have allowed much of what has happened off the field to define their tenure, as much as what has happened on it.

Starting in December the Emmy-winning actress Laurie Metcalf (''Roseanne''), below, will reprise her acclaimed performance as a drug-industry businesswoman who unravels emotionally in ''The Other Place,'' a psychological drama by Sharr White that ran Off Broadway in 2011 and will be remounted on Broadway by Manhattan Theater Club, the organization confirmed on Thursday. Ms. Metcalf, who is currently drawing rave reviews in London playing Mary Tyrone in ''Long Day's Journey Into Night,'' won an Obie Award and a Lucille Lortel Award last year for ''The Other Place''; hers was the sort of performance that often draws Tony Awards attention, but ''The Other Place'' wasn't eligible because only Broadway productions are considered for Tonys. ''The Other Place'' is scheduled to begin preview performances at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Dec. 11 and open on Jan. 10. The Tony winner Joe Mantello (''Take Me Out,'' ''Wicked'') will direct, as he did at MCC Theater at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

8:54 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON - John E. Bryson announced his resignation as President Obama's commerce secretary on Thursday, citing medical reasons after an episode in which he had a seizure and was involved in a sequence of car crashes. Mr. Bryson, a longtime California electricity conglomerate executive, served in the cabinet for just eight months and had kept a low profile in Washington during his short tenure. But that changed when he was found unconscious behind the wheel of his car in California earlier this month after reportedly hitting two other vehicles.

MAYER--Terry, 89, of NYC, passed away June 19, 2012. A fashion designer, publicist, jewelry designer, and a belloligist. Services will be held Sunday, June 24, at 11am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, NYC.

The stage collapse that killed a Radiohead crew member last Saturday in Toronto also destroyed the band's sophisticated light show, forcing the British group to postpone seven concerts in Europe over the next two weeks while repairs are made, the band said on Thursday in a statement. That means Radiohead will skip a swing through the Italian cities of Rome, Florence, Bologna and Codroipo, a two-night stand in Berlin and a stop at Canton de Vaud in Switzerland. It will resume the tour in Nimes, France, on July 10. ''The collapse also destroyed the light show - this show was unique and will take many weeks to replace,'' the band said. ''The collapse also caused serious damage to our backline, some elements of which are decades old and therefore hard to replace.''

ATHENS -- Greece's new coalition government, sworn in on Thursday, declared that its chief goals were ''to tackle the crisis, pave the way for growth and revise the terms of the loan agreement without endangering the country's European course and its position in the euro zone.'' The statement from the office of the new prime minister, Antonis Samaras of the conservative New Democracy party, said the government would serve the full four-year term set out in the Greek Constitution. But the tenuous coalition among the conservatives, the Socialist Party known as Pasok and the moderate Democratic Left may struggle to last even a fraction of that time.

An article on Wednesday about officials of Armenia and Azerbaijan who blamed each other publicly on Tuesday for the war they have fought for more than 20 years over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh -- a day after the presidents of the United States, Russia and France had called for a peaceful settlement -- misidentified the region of the conflict in some editions. It is the South Caucasus, not the North Caucasus.

BOXENBAUM--Gloria, 76, of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY, passed away on June 21, 2012 after a brief illness. She was a selfless and devoted wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Her life was dedicated to giving to her husband Bernard of 57 years, daughter Abby (Jonathan) Rubin, grandchildren Jessica (Yehoshua) Sova, Josh (Dina), Zachary and Benjamin, and great grandchildren Aryeh, Racheli, Asher, Motti and Rachel. They were her life. She will be truly missed by all who had the good fortune to know her.

In May of last year, Court Street in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, was transported back in time for a few days. Vintage yellow taxis lined the street, silver and blue street signs were superimposed over the existing green ones, and newspaper stands were filled with papers displaying headlines that were decades old.

KALLMANN--Gerhard Michael. The Officers of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourn the passing of visionary architect and distinguished Academy Fellow, Gerhard Michael Kallmann. A noted theorist, committed educator, and pioneering designer of iconic structures, he had an extraordinary impact on 20th and 21st century architecture. With his colleague Michael McKinnell, he designed the House of the American Academy in Cambridge, Massachusetts, the organization's headquarters. The building is an enduring legacy of his inspiring aesthetic vision. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Louis W. Cabot, Chair of the Board Leslie C. Berlowitz, President

NEIMAN--LeRoy. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House of New York wish to express our sincere sympathy of the passing of our dear friend and benefactor, LeRoy Neiman. Mr. Neiman was both generous and creative to the special kids and families battling cancer at the Ronald McDonald House. Our sincere sympathy and deepest condolences go out to his wife Janet and the entire Neiman family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President & Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

Cecilia Conrad, vice president for academic affairs and dean of Pomona College in Claremont, Calif., has been named the next director of the MacArthur Foundation fellowship program, foundation officials said Thursday. Ms. Conrad, 57, was selected though a national search, after the current director, Daniel J. Socolow, decided to leave the position after 15 years. Ms. Conrad, an economist who conducts research on economic inequality, will start on Jan. 15. Some 850 people in a range of fields encompassing poetry and physics have been named fellows since 1981. Each winner has the prestige of the so-called genius awards (a term the foundation discourages) and receives a no-strings-attached $500,000 fellowship from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation in Chicago. Ms. Conrad said she could not imagine any major changes in the program but is open to new directions.

A court on Thursday sentenced a militant to 20 years in prison for his role in several terrorist acts, including the twin nightclub bombings on the resort island of Bali in 2002 that killed 202 people, mostly foreigners. The militant, Umar Patek, left, is believed to be a leading member of Jemaah Islamiyah, a radical splinter group linked to Al Qaeda and blamed for a series of terrorist attacks in Indonesia, including the blasts on Bali. Mr. Patek was the last remaining defendant to be tried in Indonesia for the bombing. His capture last year in Pakistan ended a manhunt that had lasted for nearly a decade.

An obituary on June 14 about Henry Hill, whose experiences were documented in the book ''Wiseguy'' and in the movie ''Goodfellas,'' described his position in the Luchese crime family incorrectly. He was an associate -- not a ''soldier,'' in the context of how that word is used in organized crime.

GEORGIS--Mitzie, of La Jolla, CA, 80, died on June 19, 2012. Mitzie was born on July 8, 1931 in Chicago, IL to Peter and Chrisoula (Ganas) Chronos. She was the beloved wife of the late Ted W. Georgis, mother of Demi Bowles Lathrop (Thomas N. Lathrop), Ted Georgis, Jr. and William T. Georgis (Richard D. Marshall) and grandmother to Henry M. Bowles, III, Nellie C. Bowles, Matthew T. Georgis, Kelly E. Georgis and Jessica K. Georgis. She is also survived by brothers; George P. Chronos and Harry P. Chronos. Mitzie was an inspired gardener, hostess extraordinaire, bon vivant, and life force. She leaves a veritable legacy of love and laughter. Her spirit carries on in the lives of those she touched. Mitzie loved life! The following services will be held at Sts. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church, 3459 Manchester Ave., Cardiff by the Sea, CA 92007. Trisagion will be at 6:30pm., Friday, June 22, 2012. Funeral Service at 10:00am., Saturday, June 23, 2012 with burial immediately following at El Camino Memorial Park. Services under the direction of El Camino Memorial 5600 Carroll Canyon Rd., San Diego, CA 92121 www.elcaminomemorial.com.

A STRUGGLE FOR KPN KPN, the Dutch telecommunications company, has been trying fend off a hostile bid from América Móvil for weeks. In May, América Móvil, which is owned by the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helú, below, offered 8 euros a share ($10) to increase its stake in KPN to 28 percent. After rejecting the offer, KPN moved to block América Móvil by putting its German unit, E-Plus, up for sale. But now that sale to Telefonica, according to a person with the knowledge of the matter, has fallen through. In a statement, the Dutch operator said ''current adverse conditions in the financial markets'' had forced it to call off the discussions. KEVIN J. O'BRIEN

PARIS -- It is a most unusual and diverse art exhibition for Unesco, the United Nations arm dedicated to preserving and promoting the world's culture. On Wednesday, 31 rare artifacts and works of art - all of them stolen or illegally exported, mostly in or from Italy - went on display at UNESCO's Paris headquarters, in an exhibition called ''Recovered Treasures.'' ''All the objects were kidnapped at some point,'' said Iñigo Martinez Möller, curator of the exhibition, in an interview. ''The point of the exhibition is to show how damaging this illicit traffic can be and how original pieces can be taken apart in violent ways.''

A search was under way on Friday to find possible survivors from a fishing vessel carrying about 200 people believed to be seeking asylum in Australia after the boat capsized in rough seas south of the main Indonesian island, Java. Australian and Indonesian warships joined Australian merchant and government vessels to search for about 90 people still missing after the boat capsized. An Australian Navy patrol boat and three cargo ships have rescued 110 survivors, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority said. Three bodies have also been found, the agency said. The Australian home affairs minister, Jason Clare, said that crews aboard search planes had seen more bodies, but had not yet spotted any more survivors.

Bain Capital agreed on Friday to buy 50 percent of one of Japan's biggest television shopping companies marking the latest move by the private equity firm into that country. Bain is acquiring the stake in the company, the Jupiter Shop Channel Company, from Sumitomo. The firm is paying more than $1 billion, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook.

The graying but still spry grandfather of new-music groups, the Ensemble Intercontemporain, said on Friday that the composer and conductor Matthias Pintscher would become its next music director, starting in 2013. Mr. Pintscher, 41, who has an increasingly busy conducting career along with his work as a composer, will succeed Susanna Mälkki. Born in West Germany and now living in New York, Mr. Pintscher will serve as one of the conductors with the New York Philharmonic in a performance of Stockhausen's ''Gruppen,'' a work for three orchestras, at the Park Avenue Armory next week. Pierre Boulez founded the Paris-based Ensemble Intercontemporain in 1976. It has 31 members who play a wide variety of recent works, a model followed by many new groups.

A picture caption on Friday with the Advertising column, about new campaigns by several travel firms, described incorrectly the promotional effort by one of them, Air France. The company has released an iPhone app that lets passengers create photo albums of their trip; it has not placed ads as part of the campaign.

HUSZAR--Kenneth D. June 19, 2012. Loving brother of Janet Thompkins, dearly loved by cousin Ted Hussar and wife Susan. KOSTRINSKY--Sam, 93, President of Grand Silver Co.,beloved husband, father, and grandfather passed Thursday with his family at his side. Services at 9am on Sunday, Congregation Emanu-El, Rye, NY. Donations may be made to The Myasthenia Gravis Foundation.

A former New York police officer who used a racial slur while bragging about falsely arresting a black man last year was sentenced on Friday to nine months in prison for violating the man's civil rights. The former officer, Michael Daragjati, 33, who is white, was recorded telling a friend on the telephone last year that he had ''fried another nigger,'' explaining that he had falsely charged a man with resisting arrest after stopping and frisking him on Staten Island. The man was held in jail for nearly two days.

The Foreign Ministry said Friday that Cambodia had no plans to extradite to China or France a detained French architect with links to a disgraced Chinese politician and his wife, but that the architect was not yet being set free, either. A spokesman for the Cambodian Foreign Ministry, Kuy Kong, said that he did not know how long the architect, Patrick Devillers, would be held, nor why he was being held. Hor Nahong, Cambodia's foreign minister, said Thursday night that Mr. Devillers was still being investigated. The police said that Mr. Devillers had been arrested about two weeks ago at China's request. The Chinese Foreign Ministry declined to comment. Mr. Devillers has been linked to Bo Xilai, a powerful Chinese politician who was removed from his post in Chongqing and suspended from the Communist Party's Politburo, and to Mr. Bo's wife, Gu Kailai. Ms. Gu is being investigated on suspicion of involvement in the killing of a British businessman, Neil Heywood, who had reportedly been engaged in international financial transactions on Ms. Gu's behalf.

Strikes continued on both sides of the Gaza border, with four Palestinians killed in Gaza and an Israeli man injured in Sderot.

An article on Friday about a credit downgrade of 15 large banks by Moody's Investors Service misstated, in some editions, its cut for Bank of America. Bank of America's credit rating was cut by one notch, to Baa2, from Baa1; it was not cut by two notches.

In the long war over Wall Street regulation, a little-noticed clash erupted this week over a plan to rein in risky trading overseas. Signs that a clash was brewing behind the scenes came after the Commodity Futures Trading Commission abruptly canceled a meeting to vote on the overseas trading proposal with just hours to spare. The agency provided no explanation, sending out only a short e-mail that it would ''no longer hold a scheduled meeting on June 21, 2012.''

An art review on Friday about ''Black 1973-1986,'' an exhibition of black-and-white photographs by George Dureau at Higher Pictures on Madison Avenue in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to Mr. Dureau. He is not black.

American Airlines and the union representing its pilots are close to reaching a deal on a new contract, a significant milestone in the ailing carrier's seven-month-old bankruptcy, although one that still leaves the door open for a possible merger with US Airways. The accord potentially resolves a major sticking point with the carrier's most expensive employee group and a group critical to American's continued operation.

A man involved with a Web site that posted threatening messages about the creators of the Comedy Central series ''South Park'' was sentenced to 111/2 years in prison on Friday, The Associated Press reported. The man, Jesse Curtis Morton, pleaded guilty in February to federal charges that stemmed from messages that he and an associate, Zachary A. Chesser, wrote on a Web site called Revolution Muslim after an episode of ''South Park'' that they said had insulted the Prophet Muhammad.

Nine months ago, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly issued a memorandum directing police officers not to make arrests for possession of small quantities of marijuana discovered when suspects are ordered to empty their pockets in stop, question and frisk encounters. But police officers have continued to charge New Yorkers with misdemeanor crimes - rather than issuing them tickets for violations - for possession of small amounts of marijuana despite Mr. Kelly's directive, according to a lawsuit filed on Friday by the Legal Aid Society.

ETTENBERG--Sylvia, died on June 21 at the age of 94. She was a distinguished Jewish educator, founder of Camp Ramah and Dean at the Jewish Theological Seminary; as well as a loving wife, sister, mother and grandmother. ROTHENBERG--Sheldon P. May 28, 1929 June 22, 2012. Born in Brooklyn, NY. Shelly attended Stuyvesant High School and graduated in 1950 from New York University. In 1955 he graduated first in his class from Chicago Medical School. During his residency at The Bronx VA Medical Center, he was introduced to basic research by Drs. Solomon Berson and Rosalind Yalow (Nobel Laureate). This launched his passion for scientific research and drove him through his career to investigate the scientific basis of clinical problems. He joined the faculty of New York Medical College in 1961. In 1980, he moved to SUNY Downstate Medical Center as Chief of the Division of Hematology/Oncology at the Veteran Affairs Medical Center Brooklyn, and then at Downstate Health Science Center. Shelly's research focus was vitamin B12 and folic acid metabolism. He developed the first radioimmunoassays for both vitamins and his studies of their physiology and functions in related disease processes were recognized nationally and internationally. Shelly was a brilliant diagnostician and caring bedside doctor sought after by colleagues for his clinical acumen and loved by his patients. He was an inspiring and demanding teacher who insisted on learning from the book and more importantly from the patient. Medical students and residents vied to be assigned to his service. He repeatedly received the Excellence in Teaching Award at New York Medical College, and later at SUNY Downstate Medical Center. Shelly retired as Chief of Hematology/Oncology in 2003, but continued to direct his laboratory until 2007, finally stepping down after half a century of unstinting devotion to his beloved profession. Shelly's career as a professor, physician and scientist epitomized the best of the medical profession. In recognition of his accomplishments he received The New York State University Chancellor's Award for Exemplary Contributions to Research and Scholarship in 2005. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Maria da Costa, his daughters, Pamela (Mark) and Diane (Fletcher) and grandchildren Tess, Jeremy, Callie and Mia. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, June 24, 2011 at 12:30 p.m. at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10024. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, P.O. Box 4072, Pittsfield, MA 01202.

DONTZIN--Michael Joseph. Retired Justice of the Supreme Court of the State of New York, New York County, died peacefully at his home in New York City on June 22, 2012 after a long battle with cancer. Judge Dontzin was 89 years old. Judge Dontzin was born in New York City to immigrant Russian parents, Joseph and Miriam, and attended Stuyvesant High School. During the Korean War, he served as a corpsman in the US Navy. He went on to attend Washington State University in Pullman, then transferred to New York University where he received a B.A in 1948 and a J.D. in 1951. Working as a trial lawyer in private practice, Judge Dontzin became an activist in the Liberal Party, where he was a protege to leaders Alex Rose and David Dubinsky. His activity in politics reflected his passion for social justice, and for the vibrancy and well-being of the city he loved. He practiced law until 1966 when he was appointed as Counsel to Mayor John Lindsay, where he was the Mayor's liaison to the Police Department and the Court System, and led the Mayor's Screening Committee on the Judiciary. Appointed by Mayor Lindsay as Judge of the Criminal Court of the City of New York in 1972, he was elected as a Justice of the Supreme Court, New York County in 1976 and re-elected to successive terms until his retirement from the bench in 1992. Judge Dontzin became the Chief Judicial Officer of the alternative dispute resolution firm Endispute in 1992, which later became JAMS. He resolved thousands of commercial, employment, insurance, mass tort, and other cases as mediator or arbitrator, and became a leading proponent of ADR. At the same time, he founded The Dontzin Law Firm with his son Matthew S. Dontzin and practiced law actively until his death. In the last days of his life, he presided over the marriage of a gay couple in his home, keeping a promise to a friend. The law was his great passion and he will be remembered as a skillful and accomplished jurist. He is survived by his devoted wife of 35 years, Janet Sarno, an actress; daughter Lisa; son Matthew; daughter-in-law Ginger; and grandchildren Maegan Mishico and Cole Dontzin. When not practicing law, Judge Dontzin's other great passion was to serve as his wife's Stage Door Johnny, accompanying her to each of her theater performances. Judge Dontzin was predeceased in 1990 by his former wife Marion Bell Seldin, who remained a close friend after their divorce. The family will receive guests on June 25 and 26 from 6pm to 9pm at the home of Matthew S. Dontzin, 6 East 81st Street, NYC. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

An hour before President Obama spoke to Latino officials in Orlando on Friday, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida lamented how the immigration issue had become hostage to politics -- on both the left and right. ''I have seen people take the legitimate concern about illegal immigration and turn it into panic and turn that panic into fear and anger and turn that anger into votes and money,'' Mr. Rubio said.

An obituary on Wednesday about the actor Victor Spinetti erroneously credited him with a distinction for his work on movies with the Beatles. While he was the only person besides the Beatles themselves to appear in their movies ''A Hard Day's Night,'' ''Help!'' and ''Magical Mystery Tour,'' he was not the only person other than the Beatles to appear in ''all of their movies.'' (He was not in ''Let It Be,'' a documentary about the Beatles, or the animated feature ''Yellow Submarine,'' which featured their songs on the soundtrack and in which they appeared as cartoon characters, with other actors supplying their speaking voices.)

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about Democrats in New Jersey's Legislature who have called for stricter oversight of the state's troubled system of halfway houses misstated, in some editions, the day they announced their plan. It was Thursday, not Monday.

BATAVIA, Ohio -- The tumor grew like a thick vine up the back of Eric Richter's leg, reminding him every time he sat down that he was a man without insurance. In April, when it was close to bursting through his skin, he went to the emergency room. Doctors told him it was malignant and urged surgery. His wife called every major insurance company she found on the Internet, but none would cover him: His cancer was a pre-existing condition. In desperation, the Richters agreed to pay half their hospital bill, knowing they could never afford it on their combined salaries of $36,000 a year.

As of July 22, JPMorgan Chase will no longer charge its checking account customers overdraft fees for any purchase of $5 or less. The change will help eliminate multiple overdraft fees - charged when customers overspend their account - for small purchases. Say that you have overdrawn your account and have a negative balance of, oh, $60 (probably incurring an overdraft fee of $34, according to Chase's checking disclosure). Then you use your debit card to buy a snack for $4.50 and a cup of coffee for $3.50. The new rule means you won't be charged overdraft fees on the two purchases. Previously, you could have been charged a separate fee for each purchase.
An article last Saturday about Jo Nesbo, a Norwegian writer of crime thrillers, misstated the number of his books that are available in English. There are seven, not six.

As the nation awaits the Supreme Court's ruling on challenges to the health care law, Americans continue to report that they struggle to pay for medical care. A quarter of Americans report problems paying medical bills in the past year, and about 60 percent say they've ''cut corners'' to avoid health care costs, according to the May tracking poll conducted by the Kaiser Family Foundation.

On the evening of Feb. 10, 1939, the oil tanker Lightburne ran aground in dense fog on a shoal off Block Island, R.I. In lashing winds and pounding surf, the Coast Guard raced to the site and performed what The New York Times called ''one of the most spectacular ship rescues in recent years,'' saving all 35 crew members. Today the Lightburne, or what's left of it, sits in about 30 feet of cold, turbid water about 35 miles east of Montauk, N.Y., its once formidable steel hull a cage of ghostly ribs encrusted in algae.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE DEBT (2011) John Madden's remake of a 2007 Israeli thriller shuttles between an East Berlin apartment in 1965 and Tel Aviv 30 years later. Helen Mirren, above, portrays Rachel Singer, a celebrated Mossad operative who, with two other agents -- her ex-husband, Stephan Gold (Tom Wilkinson), and David Peretz (Ciaran Hinds) -- captured and killed the Mengele-like Nazi fugitive Dieter Vogel (Jesper Christensen), known as the Surgeon of Birkenau. Her exploits have become the subject of a book written by her daughter (Romi Aboulafia). But eventually the accepted account of Rachel's actions begins to erode. Jessica Chastain, Marton Csokas and Sam Worthingon play the agents as young adults in Berlin. ''The claustrophobic, unspoken bonds and rivalries that link Rachel, David and Stephan in their younger and older incarnations are overshadowed by Vogel and everything he represents, and a finely observed study of desire under duress gives way to a breathless and pedestrian globe-trotting thriller,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Not a bad one, it should be said.'' NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of The New York Times Book Review, ponders whether the end of the country's political system is near.

Politico, the Web site devoted to covering all facets of the political news cycle, said late on Thursday that it had suspended one of its White House reporters for making numerous disparaging and vulgar comments about Mitt Romney. The reporter, Joe Williams, had a history of describing Mr. Romney and other conservatives in provocative terms on his Twitter feed. And on Thursday, after Mr. Williams appeared on MSNBC and said that Mr. Romney only appeared comfortable around ''white folks,'' Politico said that it had taken action.

When a consumer'screditscore drops, it is hard to recover financially. Wall Street firms could face the same fate. Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Citigroup all suffered credit ratings cuts on Thursday. A decision by the Jewish Museum to remove a photographic installation from an exhibition about the politics of sex and desire has drawn criticism from the artist who created the work. The installation, by the San Francisco artist Marc Adelman, shows a selection of 50 profile pictures of men appropriated from a gay Berlin Internet-dating site; the pictures show the men photographed against the minimalist forms of Berlin's Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe.

ETTENBERG--Sylvia. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the loss of Sylvia Ettenberg, Dean Emerita at JTS, and a presence at the institution for over half a century. She had a crucial role in founding and leading virtually every JTS enterprise in the field of Jewish education: most famously, Camp Ramah, but also the Ivry Prozdor High School, the Melton Research Center, JTS's Department of Jewish Education, and the William Davidson Graduate School of Jewish Education. Throughout her distinguished service, her thoughtful counsel and leadership were guided by her strong commitment to traditional Jewish values, and to her continued championship of education. Loving wife of the late Moshe Ettenberg, mother of Isa Aron and David Ettenberg, grandmother of Hillel Aron and Jesse Aron. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

The High & Low Finance column on Friday, about the case for a federal program to support a fueling infrastructure for natural gas vehicles, misstated Honda's marketing of its natural gas-fueled Civic.
