A headline in some editions on Saturday with an article about a national campaign by the Roman Catholic Church against President Obama's health care mandates and other government policies overstated a point made by Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York, who helped kick off the campaign on Friday. When Cardinal Dolan referred to defending ''sacred liberties'' during a Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral that morning, he did so in the context of threats against religion throughout the history of the United States. He did not say the president's policies ''threaten 'sacred liberties.' '' (The cardinal has, on other occasions, criticized specific policies of the president.)

The National Book Foundation has created an online exhibit to highlight notable American authors like Cynthia Propper Seton, Earl Thompson and Alan Saperstein. Oh, and Hemingway, Faulkner and Flannery O'Connor, too. They're all among the 373 finalists for the National Book Award for Fiction since the honor was first issued in 1950. The legends and the largely forgotten exist side by side on the site, which allows readers to scroll through the front covers of the nominees and winners. (This somewhat ungainly method is the only way to browse for now.)

For nearly four decades, as the second-in-command at Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities, Peter B. Madoff ran the family business alongside his older brother. On Friday, Peter Madoff - more than three years after his brother, Bernard, confessed to running a vast Ponzi scheme that swindled investors out of billions of dollars - is expected to appear in Federal District Court in Manhattan and plead guilty to criminal charges, according to prosecutors. He would be the first relative of Mr. Madoff's to admit to wrongdoing in connection with the fraud.

An overwhelming majority of Americans support the Postal Service's plan to end Saturday mail delivery, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times/CBS News. The survey found that about 7 in 10 Americans say they would favor the change as a way to help the post office deal with billions of dollars in debt. The Postal Service continues to suffer losses of $36 million a day and is headed for projected losses of about $21 billion a year by 2016.

Harry Levinson, a psychologist who helped change corporate America's thinking about the workplace by demonstrating a link between job conditions and emotional health -- a progressive notion when he began developing his ideas in the 1950s -- died on Tuesday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 90. His death was confirmed by his son Marc.

BARASCH--Norma. Passed away peacefully, June 26, after a long illness, with her family by her side. Beloved wife of Norman, devoted mother to Michelle and Suzanne, and son-in-law, Joel. Loving grandmother to Erika, Justin and Emily. All the memories we've shared will forever remain in our hearts.

After seven seasons playing the charismatic, controlling network executive Jack Donaghy on the NBC comedy ''30 Rock,'' Alec Baldwin will return to Broadway in spring 2013 in a much darker show - but in a role that is no less charismatic or controlling. Mr. Baldwin will portray Harold, a mobster who is kidnapped and held by two troubled brothers in Lyle Kessler's 1983 drama ''Orphans,'' the show's producers said on Wednesday. The play will be directed by the Tony Award winner Daniel Sullivan (''The Columnist,'' ''Proof''), who is also staging a Broadway revival of ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' this fall. ''Orphans'' is best remembered in New York as a critically acclaimed hit Off Broadway in 1985, starring John Mahoney (''Frasier'') as Harold and Terry Kinney and Kevin Anderson as the brothers, Treat and Phillip. That production, directed by Gary Sinise, started at Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago, and it was one of several New York transfers that brought Steppenwolf to wider attention in the 1980s. ''Orphans'' was also made into a movie in 1987 by Alan J. Pakula, which featured Albert Finney as Harold.

Sharon was an esteemed friend and neighbor to all who live and work at The Sherry-Netherland and she will be missed.

Roger Savell, President Lee Charles, Secretary

Diller Scofidio + Renfro, the architectural firm responsible for the redevelopment of Lincoln Center and the city's High Line, has been chosen to design the gallery and visitor experience at the remodeled Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum on the Upper East Side. Local Projects, a design firm, will also be part of the team and responsible for the museum's digital offerings. The renovations of the museum's Carnegie Mansion are part of a $64-million capital campaign. ''This project gives Cooper-Hewitt the opportunity to re-invent itself, to rethink museum conventions and the entire museum 'visit,''' said Caroline Baumann, associate director of the museum. ''We're delighted to be working with DS+R and Local Projects in creating a distinctly contemporary vision that will serve as a model for a new type of museum.'' While the renovations are underway, Cooper-Hewitt, which is part of the Smithsonian Institution, is offering exhibitions and educational programs at the Cooper-Hewitt Design Center in Harlem, the Enid and Lester Morse Historic Design Lecture Series at the University Club, and elsewhere. The museum on East 91st Street at Fifth Avenue is scheduled to re-open in 2014. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article last Thursday about the crossroads at which football finds itself because of increased awareness of possible long-term health risks misidentified the educational institution where Michael McCann is the director of the Sports Law Institute. It is the Vermont Law School, not the University of Vermont.

An obituary on Wednesday about Nora Ephron, the writer and filmmaker, omitted the name of a co-editor of the book ''Not Quite What I Was Planning: Six-Word Memoirs by Writers Famous and Obscure,'' in which Ms. Ephron is quoted as saying: ''Secret to life, marry an Italian.'' Besides Larry Smith, the book was also edited by Rachel Fershleiser.

Part of the beauty of fireworks is their impermanence. They are a momentary flash of beauty that fades to a memory. Unless, perhaps, you know the tricks of photographing fireworks. Kike Calvo, a photographer whose work appears in National Geographic and The New York Times, took the above shot at the Fallas celebration in Valencia, Spain. With the Fourth of July just ahead, he offered some tips so that you can preserve your fireworks for viewing all year round.

Losses on JPMorgan Chase's bungled trade could total as much as $9 billion, far exceeding earlier public estimates, according to people who have been briefed on the situation. When Jamie Dimon, the bank's chief executive, announced in May that the bank had lost $2 billion in a bet on credit derivatives, he estimated that losses could double within the next few quarters. But the red ink has been mounting in recent weeks, as the bank has been unwinding its positions, according to interviews with current and former traders and executives at the bank who asked not to be named because of investigations into the bank.

1:13 a.m. | Updated Ann Curry will step down on Thursday morning from her co-host chair on NBC's ''Today'' show, capping weeks of private negotiations with the network officials who have been trying to ease her out of the job that she has held for just over a year. Ms. Curry said in an interview with USA Today that she will address her departure on the show. ''I'm going to have to tell our viewers,'' she said. ''That's what makes me more emotional than anything. I don't want to leave them. I love them. And I will really miss them.''

An article on Monday about the response by President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan to recent allegations that insiders close to him are plundering the nation's mineral wealth, using a statement from his office, misstated part of the name of the Chinese company that along with an Afghan company had won the contract to develop the Amu Darya oil field. It is the China National Petroleum Corporation, not the Chinese National Petroleum Company.

7:11 p.m. | Updated Jim Wilson, the peripatetic, profane, pipe-smoking volunteer for Mitt Romney whose pickup truck was destroyed in a fire last week, has a new set of wheels, donated by the campaign to which he has devoted a year of his life. Mr. Romney himself presented Mr. Wilson, a 70-year-old Virginian, with a replacement vehicle during an event in Sterling, Va., on Wednesday, ensuring that Mr. Wilson can keep popping up at campaign stops in a truck festooned with dozens of giant ''Romney for President'' posters and stickers.

An obituary on Wednesday about George Randolph Hearst Jr., the former chairman of the Hearst Corporation, misstated the circumstances under which he took that post in 1996. It was after the retirement -- not death -- of his uncle, Randolph A. Hearst. (He died in 2000.)

THE Israeli-American designer Nili Lotan has trafficked in sociopolitical imagery ever since 2006, when the war in Lebanon prompted her to incorporate a gun print on fabric for dresses and scarves. In 2009, she used images of the crumbling Berlin Wall in her designs. In 2010, it was shots of '60s protest graffiti taken by the photographer Peter Simon. This season, in keeping with her focus on agents of change, Ms. Lotan reproduced an image of Bob Dylan recording his first album for Columbia Records for this sheer silk georgette tank, $315, and charmeuse cami dress, $415. Wear one and unleash the rebel poet in you. At Nili Lotan, 188 Duane Street, (212).219-8794; and 38 Main Street, East Hampton, N.Y., (631).329-8338; nililotan.com.

9 P.M. (BBC America) TWENTY TWELVE Fans of Hugh Bonneville in ''Downton Abbey'' can watch him trade his Savile Row tailcoat for spandex gym shorts and the Edwardian estate for a Canary Wharf office building in this new mockumentary series that follows the Olympic Deliverance Commission as it prepares for the London summer games. Mr. Bonneville plays Ian Fletcher, the head of deliverance, charged with overseeing a staff (Karl Theobald, Amelia Bullmore and Vincent Franklin) so inept that it's a surprise anything gets done. Olivia Colman is Sally Owen, Ian's ultraefficient and overly protective assistant, who lives in hope that one day he will notice her. And Jessica Hynes (above with Mr. Bonneville) is Siobhan Sharpe, the speed-talking public relations specialist who undoes Ian and just about everyone else in her path. The chaos begins as the team promotes ''1,000 days to go'' with a clock intended to tick down toward opening day. In Episode 2, at 9:40, dignitaries from the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics commission visit London. And in Episode 3, at 10:20, Roman ruins are discovered on the site of the aquatics center. ''The Olympian spirit is all about relentless rigor, steely self-discipline and doing the impossible,'' Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. '' 'Twenty Twelve' celebrates sloth, inattention and surrender. There should be a gold medal for that too.'' 8 P.M. (NBC) UNITED STATES OLYMPIC TRIALS Day 4 of swimming, broadcast from Omaha, features the women's 200-meter freestyle and individual medley, and the men's 200-meter butterfly.

The Seattle Opera says an anticipated $1 million budget shortfall this season will mean cuts in salaries and staff and a reshaping of its programming, with a four-opera season instead of five beginning in 2014. Opera company officials said in a press release issued Tuesday night after a board meeting that a difficult economy, along with a drop in subscription sales and major donations, have contributed to its fiscal woes. ''Given the economic situation, and our need responsibly to steward the money contributed by our community of donors and ticket-buyers, we are making some changes to our long-range plans,'' Speight Jenkins, the general director, said in the release. ''When the financial situation improves, we will move as quickly as possible to restore what we have at this time either eliminated or put on hold.''

An article on Friday about the first round of the Travelers Championship golf tournament, which featured a grouping of the three most recent major winners -- Keegan Bradley, Bubba Watson and Webb Simpson -- misstated the name Simpson's wife goes by. She is Dowd, not Dakota.

An article last Thursday about clothing worn by New York City beachgoers misidentified, in some copies, the portion of the Rockaway Peninsula where the interviews took place. It was Rockaway Beach, not Far Rockaway.

BY eliminating the middlemen, Everlane, an e-commerce-only line of high-quality basics, can sell $15 T-shirts that would likely cost quadruple that amount in department stores. On Thursday, Everlane will open a pop-up in SoHo. It's called Not a Shop, and on view will be the full collection of American-made soft cotton tees, slim leather belts, and leather and canvas bags that are all available online for under $100. But there's a twist. Walk out with an item, and you will pay a marked-up retail price ($150 for this canvas and leather backpack, say) or be directed online to buy it for $50. Clever or annoying? ''How you convey quality online has been a really interesting problem for us,'' Michael Preysman, a founder of the company, explained, an acknowledgment that many of us window-shop in stores, then buy online at a discounted price. ''At the shop you can touch and feel the product.'' We're just browsing, thank you. Not a Shop is open from June 28 to July 1 at 65 Prince Street; everlane.com.

Need to frequently copy and paste text from Web pages? If so, the ''caret browsing'' feature in some browsers can make text selection more precise. It lets you use the keyboard to grab the text instead of swiping across it with the mouse - and possibly getting text you do not want in the selection. Pressing F7 in Internet Explorer 9 turns on caret browsing; Microsoft has more information on using the feature here. Likewise, in the Firefox browser, press the F7 key and click the Yes button in the box to turn on caret browsing.

Regulators delivered the first blow in a major investigation into whether big banks had improperly set key interest rates that affected how consumers and companies borrowed money around the world. On Wednesday, Barclays agreed to pay $450 million to resolve accusations that it had tried to manipulate rates to benefit the bank's own bottom line. At the height of the financial crisis, regulators say, the big British bank reported bogus figures that in some cases had influenced a benchmark for student loans, credit cards and mortgages.

It's hard to argue with the premise that in the United States some parents take their ability to vaccinate their children lightly. Recent studies suggest that as many as 21 percent of parents in this country are delaying or refusing some or all of the recommended early childhood vaccines. That's in the United States. In India and other developing countries, educated parents seem far less relaxed about the risks that measles, mumps, rubella or pertussis could present to their children. Instead of going to great lengths to delay or avoid vaccination, as some American parents do, mothers in the developing world may struggle to get to clinics to get the required vaccinations.

Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey promised a have-your-cake-and-eat-it-too budget for next year, one that would make the state's pension payments, increase money for schools, provide drug treatment for nonviolent criminals, restore tax credits for the working poor and give every taxpayer a 10 percent income tax cut. At $32 billion, the proposal for the next fiscal year -- unveiled in February -- included the biggest spending increase of any governor in the country. But it was based on the most optimistic revenue projections in the country, too, assuming that taxes and fees paid to the state would rise 7.3 percent.

WITH the UV index as high as it is, it's a good thing sun visors are having a moment. They first caught our eye in the Givenchy 2012 resort collection, in which Riccardo Tisci accessorized his looks with crocodile-trimmed visors. They were also on the spring runway at Marc by Marc Jacobs. And they're not going away anytime soon: a silvery futuristic visor punctuated every look of the Alexander McQueen fall show. Here is a selection of accessible summery styles that will both shield your face and keep you presentably chic. Really, though, anything is chicer than leather skin. From top: Helen Kaminski striped visor with an adjustable tie, $128 at helenkaminski.com; Eugenia Kim straw and horsehair visor, $125 at eugeniakim.com; Eric Javits raffia visor with a Velcro closure, $145 at Saks Fifth Avenue; Eric Javits wide-brimmed visor, $175 at Bloomingdale's; Asos Perspex visor, $16.57 at asos.com; Barbara Feinman crochet raffia and leather visor cap, $210 at Barbara Feinman Millinery, 66 East Seventh Street, barbarafeinmanmillinery.com.

An article on Wednesday about News Corporation's potential spinoff of its publishing operations misspelled the surname and reversed the titles of an executive considered a candidate to head the new company. He is Robert Thomson, not Thompson, and he is managing editor of The Wall Street Journal and editor in chief of its parent company, Dow Jones & Company.

The stop-and-frisk has emerged as one of the New York Police Department's favored tactics for fighting crime in troubled neighborhoods, but based on reader comments submitted to nytimes.com, the policy is wildly unpopular with readers of The New York Times. An article Wednesday in The Times about the experiences of 100 New Yorkers who said they had been stopped by the police drew more than 500 comments, most of them critical of the practice or of the Bloomberg administration's use of it.

Don't blame me, Dewayne Wise said, ''It's not my fault.'' He had not pretended his way to first base when an inside pitch hit his bat, as Derek Jeter had in 2010. He had not yelled at a third baseman in Toronto, helping to cause an infield fly to land safely, as Alex Rodriguez had in 2007.

A rare copy of the Emancipation Proclamation, the document signed by President Abraham Lincoln during the Civil War that freed tens of thousands of slaves and laid the foundation for the end of slavery, sold for $2.085 million at auction in New York City on Tuesday. The sell, which included a ''buyer's premium'' or commission of $235,000, is the second-highest price ever paid for a Lincoln-signed proclamation. Another copy of the document, once owned by Robert Kennedy, sold for $3.8 million two years ago. The copy sold on Tuesday was auctioned at the Robert Siegel Auction Galleries and went to David Rubenstein, managing director of The Carlyle Group investment firm. The American seller remained anonymous.

A multiyear, global investigation into the setting of interest rates has focused on often complex trades in the financial centers of New York, London and Tokyo. But the accusations in the case have real-life consequences for consumers and businesses in the United States. Banks around the world use financial benchmarks to set the interest rates on many of the loans they make. The most prominent of those benchmarks is the London interbank offered rate, Libor.

A 230-foot section of a road built by the Romans nearly 2,000 years ago has been discovered by archaeologists in Thessaloniki, Greece's second-largest city, during excavations for a new subway system, the Associated Press reported. The marble-paved road, once the city's main travel artery, was unearthed during excavations in the northern port city for the subway project due to be completed in 2016. Now the road will be raised and put on permanent display when the subway opens.

EPHRON--Nora. The Board of Trustees, artists, and staff of The Public Theater mourn the passing of our dear friend and long-time Board member, Nora Ephron. The Public is deeply grateful for Nora's devoted service and deeply saddened by the loss of a great talent. Nora's passion for her craft touched all who knew her. Her boundless generosity, keen wit, and ability to strike right to the heart of every story will be greatly missed. We offer our deepest sympathies to her husband, Nicholas Pileggi, and children, Jacob and Max Bernstein. Oskar Eustis, Artistic Director Patrick Willingham, Executive Director Warren Spector, Chairman

DIGAN--Marjorie, passed away peacefully June 27, 2012 surrounded by her loved ones. She was born May 22, 1928 in St. Joseph Michigan. She was the daughter of Marjorie and James McKeon. She was predeceased by her husband Richard, son Michael Francis and brother John McKeon. Marjorie is survived by children Richard (Karol), Timothy, Marjorie Dwyer (Matthew), Barbara Zweig (Martin), Matthew (Kate), Terence (Chris), James and 15 grandchildren and her sister Mary Jane Gray, and many nieces and nephews. Marjorie was a longtime resident of Garden City. She lived most of that time on Salisbury Avenue and more recently at The Wyndham Condominium. She was a graduate of St. Mary's College in South Bend, Indiana, graduating with a degree in Chemistry. Marge worked in the Garden City School System (Homestead School) for many years. As a member of The Cherry Valley Golf Club, she was an avid golfer and served as a past Chairman of The Ladies 9 Hole Group. Marge loved her family, bridge group, serving as Eucharistic Minister at St. Joseph's RC Church, volunteering at the Garden City Exchange and her many friends. Wake will be held at the Fairchild Funeral Home, Franklin Avenue, Garden City from 2-4pm and 7-9pm on Friday, June 29th. A funeral mass will be celebrated on Saturday, June 30th at St. Joseph's RC Church, Garden City at 9:30am. In her memory, play a round of golf, a game of bridge, or spend a day in a garden surrounded by family and loved ones and remember her with a smile.

Over the past five years or so, the Romanian Cultural Institute has become an important force in global cultural exchanges, promoting writers, artists and especially the critically acclaimed cinema movement known as the Romanian New Wave. But the coalition government that recently came to power in Romania has ordered an end to that international focus as it tightens its political control over the institute, actions that have set off protests among arts groups throughout Europe and the United States. Under an ''emergency decree'' handed down on June 14, the institute, a non-partisan entity that formerly reported directly to the president, now responds to a Senate riven by partisanship. Its new mandate: to direct its activities at the Romanian diaspora community. As a result, collaborations with American arts institutions - including Lincoln Center, co-sponsor of an annual Romanian film festival, and publishing houses specializing in translated literature -- could be in jeopardy. And in recent days, organizations including the Museum of Modern Art, Film Forum and Melville House have sent letters to the new prime minister and other government authorities, urging them rescind the measure.

TOKYO -- To say that Yui Kimura is a distressed investor might be an understatement: She is a small shareholder in the operator of the nuclear power plant at Fukushima, Tokyo Electric Power, whose shares have lost nine-tenths of their value. Now, she would like the company to at least face up to its responsibilities to the more than 100,000 people who have been driven from their homes after the tsunami disaster. She co-sponsored four resolutions at the annual shareholders' meeting Wednesday, including one demanding that the company decommission all of its nuclear reactors.

Brown--Chilton Pleasants, 89, of Brooklyn, NY died on June 27, 2012 following a long illness. Survived by his wife of 61 years, Mary Louise, sons Randall of Felton, California; Hubert of Santa Cruz, California; Curtis of Coconut Grove, Florida; and Gregory of Brooklyn; sister Katherine Lee (Kitty) Burkhart of Bloomington, Indiana; and six grandchildren. Arrangements will be private.

JACKSON--Renee Wile (February 5, 1919 - June 27, 2012), psychiatric social worker and psychotherapist, after a short illness. Beloved wife of Edgar, she is survived by nephew and niece Jerome and Judith, great-niece and nephew Jessica and Barnaby, stepchildren Ned and Judy, as well as devoted in-laws Catherine, Ron and Sofi and a host of long-time friends and clients. The American wrestler Stephany Lee, who celebrated her Olympic trials victory in Iowa two months ago by marrying her longtime girlfriend, has been bumped from the team for testing positive for marijuana. Lee, 27, received a one-year suspension from the United States Anti-Doping Agency and will miss the London Games. She will very likely be replaced in the 158-pound class by Ali Bernard, a 2008 Olympian who lost to Lee in the final at the trials in Iowa City.

A news analysis article on Tuesday about the impact of the Supreme Court's decision on Arizona's immigration enforcement law misstated the number of joint agreements with Arizona police that the Department of Homeland Security rescinded in response to the court's ruling. The department halted agreements with seven Arizona police departments under which federal officials had authorized state and local officers to check immigration status and to detain illegal immigrants during stops or investigations. The department did not suspend all joint agreements in Arizona under the program, which is known as 287g. Homeland Security officials say four agreements remain in force; they allow Arizona police to determine the immigration status of foreigners held in jails.

SANFORD--Bruce, on June 26, 2012. Loving brother of John. Uncle of Jon and Paul. For many years he ran his own executive search company. Bruce enjoyed music and loved to sing. He also mentored people struggling with substance abuse issues. He was a loving friend to many. Services: Sunday, 9:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, has received a major donation of Benin bronzes and ivories, a gift that promises to transform its African collection. The works, from the collector Robert Owen Lehman, include 28 bronzes and 6 ivories, which will go on display at the museum in late 2013, joining the lone Benin work, a terra-cotta head, now in the permanent collection.

ELION--Burton, at age 75, died peacefully surrounded by family. Retired partner of coffee distributing company and a proud member of Jewish War Veterans. He is survived by his sister Sheila Shaw and his children Beverly Fein (Steven), Jodi Brenner, Jarett Elion (Lisa) and his wife in spirit Shirley Kesselman. His children, family and friends mourn his passing. Funeral services on Friday, June 29th at 12 noon at Temple Beth El in Chappaqua, NY. Interment will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

The Side Effects column on Tuesday, about how scientists choose -- and often become enchanted with -- the creatures they study, misspelled the given name of the behavioral scientist who collaborated with the biologist Edward O. Wilson to write ''The Ants.'' He is Bert Hölldobler, not Berth.

In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106.

An article on Wednesday about a Food and Drug Administration meeting on monitoring the risk of all-metal hip implants misstated the year the agency ordered five makers of the devices to do follow-up studies on recipients. It was May 2011, not 2001.

The City Council approved a zoning change on Thursday that is meant to stop the proliferation of impersonal bank branches and other large storefronts along the major commercial avenues of the Upper West Side. The new rules, which were developed by the City Planning Department in response to requests from the local community board and the local councilwoman, Gale A. Brewer, limit street-level storefronts on Broadway, Amsterdam Avenue and Columbus Avenue to a maximum width of 40 feet, with banks held to 25 feet.

American Ballet Theater's 2012 fall season at New York City Center, which runs from Oct. 16 to 20, will include the premiere of a new work by Alexei Ratmansky, the company's artist in residence, Ballet Theater said. Set to Symphony No. 9 by Dmitri Shostakovich, the ballet, which will have its world premiere on Oct. 18, will be the first of three new one-act ballets by Mr. Ratmansky to Shostakovich. All three will be presented as an evening-length program during the company's 2013 spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House. The three works will feature scenery by George Tsypin and costumes by Keso Dekker.

Paul Schimmel, the chief curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, and one of the most respected authorities on postwar Los Angeles art, is leaving the museum, according to its board. No explanation was given for Mr. Schimmel's departure, though it was known in the museum world that he and MOCA's director, Jeffrey Deitch, had a contentious working relationship. The board issued a brief statement describing the decision as ''amicable'' and saying that a more detailed explanation would be issued Friday.

The New York law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore announced on Thursday that it had elected C. Allen Parker as its next chief, succeeding Evan R. Chesler, who will become chairman. Mr. Parker, a corporate lawyer who has spent his career with Cravath, will assume his leadership post in January. His official title at Cravath, an old-line firm founded in 1819, will be presiding partner.

Federal agents on Thursday arrested four employees of a now-defunct Texas medical equipment supplier who are accused of bilking Medicare and Medicaid out of millions of dollars via fake claims, including some made on behalf of dead people, according to court documents.
TALBOT--Donald E. Always. Roslyn and James

One of the theater producers aiming Nora Ephron's new play ''Lucky Guy'' for Broadway confirmed on Thursday that he is going forward with the show, a bio-drama about the New York newspaper columnist Mike McAlary. Ms. Ephron, a celebrated humorist and Oscar-nominated screenwriter, died on Tuesday at the age of 71 from pneumonia brought on by acute myeloid leukemia. In a statement the producer, Colin Callender, expressed condolences to Ms. Ephron's family and praised her ''incomparable talent, wit and heart.'' Mr. Callender, a former president of HBO Films, then added, ''We are honored to be part of her legacy and remain committed to seeing her magnificent work 'Lucky Guy' shine on Broadway and can think of no more fitting tribute to her extraordinary writing and remarkable body of work.''

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about a controversial play during the Yankees' victory over the Cleveland Indians on Tuesday in which Yankees left fielder Dewayne Wise was mistakenly credited with an out on a foul fly ball misstated, in some editions, the inning the play occurred. As the article correctly noted, it was the seventh inning, not the eighth.

DUKEK--Nancy Bowman Williams, 96, died June 13 at Winchester Gardens, Maplewood, NJ. She was the widow of William G. Dukek and Roger W. Williams. She was born in Harrisburg, PA, daughter of Ernest L. Bowman and Gertrude Horning. She graduated Phi Beta Kappa with Honors from Ohio Wesleyan University and received a Master of Science in Retailing from NYU. She owned and managed Dukay Travel in Summit, NJ, and was active in Fortnightly Club, AAUW, and League of Women Voters. Survivors are a brother David F. Bowman; her children, Cynthia W. Hinchman, Todd R. Williams, Janet B. W. Williams, and Patricia D. Williams; eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Service at the Unitarian Church in Summit, NJ, Sunday, July 1, 2pm. Donations may be sent to the Unitarian Church of Summit.

MULLER--Edward M.,age 76, of Westport, CT and Manhattan, the beloved husband of Jane Muller, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, June 27, 2012 with his family by his side. A native of Scotland, Ed made New York his home since 1952 and in 1980 relocated to Westport. His passions for science and knowledge were pursued at the Cooper Union and later at NYU where he received his MBA. His most notable professional achievements included his work with Halcon and most recently Metabolix. Ed will be remembered by his family, friends and colleagues for his thoughtful dependability and uncompromising generosity, amassed over a life well traveled and stylishly spent. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his loving daughters, Gwyneth Muller of Manhattan and Lara Muller and her fiance, Seth Estep of Alexandria, VA. He was preceded in death by his mother, Catherine MacKay. Friends are invited to greet the family on Sunday, July 1, 2012 from 1- 4pm at the Shaughnessey Banks Funeral Home, 50 Reef Rd. Fairfield, CT 06824. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, because Ed wouldn't want the fuss, the family asks for donations in his name to be made to the American Chemical Society 1155 16th St. NW, Washington, D.C. 20036. To send an online condolence, please visit www.shaughnesseybanks.com

The Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr., faced a political backlash on Thursday, a day after the British bank agreed to pay more than $450 million to settle accusations that it had attempted to manipulate key interest rates. Several current and former politicians took aim at Barclays over the matter on Thursday, with some calling for him to resign. The cacophony of criticism comes as Mr. Diamond deals with shareholder opposition about his pay.

KLINGENSTEIN--Sharon. The Board of Directors of The Sherry-Netherland and its staff want to express our sincere condolences to our Board member and former President, Frederick Klingenstein and his entire family on the passing of his wife Sharon. Sharon was an esteemed friend and neighbor to all who live and work at The Sherry-Netherland and she will be missed.

11:54 p.m. | Updated On Friday morning, Savannah Guthrie is scheduled to be sitting beside Matt Lauer on the ''Today'' show - and once again, NBC's ability to pull off talent transitions will be put to the test. Ms. Guthrie is expected to succeed Ann Curry on ''Today,'' a hugely popular but now highly vulnerable morning show that is a profit center for NBCUniversal and its parent company Comcast.

An article on Saturday about contract negotiations between American Airlines and its pilots' union rendered incorrectly part of the name of the employer of Hunter Keay, an airline analyst who commented on the issue. It is Wolfe Trahan, not Wolf Trahan.

David Beckham revealed Thursday that he would not be picked for Britain's soccer team for this summer's London Olympics. ''Everyone knows how much playing for my country has always meant to me, so I would have been honored to have been part of this unique Team GB squad,'' Beckham said in a statement to Britain's Press Association.

The Deal Professor column on the DealBook page on Wednesday, about proposed changes to money market mutual funds, misidentified the government agency that pledged $50 billion to backstop these funds in 2008. It is the Treasury Department, not the Federal Reserve.

KLUGMAN--Werner. Former president of the American Ethical Union and Landers Segal Color Co., Werner died on June 14, 2012 at the age of 92. His humor, sense of adventure, and above all, unwavering love of those around him marked all that he did. Service: June 30 at the Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64 Street, New York, NY at 6pm.

10 P.M. (13) MY REINCARNATION (2011) ''POV'' begins its 25th season with this chronicle of the relationship between Chogyal Namkhai Norbu, a master of the Dzogchen tradition of Buddhism who has lived in Italy for a half-century, and his Western-born son, Yeshi. Recognized since the age of 5 as the reincarnation of his father's uncle Khyentse, a Dzogchen master himself, Yeshi (above right, with his father) has instead embraced the modern world despite the hundreds of followers in Tibet who have long hungered for his arrival. Now in his 30s, he has a family of his own and a career in information-technology management. The director Jennifer Fox followed the family for more than 20 years and was granted access to the Dalai Lama to tell this story of love, spiritual awakening and destiny. ''Especially in the early footage Chogyal Namkhai Norbu is an engaging, charismatic figure; by the end Yeshi is finding his own footing, able to relate to a young, wired-in audience,'' Daniel M. Gold wrote in The New York Times. '' 'My Reincarnation' makes a pretty strong case: When the family business is enlightenment, listen to your dad.'' 8:30 A.M. (Bravo) TRANSAMERICA (2005) Felicity Huffman plays Bree, a preoperative transsexual who, though still technically a man, passes for a woman through the use of tasteful pink outfits, meticulously applied makeup and a breathy voice. But before the gender-reassignment surgery Bree must tie up a loose end and soon is on the road with the previously unknown son (Kevin Zegers) she fathered when she was known as Stanley. ''In this debut feature by Duncan Tucker, who wrote and directed it, 'Transamerica' sets out to affirm Bree's dignity, to liberate her and others like her from any association with camp or freakishness,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times. ''That the film succeeds without slipping too far into sentimentality or didacticism is in no small measure the result of Ms. Huffman's wit and grace. (She may also be the first film actor of either sex to do frontal nudity, in a single movie, as both.)''

LOS ANGELES - While the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science tries out new rules for its documentary Oscars, DocuWeeks - a showcase that helps documentarians without commercial distribution qualify for the awards - is forging ahead. The International Documentary Association, which sponsors DocuWeeks, said this year's program would include 17 feature films and 11 shorts. The screenings are scheduled Aug. 3-23 at the IFC Center in New York, and from Aug. 10-30 at the Laemmle NoHo 7 theater in Los Angeles. The offerings portray suffering humanity, as in ''Drought,'' about an annual search for water in northeast Mexico; unusual passions, as in ''Digital Dharma: One Man's Mission to Save a Culture,'' about a Mormon from Utah who struggled to preserve Tibetan texts; and heartwarming aspiration, as in ''Once in a Lullaby,'' about singing schoolchildren.

Predeceased by his wife Zena, he is survived and will be dearly missed by his children Robert (Karen), Ellen (Michael), and Paul; his adoring grandchildren Samantha, Valerie, Charlotte, Jonathan, Diana, James, Emily, Meagan, and Gillian; and his dear friends sister-in-law Gloria and brother-in-law Henry. A renowned practitioner of medicine for more than 40 years, Dr. Brody leaves behind a legacy of genuine caring and devotion that will also be long remembered by the many patients whose lives he touched. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Mt. Vernon, NY on Friday, June 29th at 12:00 noon.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Thursday about Harry Levinson, a psychologist who demonstrated a link between job conditions and emotional health, misidentified the person who began visiting corporations to study their treatment of workers. It was Dr. Levinson -- not William C. Menninger, his superior at the Menninger Clinic.

The New York law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore announced on Thursday that it had elected C. Allen Parker as its next chief, succeeding Evan R. Chesler, who will become chairman. Mr. Parker, a corporate lawyer who has spent his career with Cravath, will assume his leadership post in January. His official title at Cravath, an old-line firm founded in 1819, will be presiding partner.

LITTLE FAITH Investors are still not convinced that Glencore International will pull off its $24 billion deal to buy the piece of the mining giant Xstrata it does not already own. Late on Wednesday, the companies made changes to the incentive pay for Xstrata executives to appease shareholders who have said the bid was too low and the retention packages were too high. But shares of both companies fell more than 1 percent on Thursday.

REILLY--Ellen Chapman, known as Lukie to all, passed away on June 20 after a four-year battle with Multiple Myeloma. She was much loved and will be missed. Born February 3, 1935 in New York, she grew up in New Hope, PA and Manhattan. She attended Friends Seminary in Greenwich Village and graduated from St. Mary's in the Mountains (The White Mountain School) in New Hampshire. In 1953, Lukie was accepted to attend the Rhode Island School of Design and forever after pursued her creative passions. She studied art in Paris and was a student of the famed sculptor, Louise Nevelson. She found diverse inspiration working as an editor for Mademoiselle magazine and as a dress designer for Tanner of North Carolina. In the months following her 60th birthday, Lukie discovered that she was also a supremely talented writer and one of her essays eventually appeared in the Best American Essays collection of 1997 published by Houghton Mifflin. For many years, she owned an art gallery in Charleston, SC and was herself a decorated watercolorist, winning The James Sudem Award from the National Academy of Fine Art in 1980. She is survived by three brothers, William, John and Alexander, her twins, Jane and Anthony and five grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for July 13 at four o'clock at the Westhampton Presbyterian Church in Quiogue, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors without Borders P.O. Box 5030 Hagerstown, MD 21741-5030.

Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center will become more accessible to people with disabilities under a court settlement reached Wednesday between the performing arts center and the United States attorney's office in Manhattan. Civil rights investigators for the office had brought a lawsuit against Lincoln Center for failing to comply with the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990 at Avery Fisher, home to the New York Philharmonic.

KESICH--Professor Veselin Kesich, an expert on Eastern Orthodox theology, early Christianity and Serbian Church history, died Tuesday at his home. He was 91. Dr. Kesich was a professor emeritus at St. Vladimir's Orthodox Theological Seminary & Sarah Lawrence College, and the author of numerous books and articles. He was predeceased by his beloved wife and intellectual partner, Lydia Weston Kesich. Donations may be made to the Professor Veselin Kesich Scholarship Fund at St. Vladimir's. Funeral 10:30, July 2, Holy Trinity, Portland, Maine

There are lots of taxes that people pay only if they buy something -- sales taxes, taxes on cigarettes and taxes on airline tickets among them. But by calling the penalty for not buying health insurance a tax, the Supreme Court on Thursday effectively created a tax that people will pay only if they do not buy something.

LONDON - At Christie's post-war and contemporary art auction here on Wednesday evening - an event aptly described by the super dealer Larry Gagosian as ''Masterpiece Theatre'' - collectors from around the world dropped millions of dollars on works by many of the major names of the 20th century, and record prices were set for two of them: Yves Klein and Jean-Michel Basquiat. Hoping to capture the attention of both established collectors and new-rich ones from places like the Middle East, Russia and Asia, Christie's had marshaled its international connections, pulling in exceptionally strong artworks for an evening auction like few others London has seen. The sale totaled $207.3 million, against an estimate of $160.1 million to $216.9 million, the highest total of any auction in the category that Christie's has held in Europe.

The State of the Art column on Thursday, a review of the Sony Cyber-shot DSC-RX100 camera, misstated the size of the camera's sensor relative to that of the Olympus XZ-1 and the Canon PowerShot S100. It is two and a half times as large as the XZ-1's sensor and nearly three times as large as the S100's -- not four times as large as each. The column also misidentified, in some editions, the brand of the XZ-1 as Panasonic rather than Olympus.

RITTERMAN--Ettie, on Tuesday, Ettie Fried Ritterman, the last, but not least loved, of the eight children of Samuel and Rachael Fried passed on at the age of 98. She leaves behind countless memories, more love than one heart can hold, and the affection of all who were privileged to have known her. Following the untimely death of her husband Nat, she alternately served as a special education teacher, a retail store operator, watch assembler, a union shop steward and film booker for Warner Brothers. Surviving are her son and daughter-in-law Stuart and Sharen Ritterman, grand children Moriah Richardson and Joshua Ritterman, and great grandchildren Kelsey and Emma Richardson. Ettie served as surrogate mother, adviser, and confident to countless nieces and nephews. In her last days, she would recite a litany of their names, lest she forget one. She never did. Forgive us if we fail to list them all here. Know that she loved each and every one of you. As per her wishes, her remains have been left to the Medical School of Texas A&M University. In lieu of flowers, please give a needy child a chocolate bar.

A number of years ago, it was time to buy a new road bike. There was one that I had always wanted, but it cost more than I could afford. I remember thinking that I should just settle for a cheaper bike, one that I didn't really want but told myself would be fine. But I decided instead to wait until I could afford the bike I really wanted.

Anheuser-Busch InBev agreed on Friday to buy the half of the Mexican brewer Grupo Modelo it does not already own for $20.1 billion, the latest deal in the fast-consolidating global brewing industry. Anheuser-Busch InBev, whose brands include Budweiser and Stella Artois, said it will pay $9.15 for each share of Grupo Modelo, a 30 percent premium to the company's closing share price on June 22 before the deal was first reported.

A Political Memo article on Thursday about the proposed budget of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey for fiscal year 2013 misstated the anticipated percentage increase in revenue and also overstated a comparison of the state's revenue projections. The governor anticipated that revenue would rise 7.2 percent, not 7.3 percent. And his projection is the second most optimistic in the country (behind California's), not the most optimistic.

Eleven times your final working salary. That's how much an average worker needs beyond Social Security, from sources like personal savings and employer benefits, to pay for retirement at age 65, a new analysis from the benefits consultant Aon Hewitt finds. The estimate takes into account inflation and postretirement medical costs. And it is based on the retiree's continuing the same standard of living.

Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes, whose high-profile marriage has been tasty fodder for the Hollywood celebrity media, are getting divorced. After five years of marriage, Ms. Holmes, 33, filed for divorce from Mr. Cruise on Thursday, said Bert Fields, the actor's lawyer. Mr. Cruise, 49, who years ago proclaimed his love for Ms. Holmes by jumping on Oprah Winfrey's couch on national television, told The Associated Press through a spokeswoman that he is ''deeply saddened and is concentrating on his three children.''

Coty filed to go public on Friday, revisiting a strategic plan it had formed before trying to buy Avon Products for $10.7 billion this year. The beauty products maker hired Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch, JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley to lead its initial offering. While the company listed a $700 million fund-raising target to determine listing fees, people briefed on the matter had previously said that it might seek to raise up to $1 billion.

Bristol-Myers Squibb agreed late on Friday to buy Amylin Pharmaceuticals, the maker of a promising new diabetes drug, in a complicated deal that is valued at about $7 billion. To help finance the transaction, Bristol-Myers is teaming up with AstraZeneca, which will pay about $3.4 billion in cash and will share in the profits from Amylin's sales.

An article in some editions on Friday about the City Council's approval of a zoning change that limits the widths of new storefronts at street level on the Upper West Side described incorrectly one of the restrictions. While banks will be limited to 25 feet on Broadway and Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues, and storefronts will be limited to 40 feet on Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, it is not the case that storefronts besides banks will be limited on Broadway. (The restrictions generally apply from 72nd to 110th Street on Broadway and Amsterdam, and from 72nd to 87th Street on Columbus.)

Charlie Sheen is still ''winning.'' The debut of his new series, ''Anger Management,'' was the most-watched series premiere in FX history in total viewers. The premiere episode, at 9:00 p.m. Thursday, drew 5.47 million total viewers, including 2.65 million in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the category most beloved by advertisers, according to Nielsen. The episode that immediately followed did even better, with 5.74 million total viewers. Both episodes beat every other program on broadcast and cable television on Thursday in the 18-to-49 category.

An arbitrator on Friday halted a central element of the Bloomberg administration's plans for closing and reopening 24 schools, saying its method for overhauling the staff at those institutions violated labor contracts. The arbitrator's decision, issued two days after public schools closed for the summer, was a setback for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's vision of how those schools, deemed as failing, should look beginning in September. It also put in jeopardy nearly $60 million in federal aid for struggling schools, officials said.

An article on Friday about the Supreme Court's ruling on the health care law misstated the terms of an increase in the Medicare tax, to take effect in 2013, that was part of a second health care bill passed in 2010. The higher rate of 3.8 percent will apply only to incomes higher than $200,000 per year, or $250,000 for married taxpayers filing joint returns, and will be applied to investment income as well as ordinary income. Those earning less will continue to be taxed at the rate of 2.9 percent, which will apply only to earned income, as it does now. The article also gave an incorrect source for an anecdote about Frances Perkins, then the labor secretary, and Justice Harlan F. Stone in 1934 when the Roosevelt administration was seeking a justification for the Social Security program. The anecdote was taken from a a Social Security history on the agency's Web site that was forwarded to The Times by Matt Fink, a biographer. It was not related by Mr. Fink himself.

Peter B. Madoff, the former No. 2 executive at Bernard L. Madoff Securities, stood before a judge on Friday and admitted to committing numerous crimes. He avoided paying taxes on tens of millions of dollars in income, he said. He put his wife on the firm payroll even though she never worked there. He submitted false filings to securities regulators.

Construction began on the new, 17-story, $325 million Fiterman Hall of the Borough of Manhattan Community College in 2009. It is to start receiving students and faculty members this fall, making it a three-year project, more or less.

It's Weaver and Durang - together again. Lincoln Center Theater announced on Friday that Sigourney Weaver will once again work with Christopher Durang, as she stars in the New York premiere of his new play, ''Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike.'' Ms. Weaver met Mr. Durang when they were classmates at the Yale School of Drama in the 1970s and has previously appeared in his plays including ''Beyond Therapy,'' ''The Nature and Purpose of the Universe'' and ''Sex and Longing.'' The play sets characters and themes from Chekhov in present day Bucks County, Pa. Other cast members include Genevieve Angelson, Shalita Grant, Billy Magnussen, Kristine Nielsen and David Hyde Pierce. Directed by Nicholas Martin, the play is to begin performances October 25 at Lincoln Center's Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. Lincoln Center Theater is producing the play in association with the McCarter Theater, where it was commissioned and will run from Sept. 7 through Oct. 7

Memorial donations may be made to StoryCorps' Richard Isay Memorial LGBT Initiative. www.storycorps.org.

7:38 p.m. | Updated An investor group led by Sony closed its $2.2 billion acquisition of EMI Music Publishing on Friday, creating a giant force in music publishing, the unglamorous but lucrative side of the music business that deals with songwriting rights. The deal will give Sony control over a catalog of more than two million songs, and a global market share of about 31 percent, nine points above that of Universal, its closest competitor, according to an estimate by the trade publication Music and Copyright.

It gives Hollywood hairstylists only a whisker of added industry respect, but there is celebrating nonetheless in the celebrity blow-out and bun-knotting world: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences this week decreed that the Oscar for makeup will henceforth be called the ''makeup and hairstyling award.'' Hairstylists have long grumbled about being lumped into the makeup category, asserting that they deserve their own little gold man. Last August, however, Ted Gibson, who has worked on the heads of stars like Angelina Jolie and Anne Hathaway, started a public campaign on Facebook. (''We need an Oscar for hair!'')

Adams Jr., a lawyer based in Geneva, and Matthew Barzun, the Obama campaign's national finance chairman and a former United States ambassador to Sweden.

10 P.M. (Sundance) THE QUIET AMERICAN (2002) Michael Caine portrays Thomas Fowler, a British journalist who flees a loveless marriage in England to live in Southeast Asia and report on the Vietnamese fight for independence from French colonial rule. He becomes infatuated with Phuong (Do Thi Hai Yen, above with Mr. Caine), a beautiful former taxi dancer, in a relationship that can last only as long as he keeps his job. Then Alden Pyle (Brendan Fraser), an American intelligence officer, comes along. And he wants Phuong too. ''Fowler may be the richest character of Mr. Caine's screen career,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this adaptation of Graham Greene's novel, by Phillip Noyce. ''This great English actor gives a performance of astonishing understatement whose tone wavers delicately between irony and sadness.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Fred de Sam Lazaro reports from Niger, where the government and relief organizations are trying to fend off mass starvation while increasing tree vegetation, so that the country will be less imperiled by drought.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, which filed for bankruptcy last year, jolting the classical music world, announced on Thursday that its reorganization plan had been approved by a federal bankruptcy court and that it expects to emerge from Chapter 11 by the end of July. The filing on April 16, 2011, was unprecedented among the country's major orchestras; several smaller orchestras have faced similar trouble in recent years. The Philadelphia Orchestra had endured years of declining ticket sales and donations, causing mounting losses. It saw the filing as a way to eliminate pension costs and uncertainties as well as reduce musician salaries and operating bills.

An article on June 14 about the way in which broccoli entered the debate over the federal health care law misstated the source of figures for donations to the Reason Foundation, a research organization that played a role in promoting the idea that the law was akin to forcing Americans to buy broccoli. The figures came from the most recent filings of the donors, the David H. Koch Charitable Foundation and the Sarah Scaife Foundation; they were not disclosed by the Reason Foundation.

KATZ--Selma. Selma Rebecca (Hersh) Katz born on January 31, 1913 in Waterbury, Connecticut passed away, peacefully, in her sleep, on Thursday evening, June 28, 2012, at Memorial Hospital in Colorado Springs, Colorado. Selma spent most of her childhood and adult life in New York City, living between the Lower East Side of Manhattan where she was an early resident of 91 Orchard Street, now the home of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, and then moving to Brooklyn and subsequently to Queens. She was married on March 9, 1930 to Joseph Katz (deceased). Together, they are survived by a legacy of their seven children, Stanley Katz, Roslyn Padgett, Larry Katz, Carol Sperber, Irwin Katz, Gary Katz and Ellen Taubman, sixteen grandchildren, eighteen great-grandchildren and seven great-great grandchildren, with another expected, ranging between the ages of 81 years and 18 months old. Selma was also an active member of the Flushing Chapter of Hadassah. Services for Selma will be held in Colorado Springs on Sunday, June 30. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Selma Katz Preservation Fund at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 91 Orchard Street, New York, NY 10002. Funds will be used to preserve the now-National Landmark tenement in which she grew up.

FACHE--Elliot Jay Simon, passed peacefully on June 28, 2012 at the age of 72, following a long illness. He leaves behind his beloved wife Maxine (Fertel), loving daughter Joy and future son-in-law Larry Palmer, devoted step children Gerry and Joan Marie dellaBadia, Lewis and Caroline Lilla, Beth Piscitelli, cherished grandchildren JoAnn, Anthony, Richard, David, Amanda, Jessica, Alexa, Julianna, Bianca, Mario and Umberto, and his daughter Marni and her husband Greg Blake. A warm and loving man, Elliot had many friends and helped all who came his way. The courage he showed throughout his illness brought strength to us all. His greatest legacy will be the lessons taught to his extended family about trust, respect and accountability. Contributions in his honor should be made to the NYU Langone Medical Center Cancer Center. Funeral services Sunday, July 1st 10:00am at "Schwartz Bros.- Jeffer" 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76th Rd.) Forest Hills, NY.

The TV Watch column on Friday, about Ann Curry's final appearance as a host on NBC's ''Today'' show, referred erroneously to a highlight reel of Ms. Curry. The highlight video was available on the show's Web site; it was not shown on the television show Thursday and should not have been included as part of the critique of Thursday's show. The highlight reel was created last year, when Ms. Curry started in her role as host, not in connection with her departure.

Lauryn Hill, the Grammy-winning singer, has pleaded guilty in New Jersey to charges that she did not pay income taxes for three years running, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Hill, whose solo debut album in 1998 established her as a major figure in hip-hop and R&B, admitted in federal court in Newark on Friday that she had not filed tax returns from 2005 to 2007, a period during which she earned more than $1.5 million. She faces a maximum of one year in prison on each count. Ms. Hill, 37, of South Orange, N.J., has kept a low profile since she put out the critically acclaimed ''Miseducation of Lauryn Hill'' in 1998, focusing instead on raising her six children. She did make an appearance at Hot 97's Summer Jam concert this year. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

In its never-ending quest to find ways to circumvent corporate and governmental power, WikiLeaks has announced that it is getting into the music business, releasing a CD called ''Beat the Blockade'' that is chock-full of songs about this whistle-blowing Web site's struggles with Washington and American banks. Proceeds from the sale of the album will go to keeping the Web site afloat in the face of decisions by several American financial companies -- Visa, MasterCard, Bank of America, Western Union and PayPal -- to stop processing payments for WikiLeaks, the group said in a statement on Thursday. The companies' decisions, 19 months ago, have made it difficult for the site to collect online donations from supporters.

Nearly half of Americans say they lack enough emergency savings to cover three months of expenses, according to a new survey from Bankrate.com. Still, Bankrate noted that a similar poll taken in 2006 found that 61 percent of Americans lacked a three-month cushion. So the recent findings suggest that the financial crisis persuaded more Americans of the importance of savings.

Bobby Richardson, who was scheduled to attend Sunday's Old-Timers' Day at Yankee Stadium, played his entire career in pinstripes, from 1955 to 1966. A seven-time All-Star second baseman, he won five Gold Glove awards. Richardson remains the only player from the losing team to win the World Series Most Valuable Player award (in 1960 against the Pittsburgh Pirates). He played in seven World Series, including a record 30 consecutive games, and he won championships, in 1958, '61 and '62.

From a worker's-eye view, it continues to be the case that one of the best forms of security anyone can get against bad conditions at work is a credible right of exit. Even relatively modest licensing requirements make it very difficult to quit the job you have. After all, if you quit, you'll have no income while you go about getting yourself licensed. But as long as you're working, family responsibilities may make it impossible for you to go through the process. MATTHEW YGLESIAS, posted on slate.com

PULASKI--Charles, of Phoenix, Arizona passed away on June 21, 2012 at age 70. A 1964 graduate of Yale College, he received an LL.B. degree from Yale Law School in 1967. He served on the faculties of the University of Iowa College of Law (1972-1980) and Arizona State University College of Law (1980-1986), and later became a senior tax partner at Snell & Wilmer in Phoenix, Arizona. He was a loving husband of 47 years to Linda, father to Alison, father-in-law to John Carter, grandfather to Charles Holden Carter, brother to Betsy Mertens, uncle to Chris Milk and Jeff Mertens, teacher, advocate, counselor, mentor, author and friend. He lived a life worth celebrating. Memorial services will be held in Cape Cod this summer and in Phoenix this fall. Donations can be made to the ASU Foundation-Pulaski Memorial, P.O. Box 879901, Tempe, AZ 85287.

KATZ--Selma. Selma Rebecca (Hersh) Katz born on January 31, 1913 in Waterbury, Connecticut passed away, peacefully, in her sleep, on Thursday evening, June 28, 2012, at Memorial Hospital in Colorado Springs, Colorado. Selma spent most of her childhood and adult life in New York City, living between the Lower East Side of Manhattan where she was an early resident of 91 Orchard Street, now the home of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, and then moving to Brooklyn and subsequently to Queens. She was married on March 9, 1930 to Joseph Katz (deceased). Together, they are survived by a legacy of their seven children, Stanley Katz, Roslyn Padgett, Larry Katz, Carol Sperber, Irwin Katz, Gary Katz and Ellen Taubman, sixteen grandchildren, eighteen great-grandchildren and seven great-great grandchildren, with another expected, ranging between the ages of 81 years and 18 months old. Selma was also an active member of the Flushing Chapter of Hadassah. Services for Selma will be held in Colorado Springs on Sunday, June 30. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Selma Katz Preservation Fund at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, 91 Orchard Street, New York, NY 10002. Funds will be used to preserve the now-National Landmark tenement in which she grew up.

The Olympics may be in London, but guests at New York City hotels during the Games can nevertheless get a taste of competition. Affinia Hotels, in a nod to the campaign to make yoga an Olympic sport, has created a challenge for its guests at its five Manhattan locations. Those who complete three yoga poses when they check in (tree pose, downward dog and head-to-knee) will receive prizes like cupcakes, wine and a $25 room credit.

DUNLOP--Joan. The Open Society Foundations mourn the death of Joan Dunlop, a member of the Board of Directors of our United States Programs and the former Chair of the Board of our International Women's Program. All of us who had a chance to work with Joan over the years respected her greatly as a woman of courage and principle, and many of us also came to know her as a friend. We will greatly miss her wise counsel at our meetings and the opportunities we had to enjoy her company. George Soros, Chair Sherrilyn Ifill, Chair, U.S. Programs Aryeh Neier, President Emeritus

RICHTER--Maurice L.,82, on June 26, 2012. He is survived by his wife Eva, sons Chris and Jon, daughters-in-law Jenny and Julianna, and three grandchildren, Noah, Allie and Shayni. Maurice loved classical music, astronomy, mathematics, art, good Szechuan food, and model trains. He was a witty and prolific poet, writing for family and friends to commemorate birthdays, anniversaries, and diplomas earned. He saw the world with wonder and awe, marveling at the stars - their beauty and supreme logic. Summers spent in Boothbay Harbor, ME, in Woodstock and Phoenicia, NY, surrounded by family and friends, were among his happiest times. Maurice was one of the early pioneers of the move from Manhattan to Park Slope, Brooklyn, where the family lived for forty-one years. He attended the Bronx High School of Science and New York University-BS., MS., PhD. - and taught Mathematics at the College of Staten Island, CUNY, for forty years. Upon retirement he traveled, immersed himself in his extensive collection of art books, listened to music, and wrote classical music reviews for the online publication LaFolia. We will miss him very much.

MIDNIGHT movies come in various flavors. Some, like David Lynch's ''Eraserhead,'' are creepy; others, like John Waters's oeuvre, are perversely funny. And then you have ''THE ROOM,'' which hits the Landmark Sunshine Cinema on Saturday night, at the appropriate hour. That film falls squarely into ''Plan 9 From Outer Space'' territory, in the pantheon of So Bad It's Good Cinema. But ''The Room,'' from 2003 and produced, written and directed by (and starring, of course) Tommy Wiseau, occupies a singular niche. This isn't amateurish sci-fi. It's more like excruciating soft-core soap opera, with so many continuity errors that the whole enterprise resembles a kind of unwitting cinematic dada. What began as a West Hollywood phenomenon has a regular New York home at the Landmark Sunshine, with fans near ''Rocky Horror'' mania. Audience participation -- flinging plastic utensils during the abundant displays of cryptic spoon imagery in the movie -- has gained traction. Come and savor the sublime awfulness. 143 East Houston Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-7289, landmarktheatres.com.
KLINGENSTEIN--Sharon. To our Contessa, thanks for the friendship, the laughs and the special memories. We'll never forget!! Your loving Mexicans

THE powerfully expressive voice, dusky low range and vivid dramatic gifts of the Polish contralto EVA PODLES have thrilled her fans over the years. As part of the annual Bel Canto at Caramoor series, she returns to the Venetian Theater to sing the title role in what is said to be the American premiere of Rossini's ''Ciro in Babilonia.'' Will Crutchfield conducts the Orchestra of St. Luke's and a promising cast that also includes the soprano Jessica Pratt, the tenor Michael Spyres, the mezzo-soprano Sharin Apostolou and the baritones Scott Bearden and Krassen Karagiozov. There will be lectures and performances relating to the opera on Saturday afternoon and in the early evening. Saturday at 8:30 p.m., 149 Girdle Ridge Road, Katonah, N.Y., (914) 232-1252, caramoor.org; $15 to $100. Also on Saturday the Glimmerglass Festival kicks off its season with Verdi's ''AIDA'' starring the terrific bass-baritone Eric Owens, who sings his first Amonasro. Francesca Zambello directs the production, which features Michelle Johnson in the title role, Noah Stewart as Radames and Daveda Karanas as Amneris; Nader Abbassi conducts. 8 p.m., through Aug. 25, Cooperstown, N.Y., (607) 547-2255, glimmerglass.org; $26 to $132.

Before reading this article, I was always opposed to the legalization of drugs. It seemed as though legalization would place new burdens on law enforcement and lead to unforeseen consequences. I would like to thank Patrick Radden Keefe for disabusing me of this overly simplistic view of drug policy. In his article, Keefe does a masterful job of depicting the complexity of the drug trade, showing the lengths to which the Sinaloa cartel will go to feed demand in the United States. Some form of legalization would allow these drugs to be produced more cheaply and thus cut into the cartels' profits. It would also reduce their ability to hire enforcers, bribe officials and transport their products across borders. A less muscular enemy might then give law-enforcement bodies a fighting chance. SR, Toronto, posted on nytimes.com

SALOMON--Joseph D. of R.F.R Distributors Inc.,passed away peacefully at his home on Friday, June 22, 2012. He was a noted businessman and much loved husband, father, grandfather and friend. He is survived by his wife Joan, daughters Mallorie and Stefanie, and five grandchildren. Services were private.

The Red Bulls and host Toronto each scored a goal in the first six minutes of their game Saturday night, playing to a 1-1 tie at BMO Field. Jan Gunnar Solli, playing again in the Red Bulls' midfield, scored a goal for the second straight game (after not having scored in his Red Bulls career, now in its second season) for a 1-0 lead four minutes into the match. Solli hit a side-footed volley from a long, diagonal cross from Brandon Barklage on the right side.

FOR even the hardiest shopper, browsing through the name-brand luxury goods in the glossy Gold Coast stores in downtown Chicago can elicit a been-there-bought-that ennui. Recently, though, several homegrown stores with a more indie aesthetic have taken root in the district, providing rare finds and little-known labels. Even though some of these new shops are high-end outposts of stores that got started in scruffier parts of the city, all of them have helped lend a neighborhood feel to a shopping mecca that had previously lacked it. ROSE MAURA LORRE

FIRES in the vicinity of Pikes Peak in Colorado have led organizers to postpone the annual hill climb race, which was scheduled for July 8. Organizers expect to hold the event later in the summer. Andrew Lipman, an Audi spokesman, wrote in an e-mail on Thursday that Walter Röhrl, who Wheels reported was scheduled to drive a 1987 Audi Sport quattro S1 to the summit, still hoped to participate, but not in competition. He won the race in the same car in 1987.

SETZEN--Rita (nee Shishler), passed away on June 22, 2012 in Johannesburg, South Africa, beloved wife of the late Morris, mother of Michael, Raymond and Gavin, mother-in-law of Sheryl, Heather and Karen, grandmother of Nicole, Roy, Alexa, Melyssa, Rafi, Lee and Sean, and great-grandmother of Noah. Funeral and services were held in Johannesburg. She will be lovingly remembered and deeply missed by all.

AFGHANISTAN looks different from what we're used to seeing, at least through the eyes of the Italian conceptualist ALIGHIERO BOETTI, who traveled extensively there, operated a hotel and worked with its artisans to produce embroidered maps until his death in 1994. Starting Sunday the Museum of Modern Art looks at Boetti's career in a retrospective organized with the Museo Reina Sofía in Madrid and the Tate Modern in London. Best known as one of the leading artists of the Arte Povera movement, Boetti worked in his hometown, Turin, in the early 1960s, along with artists like Luciano Fabro, Mario Merz, Giulio Paolini and Michelangelo Pistoletto. The show, ''Alighiero Boetti: Game Plan,'' is perhaps the largest presentation outside Italy of works by Boetti, starting with his sculptural objects made of everyday materials like cardboard and including drawings like his ballpoint pen rendering from 1973, spelling out ''Mettere a Mondo il Mondo,'' or bringing the world into the world. In 1969 he started postal and map works, in which he mailed envelopes to friends, family and fellow artists in made-up places, forwarding each returned envelope to another nonexistent locale, creating imaginary journeys for people in his life. Through Oct. 1, (212) 708-9400, moma.org.

An answer in the Q&A column last Sunday about the replacement of carbon monoxide detectors in New York City apartments described incompletely the circumstances under which they must be replaced and who must pay for them. Because of a new law that took effect in April, landlords will indeed have to replace detectors that are damaged or lost, and also those that have exceeded the manufacturer's suggested ''useful life,'' beginning in October. Tenants must pay $25 for the detectors, but have a year to do so.
BARON--Miriam, of Rego Park, died June 22. Funeral held June 26. For info, call daughter Cheryl, 212-476-6043.

KAUFMAN--Barbara Mussett, beloved wife of Lewis C. Kaufman, died peacefully of pneumonia at age 79 on June 24, 2012 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She is survived by her husband, stepson Richard Kaufman, daughter-in-law Elizabeth, granddaughter Emma of Chevy Chase, MD, and devoted family and friends. She was the daughter of Michael and Estelle Mussett of Flushing, NY, and a graduate of Southern Seminary College in Virginia. From 1952 to 1986 Mrs. Kaufman was employed by B. Altman and Co. as a fashion buyer in various areas, eventually rising to Better Dress Buyer. She married Mr. Kaufman in 1969, and they would have celebrated their 42nd wedding anniversary this August. Mr. Kaufman rose to become president of B. Altman and Co. and together they traveled the world for business and adventure.

GROWING up in the Paris suburbs, David Obadia (at right in the photo) was obsessed with Air Jordans and the American street-wear brands Supreme and Stussy. His best friend, Nelson Hassan (at left), was more drawn to the avant-garde looks of Commes des Garçons and Raf Simons. No wonder, then, that upon graduation from business school and fashion school, respectively, they started their own label, Brooklyn We Go Hard, named for the Jay-Z song. ''We like everything about Brooklyn, including Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg, Dr. Brown's soda and the Nets,'' Mr. Obadia says. (They've both been there several times, he assures us.) ''Brooklyn brings together the mainstream and the underground, which is what we want to do with the clothes.'' Last year the label gained steam when the designers introduced a sweatshirt (about $140) with ''Brooklyn Parle Français'' embroidered across the chest. It got picked up by Colette in Paris, and has been worn by Kid Cudi at the ''Hunger Games'' premiere, as well as Olivier Nakache, the director of the recent French box-office success ''Les Intouchables.'' (''Can you help us get the sweatshirt on Jay-Z or anyone from the Nets?'' Mr. Hassan asks.) They're showing their first full collection at the Paris men's Capsule show. TIM MURPHY

ARON MÖREL is the antithesis of the typical bottom-line-observant publisher. He greets missed deadlines with aplomb. He ignores the time-honored spring/autumn publishing schedule, preferring to bring out books whenever they're ready. He's perfectly comfortable letting his authors steer their own projects, right down to the type of binding. This unorthodox formula has yielded some of the hippest art books of the last few years. His latest output is ''Night and Day,'' a collection of photographs by David Armstrong that were taken at the Mudd Club and other downtown Manhattan spots in the late 1970s and '80s, and that coincides with a show at the Half Gallery on Forsyth Street, through July 23. The book includes a facsimile of a poem by René Ricard (who also designed the cover) and a conversation between Mr. Armstrong and the artist Jack Pierson. ''There are no set formulas,'' Mr. Mörel says. ''We keep everything as intimate as possible. The print runs are limited. The only real rule is that the artist has to take as much control as possible.'' Mr. Mörel takes this one rule seriously: Describing a project with Elizabeth Peyton and Jonathan Horowitz, he sums up the collaboration by saying, ''I really don't know what they're going to do.'' NANCY MacDONELL
