SAWYER--Herb, passed away peacefully on Thursday, June 28th, 2012, after a prolonged illness. Herb was born December 26th, 1956. Herb was predeceased by his beloved wife, Michelle "Shelly" Andrews, and father, Norman Sawyer. He is survived by his two loving children, Nina Victoria and William Andrews, mother, Annette Sawyer, sister, Rachel Sawyer, brother-in-law, James Little, and other devoted family and friends. A service will be held this Sunday, July 1st, at 2pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st Street. Donations may be made in his memory.

An article last Sunday about a one-woman show based on the life of Dr. Ruth Westheimer, ''Dr. Ruth, All the Way,'' misstated the trepidation felt by the actress Debra Jo Rupp in tackling Dr. Ruth's distinctive voice. Ms. Rupp said she was worried that people would want her to do ''a Rich Little imitation,'' referring to the comic impressionist -- not ''a rich little imitation.''

REILLY--Ellen Chapman, known as Lukie to all, passed away on June 20 after a four-year battle with Multiple Myeloma. She was much loved and will be missed. Born February 3, 1935 in New York, she grew up in New Hope, PA and Manhattan. She attended Friends Seminary in Greenwich Village and graduated from St. Mary's in the Mountains (The White Mountain School) in New Hampshire. In 1953, Lukie was accepted to attend the Rhode Island School of Design and forever after pursued her creative passions. She studied art in Paris and was a student of the famed sculptor, Louise Nevelson. She found diverse inspiration working as an editor for Mademoiselle magazine and as a dress designer for Tanner of North Carolina. In the months following her 60th birthday, Lukie discovered that she was also a supremely talented writer and one of her essays eventually appeared in the Best American Essays collection of 1997 published by Houghton Mifflin. For many years, she owned an art gallery in Charleston, SC and was herself a decorated watercolorist, winning The James Sudem Award from the National Academy of Fine Art in 1980. She is survived by three brothers, William, John and Alexander, her twins, Jane and Anthony and five grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for July 13 at four o'clock at the Westhampton Presbyterian Church in Quiogue, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Doctors without Borders P.O. Box 5030 Hagerstown, MD 21741-5030.

A report on June 10 in the In Transit column about the new SC Johnson Gallery in Racine, Wis., misidentified the building that houses the gallery and misidentified its architect. The gallery is in Fortaleza Hall, not in the SC Johnson Administration Building, and it was designed by Foster + Partners, not by Frank Lloyd Wright. (The headline also misidentified the architect.) The report also referred incorrectly to the gallery's inaugural exhibition. It focuses on Wright's Prairie style; it is not titled ''At Home With Frank Lloyd Wright.'' (That is part of the full name of the gallery -- the SC Johnson Gallery: At Home With Frank Lloyd Wright.)

In a front-page Times article last week -- one discussed in this week's Big City column -- Tek Young Lin, a retired Horace Mann teacher, admitted he had had sex with students during his career. Mr. Lin downplayed the seriousness of his actions by suggesting that times were ''different.'' Hundreds of readers responded on NYTimes.com, many addressing Mr. Lin's self-justifications. A selection of reader comments is below. As one of his students, I can say that Tek was a brilliant teacher. I honestly believe HE considers his actions as ''warm'' and ''casual.'' Today we have the knowledge and wisdom to know that there is never anything ''casual'' about an adult male pursuing a young boy or girl. But the '60s and '70s in N.Y. were a time of societal oddities, and Horace Mann was a breeding ground for pushing boundaries. The lines between intimate adventure and sexual conquest were completely obliterated. With as many rules as existed in our studies in things like grammar, there were few, if any, when it came to sexual conduct. Not that it was a free-for-all, but there was bewilderment and excitement in defining what was appropriate.

There is so much to celebrate about the All-Star Game. From the relay of dominant pitchers to the kaleidoscope of uniforms to the wonderfully inclusive rule that every team must be represented, baseball should be proud of its summer showcase. Yet here we are, a full decade since the infamous tied All-Star Game in Milwaukee, and baseball is still trying to convince fans that the players actually care. This year's slogan: ''I Will Win.'' You see it on T-shirts in the clubhouse, and in television commercials with stone-faced players looking into the camera, stating the league they play for and promising, with great purpose, that they will win.

ALL three works on the new program by the tap virtuoso JASON SAMUELS SMITH have something to do with the life and music of Charlie Parker, the jazz saxophonist and composer known as Bird, who was one of the most influential figures in bop's development during the 1940s. Parker, who died in 1955, became famous for complex and brilliant improvisations. Mr. Smith, known for his own intricate rhythms, opens his Joyce program with ''Imagine,'' a new solo danced to a live five-piece band that reveals how his experiments in sound and movement led in 2009 to the creation of ''Charlie's Angels: A Tribute to Charlie Parker,'' in which the cast here will include three female tappers: Dormeshia Sumbry-Edwards, Chloe Arnold and Michelle Dorrance. The program concludes with the premiere of another group work, ''Chasing the Bird.'' All three pieces seek to unite the sounds of bop with the sights and sounds of tap. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Wednesday at 5 p.m., Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m. and Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $10 to $39.

HILLSBOROUGH, N.J. WALKING into the research facility of Primus Green Energy is not unlike wandering onto the set of ''Dr. Who.'' Everywhere you look, there is plumbing, usually covered in multiple layers of shiny aluminum foil. The foil is hot, it's festooned with hundreds of wires and reeks of solvents.

That was the total number of viewers for the June 24 series premiere of ''The Newsroom,'' the HBO drama created by Aaron Sorkin and starring Jeff Daniels, right. It reached more viewers than the recent premiere of HBO's ''Luck'' but fell short of the 2.2 million who watched the first episode of ''Game of Thrones'' last year. So how would this fake cable news show rank against a real one? It would be the crown jewel of CNN, where ''Anderson Cooper 360'' averaged 420,000 in May, and MSNBC, where ''The Rachel Maddow Show'' averaged 901,000, and a competitor to Fox News's ''O'Reilly Factor,'' which frequently reaches two to three million viewers.

The Sky Watch column in some editions last Sunday misstated the local time at which a ''leap second'' will be inserted into the atomic time scale. This happened on Saturday, when the final minute of the day (as measured at Greenwich, England) lasted 61 seconds. This will correspond to 7:59:60 p.m. -- not 6:59:60 p.m. -- Eastern time.

Tell people you're off to spend the weekend in Oslo with $100 in your pocket, and the warnings start flowing. Some came in the form of legitimate research like the UBS report that has ranked Oslo the world's most expensive city for the last three years; others were shock-and-awe anecdotes, like ''Food in Oslo is so expensive you can actually buy half a cucumber.'' I'm not easily spooked. Seven previous $100 weekends in pricey places like Paris and Rio de Janeiro have shown me that such cities can be enjoyed, even on a pittance. But I'm also not stupid. On my way to the airport in Copenhagen I bought a dense loaf of softkernerugbrod, soft-seed Danish rye, and stuck it in my bag. Good thing, too. By the end of the weekend, it was gone.

The At the Table column in some editions last Sunday about Brooklyn Crab, in the Red Hook neighborhood, misstated the serving size of steamed King Crab legs that customers get for $48. It is 1 1/2 pounds, not half a pound.

KIEZ--Gregory Michael, a Board Member of Global Investment Holdings and Chairman of the Board of Global Ports Holding, has died at the age of 50 on June 30, 2012. Mr. Kiez had been battling brain cancer, specifically glioblastoma multiforme (GBM). Mr. Kiez was born in Canada and lived for the past 20 years in Turkey. He was Chairman of the Board of Ege Ports - Kusadasi, Chairman of the Board of Port Akdeniz - Antalya and Chairman of the Board of Global Ports Holding, all of which operate under Global Investment Holdings, where Mr. Kiez also served as a Board Member. Mr. Kiez held a BA degree in law from the University of Toronto and an LLB. He received numerous awards during his academic career, including scholarships from Norman Levy, Borden & Elliot, Dow-Hickson, as well as the James Cappon Award and the James McGill Award. During the time he spent in Turkey, Mr. Kiez, promoted Turkey and created a new maritime industry sector, positioning Turkey as a major player within it. Today, his speech at the "Security Pollution" Panel of the 2004 Maritime Trade Congress in Miami is considered the milestone of port sector development in Turkey. Mr. Kiez played a significant role in social welfare initiatives targeted at underprivileged children and the improvement of educational services. His philanthropic activities included the establishment of The Gregory Michael Kiez Applied and Theoretical Classrooms of the Adnan Menderes University Tourism and Hotel Management College facilities. From 2006, he served as a board member of Texas A&M University-Institute of Nautical Archeology that spearheaded many crucial excavations. Mr. Kiez supported multiple initiatives and made donations to create awareness of GBM, to develop treatment methods and help others in their struggle against it. A trust has been established in his name for Brain Tumors at the Yale Medical School. Funeral Mass 05 July 2012, 2012 at 10.30am at St. Esprit Church - Istanbul Funeral Ceremony 05 July 2012, at 18.30, Sandima Koyu Cemetery Yalikavak-Bodrum. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to TAY Project (The Archaeological Settlements of Turkey) http://www.tayproject.org/ enghome.html

The summer is certainly the right time to take in films inspired by comic books, as this week's Arts & Leisure cover article attests, but it's also the perfect time to catch up on the vivid source material itself. What was better as a kid than to be curled up in your favorite reading spot, orange Popsicle (carefully) in hand, a stack of funny books at your beck and call -- Archie, Sgt. Rock, the Incredible Hulk -- and the radio tuned to your favorite Top 40 station? Has it been too long since you lost yourself in the paper-and-ink adventures of Batman or Spider-Man? Then The New York Times's best-seller lists for graphic books (hardcover, paperback and manga) can help put you on the road to sultry comic book nirvana: nytimes.com/best-sellers-books.

LEINWAND--Freda, (1932-2012), photographer, passed away peacefully June 27, surrounded by her family. Ms. Leinwand is well known for a lifetime of dedication to recording the Women's Movement through photography, and in particularly for chronicling the Women's Literary Salon. She is also known for photographs of women working in non-traditional jobs, and of children and adults with disabilities. Ms. Leinwand exhibited in New York and Canada, and received notable reviews from the New York Times, Popular Photography, the Village Voice, and Artspeak. Her work is in the Schlesinger Library collection at Radcliffe College, the permanent collection of the Women's Rights National Historical Park, and the Library of Congress. Ms. Leinwand lectured at Columbia University, Marymount Manhattan College, and Apeiron Workshops. She was awarded a Veteran Feminists of America Medal of Honor and in 2002 received the Susan B. Anthony Award from the National Organization for Women. A petite creative dynamo, Freda is survived by four devoted siblings and six nieces and nephews.

SHAVER--George J. Jr.,January 30, 1929-June 12, 2012 Resident of Newport, RI, Oakland, CA and Huntington, NY; died peacefully with his three children at his bedside listening to his favorite music. Witty, unique, charming man who loved words, his family, dogs, music and yachting. Wife Dorothy, daughter Pamela predeceased him. Survived by sister Francis Lauda, children, Patricia C. Shaver, Linda H., George J. Jr. III grandchildren, Harrison G. Steinorth, George J. Shaver IV, Gwendolyn Grace Shaver. Princeton grad B.A. Class of 1951. 53 Served U.S. Army Counter Intelligence Corps. Bridge Life Master. The proverbial "Ad Man" George spent 20 years at DFS advertising agency Sr. VP Creative Director. Won numerous Clio and Effie Awards A "class act" that made an impact on many people's lives.

A THREE-BEDROOM condominium that sold for $17 million, boasting stratospheric views from the 70th floor of the Residences at Mandarin Oriental at the Time Warner Center, was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. The unit, No. 70B, has views of Central Park, the Hudson and virtually the entire Manhattan skyline. Neither the seller, the Pacific American Corporation, nor the buyer, Mikimmos NY, a limited-liability company, would discuss the transaction, according to the seller's agent, Setsuko Hattori of Prudential Douglas Elliman, which co-brokered the listing with the Corcoran Group. The buyer was represented by Adam Modlin of the Modlin Group.

Loving father of Mary Ann Radioli-Samaha and her husband Jeff, Paul Radioli and his wife Alcira, and the late Veronica Radioli. Cherished grandfather of Kristina Samaha, Jacqueline Samaha, and Andrew Samaha. Funeral Tuesday, 9am from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass 10am at Good Shepherd R.C. Church. Interment Forest Green Park Cemetery. Visiting Monday 2-5 and 7-10pm.

Is philosophy literature? Do people read philosophy for pleasure? Of course it is, and of course they do. Well, what is literature? That in itself might appear to be a philosophical question. Yet the most persuasive answer, to my mind, was supplied by a novelist, Evelyn Waugh. ''Literature,'' he declared, ''is the right use of language irrespective of the subject or reason of utterance.'' And what is ''the right use of language''? What distinguishes literature from mere communication or sheer trash? Waugh had an answer to this, too: ''Lucidity, elegance, individuality.''

Last week's chess column about the results of the Tal Memorial tournament misstated and mischaracterized Black's 34th move as a mistake in an analysis of a game between Luke McShane and Magnus Carlsen. Carlsen, who was Black, played 34 . . . Qc4, not 34 . . . Rf4. The mistake was on his 33rd move, when he should have played 33 . . . Rad8.

HERMAN--Donald J. Donald J. Herman, who rose to prominence as a software-development visionary in the 1960s and '70s, died on June 24 at home in Tampa, Fla. He was 82. Mr. Herman was born in 1930 in Aberdeen, S.D., the fourth of five children to Jacob and Mary Herman. He graduated from Aberdeen's Central High School and later worked his way through the University of South Dakota to earn an engineering degree. Mr. Herman served twelve years in the US Navy, six years as a U.S. Naval Intelligence Officer assigned to the National Security Agency. In 1962 Mr. Herman co-founded COMRESS Inc., an early pioneer in the development and leasing of proprietary software. Ultimately, the entrepreneurial engineer would use COMRESS-profit "seed money" to start five other computer-related companies. The most notable was COMTEN, which Mr. Herman sold to the NCR Corp. in 1979. He would, in turn, become the Chief Executive of NCR. He also founded two nonprofit organizations, the Corporation For Open Systems and UNIX International, which helped establish software standards for the international computer industry. He would later chair the U.S. Department of Defense Computer & Communications Cost Reductions Committee. After taking early retirement in 1988, Mr. Herman relocated from Dayton, Oh. to Naples, Fla., where he married Joan. His community involvements ranged from the Miami Valley Hospital Board of Trustees to the vice chairmanship of the Naples Chapter of the American Red Cross. The Hermans moved to Tampa in the fall of 2008. Mr. Herman is survived by his wife, Joan; brothers, Vernon and Harlow; sister, Cleo (Donovan); sons, Daniel (spouse, Judith), Jeffrey (Jeanette), James (Jane), David (Sandy), Robert (Doreen) and stepson Paul Stock (Bonnie); daughters, Julie (David Holt) and stepdaughter Stephani (Rodrigo Vallejo); 14 grandchildren; and one great-grandchild. Mr. Herman was preceded in death by his father, Jacob; mother, Mary; and brother, Bernard. Visitation services will be held Friday, June 29 from 5:30pm to 7:30pm at Blount & Curry Funeral Homes, 605 S. MacDill Ave. Memorial services will be held Saturday, June 30 at 11:00am at St. John's Episcopal Church, 906 S. Orleans Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Tampa Theatre.

HIS fascination with freckles led Reto Caduff, a photographer based in Los Angeles, to capture images of scores of prettily pigmented women. ''I've always liked freckles,'' he said, ''but working on shoots over the years, I noticed that they usually get covered with makeup or digitally removed in post-production. So I decided to celebrate the spots rather than erase them.'' The resulting project, a self-published limited-edition tome of black-and-white portraits called ''Freckles,'' is $69 at Dashwood Books, 33 Bond Street; (212) 387-8520. SANDRA BALLENTINE

LOUIS VUITTON is celebrating all things French just before Bastille Day (July 14), opening its first fine-jewelry and watchmaking boutique Tuesday on the Place Vendôme in Paris. To celebrate the occasion, Lorenz Bäumer, the artistic director of haute joaillerie for Vuitton, has designed three new collections inspired by three Parisian icons: the Place de la Concorde, the Champs-Élysées and the Tuileries. Here, the Orangerie des Tuileries brooch features two flowers lifted from L. V.'s near-synonymous logo, one made of tsavorite and diamonds, and a larger one with a blue tanzanite gemstone in the center. Louis Vuitton Orangerie des Tuileries brooch, price on request, available at the fine-jewelry boutique at 23 Place Vendôme starting Tuesday. Go to louisvuitton.com. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

THE evolution of CBGB -- from a physical place to an aesthetic ideal to a cultural shorthand to a multipurpose brand -- reaches another strange plateau this week with the onset of the CBGB FESTIVAL. Scheduled to run from Thursday through next Sunday, around downtown Manhattan and Brooklyn, it's part music festival, part industry showcase and part film conference -- in other words, like a smaller version of the CMJ Music Marathon, which happens in the fall. There are some choice concessions to the punk ethos once synonymous with CBGB, the old Bowery club: Fishbone and Cro-Mags, surely, along with David Johansen. And there are scattered shows by artists who would seem to suggest an extension of that impulse, like Craig Finn of the Hold Steady. But the festival also features a lot of nonconfrontational indie rock -- by Guided by Voices, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah and Dale Earnhardt Jr. Jr., for starters -- and a daylong spirits celebration. The keynote address will be by Krist Novoselic, the bassist formerly with Nirvana and, less famously, the San Francisco Bay-area punk band Flipper. Go ahead, try to make sense of the whole thing: cbgb.com.

Orbitz recently released a new version of its iPhone app that allows users to book flights, hotel rooms and car rentals in one seamless session. The upgrade is a departure from other travel apps that handle multiple reservations, like Kayak's, which sends users to browser screens within the app, and Expedia's, which requires users to enter their data repeatedly. Orbitz's investment in the app reflects its belief that travelers will increasingly make reservations by smartphone or tablet, perhaps even choosing those devices over other traditional platforms like laptops and desktops.

Unfortunately, parents raising children of color don't have the luxury of choosing not to address how the ''horrors [of history] play out in everyday life, through a thousand subtle means, often unexpected.'' For that reason, parents raising white children have a responsibility to address our racist past (and present) with our children in order to help them understand it as something we must actively work to end. This is hard work, but most of parenting is hard, and there are plenty of parents out there who are struggling to succeed. ALI KRONLEY, Philadelphia

Dr. Dupuis also taught at Cornell University College of Medicine and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, and was a major in the US Army Reserves. A resident of East Hampton since 1984, he was a Consulting Psychiatrist for the Family Service League. Andre is survived by a niece, Francine Lavallee, and many dear friends and associates. He will be greatly missed. Contributions in the name of Dr. Andre Dupuis can be made to Opera Index (operaindexinc.org), or the William Alanson White Institute's program for LGBT clinical services (wawhite.org)

At a statuesque 5-foot-9, Bunny Yeager had no trouble adopting the pinup poses of the '50s and '60s. Then she moved behind the lens and started taking the pictures herself. Born Linnea Eleanor Yeager, she took her nickname from Lana Turner's character in ''Week-End at the Waldorf.'' One of her most famous photos captured Bettie Page posing in front of a Christmas tree wearing only a Santa hat and a wink, a shot that helped make both of them famous when Yeager sold it to Playboy. Being a woman ''was probably an advantage,'' Yeager says, ''because young girls were relaxedwhen they posed for me.'' More than 250 of her pictures will appear in the book ''Bunny Yeager's Darkroom,'' coming from Rizzoli in September. Yeager still goes to her Miami studio every day. ''I'm 83 years old now, and I feel the same as when I started,'' she says. ''Now I am writing a new book. It is called 'Lovely Luscious Legs.' '' 'I didn't decide to become a photographer. It was forced on me. I took a course in photography to learn how to make copies of my professional

LAST season on Showtime's ''EPISODES'' Beverly and Sean Lincoln, the fictional creators of a British TV hit made unrecognizable by an American studio, found their marriage upended by an unlikely collision with Matt LeBlanc (the character, played by the man). That Beverly seemed the last woman who would succumb to Mr. LeBlanc's charms, or that hers would even register on his celebrity radar, pushed the humor over the top. The role earned Mr. LeBlanc, spoofing himself, a Golden Globe. But it's the Olivier Award-winning Tamsin Greig, as Beverly, who is threatening to steal the show. Boyishly slim and fortysomething with close-cropped hair in a sea of blond tresses and breast implants, Beverly is all the more beguiling because of what's not there. In Season 2, starting Sunday at 10:30 p.m., Beverly and Matt plead, cajole and wield big gifts to win back Sean (Stephen Mangan), the man they both love. But in a real-life fairy tale Ms. Greig has been transformed from a British character actor into a different kind of Hollywood swan. Leaving the girls to that other network, she joins the ranks of Showtime's fearless leading ladies of a certain age: Edie Falco, Laura Linney and Mary-Louise Parker, whose ''Weeds'' leads in at 10.

TERINO--Anthony E.,a former Chief of the Bureau of Secondary School Supervision for New York State, died in his sleep Wednesday, June 20, 2012. He was over 100 years of age. The son of immigrant Italian parents, Anthony was first in his family to attend college and obtain advanced degrees. He grew up in Far Rockaway, New York, and later taught in the same high school from which he had graduated. While studying at City College of New York and NYU, Anthony helped support his parents by working as a letter carrier. Anthony interviewed H.L. Mencken for his college newspaper and was instrumental in bringing noted Italian author Giuseppe Prezzolini to the Italian-American club to speak. Anthony went on to further his education at Columbia University. Later in life, he was awarded an honorary doctorate for his contribution to the education of youth. While teaching in night school as a young man, Anthony met and married Frances Owens of Alford, MA. She was his life partner and soul mate for 64 years until her death in 1999. After various teaching positions, Anthony began to work in the New York State Education Department, where he ultimately served as Bureau Chief for Secondary School Supervision. In this capacity, Anthony was responsible for the accreditation of all secondary schools in New York State. During these years, he was co-author of the popular textbook, Modern English in Action. In his sixties Anthony taught and served as acting president of the then fledgling Schenectady Community College. He taught at Hudson Valley Community College as well. Many private schools throughout New York State received Anthony's help and guidance in securing the required charters to operate. Among the most notable schools in New York City were St. Sergius High School for Russian Orthodox students and schools for the children of Japanese and Italian diplomats. For his work with the latter, Anthony was awarded the honor of "Cavaliere della Repubblica Italiana," a form of knighthood, by the Italian government. In recognition of all his educational contributions, a Long Island lodge of the Order of the Sons of Italy in America was named for him. Anthony was loved, respected, and admired by those who knew him. He will be deeply missed by his two children, Edward and Dorothy; Edward's children, Tara, Vanessa, Wendy, Laura, and Taylor, Dorothy's children, Emily and Theodore; eight great-grandchildren; and his devoted caregivers, Donna, Johanna, Pam and Pat. Condolences may be made through: birchesroyfh.com.

WHEN the signal was finally given on Thursday morning, New York City's 55 public outdoor pools officially opened for the season, beckoning young and old to take the plunge. There were the usual sights and sounds of summer -- cerulean basins and Marco Polo, blue lips and splash fights. Less evident were the weeks and months of preparation by the city's parks department, which must ready filtration systems, train lifeguards and paint pool surfaces. Last summer, the city hosted nearly two million people at its outdoor pools, which range from aboveground minipools that hold only 18,000 gallons of water to behemoths like the Astoria Pool in Queens, one of 11 mega-pools that opened during the Great Depression. It holds 1.8 million gallons.

ZIVOTOVSKY--Michael. The partners and staff of WeiserMazars LLP mourn the passing of our esteemed partner and friend, Michael Zivotovsky. Michael's dedication to family, friends, partners, staff and clients will be deeply missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Joyce, sons Evan and Mark and his entire family.

IF you live in America in the 21st century you've probably had to listen to a lot of people tell you how busy they are. It's become the default response when you ask anyone how they're doing: ''Busy!'' ''So busy.'' ''Crazy busy.'' It is, pretty obviously, a boast disguised as a complaint. And the stock response is a kind of congratulation: ''That's a good problem to have,'' or ''Better than the opposite.'' Notice it isn't generally people pulling back-to-back shifts in the I.C.U. or commuting by bus to three minimum-wage jobs who tell you how busy they are; what those people are is not busy but tired. Exhausted. Dead on their feet. It's almost always people whose lamented busyness is purely self-imposed: work and obligations they've taken on voluntarily, classes and activities they've ''encouraged'' their kids to participate in. They're busy because of their own ambition or drive or anxiety, because they're addicted to busyness and dread what they might have to face in its absence.

IT seems that most any theatrical classic can be presented as the diary of a madman. ''Hamlet'' (but of course), ''Sweeney Todd'' (ditto) and ''South Pacific'' (huh?) have all been reset in mental institutions, with varying success. But surely few such productions have been as ambitious -- or as labor efficient -- as the National Theater of Scotland's ''MACBETH,'' which begins performances Thursday as part of Lincoln Center Festival 2012. Directed by John Tiffany (''Black Watch,'' ''Once'') and Andrew Goldberg, this production features a cast of exactly one. That's Alan Cumming, who has embodied all manner of decadence, divine and otherwise, in roles that include the M. C. in ''Cabaret,'' the pope according to Jean Genet and a kilt-sporting Dionysus in Mr. Tiffany's version of ''The Bacchae.'' Having passed (wisely) on the role of the Green Goblin in ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' Mr. Cumming now gets to strut his real superpowers by portraying every single character in ''Macbeth'' as the products of one demented soul's fevered brain. Expect the sound and fury of a cast of thousands. Through July 14, Rose Theater at Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenterfestival.org; $50 to $100.

FLENDER--Norma Fast. Musician and resident of Manhattan and East Hampton, NY. Norma passed peacefully on June 14, 2012 at the age of 81. Born on February 9, 1931 in Uniontown, PA, Ms. Flender began her piano lessons at age five and continued her studies with Ferguson Webster in Pittsburgh, PA then with Beveridge Webster at The Julliard School of music in New York. Upon graduating from Julliard she studied in Fountainbleau and Paris with Nadia Boulanger. Norma was granted a French Government music scholarship and was a recipient of the H.H. Wooley prize. Norma has soloed, accompanied, and performed chamber music extensively in New York city and has appeared with orchestras and given numerous recitals in the United States and Europe. In the 1980's Norma performed the works of her dear friend, Virgil Thomson, with the late John Houseman. Ms. Flender was a member of the Cosmopolitan club, the New York musicians club and was vice president of the American composers Orchestra as well as serving as chairwoman of Pianofest in The Hamptons. Norma was dedicated to helping young musicians careers and was tireless in her generosity and efforts supporting this cause. Norma married the late Richard Flender, her husband of over 50 marvelous years on June 3, 1960. She is survived by her son Charles Flender and wife Kathryn, grandson Richard, also by her daughter, Sylvia Scott Flender, granddaughters Nina and Elizabeth (Zizi) and grandson, Gage. Norma also leaves a brother, Edwin Fast and wife Sue, her nieces and nephews, Margaret (Scottie) Fast, Jeanne Kingsland, Penn Hackney and William Flender. Norma filled our hearts and lives with music, she was so beautiful, so gifted, so kind and giving, she was as lovely as any person could hope to be. She lived and loved life, warmed people and cared so much for so many. Norma will be dearly missed by her family and many friends though everyone knows she is happy, she is again with the love of her life, her husband, Dick, and with her beloved black lab, Fiona. Donations in her memory may be made to The American Composers Orchestra.
Manhattan

MCDERMOTT--Gelsy. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the passing of Gelsy McDermott, Special Assistant from 1952 to 1994 to GNYHA presidents John V. Connorton, Sr., S. David Pomrinse, M.D., and Kenneth E. Raske. In a career marked by professionalism and integrity, Gelsy was a wealth of knowledge and a mother figure to a generation of New York health care executives. JONES--Evelyn S. "Love doesn't tell time and time doesn't diminish love" Evelyn S. Jones, of Hanover, PA, passed away on May 25, 2011. She left this world while being held in the arms of her husband, Dick. They have been married for 48 years. A stronger bond between two souls would be hard to find. They were lucky to have each other and enjoyed every moment of every day fully, with boundless respect, kindness, patience and love for one another. They truly lived a love story. Evelyn's interests and curiosities were limitless and life experiences many. Few people knew that she earned her pilot's license at the age of 19 and jumped 12 times at the old Harrisburg, PA airport. She had so many loves her pets (dogs, cats and parakeets), anything from Tiffany's, the Sunday New York Times, auctions and antiques, Frank Sinatra (Strangers in the Night, Fly Me to the Moon and all the rest), hard shell crabs and a beer or two, horse races and slot machines, slightly off-color jokes, the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Blue Angels, flowers and "pretty things", her convertibles, shopping for anything, Ocean City summers, driving and exploring and making friends. A good and generous friend to many, she was always ready to listen and never missed a chance to provide a kindness. Almost 5'2" and with a commanding presence, Evelyn could be as tough as nails. She met her life's many challenges head on with unbelievable strength and courage. Evelyn has been a wonderful mother to three girls: Jessica, Laurie and Jennie. It gave her great pleasure to spend time with her children teaching, guiding and caring for them. She was always ready to tell a story, share a kindness and be quick with a smile and a laugh. A voracious reader who loved to learn about almost anything and everything, she was embracing the new technologies and the world they opened up to her. Dick and Evelyn were partners in creating and operating Dick Jones Sales, Inc., a nationwide industrial equipment distributorship. For many years, Evelyn also operated her pride and joy enterprise, Evelyn Jones Antiques and Surprises in New Oxford, PA where she enjoyed a clientele from near and far. Her extensive knowledge of, special interest in, and collections of carousel horses, majolica, oyster plates, silver and fine porcelains have afforded her a national reputation in some circles. A loving wife, mother, grandmother and friend Evelyn provided joy and inspiration to the many lives she touched. She will always be in our hearts and we will forever love her and miss her. We are who we are because of her. Ev, my life began when we met. I fell in love with you every day still do, always will. You always made the impossible possible. One of my greatest joys was the sound of your laughter. And now"How Deep Is The Ocean"over and over. Rick

The phrase ''travel etiquette'' may at times seem like an oxymoron, but the Travel Leaders Group of agents surveyed more than 800 people this spring and found broad areas of agreement on how to respond in hypothetical situations that are fairly common in real life on the road. Confronted with the perennial question of whether to tell the person whose headphones are so loud that everyone can hear the dialogue of his in-flight entertainment, nearly three-quarters of respondents said that they would ask him to turn it down or solicit a flight attendant to. And if a child is kicking your seat? More than 6 of 10 would say something directly to the child or to the parent. What about getting upgraded to first class when your travel companion doesn't? Nearly 30 percent said that they'd remain loyal and tough it out in steerage.

LEMON--Richard C.,81, of Bedford, NY, died Friday, June 29, 2012. He is survived by his wife, Molly; two sons, Ben and his wife, Fionn, of Los Angeles, CA, and Ted and his wife, Heidi, of Sebastopol, CA.; and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

9 P.M. (HBO) MARINA ABRAMOVIC THE ARTIST IS PRESENT (2012) For more than 90 days in the spring of 2010, the performance artist Marina Abramovic, above, sat in a plain wooden chair at the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan and gazed silently into the eyes of a succession of patrons, hundreds of thousands of whom had lined up for a chance to see her face to face. Some were held rapt; others cried. The effect was recorded in this documentary from Matthew Akers, who traces the genesis of that work. He also uses interviews and archival clips to chronicle the career of Ms. Abramovic, born to national heroes in Tito's Yugoslavia, who, as a member of the European avant-garde in the 1960s and '70s, gained a measure of fame for the fearless and sometimes violent ways she used her body in her performances. Embedded in the film is the love story between Ms. Abramovic and the German performance artist Frank Uwe Laysiepen, known as Ulay, who were romantic partners and collaborators. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said, ''Like many other recent documentaries about artists, it is more celebratory than analytical, a kind of slick, extended promotional video for its subject.'' 7:45 P.M. (Sundance) LITTLE CHILDREN (2006) Kate Winslet and Patrick Wilson, above, play Sarah Pierce and Brad Adamson, unfulfilled suburbanites who counter the boredom of their lives by embarking on an adulterous affair, in Todd Field and Tom Perrotta's screenplay from the novel by Mr. Perrotta. When Sarah joins a book club, it's ''Madame Bovary'' that's under discussion. Writing in The Times, A. O. Scott called the film superb, adding that ''Mr. Field, with his second feature -- his directing debut was 'In the Bedroom' -- proves to be among the most literary of American filmmakers, one of the few who tries to find a visual language suited to the ambiguous plainness of contemporary realist fiction.'' The result, he said, ''is a movie that is challenging, accessible and hard to stop thinking about. At one point Brad tells Sarah that beauty is overrated, something that, as the narrator notes, only someone secure in his own beauty would say. He may nonetheless be right. But in too many recent movies intelligence is woefully undervalued, and it is this quality -- even more than its considerable beauty -- that distinguishes 'Little Children' from its peers.''

Whoosh. There's nothing like an actor's pumping legs to stir up a breeze on a summer night. Make that legions of actors' legs, running and running and running in circles through (and at eye level with) much of the audience at the Gielgud Theater, where ''Chariots of Fire'' is now in residence. I was seated next to one of the (oh, what should I call it?) runways of the circular, multi-part stage that has been created for this amiable adaptation of the 1981 Oscar-winning movie about odds-beating British athletes at the 1924 Olympics. It's rather refreshing how much wind these lads manage to generate. They obviate the necessity of using one's program as a fan. Should the West End experience a power failure this summer, it's reassuring to know that the Gielgud has a human equivalent to air-conditioning.

Dear Diary: It's a typical late spring Thursday morning commute on a 5 train headed downtown from 59th street but standing out among the tableau of crammed commuters is a middle-aged man dressed in standard business casual attire, his blue button down shirt unremarkable but for a large, fantastically colored butterfly brooch affixed to the back of his shirt just below the collar.

The Park Avenue Armory's Board of Officers Room is to be restored by the architecture firm Herzog & de Meuron with a $15 million gift from the Thompson Family Foundation. The gift - from Angela Thompson and the family of Wade F. B. Thompson, the founding chairman of Park Avenue Armory, who died in 2009 - brings the family's total Armory donations to $50 million. The Armory's 55,000-square-foot Wade Thompson Drill Hall is named in honor of a $35 million gift in 2007. The Officers Room, one of the few remaining interiors by Herter Brothers - most recently used as a coat-check space for art fairs - will hold recitals, other small performances and art installations. Work will begin in the next few weeks and is to be completed in the fall of 2013.

One day, people will not have to type queries into a box to search for information. It will be delivered, via various devices, based on where they are, who is nearby and what they might like and need to know. Google gave a glimpse of that future last Wednesday at its developer conference in a feature called Google Now. It acts as a kind of automated personal assistant on Android smartphones.

According to Nielsen, more than 276 million Americans had access to the Internet in May. Of these, 173 million used a Google Web site, and 153 million visited Facebook. The average person visited 97 domains in the month, and had 2,716 page views. The time spent at each property represents the average among all users. In Facebook's case the average may be driven up by people who spend far more than seven hours each month posting and playing Scrabble. In YouTube's case, one hour and 50 minutes still represents a lot of five-minute video segments. SHELLY FREIERMAN

DEAR DIARY: I'm a stoop gardener. For six years I bounced around Williamsburg and Greenpoint, Brooklyn, with nary a slab of concrete to call my own. But since last year, when I moved to Crown Heights, I have 12 of them leading up to my door.

LOS ANGELES - Success in Hollywood can be measured in any number of ways: box-office grosses, the number of assistants you employ ... the size of your theme park ride. John Lasseter, Pixar's chief creative officer, now has an entire ''land'' devoted to his ''Cars'' movies - 12 acres in all at a Disney park called California Adventure. James Cameron and Disney are working on a similar size ''Avatar'' land in Orlando. You can almost hear the grumbling from George Lucas, who has a Disney ride based on his ''Star Wars'' films: James Cameron gets an entire land?
SLIDESHOW Fleeing the war in Sudan's Nuba Mountains, a new generation of Lost Boys, and some girls too, is being born. nytimes.com/world

Yo-Yo Ma, John Lithgow, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra are among the artists to be featured in Dartmouth College's special celebration of culture for the 2012-13 academic year, the New Hampshire college announced Friday. The programming is to begin in September with the inauguration of Dartmouth's new arts district, which includes the recently completed Black Family Visual Arts Center. The school's Hood Museum of Art and Hopkins Center for the Arts -- known as ''the Hop,'' which celebrates its 50th anniversary this fall -- are also planning expansions and renovations.

SIEGEL--Joan M.,born on June 7, 1917 in Hartford, Connecticut passed away peacefully on Saturday afternoon, June 23, at White Plains Hospital in White Plains, New York, and was laid to rest at Mount Lebanon Cemetery in Queens in a private, family ceremony on Thursday, June 28. Joan grew up in Connecticut and New York City and lived in Harrison, New York, and Palm Beach, Florida. She married her late husband, Fred Siegel in 1939 and was joyously married to him for sixty years until his death in 1999. She is survived by her son Kenneth, daughter-in-law Mary Clare, grandson Joseph, and grand daughter Eileen all of whom were dearly loved by her and devoted to her. She was the loving and beloved aunt of Robert Schoen and Ronni (Schoen) Fitzgerald, the son and daughter of her dear late sister and brother-in-law, Ruth and Murray Schoen. A long time member of Fenway Country Club in White Plains, New York, and the Palm Beach Country Club in Palm Beach, Florida, Joan was an active and eager supporter of the arts, being with her husband a founder of the Kravitz Center in West Palm Beach, Florida. A committed philanthropist all her life she and her husband were founders of the Albert Einstein School of Medicine. Joan strongly supported the United Jewish Appeal, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, the Holocaust Museum, and many other charities. She was a member of Temple Emanuel in Harrison, New York, and Temple Israel in West Palm Beach, Florida. Joan is sorely missed by her family and many friends and the grace, and loving kindness she exhibited all her life are an inspiration to all who knew her.

On a wild, whirling first day of free agency, Steve Nash emerged as the N.B.A.'s most coveted player and the Nets as the league's most active shopper. While Nash entertained presentations from the Toronto Raptors and the Knicks on Sunday, the Nets locked up one player (Gerald Wallace), engaged in trade talks for another (Joe Johnson) and made contact with seemingly half the league in a frantic effort to persuade their own free agent (Deron Williams) to stay.

As an avid Yankees fan for years, Edwin Tavarez often noticed bat boys on the field catching foul balls outside the first- and third-base lines and retrieving bats flung by hitters. But Edwin, an 18-year-old senior at Urban Assembly School for Careers in Sports, never imagined that one day he would have the opportunity to become one. ''I didn't know how they got the job,'' he said, ''so I didn't think I'd get it.''

Heard the one about the pregnant man? Yes, you probably have. But what if the joke turns out to be that he's basically the same as a pregnant woman? Oh, you've heard that one, too? Then you're unlikely to be terribly fascinated by ''Birthday,'' Joe Penhall's new play about one couple's agony in a maternity ward, which opened on Thursday night at the Royal Court Theater. Mr. Penhall, the author of the Olivier Award-winning ''Blue/Orange,'' would appear to have written ''Birthday'' as a male exercise in empathy for what child-bearing women are subjected to, especially at the clumsy hands of the National Health Service.

The rule, long on the books of the New York City Housing Authority, has not been heavily enforced: public-housing tenants who install air-conditioners in their windows must follow the manufacturer's specifications and have their work inspected by the housing authority. Penalties for noncompliance can include eviction, though no one has ever been kicked out of their apartment over an air-conditioner, the authority said.
GUTTMANN--Selma, on June 29, 2012. Beloved sister of Hilda Lededun of St. Louis, MO. Selma and Hilda both survived Auschwitz. Services were held on July 1, 2012 at Montefiore Cemetery.

KIEZ--Gregory Michael, a Board Member of Global Investment Holdings and Chairman of the Board of Global Ports Holding, has died at the age of 50 on June 30, 2012. Mr. Kiez had been battling brain cancer, specifically glioblastoma multiforme (GBM). Mr. Kiez was born in Canada and lived for the past 20 years in Turkey. He was Chairman of the Board of Ege Ports - Kusadasi, Chairman of the Board of Port Akdeniz - Antalya and Chairman of the Board of Global Ports Holding, all of which operate under Global Investment Holdings, where Mr. Kiez also served as a Board Member. Mr. Kiez held a BA degree in law from the University of Toronto and an LLB. He received numerous awards during his academic career, including scholarships from Norman Levy, Borden & Elliot, Dow-Hickson, as well as the James Cappon Award and the James McGill Award. During the time he spent in Turkey, Mr. Kiez, promoted Turkey and created a new maritime industry sector, positioning Turkey as a major player within it. Today, his speech at the "Security Pollution" Panel of the 2004 Maritime Trade Congress in Miami is considered the milestone of port sector development in Turkey. Mr. Kiez played a significant role in social welfare initiatives targeted at underprivileged children and the improvement of educational services. His philanthropic activities included the establishment of The Gregory Michael Kiez Applied and Theoretical Classrooms of the Adnan Menderes University Tourism and Hotel Management College facilities. From 2006, he served as a board member of Texas A&M University-Institute of Nautical Archeology that spearheaded many crucial excavations. Mr. Kiez supported multiple initiatives and made donations to create awareness of GBM, to develop treatment methods and help others in their struggle against it. A trust has been established in his name for Brain Tumors at the Yale Medical School. Funeral Mass 05 July 2012, 2012 at 10.30am at St. Esprit Church - Istanbul Funeral Ceremony 05 July 2012, at 18.30, Sandima Koyu Cemetery Yalikavak-Bodrum. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to TAY Project (The Archaeological Settlements of Turkey) http://www.tayproject.org/ enghome.html

''In Japan, the hand can be used like a knife,'' the off-screen narrator of a television commercial intones as a wooden board is karate-chopped in two. ''But this method doesn't work with a tomato.'' Suddenly the hand tries to cleave a plump tomato. Splat! That commercial was the first of a hokey series for Ginsu knives, broadcast from 1978 to 1984. And masterminding them were Barry Becher and Ed Valenti, business partners who made a fortune marketing the knives on television as ultrasharp and versatile and helping to pave the way for the infomercial and other kinds of direct-response television.

COHEN--Elias A. Although 60 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1st, 1919. In the spirit of Noblesse Oblige his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 94th year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc.Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President

LEWENT--Rose-Marie, of Manhattan, passed on Friday evening June 29, 2012. Beloved wife of Dick H. Devoted mother of Judy Lewent, Steven Lewent, and Jeffrey Lewent. Loving grandmother of Gabriel Lewent. Her independence and indomitable spirit is an inspiration to us all.

GEORGETOWN, Cayman Islands - Just off the tarmac at the Grand Cayman International Airport, visitors were recently greeted by colorful banners advertising the Caribbean island's sunny offerings: waterfront seafood restaurants, tax-free shopping - and hedge fund directors for hire. In the last decade, as hedge funds ballooned in size and number to become a dominant force in the investing universe, directorship services have grown from a cottage industry into a big business on the Cayman Islands. Many funds run by United States money managers have their legal residence here for tax reasons. And because of a quirk in the island's tax code, these funds must appoint a board.
THIS BRIGHT RIVER By Patrick Somerville

It's no secret that programmers at start-ups are predominantly men. A group of technology companies hopes to change that. On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced that they were joining an initiative called ''Girls Who Code,'' which they hope will increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers. They want to create a mentoring and teaching program. The Girls Who Code group was founded by Reshma Saujani, a former New York City deputy public advocate, who plans to begin the coding program in New York this summer.

A play by the actor Jesse Eisenberg is one of five world premieres that will highlight the 2012-13 season for the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, the company announced. Mr. Eisenberg (''The Social Network'') was nominated for a Drama League Award this year for his previous Rattlestick production, ''Asuncion,'' which he wrote and starred in. His forthcoming drama, ''The Revisionist,'' focuses on a struggling writer who travels to Poland to stay with his 73-year-old second cousin, who is a Holocaust survivor. The play will be directed by Kip Fagan, with performances scheduled to begin on Feb. 6 at the Cherry Lane Theater. The season will start on Sept. 13 with ''Through the Yellow Hour,'' a new play written and directed by Adam Rapp (''Red Light Winter''), about one woman's attempt to survive apocalyptic events. That is to be followed by, among others, ''The Correspondent,'' written by Ken Urban (''The Private Lives of Eskimos''), and ''Basilica,'' written by Mando Alvarado (''The Yellow Brick Road'').

Survived by her husband of 65 years, Dr. Victor Baum and her two children, Dr. Michael Baum and Deborah Chapin-Horowitz and her sister, Lia Friedman. Grandmother of Daniel Baum and Joshua Chapin. Services were held in Sarasota, Fla. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Queens College ACE program.

BARLOW--Mark, 87, On June 23, 2012, Dean at Wesleyan University 1957-1965, VP for Student Affairs at Cornell University 1965-1979, and Headmaster at St. Mark's School 1979-1988. Memorial service August 25 at Kendal in Hanover, NH. Details at www.rand-wilson.com

Dear Diary: Summer means corn on the cob. Back in the 1940s, when I was a kid, the best place to bite into an ear was at Coney Island. After a day of looping-the-loop at Luna or Steeplechase Park, my dad and I always made it a point to stop at a beachy restaurant with a caldron of boiling water standing in its windowless front, with lots of Golden Bantam dancing in the bubbles.

BARTLETT--Peter Barry. February 21, 1934 -- June 27, 2012. Peter Barry Bartlett passed away peacefully in his home in New York City on June 27, 2012. He was born in Boulder, Colorado in 1934 an only child to Christopher Hammond Bartlett and Marie Powers Bartlett. He graduated from Phillips Andover Academy in 1952 as a varsity basketball and soccer player. He then graduated from Yale University in 1956 where he was the Captain of the 1955 soccer team. As goalie, he held the career shutout record for over 30 years. Upon graduating, he moved to New York City and joined Brown Brothers Harriman, Inc. where he was named Partner in 1974. He served on the Steering Committee for 15 years and was the supervising partner of Banking and Treasury. Peter remained a Limited Partner until his death. He was a 30-year member of the Board of Directors for Kennametal Inc. and also a board member for Erie Insurance. He served his community as a member of the Board of Directors for Beekman Downtown Hospital and as a member of the Pension and Investment Subcommittee at Meridian Health System, Inc. An avid outdoorsman and sports enthusiast, he raised his family in Summit, NJ and in later years divided his time between his homes in Bay Head, NJ and Kiawah, SC. He served on the Finance Committee at the Bay head Yacht Club and was a founding member of Briar's Creek Golf Club on St. John's Island, SC. He also enjoyed spending time at The Links Club in New York and Rolling Rock Hunt Pony Club in Ligonier, PA. As a devoted family man and friend, he will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his former wife Elizabeth Easton Bartlett of NY, NY and Weston, CT and his children, Kim Kernan, of Rowayton, CT, Chris Bartlett of New Canaan, CT and Gibson Island, MD, Kate Lieder of Ridgefield, CT and Ian Duvenhage of Nashville, TN. He is also survived by his six grandchildren, Peter and Avery Kernan, Elizabeth and Nicholas Bartlett and Christopher and Carly Lieder. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children 161 William Street, 9th Floor, NY, NY 10038 or The Boy's Club of New York 287 East 10th Street, NY, NY 10009. Information regarding a Memorial Service will be announced at a later date.

When I played a lot of golf, I would sometimes wake up to find my arms stretched above me with hands in an interlocking grip. I would have anxious, confusing dreams about making tee times, finding the first tee and hitting impossible shots. I used to participate in a PGA Tour pro-am tournament every year. In my conscious mind, I was naturally worried about taking my game to a difficult golf course with thousands of eyes watching me play. In my dream-state mind, visions of potential disastrous pro-am shots were plentiful. In one dream, I hit a shot into a V.I.P. tent, and my ball landed on top of a table in someone's dinner plate. When I walked into the tent to find my ball, everyone inside the tent went ''Shhhhhhh'' and grew quiet. Carefully, I climbed on top of the table and hit my shot out of someone's plate. The ball ricocheted around the tent, landing in various places, and I kept hitting the ball until it finally flew out from the tent flaps and back into the fairway.

Horacio Coppola, whose black-and-white photographs of the cafes, side streets and neon-lit boulevards of Buenos Aires in the 1930s, and of ordinary objects like a typewriter and a doll, introduced avant-garde photography to Argentina, died on June 18 in Buenos Aires. He was 105. His death was confirmed by Michael Hoppen, a gallery owner in London who deals in Mr. Coppola's work. Mr. Hoppen donated a Coppola photograph to the Tate Modern museum in London, where it was put on display just a few weeks before Mr. Coppola's death.

Facebook's debut was supposed to be Nasdaq's ultimate coup. But in the weeks since the social network's much-ballyhooed - and ultimately botched - initial public offering, the relationship has soured.

The ''Star Trek'' shuttle craft from the U.S.S. Enterprise sold Thursday at auction for more than $70,000 after a bidding war, the Associated Press reported. The partially restored 24-foot-long Galileo craft that was used in the original 1960s TV series had been stored by a collector in the area of Akron, Ohio, for years, according to a report in the Repository in Canton.

Linde of Germany said Sunday that it had agreed to buy Lincare Holdings, a Florida-based provider of respiratory therapy equipment for homes, for $3.5 billion to expand its product offerings. Linde, one of the biggest providers of industrial air and gas products in the world, will pay $41.50 a share in cash. That represents a 22 percent premium over Lincare's closing price on Friday. It is also a 64 percent premium to Lincare's closing price on June 26, the day before The Financial Times's Alphaville blog reported that the company might sell itself to Linde.

Dear Diary: As they say, one is a sighting, two is a coincidence, three is a trend, but four? I have had the following sightings starting in late May: No. 1. Driving on West 202nd Street to get to the Harlem River Drive. Chicken crosses road, immediately followed by a rooster (giving birth to my own personal theory of ''Why did the chicken cross the road?'').

SKLAR--Robert. (December 3, 1936 - July 2, 2011) Remembered with great love, and with abiding, daily sadness by family, friends, colleagues, students, and all who felt so privileged to know and love him. So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

Friday was the fifth anniversary of the sales debut of the iPhone. Love it or hate it, Apple's touch-screen handset has made an impact on some aspect of your life -- whether it's how you work, communicate with friends, plan your day or read the news. What follows is a quick reflection on the two major markets that the iPhone disrupted.

Uber, a start-up based in San Francisco, has won a following among urbanites with its novel twist on calling a car service: its app lets you summon a luxury sedan with a tap on your phone. Now it is trying to appeal to the less affluent by adding less luxurious cars. In San Francisco and New York on Wednesday, Uber will start to give customers the option of choosing a hybrid car at a price that it says will be 10 to 25 percent more than a taxi. That compares with the 40 to 100 percent premium that customers pay for a black town car.

On Old Timers' Day at Yankee Stadium, Joe Torre said of his old friend Yogi Berra, ''Since he's been back, he never misses anything - especially this day.'' But until Berra arrived at Yankee Stadium on Sunday morning - accompanied by Dave Kaplan and Joni Bronander of his museum and learning center staff in Little Falls, N.J. - there was some question as to whether Berra would attend the annual event, the last of its kind in the major leagues.

After a year of trying a Tumblr page, the Web site for NBCLatino.com is ready to face its readers. On Monday, NBC News will officially announce the site dedicated to news and features for a Latino audience. ''We want to tell the Hispanic-American story with Hispanic-American voices in English,'' said Chris Peña, the site's executive editor. ''It's a young demographic; we know it's a growing demographic.''

I have seen the future, and it is wearable. But before I tell you about this future, let's take a short trip into the past, specifically to the mid-1400s, when a German by the name of Johannes Gutenberg was hard at work inventing the printing press. There's a common misconception that Gutenberg's press instantly changed society. This isn't quite so.

The lead singer of the metal band Lamb of God has been arrested on manslaughter charges in the Czech Republic in connection with the death of a fan who jumped onstage two years ago during a concert, The Associated Press reported. The singer, Randy Blythe, an American, was taken into custody before the group's scheduled performance on Thursday at the Hard Rock Cafe in Prague. The police said that he had tussled with a fan who tried to leap on the stage while the group was pounding through a heavy-metal set in 2010 at Club Abaton in Prague. The man later died from his injuries. A statement from the Prague police said that Mr. Blythe, right, had been charged ''with the crime of bodily harm of the fourth degree resulting in the death of the fan.'' But a publicist for the band, which is from Richmond, Va., said that no formal charges had been made, and that the case remained under investigation. The publicist, Maria Ferrero, said in a statement that Mr. Blythe had been accused of pushing the fan off the stage after the fan got past security guards. ''This incident deals with a fan that three times during the concert jumped the barricade and rushed Randy during the performance,'' Ms. Ferrero said in a statement. ''It is alleged that the third time, security was not able to reach him, and that Randy pushed him back into the audience where supposedly he fell and hit his head.''

Deron Williams formally committed to the Nets on Tuesday night, boosting their fortunes on and off the court as the franchise moves to Brooklyn next fall. Williams announced his decision on Twitter, sending a message at 7:03 p.m. Eastern that featured the Nets' new black-and-white logo under the words, ''Made a very tough decision today.'' He chose the Nets over the Dallas Mavericks, his hometown team, who were also aggressive in their pursuit.

Thoughts may be ephemeral, but a tweet, apparently, is forever. A Criminal Court judge in Manhattan ruled on Monday that Twitter must turn over to prosecutors messages sent by a Brooklyn writer during the Occupy Wall Street protests last fall. In doing so, the judge, Matthew A. Sciarrino Jr., indicated that although private speech was protected, the same did not apply to public comments on Twitter.

I grew up with a fat dad -- 450 pounds at his heaviest. Every week he would rotate to a new fad diet, and my family ended up eating whatever freeze-dried, saccharin-loaded concoction he was trying at that moment. By the time I was 9, I was an expert on Atkins, Pritikin and Weight Watchers, just to name a few. Did I mention spending four weeks at Duke University's ''fat farm'' consuming only minuscule bowls of white rice, while my 10-year-old peers were home eating ice cream cones? In spite of being shorter and scrawnier than my classmates, I was eating calorie-free astronaut mystery powders and drinking diet sodas, which were the only staples in our kitchen. My dad was obsessed with his career in advertising and his fluctuating weight, which was fluctuating mostly in the wrong direction. Every new diet, no matter how stringent or odd, was the potential solution for his expanding waistline.

An art review on Friday about an exhibition of drawings and prints by the 17th-century artist Giovanni Benedetto Castiglione at the David Tunick gallery in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the connection between Castiglione's drawings and the work of Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. Tiepolo was born 32 years after Castiglione died, thus Castiglione's drawings may look ahead to Tiepolo's work but they do not ''nod'' to it.

Millens Sons (founded in 1888 in Kingston) and Charles Effron & Son (since 1972) of Poughkeepsie. Both companies operate in the scrap iron and metal businesses. Husband of Joan, father of Samuel and the late Jennifer. Funeral at 12:00 on Tuesday in Kingston. Shiva at the Millens' residence on Tuesday - Thursday from 6:00-9:00pm. Donations to Hospice Foundation, 34 Broadway, Kingston, NY 12401. www.SimpsonGaus.com

BARTLETT--Peter Barry. February 21, 1934 -- June 27, 2012. Peter Barry Bartlett passed away peacefully in his home in New York City on June 27, 2012. He was born in Boulder, Colorado in 1934 an only child to Christopher Hammond Bartlett and Marie Powers Bartlett. He graduated from Phillips Andover Academy in 1952 as a varsity basketball and soccer player. He then graduated from Yale University in 1956 where he was the Captain of the 1955 soccer team. As goalie, he held the career shutout record for over 30 years. Upon graduating, he moved to New York City and joined Brown Brothers Harriman, Inc. where he was named Partner in 1974. He served on the Steering Committee for 15 years and was the supervising partner of Banking and Treasury. Peter remained a Limited Partner until his death. He was a 30-year member of the Board of Directors for Kennametal Inc. and also a board member for Erie Insurance. He served his community as a member of the Board of Directors for Beekman Downtown Hospital and as a member of the Pension and Investment Subcommittee at Meridian Health System, Inc. An avid outdoorsman and sports enthusiast, he raised his family in Summit, NJ and in later years divided his time between his homes in Bay Head, NJ and Kiawah, SC. He served on the Finance Committee at the Bay head Yacht Club and was a founding member of Briar's Creek Golf Club on St. John's Island, SC. He also enjoyed spending time at The Links Club in New York and Rolling Rock Hunt Pony Club in Ligonier, PA. As a devoted family man and friend, he will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his former wife Elizabeth Easton Bartlett of NY, NY and Weston, CT and his children, Kim Kernan, of Rowayton, CT, Chris Bartlett of New Canaan, CT and Gibson Island, MD, Kate Lieder of Ridgefield, CT and Ian Duvenhage of Nashville, TN. He is also survived by his six grandchildren, Peter and Avery Kernan, Elizabeth and Nicholas Bartlett and Christopher and Carly Lieder. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children 161 William Street, 9th Floor, NY, NY 10038 or The Boy's Club of New York 287 East 10th Street, NY, NY 10009. Information regarding a Memorial Service will be announced at a later date.

Microsoft owned up on Monday to the collapse of its biggest push into digital advertising, announcing that it would take a $6.2 billion accounting charge in its online services division for a failed acquisition. The accounting charge, called a write-down of good will, was essentially a write-off of the value of aQuantive, a digital advertising company that Microsoft bought in 2007. It will effectively wipe out Microsoft's fourth-quarter profit.

It is more generally the custom for a new bride and groom to get presents rather than to give them. But two days after Alec Baldwin and Hilaria Thomas were married at a star-studded and music-filled wedding in Manhattan, the New York Philharmonic said on Monday that it had received a gift of $1 million from Mr. Baldwin to honor Zarin Mehta, its outgoing president and executive director. Mr. Baldwin, the actor and ''30 Rock'' star, is a member of the Philharmonic's board and the host of its radio show, ''The New York Philharmonic This Week''; he is also an enthusiastic advocate for that orchestra, which he has plugged in the occasional Capital One credit card commercial.
