LOOKER--Robert, 1922-2012. Founder of Satco. Robert Looker, well-known industrialist, businessman, patron of the arts, and philanthropist, founder and chief executive officer of El Segundo-based Satco, has died. He was in his 90th year. Looker died at UCLA Santa Monica Hospital on June 28 after a brief illness. Satco, which Looker established in 1968, benefited greatly from his engineering inventiveness to produce pioneering models and variations of so-called unit load devices (ULDs) for air cargo, which won for his company the major market share in the field, notably with FedEX, UPS, and many airlines worldwide. Operations take place in El Segundo, near LAX, in seven buildings dedicated to the design, manufacture, sales and service of the various products. In addition there are three repair stations located in Memphis, Louisville, and Indianapolis, where maintenance service is conducted. Looker remained at the helm of the company until the end, appearing at his desk every day of the week. For most of his life, he would drive down the coast from his home in Montecito, "Villa Califia" (built by Gordon Kaufman, architect of the Greystone Mansion, Santa Anita and the Los Angeles Times Building); but in recent years he stayed more often at his new house on The Strand in Manhattan Beach, designed by architect Frederick Fisher. "Dad was a hands-on and feet-on boss," says his son Peter, Executive Vice-President of the company. "We called him 'Designer Bob'--he was always innovating, always improving, always leading the way. When he got something in his sights, change was on the way." He established the high standards for the air- cargo business that remain active today. Looker was a patron of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and especially of the art scene in the city. He was at one time on the Board of Trustees of both LACE and MOCA, and was still a trustee of LACMA, and a member of the National Gallery of Art Acquisition Committee. He was an important collector of modern and contemporary art, especially German Expressionism, and his acquisitions were on display in his homes in California, New York (Greenwich Village) and London (Brompton Square). Robert Looker was born in Grosse Pointe, Michigan, on August 30, 1922, son of Oscar Looker and Dorothy Jane West Bernard, where he grew up with his older sister Dorothy. During World War II he entered the navy and attended the Naval Academy at Annapolis, graduating in 1946. He remained devoted to the school, making major donations to it, and for the last ten years he served as a member of the Academy's President's Circle. He was prominent in celebrating his class's major anniversaries, although after the 50th he organized one for 52 ++ years in New Orleans, fearing that some colleagues might not last until the 55th date. He himself went beyond year 65. While still in the Academy, on June 12, 1945, he married Mary Marjory Macbeth of Grosse Pointe, who remained his constant companion all his life; they had six children together. After his naval service, Looker joined the Huck Manufacturing Company of Detroit to work for his stepfather and mentor (Lou Huck) and became national sales manager. In 1957, he moved his family from Grosse Pointe to Santa Monica, and bought the Brownline Manufacturing Company, which he operated until 1968, when he formed Satco--as in "Satisfactory Company." Bob Looker was constantly striving to expand his intellectual as well as artistic horizons. He was always very interested in philosophy, theology, and hagiography (the scholarly history of saints), especially after he and his family became Catholics in 1968 and fans of the Paulist Fathers at St. Paul the Apostle Church in Westwood. Among his favorite thinkers were Cardinal Newman, Friedrich Nietzsche, Martin Heidegger, Dietrich Bonhoeffer, Hannah Arendt, and, most recently, Epicurus and Lucretius. He was so impressed with Nietzsche, and eager to spread his enthusiasm for his works, that he tried for several years to create a chair of Nietzsche studies at a suitable university, but in the end he decided that his efforts and resources would be best employed in funding the preservation and restoration of the philosopher's personal notes and papers, which were in disarray and decay in the Nietzsche archives in Weimar, Germany. With the grateful assent of the local authorities, he imported expert technicians who went to work, and after long labors put everything in order, producing 45 volumes bound in gold-tooled leather, of all of Nietzsche's published works (5 vols.), lecture notes (3 vols.), philosophical notebooks (24 vols.), memoranda (10 vols.), and musical compositions (3 vols.). An additional volume contained an index and description of the over 900 books in Nietzsche's personal library. An exact duplicate of these volumes, and microfilms of all of the material, were donated by Looker and his philanthropic arm, the Looker Foundation, to the New York Public Library in 2002. The Nietzsche project led to the founding of The Looker Foundation in 1995 for the purpose of supporting programs that address the unmet needs of children, families, education, the environment, and culture and arts. Over the years, major grants have been rewarded to Skowhegan School of Painting & Sculpture, Wheels for Humanity, and the Environment Defense Fund among many other worthy and important organizations. His family looks forward to many more years of honoring the entrepreneurial spirit of Looker and keeping the Foundation alive and giving. Looker's interest in Eastern thought and esthetics, especially Indian philosophy and Japanese design, should also be mentioned. He was a great supporter of Professor Raimundo Panikkar of the School of Religious Studies at the University of California, Santa Barbara, who helped shape his passion for these subjects, especially when viewed through Panikkar's unique merging of Eastern and Western traditions. Looker is survived by his wife Mary, his daughters Blair Ridenour (Tom) and Amy; his sons David (Monica), John, Peter, and Robert; and 10 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A funeral mass will be celebrated at St Paul the Apostle Church, Westwood, on Thursday, July 5, at 1:00pm.

BENANAV--Aviva. July 17, 1924 - July 1, 2012. Born Isadora Rosen in Ivesti, Romania, Aviva survived forced marches and a brutal Transnistrian ghetto during the Holocaust. She met her late husband, Joshua, in December, 1944, on the deck of a refugee boat sailing across the Black Sea, and married him three days later on a train in Turkey, bound for Palestine. Her incredible story of survival is told in Joshua and Isadora (Lyons Press, 2008), a book written by her grandson, Michael Benanav. After nine years in Israel Joshua and Aviva moved to the U.S., where she enjoyed a 25-year career as one of the top saleswomen at Lord & Taylor in Scarsdale, NY (which is no surprise given her charm and her love of people). She lived a life of deep emotion - joy, grief, and love - and brightened the world with her vibrance, her sense of humor, and her mondel bread. Her greatest pleasure was her family. Aviva is preceded in death by her father, Carol Rosen; mother, Anna Rosen, nee Iacobescu; husband, Joshua; daughter, Tamar; son, Jonathan; and brother Israel. She is survived by her sons, Gary, Jay, and Dan; daughters-in-law Ruth, Lucy, and Mary Ellen; grandchildren Michael, Tamara, Steven, Jesse, Aaron, David, Ethan, and Sam; and great-grandchildren David, Sara, and Lucas. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, July 5, 2012 at 10am in the Chapel of the Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Ave., Hartford, CT. Interment will follow in the Beth El Temple Cemetery, Avon. The family will be sitting Shiva at 11 Governors Row, West Hartford on Thursday and Friday, 2-7pm. Memorial donations may be made to the American Society for Yad Vashem at: www.yadvashemusa.org or by mail at 500 Fifth Avenue, 42nd Floor, New York, NY 10110. For further information, directions, or to sign the guest book for Aviva, please visit: www.weinsteinmortuary.com/ funerals.cfm.

An article on Thursday about a young woman and her family in Afghanistan who have taken the rare step of going public with allegations of rape misstated the surname of the head of the local police in Kunduz, where the attack is said to have taken place. He is Col. Mohammed Shokur, not Shutor.

Many studies have found that statins reduce the risk for recurring cardiac problems, but not the risk for death. Now an analysis suggests that the drugs may reduce mortality significantly only in men. For the report, which appears in Archives of Internal Medicine, researchers reviewed 11 randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled studies of statins that included 43,191 people, one-fifth of them women. For both sexes, statins were effective compared with placebos in preventing cardiovascular events and led to lower rates of coronary mortality and heart attacks.

OMAHA - There will be no sixth Olympic Games for Dara Torres. The 45-year-old 12-time Olympic medalist finished fourth in the 50-meter freestyle on Monday, the final night of the United States Olympic trials, then reaffirmed her decision to retire from swimming. ''This is really over,'' Torres said as she held her 6-year-old daughter, Tessa. ''That's it. I'm going to enjoy my summer and have some time with my daughter and cheer on the U.S. team from afar.''

What would a television show that explores the formative years of the tormented ''Psycho'' motel proprietor Norman Bates, and created with help from producers of ''Lost,'' ''Friday Night Lights'' and ''Parenthood,'' look like? A&E will let you know just as soon as it finds out: on Monday, that cable channel said it had ordered a new series inspired by that classic Hitchcock suspense film, one that A&E is so crazily excited about that it is going straight to work on the program without producing a pilot episode. The new series, called ''Bates Motel,'' will offer ''a contemporary exploration of the formative years of Norman Bates'' as well as ''his relationship with his mother, Norma, and the world they inhabit,'' A&E said in a news release. Produced by Carlton Cuse (a show runner of ABC's science-fiction drama ''Lost'') and Kerry Ehrin (a producer and writer for NBC's ''Parenthood'' and ''Friday Night Lights''), the show will provide ''access to the dark, twisted back story and learn firsthand how Norma helped forge the most famous serial killer of them all,'' the cable channel said.

An article on Monday about Uber, a company whose app lets users summon a car service, misstated a point made in an e-mail from Allan Fromberg, a spokesman for New York City's taxi and limousine commission. He wrote that the city supported such services as long as they followed its rules; he did not say that Uber was following them.

8:58 p.m. | Updated For one of America's best-known television news anchors to be identified as gay was, until very recently, seen as a potential career-killer. But then, on Monday, it happened. And the TV nation seemed to shrug.

An article on Friday about the N.B.A. draft misstated the significance of the first-round draft picks of North Carolina and Kentucky. Though they each had four, they did not tie the record for the number of first-round picks; Kentucky holds the record with five, in 2010. The article also misidentified, in some editions, the team to which Tyler Zeller, the 17th pick, was traded. He will play for the Cleveland Cavaliers, not for the Charlotte Bobcats.

There was much hand-wringing early this year when a shuffling of priorities at Trinity Church seemed to put that institution's greatly admired music program in jeopardy. But Julian Wachner, the church's recently installed music director, appears to have warded off the threat, and judging from Trinity's involvement in the River to River Festival, the program seems to be thriving. Last week Mr. Wachner conducted Novus NY, Trinity's new contemporary-music ensemble, in Paola Prestini's ''Oceanic Voices.'' And on Sunday evening he presided over a candlelit concert of recent sacred works by Nico Muhly, with oldies by Herbert Howells and William Byrd, at St. Paul's Chapel.

An article on June 24 about whether the success of the Mets' R. A. Dickey would inspire other pitchers to try the knuckleball described incorrectly one of his achievements at the time. Dickey had thrown two straight one-hitters, not two straight shutouts. (An unearned run scored in one of the games.)
An editorial on June 25 about the revised G.E.D. test said incorrectly that it will be offered online. It will be administered by computer at official testing centers.

An article on Wednesday about Brandon Nimmo, the Mets' 2011 first-round draft pick from Wyoming who is playing for the minor league Brooklyn Cyclones, quoted incorrectly from comments by Paul DePodesta, the Mets' vice president for player personnel and amateur scouting. He said, ''If you had any chance to interact with him, you can tell he's not just some small-town kid'' -- not ''some town kid.''
It was like a hurricane -- but we didn't get the warning that you do with a hurricane. DAVID K. OWENS,

MARSHALL--Steven (Meszaros), 76, of New York City, passed June 30. Born Budapest, Hungary. Loving son of the late Victor and Pirko, brother of Andrew (deceased). Adoring husband and best friend of Virginia (Hartley), wonderful father of Michael and Jeffrey, loving father-in-law of Phoebe Potts, and doting grandfather of Lemi. Lehigh University (1957), 2nd Lt. US Army, member of the DGA. Assistant Director and Prod Mgr for film and TV in New York/Los Angeles. At the time of his death he was Project Coordinator for the ARUBA study, Neurology Department, Columbia University. Also survived by nephew Scott, and cousins Daniel and Michael Meszaros. Memorial Service July 6, 11am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St/Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers, family suggests donation to VNSNY Hospice: vnsny.org

Chris Brown added fuel to the dispute between himself and the rapper Drake over the weekend, releasing an insulting rap track aimed at Drake on Saturday. Mr. Brown's decision to ratchet up his war of words with Drake came just as the dispute seemed to be dying down and a day before he was to appear at the BET awards. It generated another round of stories on hip-hop blogs and focused attention on his performance at the awards show, his first since he was injured during a brawl with several acquaintances of Drake on June 14 at club W.i.P. in Manhattan. Drake was also at the club but maintains he left minutes before the violence started.

LEWENT--Rose-Marie. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Rose-Marie Lewent and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein President David Edelson Central Synagogue of New York City

Robert E. Diamond Jr., the chief executive of Barclays, told employees on Monday that he was ''disappointed and angry'' about the bank's past attempts to manipulate key interest rates to bolster its bottom line. But fresh details about the case show how Mr. Diamond and other senior executives played a role in the questionable actions and failed to prevent them. In 2007 and 2008, Mr. Diamond's top deputies told employees to report artificially low rates in line with its rivals, deflecting scrutiny about the health of Barclays at the height of the financial crisis, according to several people close to the case.

PATTERSON--Lee Willing, 72, Frederick W. Hilles Professor Emeritus of English, Yale University, died peacefully at home on June 29, 2012. Distinguished scholar, author, and teacher, he is survived by five loving children, eight grandchildren, and students around the world who continue his extraordinary legacy. Memorial services will be held at 11am on July 12, 2012, at Dwight Chapel, Yale University, New Haven, CT.

In the largest settlement involving a pharmaceutical company, the British drugmaker GlaxoSmithKline agreed to plead guilty to criminal charges and pay $3 billion in fines for promoting its best-selling antidepressants for unapproved uses and failing to report safety data about a top diabetes drug, federal prosecutors announced Monday. The agreement also includes civil penalties for improper marketing of a half-dozen other drugs. The fine against GlaxoSmithKline over Paxil, Wellbutrin, Avandia and the other drugs makes this year a record for money recovered by the federal government under its so-called whistle-blower law, according to a group that tracks such numbers.

A low-carbohydrate, high-protein diet may increase the risk for cardiovascular disease, according to a large study in Swedish women. The study, published in the journal BMJ, was based on a random sample of 43,396 women ages 30 to 49, each of whom completed a dietary questionnaire. The researchers used the data to create a 20-point scale, with higher scores indicating a lower ratio of carbohydrates to protein.

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: LESLIE HOWARD During the 1930s and early '40s, Howard, whose on-screen persona was genteel and romantic, was considered among the most charismatic of British leading men. Although he appeared in comedies like ''It's Love I'm After'' (1937), he is mostly remembered as the aristocratic and melancholy Ashley Wilkes (above, with Vivien Leigh) in ''Gone With the Wind'' (1939). Born in London in 1893 to a British mother and a Hungarian father, he took up acting as therapy for shell shock after serving in World War I. He made his film debut in the British silent movie ''The Heroine of Mons'' (1914) and did a star turn on Broadway in ''Her Cardboard Lover'' before bolstering his film career in 1930 by reprising his stage role from ''Outward Bound.'' Howard died in 1943 when his flight from Portugal to Britain was shot down by the Germans over the Bay of Biscay. He had gone to Lisbon to lecture on theater but was active in anti-Nazi propaganda and may have been involved in intelligence-gathering activities. ''Gone With the Wind'' begins this monthlong tribute, although Howard is said to have disliked both the film and his character, and to never have read the novel. The lineup continues with ''Stand-In'' (1937), at midnight, in which he plays an efficiency expert for a New York bank who takes over a Hollywood studio to prove that it shouldn't be sold; ''The First of the Few'' (1942), at 1:45 a.m., in which he portrays the real-life fighter-plane designer R. J. Mitchell; ''The Gentle Sex'' (1943), at 4 a.m., Howard's fourth and last picture as a director, about the women's branch of the British Army during World War II; and ''The Lamp Still Burns'' (1943), which he produced, and which was released a few months after his death. Based on a novel by Monica Dickens, a great-granddaughter of Charles, it tells of the struggles of the nurses who served in British hospitals during the war. 7 P.M. (Starz) JUMPING THE BROOM (2011) Paula Patton and Laz Alonso play Sabrina Watson and Jason Taylor, lovebirds planning what should be the perfect wedding. That is, until Jason's mother (Loretta Devine), a postal employee, arrives with a chip on her shoulder at the estate of Sabrina's uptight parents. ''Our family were never slaves,'' says Mrs. Watson (Angela Bassett), who likes to converse in French. ''We owned slaves.'' Mayhem ensues as the movie examines, among other subjects, class conflict among African-American families. In The New York Times, A. O. Scott wrote that the film's director, Salim Akil, and its screenwriters, Elizabeth Hunter and Arlene Gibbs, ''fall back on the tried-and-true staple of the busy nuptial weekend to stage a talk show season's worth of conflicts and revelations, both serious and comical.'' The film, whose producers include T. D. Jakes, the Dallas minister and self-help author, is like one of Tyler Perry's movies, Mr. Scott added, but ''stripped of both the anarchic comedy and the over-the-top, operatic passions.''

SULLIVAN--Mary C.,on June 30, 2012. Beloved daughter of James and Catherine (nee Sheridan). For many years, Mary was the chairperson of the Department of German Language at Hunter College, NYC. Mary was devoted to her craft but most especially to her students and friends. Services will be held at St. Jean Baptiste Church, 76th St./Lexington Ave, NYC on Thursday, July 5th at 10am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

COLUMBUS, Ohio -- One day in 1991, high in the thin, crystalline air of the Peruvian Andes, Lonnie G. Thompson saw that the world's largest tropical ice cap was starting to melt. It was the moment he realized that his life's work had suddenly become a race. The discovery meant other ice caps were likely to melt, too, and the tales of past climate that they contained could disappear before scientists had a chance to learn from them.

Despite a flurry of last-minute deals, the market for mergers and acquisitions stayed in the doldrums for the first half of the year, as the European fiscal crisis and a bumpy economy sapped corporate confidence. Only the announcement of a few transactions on Friday, notably Anheuser-Busch InBev's $20.1 billion takeover of Grupo Modelo, prevented the second quarter and first half of the year from looking even worse.

As in most labor disputes, the crowd of union workers chanting outside the headquarters of Consolidated Edison near Union Square featured plenty of anti-management slogans and plenty of booing. But unlike most picket lines, it also boasted its own hip-hop artist: a 29-year-old performer who calls himself J.Scar and who arrived to cheers Monday afternoon to rap in solidarity with the pickets. He performed his song ''Underpaid,'' which features lyrics fitting for the workers' cause:

My recent column on optimism drew hundreds of comments from readers who testified to the value of living life as a glass half full. But one in particular - from a 90-year-old man living in Calabasas, Calif. - was especially telling. The reader, William Richmond, wrote that a phrase in the column, ''Fake it until you make it,'' summed up his long and very successful life. His approach to life could serve as a battle plan for the millions of recent college graduates now searching for work in an unforgiving job market, as well as for older adults trying to re-enter the workplace after a long hiatus and those who lost jobs and must now reinvent themselves.

Women who fear childbirth have longer labor than those who do not, a new study has found. Norwegian researchers assessed fear of childbirth with a 33-item questionnaire filled out at 32 weeks of gestation. After excluding those with a multiple pregnancy, breech presentation, preterm delivery or elective Caesareans, they were left with 2,206 women for the study, published online last week in the journal BJOG.

Willie Clark, the great vaudeville comedian, has a carved-in-stone list of things that are funny. Words that have ''k'' sounds, for instance, like pickle and cake and cucumber. Might I add to that list the image of a tufted Danny DeVito in striped pajamas and a sports jacket? This sight is even funnier if you place Mr. DeVito, thus attired, next to Richard Griffiths in a pinstriped suit and a fedora (accessorized with flashes of red that pick up on the colors of Mr. DeVito's pajamas). Why is this funny? Well, for starters, Mr. DeVito and Mr. Griffiths - who are starring in Neil Simon's ''Sunshine Boys'' at the Savoy Theater - are both anatomically improbable figures.

Back in the 1960s, researchers in Africa clocked the wild cheetah as it ran and determined that at full gallop, a cheetah reached a top speed of about 65 miles per hour, making it easily the world's fastest land mammal. No other quadruped or biped comes close. Galloping quarter horses top out around 47 miles per hour, while sluggish humans, in the person of the world record 100-meter sprinter Usain Bolt, have attained a top speed of less than 28 miles per hour. Even the bullet-trainlike greyhound, similar in build and running style to the cheetah, doesn't surpass 40 miles per hour. So what is it about the cheetah and its particular physiology or running form that allows it to set such a blazing pace? And can a better understanding of cheetah biomechanics help humans to move faster?

Judge Wieselthier was a great friend to our members and a protector of the rights of the disabled. Our condolences go out to his family. Gabriel Hermann, President Richard P. Morris, Secretary/Treasurer

Facing a slump after the financial crisis, JPMorgan Chase turned to ordinary investors to make up for the lost profit. But as the bank became one of the nation's largest mutual fund managers, some current and former brokers say it emphasized its sales over clients' needs.

ROSENTHAL--Ruth. Ruth Rosenthal, 91, beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grand-mother, who was always there for her family when things were most difficult, died July 1st at her Nantucket home with many of those who loved her. Ruth was born in Cleveland, OH in 1921. She married Irving Rosenthal in 1943, and they were married 65 years at the time of his death in 2008. They raised their three children in Great Neck, NY. Ruth is survived by her children David and Birgitta Rosenthal, Robert and Inka Rosenthal, Noah and Risa Finkel, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. She is also survived by her brothers Frank and Monty Moss. We will cherish her love and wisdom and know it will continue to nurture us. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be sent to: Palliative Supportive Care of Nantucket, 57 Prospect St., Nantucket, MA, 02554; Congregation Shirat Ha Yam, PO Box 1145, Nantucket, MA, 02554; The Irving Rosenthal Scholarship, CUNY Graduate School of Journalism, 219 W. 40th St., 3rd Floor, New York, NY 10018.

Days after the British bank agreed to pay $450 million to settle accusations that it had tried to manipulate important global interest rates, Robert E. Diamond Jr. resigned as chief executive on Tuesday. Marcus Agius, the chairman of Barclays' board who resigned on Monday, will now lead the bank's executive committee until a permanent replacement for Mr. Diamond has been found.

After accounting for the eight players removed from final consideration and the nine locked-in spots based on merit and service, the selection process for the United States men's national basketball team essentially comes down to five players competing for three remaining slots. There will be no additions and no compensations for injury. That bit of simplification is a gift; the Team USA pool has seen enough natural complication over the last several months, and for the first time in their team-building process, the USA Basketball chairman, Jerry Colangelo, and Coach Mike Krzyzewski have some idea of what their jumbled roster may look like.
Steve Nash, the longtime Phoenix Suns star and part-time New York resident, will join the Lakers, thrusting them back into title contention.

Regis Philbin hosts this fireworks display, the largest in the nation. The theme this year is ''Ignite the Night.'' (TMC) GREY GARDENS (1975) Before the Broadway musical and the HBO film there was this portrait of Edith Bouvier Beale and her daughter, Little Edie, directed by David and Albert Maysles. An aunt and a first cousin of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, the two lived as recluses in a deteriorating mansion in East Hampton, N.Y. ''There is no doubt about the artistry and devotion that the Maysles have used in recording the life in 'Grey Gardens,' '' said a review in The New York Times. ''There is no reason to doubt them when they say they love and admire the Beales. But the moviegoer will still feel like an exploiter. To watch 'Grey Gardens' is to take part in a kind of carnival of attention with two willing but vulnerable people who had established themselves, for better or worse, in the habit of not being looked at. And what happens when the carnival moves on?''

Students at Public School 9 Teunis G. Bergen in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, started the summer with the grim news that they would lose four teachers next academic year unless parents raised $160,000 -- and soon. The principal of the school, Sandra D'Avilar, told the parent-teacher organization last month that she would have to cut the teaching staff because the school now had fewer children officially designated ''poor,'' and so had lost $360,000 in federal Title 1 funding.

Maggie Paulus, who plans to open Populence, a sophisticated popcorn store, on Wednesday in Greenwich Village, said she might actually have popcorn in her genes. ''My father proposed to my mother with a ring in a Cracker Jack box,'' she said. Ms. Paulus, a native of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., who previously worked in fashion, is creating organic popcorn in unusual seasonal flavors. And she has nailed the production, which all happens in the back of the smart black-and-white shop, so that even in steamy weather, the ginger caramel and salted caramel flavors do not become sticky.

Opponents of the relocation of the Barnes Foundation and its world-renowned art collection from a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown museum quarter have asked a Pennsylvania court to reopen the case allowing the relocation, citing a comment made by the foundation's former director, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported. The 2004 ruling by Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans' Court permitted the foundation, which had struggled financially, to go against the wishes of Albert C. Barnes, who built the collection and stipulated that no picture in it could be lent, sold or moved from the walls of the galleries that he built for it in Merion, Pa. Judge Ott said at the time that he considered the move ''the only viable alternative'' to save the Barnes from bankruptcy, but opponents argued that the foundation's troubles had been overstated.

A theater listing in the Long Island calendar of events in some editions on Sunday misstated the address, phone number and Web address for the Long Island Shakespeare Festival in Selden, on the Ammerman Campus of Suffolk County Community College, that opens on Thursday and runs through July 15. It is at the Islip Arts Building, 533 College Road, not at the Maurice N. Flecker Memorial Gallery; the phone number is (631) 451-4163; and its Web site is lishakes.org.

DUNLOP--Joan B. The Board and the staff of the International Women's Health Coalition mourn the death of our beloved friend and colleague Joan B Dunlop (1934-2012) an ardent feminist, courageous advocate and inspirational leader. She was the first President of the Coalition, from 1984 to 1998. Under her leadership, the Coalition worked closely with women's rights activists from the developing world to persuade governments that women's reproductive health and rights had to be at the center of population policies. Joan - the women of the world will miss you!

Seventeen magazine, which in recent months has been inundated by pleas from teenage girls to publish photographs of models that don't look touched up, said on Tuesday that it would be more transparent about its photo shoots and promised to ''celebrate every kind of beauty.'' Ann Shoket, the magazine's editor in chief, wrote in the editor's letter in the August issue that the magazine had drafted what it called a Body Peace Treaty, after she heard from girls ''who were concerned that we'd strayed from our promise to show real girls as they really are.''

Heard the one about the pregnant man? Yes, you probably have. But what if the joke turns out to be that he's basically the same as a pregnant woman? Oh, you've heard that one, too? Then you're unlikely to be terribly fascinated by ''Birthday,'' Joe Penhall's new play about one couple's agony in a maternity ward, which opened on Thursday night at the Royal Court Theater. Mr. Penhall, the author of the Olivier Award-winning ''Blue/Orange,'' would appear to have written ''Birthday'' as a male exercise in empathy for what child-bearing women are subjected to, especially at the clumsy hands of the National Health Service.

President Obama remained cloistered with his wife and daughters at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland, for a fourth and final day on Tuesday - a rare long-weekend getaway that reflects the fact that the first family will forgo its usual August vacation in this election year. White House officials confirmed that the Obama family will not return to Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts as it has each summer of the president's term, and for years before. One official, who asked not to be identified discussing the Obamas' private plans, chalked up the decision - not surprisingly - to the demands of the re-election campaign calendar.

An article on Monday about the first day of free-agency in the N.B.A. misstated the amount of money remaining on Joe Johnson's contract with the Atlanta Hawks. There are four years and $89.3 million left, not $107 million. (The Nets made a deal later Monday night to acquire Johnson from the Hawks, but that will not be official until next Wednesday.)

3:39 p.m. | Updated Not unlike Kenny Powers, the supremely, magnetically arrogant baseball pitcher and protagonist of ''Eastbound & Down,'' HBO still knows how to throw a curveball now and then. Representatives for the cable channel confirmed a report in Variety that said it was ordering a fourth season of that comedy show -- an announcement that comes as a surprise after what sure seemed to be its series finale in the spring.

Manchester United filed for an initial public offering in the United States on Tuesday, a move that would return the English soccer team to the public markets. The club set a preliminary fund-raising target of $100 million to determine registration fees. It had previously hoped to raise about $1 billion in either Hong Kong or Singapore. Manchester United had traded on the London Stock Exchange before Malcolm Glazer, an American who also controls the Tampa Bay Buccaneers football team, took the company private in a $1.45 billion buyout in 2005.

What do you do if you're making a movie about a famous dead musician, and you can't get the rights to his music? Use other people's songs. That seems to be what has happened in the case of ''All Is by My Side,'' a biopic about Jimi Hendrix whose music has been the subject of some intrigue in the entertainment industry. The film stars André Benjamin of OutKast as Hendrix in 1966 and 1967, just before he became famous, and it is being shot in Ireland.

President Obama's campaign on Tuesday intensified its attacks on Mitt Romney for outsourcing jobs, releasing a new TV ad that accuses the former Massachusetts governor's old private equity firm of shipping jobs to low-wage countries. Independent fact-checking groups have criticized Mr. Obama's previous ads on the issue, saying there is scant evidence for the claim that Mr. Romney's companies shut down operations in the United States while opening new facilities in other countries.

An article on Tuesday about an announcement by Fermilab physicists that the Tevatron accelerator had fallen just short of finding the elusive subatomic particle known as the Higgs boson misstated the odds of an event's happening by chance that are required for particle physicists to use the word ''evidence'' in describing that event -- a standard known as ''3-sigma.'' The 3-sigma standard corresponds to one part in 770, not one part in 3,000.

A fresh wave of public opinion polls has been released in the last few days, measuring Americans' views of the Supreme Court and its decision to uphold most of the health care law. The surveys found Americans divided over the ruling, as they have been over the law since its enactment in 2010. The Pew Research Center found that 4 in 10 Americans approved of the Supreme Court's decision, and about the same number disapproved. Pew also found that despite the seeming great interest in the ruling on the health care law, nearly half of Americans were unaware the court had held up most of the provisions of the law. Three in 10 said they did not know how the court had ruled, while 15 percent said the court had rejected most of the law's provisions.

BARTLETT--Peter Barry. February 21, 1934 -- June 27, 2012. Peter Barry Bartlett passed away peacefully in his home in New York City on June 27, 2012. He was born in Boulder, Colorado in 1934 an only child to Christopher Hammond Bartlett and Marie Powers Bartlett. He graduated from Phillips Andover Academy in 1952 as a varsity basketball and soccer player. He then graduated from Yale University in 1956 where he was the Captain of the 1955 soccer team. As goalie, he held the career shutout record for over 30 years. Upon graduating, he moved to New York City and joined Brown Brothers Harriman, Inc. where he was named Partner in 1974. He served on the Steering Committee for 15 years and was the supervising partner of Banking and Treasury. Peter remained a Limited Partner until his death. He was a 30-year member of the Board of Directors for Kennametal Inc. and also a board member for Erie Insurance. He served his community as a member of the Board of Directors for Beekman Downtown Hospital and as a member of the Pension and Investment Subcommittee at Meridian Health System, Inc. An avid outdoorsman and sports enthusiast, he raised his family in Summit, NJ and in later years divided his time between his homes in Bay Head, NJ and Kiawah, SC. He served on the Finance Committee at the Bay head Yacht Club and was a founding member of Briar's Creek Golf Club on St. John's Island, SC. He also enjoyed spending time at The Links Club in New York and Rolling Rock Hunt Pony Club in Ligonier, PA. As a devoted family man and friend, he will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his former wife Elizabeth Easton Bartlett of NY, NY and Weston, CT and his children, Kim Kernan, of Rowayton, CT, Chris Bartlett of New Canaan, CT and Gibson Island, MD, Kate Lieder of Ridgefield, CT and Ian Duvenhage of Nashville, TN. He is also survived by his six grandchildren, Peter and Avery Kernan, Elizabeth and Nicholas Bartlett and Christopher and Carly Lieder. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children 161 William Street, 9th Floor, NY, NY 10038 or The Boy's Club of New York 287 East 10th Street, NY, NY 10009. Information regarding a Memorial Service will be announced at a later date.

An article on June 23 about threats to the artesian springs in Silver Springs, Fla., included several errors and also omitted the amount of time during which the springs' flow rate has declined. The state's main aquifer is known as the Floridan Aquifer, not the Florida Aquifer. The number of gallons sought by Frank Stronach, a rancher near the springs, was 13 million gallons a day -- not 23 million, as noted in some editions. The agency involved in a review of the groundwater supply is the Suwannee River Water Management District (not Suwanee). The director of that agency is Ann Shortelle, not Shortell. And the flow rate of the springs has declined over 10 years.

LONDON -- Robert E. Diamond Jr., a fiercely competitive Wall Street executive who hated to lose, recognized late Monday night that he was losing. Until then, the American-born chief executive of the British banking giant Barclays was convinced that he could survive the rising calls for his ouster after accusations from regulators in Britain and the United States that Barclays had manipulated important global interest rates with the knowledge of senior management.

When Barclays bank manipulated key interest rates to bolster profits during the 2008 financial crisis, senior executives said they were following a common practice that regulators implicitly approved, according to documents released by the bank and authorities. But the illicit acts, which led to a $450 million penalty for the bank, claimed its biggest victims on Tuesday: Robert Diamond, the British bank's chief executive, and one of his top deputies, Jerry del Missier, the chief operating officer. The scrutiny is expected to grow on Wednesday, when Mr. Diamond appears before a British parliamentary committee.

''Rent,'' the popular musical about the lives and loves of downtown New York artists in the era of AIDS, will close its Off Broadway run at New World Stages on Sept. 9, a little more than a year after the production opened there, its press representatives said on Tuesday. The Broadway version of ''Rent,'' Jonathan Larson's Tony Award- and Pulitzer Prize-winning update of Puccini's ''La Bohème,'' had been closed for about three years (following a 12-year-long run at the Nederlander Theater) when Jeffrey Seller, a lead producer of the original 1996 production, announced that he would present a revival at New World Stages.

LEAR--Evelyn. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of American soprano Evelyn Lear, who made her company debut in our first season at Lincoln Center, singing in the world premiere of David Martin Levy's Mourning Becomes Electra in 1967. Her Met repertoire encompassed a unique variety of roles that highlighted her astounding versatility, including the title role in Purcell's Dido and Aeneas (the only performances of the work in Met history), Countess Geschwitz in Berg's Lulu, the Countess in Mozart's Le Nozze di Figaro, and both Octavian and the Marschallin in Strauss's Der Rosenkavalier. She was an esteemed colleague at the Met and in her retirement a tireless teacher and advocate for young singers. We offer our sincere condolences to her children, grandchildren, and her many friends and admirers. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

Monday was the last day of work at the Wildlife Conservation Society for Steven E. Sanderson, the president of the organization since 2001. ERMENONVILLE, France-- Jean-Jacques Rousseau may have been born in Switzerland (Geneva in fact, in 1712) and not in France. But that tiny geographic detail has not kept the citizens of the Oise, the region north of Paris where Rousseau lived briefly and died, from celebrating the philosopher all year as a national hero. ''Rousseaumania,'' as the newspaper Le Journal du Dimanche called the celebration, includes picnics, conferences, publications, debates, plays, street theater, films, documentaries, concerts and dinners to pay tribute to the author of ''The Social Contract,'' which argues for a system of government and law based on the will of all citizens and remains one of the most influential works of Western political philosophy. Rousseau's house in the town of Montmorency, where he lived from 1757 to 1762, has reopened as a museum this month after a major renovation. Fourteen restaurants in the Oise have created special Rousseau-inspired menus. An authoritative version of Rousseau's complete works has been published in more than 15,000 pages. (The cheap version costs 720 Euros, the expensive one 1920).

An article in some editions on Friday about the Conservative Party in New York, which recently celebrated its 50th anniversary at a time when it has increased its sway within the Republican Party, referred imprecisely to the party affiliation of a candidate in the 1970 race for Robert F. Kennedy's former Senate seat, which was won by James L. Buckley, who ran solely on the Conservative line. Besides a Democrat, Mr. Buckley also defeated Charles E. Goodell, who ran as a Republican-Liberal candidate, not just as a Liberal Party candidate.

Q. I copied ''Ulysses'' from Project Gutenberg onto my Nook Simple Touch. When my Nook is connected to my computer, I can see and open the book in the Nook section of Adobe Digital Editions, but I can't find the book when I look in the Library on the Nook itself. Where is it? A. If you can see the ePub book in the Nook's library through the computer's Adobe Digital Editions program but cannot find the book on the e-reader's Library screen after you disconnect it from the PC, take a look at the pop-up menu at the top of the Nook's Library screen. Make sure the drop-down menu is set to All and not Books.

6 P.M. (Flix) THE DISCREET CHARM OF THE BOURGEOISIE (1972) Six upwardly mobile friends try to have dinner together -- but find they can't -- in this surrealist dreamscape from Luis Buñuel, which won an Oscar for best foreign film. Fernando Rey and Delphine Seyrig, above, lead the cast with Paul Frankeur and Jean-Pierre Cassel. Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby called the movie brilliant, adding, ''In addition to being extraordinarily funny and perfectly acted, 'The Discreet Charm' moves with the breathtaking speed and self-assurance that only a man of Buñuel's experience can achieve without resorting to awkward ellipsis.'' In ''A Woman Under the Influence'' (1974), at 8, Gena Rowlands plays a woman adrift, and Peter Falk is her manic husband, who keeps assuring her that everything's fine. She'll be anything he wants, she says. To which he shouts, ''Just be yourself!'' If only she were sure which one. ''A troubled person, yes, and certainly an insecure one,'' Nora Sayre wrote in The Times about this study of an unsteady marriage, written and directed by John Cassavetes, who was Ms. Rowland's husband. ''But she doesn't seem sick or crazed enough to justify the crackup that's awaiting her, nor to spend six months in a sanitarium. And that's the hitch in the movie: You can't really tell how the director regards this character.'' Still, she added, ''Mr. Cassavetes is unquestionably sympathetic to the rootless state of the Middle American housewife.'' Both Ms. Rowlands and Cassavetes were nominated for Oscars. 8 P.M. (13) NYC-ARTS Philippe de Montebello, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the journalist Paula Zahn report on the ''Dawn of Egyptian Art'' exhibition at the Met, the Theater for a New Audience and two works by the outsider artist Martín Ramírez at the American Folk Art Museum. In ''Poirot: Cat Among the Pigeons,'' on ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' at 9:30, David Suchet plays Hercule Poirot, Agatha Christie's debonair Belgian supersleuth. He takes on the case of a Middle Eastern princess who is hidden away from revolutionaries at an English girls' school, where, one after another, her teachers are found murdered.

CONNOLLY--James Patrick, a resident of both Stony Brook, NY and Sag Harbor, NY died on Monday, July 2 at Stony Brook University Medical Center. He was 90 years old. Born in New York City to parents Thomas Connolly and Catherine McDonagh both from Irish Counties Monahan and Galeway. He attended Stuyvesant High School. He enlisted in US Army in September of 1942. He saw action in campaigns and battles in Central Europe, Normandy, Northern France and the Rhineland. He received decorations and citations including The American Service Medal, Fame Service Medal, Good Conduct Medal and World War II Victory Medal. He was Honorably Discharged on December 24, 1945 with the rank of Staff Sergeant. He was a model for print advertising with the Hark Ryder Agency in New York City. Some say he had the same look as Clark Gable. He worked for and retired from The New York Times News Corporation after 25 years as a manager in the classified department. After retirement he volunteered at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, NY until he was 80 years old. He loved to travel the world especially on Ocean Liners. He was a gardener and had numerous cats and dogs throughout his life. He was strong willed, always had an opinion on any subject and would tell you as he saw it. A true fighter till the end of his life. He is predeceased by his younger brother Reverend Eugene G. Connolly of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York and his younger sister Mary Connolly Shapiro of Far Rockaway, NY. He is survived by a younger brother Francis J. Connolly Sr. and wife of Medford, NY. His two nephews, Francis J. Connolly Jr. and wife of Stamford CT, Gene M. Connolly of Sag Harbor, NY and nieces and nephews Thomas Connolly, Katherine Connolly, Lauren Connolly and Brian Connolly. Viewing is at Bryant Funeral Home in East Setauket, NY on Friday, July 6th 6-9pm with a Mass and Burial at St. James RC Church at 9:30am in East Setauket, NY. Any donations can be made to The Catholic Charities Association.

SALETAN--Eugene. Physicist, teacher, writer, poet, translator, artist, linguist, drummer, trombonist, folk dancer, skier, airman, Gene Saletan lived many lives. Until his last days, he envisioned more work to do and new paths to follow, but he ran out of time. He died on July 3rd of Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma. The second law of thermodynamics, he said, finally brought him down. He was 87 years old. The son of Russian immigrants in New York City, Gene grew up bilingual in English and Russian and went on to learn French and Italian as well as some Hindi, Spanish, Japanese, and German. He was at home and loved all over the world. During the Second World War, First Lieutenant Eugene Saletan took his place in what Tom Brokaw would later call the Greatest Generation. He served as a B-17 navigator in the 8th Air Force 96th Bomb Group and flew more than 30 missions over Germany from his base in East Anglia. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross. His service years interrupted his education. So did a period of translating scientific books, notably those of the Russian mathematician Israel Gelfand, a project he tackled with the assistance of his beloved first wife, the late Elma Margaret (Peggy) Junz Saletan. The G.I. bill helped Gene earn a Bachelor's degree from Brooklyn College and a Doctorate in physics from Princeton in 1962. He taught physics at Rutgers, Cooper Union, the Birla Institute of Technology in Rajasthan, India, and for more than 25 years was Professor of Physics at Northeastern University in Boston. As Professor Emeritus, Gene continued to flourish. He worked at Northeastern in the SEED and RESEED programs, dedicated to improving the quality of science teaching in middle and high schools. He carved out time to record science texts for blind and dyslexic students through RFB&D, now known as Learning Ally. In 1998, he and Professor Jorge Jose' published "Classical Dynamics: A Contemporary Approach." That book joined his previous texts: "Theoretical Mechanics," written with Professor Alan Cromer in 1971 and "Dynamical Systems" (1985) undertaken in collaboration with Neapolitan colleagues Professors Giuseppe Marmo, Alberto Simoni, and Bruno Vitale. And then, for fun, in 2007 he translated the children's book "The Crocodile" by K.I. Chukovsky from Russian into English. He leaves his adored and adoring wife, the former Ellen Nurnberg, also known as Ellen Cole, his dearly loved nephews, nieces, and cousins, and many cherished friends. Good night, sweet prince. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Eugene Saletan's honor to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society or The Parkinson Research Foundation. A memorial service is being planned for later in the year.

A police officer with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was stabbed in the eye on Wednesday in an apparently unprovoked attack beneath a railroad overpass in Jamaica, Queens, the authorities said. Despite a serious wound, he shot and killed his assailant, who kept coming at him and refused to drop his knife. The officer, John Barnett, 45, underwent more than four hours of surgery at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center.

Glen Duncan's novel ''The Last Werewolf'' was narrated by a 200-year-old man/wolf named Jake Marlowe. Jake's creepy condition forced him to eat a human being every month or perish, but otherwise he was a charming fellow. In The New York Times Book Review, Justin Cronin said the book ''plays out in splendid good fun, bouncing from one James Bondian locale to another, bon mot to bon mot, the text saturated with literary and cultural references.'' Mr. Duncan's new book is a sequel, ''Talulla Rising,'' about a female werewolf desperate to rescue her newborn son from a pack of vampires. In a recent interview via e-mail, Mr. Duncan discussed his relationship to the paranormal, the appeal of unsympathetic characters and why psychotherapy is not for him. Below are excerpts from the conversation. Q.

It is unlikely on this Fourth of July that anyone will be shooting bottle rockets off the copper flanks of the Statue of Liberty. But this is precisely what Pete Bluhm remembers happening on the holiday - he's not sure which year - in the mid-1930s when he lived as a child on Liberty Island next to the statue. His family was part of a small group of families of service members stationed at Fort Wood, an Army post that was operational on the island from 1811 until the 1930s.

Patrick Page, the veteran stage actor whose gleefully demonic portrayal of the Green Goblin in ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' was hailed as a consistent bright spot throughout the show's troubled development, will play his last performance on Aug. 5, a publicist for the production confirmed on Wednesday. Mr. Page, who originated the role, has been a notable survivor in a musical that has seen actors hospitalized in aerial mishaps when not being generally savaged by critics. Originally killed off in the first act, he saw his role expanded last spring after it tested well with focus groups assembled by the producers during the show's 180-some preview performances, the most in Broadway history.

It appears that Scotland's Old Firm has been liquidated, at least for now. After a meeting of the general managers of clubs from the Scottish Premier League, officials issued a brief, cryptic statement Wednesday: ''At today's general meeting, S.P.L. clubs voted overwhelmingly to reject the application from Rangers newco to join the S.P.L.'' Put most simply: Rangers, the winner of 54 domestic titles, has been kicked out of soccer's top tier in Scotland.

WASHINGTON -- Shakespeare Theater Company, one of the premiere ensembles in the nation's capital and the recent winner of a Tony award for excellence in regional theater, has gone to court to fight its threatened eviction from its home of 20 years. The Lansburgh Theater, a nonprofit that serves as the landlord for one of the sites where Shakespeare Theater performs, last year told the company that its annual rent there would jump to $480,000 from $70,000. When Shakespeare Theater refused to pay the increase, Lansburgh demanded that it vacate the site and that its managing director, Christopher Jennings, resign from the Lansburgh board. (The 451-seat Lansburgh space is where the company puts on its more intimate productions; its 774-seat main stage is now Sidney Harman Hall, which opened a few blocks away in 2007.)

WARD--Joseph Noel, M.D. F.R.C.S.,F.A.C.S., F.R.C.O.G. of Riverdale, NY on July 3, 2012. Beloved husband of the late Ann Curtin Ward M.D., and father of Fiona and Gregory Clapp, Dr. J. Desmond and Julie Ward and the late Joseph Francis Ward. Grandfather of Noel, Evangeline and Charlotte Clapp and Lily, Catherine and Colin Ward. A senior attending urologist at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center, New York and Associate Clinical Professor of Urology at College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, he was born in Northern Ireland, graduated from University College, Dublin as an undergraduate and then from medical school in 1949. He completed residencies at The Radcliffe Infirmary, Oxford, England, The Brady Institute, The Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, Maryland and Grady Memorial Hospital, Emory University, Atlanta, Georgia. He was a Diplomate, American Board of Urology and practiced urology in New York City for 40 years. For services: www.mcgrathandson.com.

Need a temporary close-up showing part of the computer's screen so you can see something better? Some versions of Windows and Mac OS X let you do just that. Windows XP, Windows Vista and Windows 7 include a utility called Magnifier that offers several ways to zoom in to specific areas of the screen. Microsoft has instructions for using it with the latest version of Windows at bit.ly/2qEU6p.

I started photographing cyclocross races five years ago, chiefly because I could not resist racing in a few of the events myself. Exhausted, exhilarated, covered in dust or mud, I took a few pictures after I raced because it was so raw and exciting that I just had to do it -- both race and shoot. The next year, some fellow photographers and I started posting images on a Web site we started, pdxcross.com, and I gradually moved from being a cyclist who had brought a camera to a photographer who had brought a bike. My wife discovered why I disappeared each Sunday. Now she races, and I cheer and heckle.

An article on Monday about Yankees pitcher Joba Chamberlain misstated his earned run average after he was called up by the Yankees in August 2007. He had compiled an E.R.A. of 0.38 with the Yankees in 2007 -- not .038.

MGM, the parent company of the film studio behind Martin Scorsese's classic 1980 film ''Raging Bull,'' has filed a legal complaint against the former boxer Jake LaMotta and the producers of ''Raging Bull II,'' looking to halt production of the sequel, which began filming in Los Angeles in June. In the seven-page complaint, which was filed on July 3 and reported by ''Deadline Hollywood,'' MGM argued that Mr. LaMotta, 90, had violated a 1976 agreement giving the studio the right of first refusal on his 1986 memoir ''Raging Bull II,'' the basis of the new film, or any other ''owner-written sequel.'' The studio is also asking RB II Productions, the company behind the sequel, for compensatory and other damages.

Configuring a new Wi-Fi router is a pain followed by the annoyance of hiding the ugly plastic square on a shelf behind some books. But Securifi is trying to take some of the grief out of set up, and it has made a router you might want to keep in plain sight.

An article on Monday about the United States Olympic gymnastics trials misidentified one of the individual events that Alicia Sacramone participated in at the trials. Besides the vault, she also competed on the balance beam -- not on the uneven bars.

When Anne-Marie Slaughter wrote ''Why Women Still Can't Have It All,'' for The Atlantic, many responded with an objection: men don't have it all, either. We all make choices. But what if ''having it all'' in this context meant that both mothers and fathers should be able to have careers and families in the same measure and to the same degree -- in the same family? Yes, parents of both sexes make choices. What's troubling is the degree to which those choices still tend to be mutually exclusive (one career parent, one sidelined), the way those choices still tend to shake out by gender and the way societal assumptions we never question support that shakeout.

A film review on Friday about ''People Like Us'' misstated the character Frankie's connection to Los Angeles. She was born there; she did not move there. The review also referred incompletely to Josh's expulsion from school. His setting off an explosion in the school swimming pool was one reason, not the sole one.

An article on Wednesday about federal approval of a rapid H.I.V. test sold over the counter for use at home reversed the odds of a person's getting a false positive or false negative result in taking the OraQuick H.I.V. test. About one person in 5,000 would get a false positive test, and about one person in 12 could get a false negative -- not the other way around.

To the Editor: Re ''The New Second Home,'' by Jennifer A. Kingson (June 28): This is a ridiculous indulgence by the dog owner. Dogs don't need froufrou doghouses, even the smallest breeds. They don't need all the silly costumes and doggy perfume. People are getting carried away with these products. Dogs don't give an arf about any of that. Next time you are tempted to buy a mansion for your darling, think about all those dogs who need a good home waiting in a shelter.

BARTLETT--Peter B. Brown Brothers Harriman mourns the loss of our friend and Partner, Peter B. Bartlett. Pete joined the Firm in 1956 and was a General Partner resident in New York from 1974 to 2008. Mr. Bartlett served on BBH's Steering Committee and as the Firm's supervising Partner for Banking and Treasury for many years. We extend our condolences to his family. Douglas A. Donahue Jr. for the Partners

For those who hunger for good sound, the Blank Sound Donut speakerphone designed by iRiver, a South Korean electronics company, has a sleek, modern look and offers a vivid sensory experience. The Sound Donut, which costs $130 and is available at iRiver's e-commerce Web site and Amazon.com, uses Bluetooth technology to sync with computers, smartphones and other devices. The display features an elegant LED interface that glows when the device is turned on. With a touch, you can play music or make a phone call.

Lyle Kessler, a playwright whose work has been scarce in New York in recent decades, is making up for it in 2013. Just after Alec Baldwin announced that he had signed on to a Broadway revival of Mr. Kessler's 1983 drama, ''Orphans,'' directed by Daniel Sullivan, came word that the downtown troupe the Amoralists would present the world premiere of the playwright's ''Collision'' early next year.

KAPLAND--Shirley H.,age 90 years. Loving wife of the late Dr. Jack A. Kapland. Devoted mother of Michael Kapland (Kathryn) and Bonnie Postel (Ira). Adored grandmother of Jacquelle Kapland and Geoffrey and Joshua Postel. Cherished great-grandmother of Cecelia and Jillian Postel. Daughter of the late Anna and Harry Stitman, sister of the late Rosalyn Gidan. Graveside services, Thursday, July 5, 2012, 11:30am at Beth David Cemetery. Donations in her memory should be made to the Jewish Museum, 1109 5th Ave., New York, NY 10128.

If 2012 is another year of the pitcher, someone forgot to tell the game's sluggers. The prevailing story of the season has been the dominance of pitchers. In a little more than three months, there have been two perfect games and three nonperfect no-hitters, and strikeouts have come at the highest rate in baseball history.

The Gotham column on Tuesday, about the New York City Board of Elections and the Democratic primary for the 13th Congressional District, misidentified, in some editions, the legislative position held by Bill Perkins, who is married to the Democratic deputy director of the board. He is a state senator, not an assemblyman.

An obituary on Monday, and in some copies on Sunday, about Horacio Coppola, who introduced avant-garde photography to Argentina, referred incorrectly to a photographer known for his images of Paris at night. He went by the single name Brassaï, not by George Brassai. (His real name was Gyula Halász.)

WHITE MARSH, Md. -- Gary L. Miller knew something was afoot in the garage rented out behind his auto equipment business. Through an open door, Mr. Miller glimpsed piles of pipes, polyethylene tanks and pumps. But nothing was hooked up. Nothing was being made. So it came as a surprise -- to say the least -- when he learned that the tenant, Rodney R. Hailey, had told a federal agency that he would produce millions of gallons of biodiesel fuel there.

An article on June 21 about alternatives to using an architect for home construction and renovation misspelled, at one point, the surname of a homeowner who used a software program to design a new kitchen. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, she is Sherry Petersik, not Petrisik. The article also gave an outdated name for a program she used. It is now Trimble SketchUp -- not Google SketchUp, which was its name when Ms. Petersik used it. (Google subsequently sold it to Trimble.)

STURGES--Anastasia "Daphne" Bakalis of Morganville, NJ, passed away at age 70 on July 3, 2012, after a fourteen year battle with cancer. She died peacefully at home surrounded by her family. She is survived by her husband, John Sturges, daughters Christina Griffin (son-in-law Eric) and Elizabeth Hoffmann (son-in-law Ethan), granddaughters Hayden, Allegra and Zoe, mother Athena Bakalis, and sisters Ourania Soumas, Rita Mergemekes and Diana Davis, and many nieces and nephews, extended family and friends. Visitation at the Riverdale Funeral Home in New York City on Friday July 6th from 2-4 and 6-8PM; Funeral service at the funeral home on Saturday July 7th at 11:00AM. Burial services will be private on a subsequent date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Cancer Institute of New Jersey.

Silicon Valley is different, they say. One of the most economically creative and dynamic pockets of the United States, it is where entrepreneurs rule. Perhaps it is no surprise then that the men who hold sway in the Valley are now looking to transform not only the global economy but the way that public companies are run, locking out both public shareholders and directors. That the call for shareholder rights is a refrain seldom heard in the Internet sector is not new. Since Google went public in 2004 in a way that maintained control for its founders, the leaders of Silicon Valley have been chary about shareholder voting rights.

NATHAN--Dave, former advertising executive with Shaller Rubin, Jack Poust Co., Gianettino & Meredith, died peacefully at home yesterday in West Orange, NJ. His indomitable spirit and love of life and friends will be sorely missed by his wife of 57 years Patti (Steiner); children Amy (Howard Fineman), Linda (Ben Capone) and Andrew (Jennifer Gibson); grandchildren Meredith and Nicholas Fineman and Nate and Leah Homan.

Goldman Sachs has been dealt another setback in its effort to overturn $20.5 million arbitration award stemming from the 2005 collapse of the hedge fund manager Bayou Group. On Tuesday, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld the award to the creditors of Bayou, who had accused Goldman of helping the fund perpetrate a Ponzi scheme.

EXPANDING WALGREEN Just two weeks after Walgreen did its biggest deal ever, buying a 45 percent stake in the British drugstore giant Alliance Boots for $6.7 billion, the company announced on Thursday that it would pay about $438 million for a collection of American drugstores. The 144 stores, mostly in the South, were purchased from the closely held Stephen L. LaFrance Holdings, and members of the LaFrance family. The stores, located across seven states, operate under the brands USA Drug, Super D Drug, May's Drug, Med-X and Drug Warehouse. Even before the Alliance Boots deal, Walgreen has been on a buying spree. Last year the company paid $429 million for drugstore.com and in 2010 it acquired the New York chain Duane Reade for $1.2 billion.
GOLD--Samuel. June 29, on his 100th birthday. Towering figure to his twins Gini and Tony. He always said "the wheel keeps spinning." Predeceased by wife Virginia.

A British documentary that raises questions about the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, is unlikely to ever be released after its producers were unable to obtain insurance that would protect its distributors from libel charges, The Evening Standard of London reported. The documentary, called ''Unlawful Killing,'' is directed by Keith Allen and financed by Mohamed al-Fayed, the billionaire businessman whose son Dodi was Diana's lover and was killed with her in a Paris car crash in 1997. A British jury ruled in 2008 that Diana and Dodi al-Fayed were unlawfully killed by the negligent driving of their chauffeur and photographers chasing after them. Mr. Allen's film, which was shown out of competition at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival, suggests that a conspiracy of British royalty, politicians and secret service officers was to blame for the deaths.

Austin, Tex. WORK and opportunity, poverty and dependency, material security and insecurity: for generations of reformers, the constitutional importance of these subjects was self-evident. Laissez-faire government, unchecked corporate power and the deprivations and inequalities they bred weren't just bad public policy -- they were constitutional infirmities. But liberals have largely forgotten how to think, talk and fight along these lines.

''The Amazing Spider-Man'' had box office bite after all. After weeks of skepticism in Hollywood that ''The Amazing Spider-Man'' could deliver a blockbuster opening for Sony Pictures Entertainment - prerelease interest was on the soft side - the movie took in a strong $59.3 million on Tuesday and Wednesday.

GOLDSCHEIDER--Robert, of Manhattan, East Hampton and Delray Beach, Florida, on July 4th after a brief illness. Born in Washington Heights in 1929 to Hugo Goldscheider and Tamina Biltuis; a graduate of Stuyvescent High School, Columbia University and The Harvard Law School. A pioneer in the field of intellectual property licensing and technology transfer. Writer, lecturer and teacher in the field he so passionately loved. Renowned member of The Licensing Executives Society and winner of their Gold Medal for outstanding work in the field. Known as the father of the 25% Rule, a method used for calculating royalties when measuring damages in infringement litigations which has been used for over 50 years by countless attorneys. At the time of his death he was actively involved in disputing a recent court decision pertaining to the Rule. Survived by his loving wife Janet A. of 38 years, sons Eric and Thomas Goldscheider, step-children, Brad Altman, Tracey Altman and Cathy Altman-Silver and nine grandchildren. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan, Sunday, July 8 at 10:00am. Contributions made to American Cancer Society.

Superchunk, Clap Your Hands Say Yeah and the Hold Steady are among the groups who will play a free concert in Times Square on Saturday from noon to 6 p.m. as part of the inaugural CBGB Festival, organizers announced. The Times Square event is one of two free concerts offered by the promoters who bought the rights to the defunct punk-rock club; another concert, at the Rumsey Playfield in Central Park, will feature Cloud Nothings, Guided by Voices and the Pains of Being Pure at Heart. The festival is being held at 40 clubs around the city, offering showcases for more than 300 indie rock, punk and hard-core bands. There is also a rock-themed film festival and a series of panel discussions aimed at helping struggling musicians. Tim Hayes, the promoter behind the festival, says the events are intended to pay homage to Hilly Kristal, the iconoclastic impresario who died in 2007 and ran CBGB on the Bowery for more than three decades before it closed in 2006. Mr. Kristal, who stressed original music in booking bands, was widely credited with helping to establish the punk rock and new wave movements of the 1970s and 1980s, giving bands like Talking Heads, Blondie and the Ramones their starts. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on Thursday about fraud connected to the federal biofuel program described incorrectly the safeguards set up by the National Biodiesel Board, a trade group, including a new monitoring and auditing system for biodiesel producers. The system is voluntary, not mandatory.

He was a man of honor and integrity and will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his daughter, Andrea Blanch, his son Harlan Korenvaes, his daughter-in-law Amy Korenvaes, and his two grandchildren Kim Faye Korenvaes and Max Z Korenvaes. Visit: www.sparkman-hillcrest.com for more information.

The Essex Street Market on Manhattan's Lower East Side; Christ Church in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; and the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City are among the venues to be used for a festival of interdisciplinary works and performances by artists from around the world this fall. DUPPER--Marion, a beloved mother and special education teacher for the New York City Public School system for many years, died on Wednesday, July 4th, 2012, while residing in Boynton Beach, Florida. She attended Fontbonne Hall Academy in Bay Ridge and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from the College of Notre Dame (now St. John's University), and later received a Masters degree from Hunter College of CCNY. Mrs. Dupper's husband, Melvin, predeceased her in 1996. They had been married for 48 years. She is survived by her sons, Mark Dupper of Lake George, NY; Michael Dupper of Oxford, MS; Thaddeus Dupper of Castle Pines, CO; her daughter, Maryeugene Dupper of Boynton Beach, FL; and by three beloved grandchildren Kieran, Andrew and Katherine, as well as her brothers, Thomas Gotimer of Phoenicia, NY; Msgr. James Gotimer of New York City, and George Gotimer of Margaretville, NY. Two sisters, Jeanne Buchanan and Sister Maryeugene Gotimer, SC predeceased Mrs. Dupper. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place at Our Lady of Angels Church in Brooklyn later this summer. The family has requested, in lieu of flowers, that donations be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, West Palm Beach, Florida, or the charity of one's choice.

An article on Tuesday about a fine levied on the British drug maker GlaxoSmithKline for illegal marketing of some of its drugs misstated the use of Depakote, an Abbott Laboratories drug involved in a similar case. It is an antiseizure drug, not an antipsychotic.

Sir Andrew Aguecheek -- Sir Toby Belch's rich drinking buddy, the sweetest of dim bulbs and the most reluctant (and terrified) duelist of all time -- would have to be on the shortlist of Shakespeare's best-loved wacky characters. And in the current New York Classical Theater production of ''Twelfth Night (or What You Will),'' Sir Andrew (the adorable Ian Antal) makes a running comic entrance worthy of Pee-wee Herman. Maybe, I thought as Mr. Antal goofily demonstrated his high-leaping dance moves, wandering around with this play won't be so bad. New York Classical Theater calls its production style ''panoramic theater,'' which means that the cast moves to a new spot for pretty much every scene, and the audience follows. For this ''Twelfth Night,'' directed by Stephen Burdman, that means 16 exhausting moves, beginning and ending at Castle Clinton in Battery Park. This will never be my favorite theater format, but by the show's courtyard ending the cast had pretty much won me over.

An article on June 21 about coolant gases for air-conditioners that contribute to global warming misspelled the name of a coolant manufacturer in Mexico. It is Quimobásicos, not Quimbasicos.

9 P.M. (ABC) HEAVEN: WHERE IS IT? HOW DO WE GET THERE? In this edition of ''20/20,'' Barbara Walters travels to India and Israel and throughout the United States to explore the meaning of heaven with religious leaders, scientists, celebrities and people who say they have been there. Among those interviewed are Cardinal Theodore E. McCarrick, archbishop emeritus of Washington; Rabbi Neil Gillman of the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan; the Rev. Calvin O. Butts of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem; Elder William R. Walker, a general authority of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints; and the Dalai Lama (above with Ms. Walters), as well as his longtime follower Richard Gere. Ms. Walters also speaks with Ellen Johnson, a former president of American Atheists; the Islamic scholar Feisal Abdul Rauf; and a member of the Palestinian group Islamic Jihad who is serving time in an Israeli prison for a failed suicide bombing. Dean Hamer, the author of ''The God Gene'' and a former geneticist at the National Institutes of Health, tries to explain why faith comes easily for some and not for others. Finally, Ms. Walters examines the near-death experience in a discussion with Deb Foster, who was clinically dead for about four minutes, and Colton Burpo, who says he went to heaven during emergency surgery. His story is recounted in the book ''Heaven Is for Real,'' written by his father, Todd Burpo, a pastor. 7 A.M. (CUNY) MOZART ON TOUR This 13-week series, hosted by André Previn and produced in 1991 on the bicentenary of Mozart's death, chronicles that composer's life and travels through the performance of his piano concertos. This premiere episode, ''London: The First Journey,'' features Vladimir Ashkenazy in Concerto No. 12. (Repeated at 1 and 10 p.m.)

GERRITY--Bob. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of Standard Motor Products mourn the loss of our friend and long-time Board member, Robert M. Gerrity. Bob passed away peacefully at the age of 74 on Tuesday, July 3, 2012, at the University of Michigan Hospital in Ann Arbor after complications from heart surgery. Bob served as a Director of our company since July 1996 and was the Chairman of our Compensation and Management Development Committee. Bob's extensive business experience included serving as a Chairman, director, and executive officer for many public and private companies, including in the auto industry, and as a principal in Gerrity Partners, a Board consulting business. For Marvel Comics, the future is Now! That's the name of the company's publishing initiative that will begin rolling out in October and will feature a new No. 1 issue just about every week through February. When DC Comics did this last year, that company called it ''the New 52,'' and that move involved reintroducing its characters for a new generation in 52 series beginning with issue No. 1. But Marvel Now! is decidedly not a reboot, according to executives at the company. ''We don't travel back in time, into the future or to an alternate universe,'' Axel Alonso, Marvel's editor-in-chief, said. Instead, creative teams will take on new assignments and characters may now fight alongside new allies, but the rich (and sometimes complex) continuity of the Marvel universe remains intact.
