SALETAN--Eugene. Physicist, teacher, writer, poet, translator, artist, linguist, drummer, trombonist, folk dancer, skier, airman, Gene Saletan lived many lives. Until his last days, he envisioned more work to do and new paths to follow, but he ran out of time. He died on July 3rd of Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma. The second law of thermodynamics, he said, finally brought him down. He was 87 years old. The son of Russian immigrants in New York City, Gene grew up bilingual in English and Russian and went on to learn French and Italian as well as some Hindi, Spanish, Japanese, and German. He was at home and loved all over the world. During the Second World War, First Lieutenant Eugene Saletan took his place in what Tom Brokaw would later call the Greatest Generation. He served as a B-17 navigator in the 8th Air Force 96th Bomb Group and flew 27 missions over Germany from his base in East Anglia. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross. His service years interrupted his education. So did a period of translating scientific books, notably those of the Russian mathematician Israel Gelfand, a project he tackled with the assistance of his beloved first wife, the late Elma Margaret (Peggy) Junz Saletan. The G.I. bill helped Gene earn a Bachelor's degree from Brooklyn College and a Doctorate in physics from Princeton in 1962. He taught physics at Rutgers, Cooper Union, the Birla Institute of Technology in Rajasthan, India, and for more than 25 years was Professor of Physics at Northeastern University in Boston. As Professor Emeritus, Gene continued to flourish. He worked at Northeastern in the SEED and RESEED programs, dedicated to improving the quality of science teaching in middle and high schools. He carved out time to record science texts for blind and dyslexic students through RFB&D, now known as Learning Ally. In 1998, he and Professor Jorge Jose' published "Classical Dynamics: A Contemporary Approach." That book joined his previous texts: "Theoretical Mechanics," written with Professor Alan Cromer in 1971 and "Dynamical Systems" (1985) undertaken in collaboration with Neapolitan colleagues Professors Giuseppe Marmo, Alberto Simoni, and Bruno Vitale. And then, for fun, in 2007 he translated the children's book "The Crocodile" by K.I. Chukovsky from Russian into English. He leaves his adored and adoring wife, the former Ellen Nurnberg, also known as Ellen Cole, his dearly loved nephews, nieces, and cousins, and many cherished friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Eugene Saletan's honor to The Leukemia & Lymphoma Society or The Parkinson Research Foundation. A memorial service is being planned for later in the year. Good night, sweet prince.

About 600 soldiers from the army of the Democratic Republic of Congo fled into Uganda, where troops from that nation disarmed them and were trying to figure out what to do with them.
The American Ballet Theater closes its Metropolitan Opera House season this week with “Le Corsaire”; on Thursday, it featured Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev.
There was no intricate celebration from Peter Sagan this time, just a primal scream and a flex of the arms as he crossed the finish line a winner for the third time in this Tour de France.

Dennis Ferrara of Brooklyn, a Transportation Department employee, provides the authentic New York voice for many “accessible pedestrian signals” aiding the visually impaired.
In a third week of protest against the government, the demonstrations in greater Khartoum and other Sudanese cities have remained small but show signs of gathering momentum.
Heavy rains and a ceaseless stream of the hungry and sick fleeing a contested border area are creating an epidemiological disaster, said Doctors Without Borders.
In April, the coach of Franklin & Marshall, a private college in Lancaster, Pa., and a perennial Division III power, was fired and the team’s juniors and all but one of its seniors were suspended.
Evidence that banks manipulated the influential London interbank offered rate for several years has called its usefulness into question.
The family limited partnership, an arcane way for affluent families to centralize the management of property, has suddenly become popular.
Roger Federer had lost six of his last seven matches against Novak Djokovic, but in their first meeting on grass, Federer won, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3.
The crucial role played by American warplanes in Afghanistan raises questions about the prospects for the fight against the Taliban in the future.
Tony La Russa, the National League manager in this year’s All-Star game, is likely to be criticized whether he chooses Matt Cain or R.A. Dickey to be his starting pitcher.

The titans of the global aerospace industry converge Monday at the Farnborough Airshow. Frenetic buying by airlines the past two years has kept Airbus and Boeing busy, but short-term prospects are dimmer.
With Nintendo’s Wii U coming out this year, gamers who prefer hand-held controllers have something to look forward to.

With Friday’s report showing the unemployment rate stuck at 8.2 percent, what looked like a blip has become a streak, and the economy is unlikely to pick up much before November.

Dynegy Inc. announced on Friday that it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in New York, the latest step to restructure the ailing energy company and settle with creditors who hold more than $2.5 billion in claims over one of its subsidiaries. The plan calls for the parent company to merge with Dynegy Holdings, a subsidiary that is already in bankruptcy, the Houston company said in a statement. The plan came about after the company transferred valuable assets - a set of coal-firing power plants - from the subsidiary to the parent company, prompting an outcry from creditors and a bankruptcy examiner to the accuse the company of ''fraudulent'' behavior.

This summer, ArtsBeat is inviting members of the theater world to contribute to the weekly Theater Talkback column, alternating with the critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. In the first guest post, Trav S. D., a historian of vaudeville, talked about the long bare-knuckles history shared between the boxing ring and the stage. This week, Alexis Soloski, a lecturer at Columbia University and a Times contributor, writes about memorable theatrical entrances (and a few exits). With its reliance on pyro, flying rigs and muscled ensembles of backup dancers, the modern pop performance is the place to look these days for the dramatic stage entrance. Lady Gaga hatching from an egg or zip-lining to the stage above the heads of fans -- now that's a way to start a show.

In a Theater Talkback column online, Alexis Soloski asked readers to recall stage entrances that proved especially memorable. Here are some of their responses: Angela Lansbury's first moment onstage, blowing a bugle at the top of a curved staircase before she slid down the banister in 1966's ''Mame.'' GEORGE HEYMONT

2:50 p.m. | Updated More than ever, getting good airplane seats is a game. And unless you are willing to bone up on the rules and develop a strategy, you may end up paying more than you want -- or getting stuck with a bad seat. Business travelers know this well, but family and leisure travelers must get savvy, too, if they don't want an expensive proposition to get even pricier. I was reminded of this recently, when booking a flight for my family's summer vacation. I had waited a bit too long to buy, but I was eventually able to find flights at a price that I could stomach, on routes that wouldn't land us at our destination at midnight. So far, so good.

CAHN--Sadie Jane Effron, 101, of Lantana, Fl and Beacon, NY passed away July 4 peacefully at home Lantana, Fl. Mrs. Cahn was the wife of Dr. Simon Cahn, who predeceased her in 1983. Mrs. Cahn, born in Poughkeepsie, NY, was daughter of Samuel and Fannie Effron. She graduated Vassar College 1933, married Dr. Cahn 1937 and for 45 years assisted in his dental practice. Survived by son W. Stewart Cahn and daughter-in-law Sandra of New York. A second son, Richard Elliott Cahn, died 1956 at age 17 from polio. In lieu of flowers, donations to Beacon Hebrew Alliance, 331 Verplanck Ave, Beacon NY 12508.

Don DeLillo has long been known for the chilliness of his vision and the icy precision of his prose. Now he's bringing a coolly minimalist literary take on climate change to the London stage with the European premiere of his unpublished one-act play ''The Word for Snow,'' The Guardian has reported. The play, which will be staged by the Future Ruins theater company from July 10 through 12 as part of the London Literature Festival, describes an encounter between a modern-day pilgrim and a self-exiled scholar on an earth where the physical world has disintegrated and been replaced with words describing what once was there. ''Are you saying children will build a snowman with the word for snow?'' one character asks.

DUPPER--Marion, a beloved mother and special education teacher for the New York City Public School system for many years, died on Wednesday, July 4th, 2012, while residing in Boynton Beach, Florida. She was 87. Marion Elizabeth Gotimer was born in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, on December 19, 1924, in the family residence at 146-78 Street. She attended Fontbonne Hall Academy in Bay Ridge and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from the College of Notre Dame (now St. John's University), and later received a Masters degree from Hunter College of CCNY. Mrs. Dupper's husband, Melvin, predeceased her in 1996. They had been married for 48 years. She is survived by her sons, Mark Dupper of Lake George, NY; Michael Dupper of Oxford, MS; Thaddeus Dupper of Castle Pines, CO; her daughter, Maryeugene Dupper of Boynton Beach, FL; and by three beloved grandchildren Kieran, Andrew and Katherine, as well as her brothers, Thomas Gotimer of Phoenicia, NY; Msgr. James Gotimer of New York City, and George Gotimer of Margaretville, NY. Two sisters, Jeanne Buchanan and Sister Maryeugene Gotimer, SC predeceased Mrs. Dupper. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place at Our Lady of Angels Church in Brooklyn later this summer. The family has requested, in lieu of flowers, that donations be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, West Palm Beach, Florida, or the charity of one's choice.

Comcast is close to selling its stake in the A&E cable networks, which would bring in nearly $3 billion for just 15 percent of the company, an executive briefed on the negotiations said Friday. The deal, first reported in The New York Post, has been in the works for many months, and now awaits approval from banks involved in lending the money.

GOLDSCHEIDER--Robert, of Manhattan, East Hampton and Delray Beach, Florida, on July 4th after a brief illness. Born in Washington Heights in 1929 to Hugo Goldscheider and Tamina Biltuis; a graduate of Stuyvescent High School, Columbia University and The Harvard Law School. A pioneer in the field of intellectual property licensing and technology transfer. Writer, lecturer and teacher in the field he so passionately loved. Renowned member of The Licensing Executives Society and winner of their Gold Medal for outstanding work in the field. Known as the father of the 25% Rule, a method used for calculating royalties when measuring damages in infringement litigations which has been used for over 50 years by countless attorneys. At the time of his death he was actively involved in disputing a recent court decision pertaining to the Rule. Survived by his loving wife Janet A. of 38 years, sons Eric and Thomas Goldscheider, step-children, Brad Altman, Tracey Altman and Cathy Altman-Silver and nine grandchildren. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan, Sunday, July 8 at 10:00am. Contributions made to American Cancer Society.

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about the Google Nexus 7 tablet, misstated the music downloading practices of the Google music store. While a song or an album can be downloaded from a personal collection to the Google Nexus 7 only twice using a Web browser, the user can make unlimited downloads using Google's Music Manager program; it is not the case that Google's music store allows only two downloads of a song.

American Express said it would begin offering credit cards with secure-chip technology in the United States this year. The company, however, isn't releasing details yet of when or how it plans to provide the cards to customers, a spokeswoman said.
This economy has no forward momentum and little help from monetary or fiscal policy. KATHY BOSTJANCIC, director of macroeconomic analysis for the Conference Board. [A1]

An article on June 27 about interviews with 100 people who said they had been stopped by the New York police in neighborhoods where the street-stop practice is most common referred imprecisely to the legal standard that governs when police officers are permitted to frisk someone. While the police can stop a person if they believe a crime is afoot, that is not sufficient legal reason to conduct a frisk. (The United States Supreme Court has held that in order for the police to frisk someone, they must have a reasonable belief that the person is armed and dangerous.)

It might not be advisable for Jake LaMotta to take on Mike Tyson in the ring, but he can still go head-to-head with him in the arena of New York theater. Just before Iron Mike arrives on Broadway with his one-man show, Mr. LaMotta, a former middleweight champion whose life inspired the film ''Raging Bull,'' is bringing back his show ''Lady and the Champ'' for a two-week run at the Richmond Shepard Theater in Manhattan, press representatives for the production said. Mr. LaMotta, who turns 91 on Tuesday, will star in ''Lady and the Champ'' with Denise Baker, who wrote the show with Bonnie Lee Sander and directed it for the stage. A news release describes the production (which has previously run at the Triad Theatre and Feinstein's at the Loews Regency) as ''an evening of stories, videos, and song and dance'' in which Mr. LaMotta recounts ''in ribald detail'' his boxing career and the years that followed, during which he ran various bars, worked as a stand-up comic and was married numerous times. (The news release says Mr. LaMotta ''affectionately refers'' to Ms. Baker ''as his future seventh wife, 'Lucky #7.' '')

ALBANY - Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo's administration likes to hear compliments so much that it will write them for you. The Democratic administration ghostwrote statements for two business groups that praised the state budget in a mid-April news release from the governor's office, according to e-mails obtained by The New York Times through a Freedom of Information request. The correspondence provides an unusual look at how elected officials try to burnish their images.

An article on Thursday about Mitt Romney's declaring that the mandate in President Obama's health care program is a tax misstated the arrangements for an interview with CBS News in which Mr. Romney addressed the issue. The timing of the interview was set more than a week earlier. It was not ''hastily arranged.''

A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about Roger Waters's live presentation of the album ''The Wall,'' at Yankee Stadium on Friday and Saturday nights, misidentified the band that recorded the album. It was Pink Floyd, not the Who.

ROUS--Vivian Solomon, died on July 6th, after 102 years on this earth. Services to be held at graveside, Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Flushing at 11:30 Sunday morning. She was the daughter of Libby Katz Solomon and Rabbi Elias L. Solomon ZL, one of the first rabbis ordained at JTS under R. Solomon Schechter in 1904. She survived her husband, Arthur Avram Rous, by 39 years, all the while continuing to grow in wisdom and open acceptance of a radically changing world. A woman with a kind heart, she was generous to a fault to all her children and grandchildren, trusting them to care for her in her last years. She recreated for us a bygone world with crystalline recollections of her childhood in New York City where horses and trolleys were still commonplace even as soldiers returned from WWI bringing the flu pandemic of 1918 with them. Razor-sharp mind, keen dry humor, and a will of iron in a quiet woman of infinite dignity. Goodbye Mom.

A Wall Street executive filed suit on Friday against what had been New York's oldest art gallery, Knoedler & Company, charging that it and its former president, Ann Freedman, conspired with others in selling him a fake Willem de Kooning painting for $4 million. The suit is the third filed by an art collector involving a painting sold by the gallery, which closed last year. In this case the executive, John D. Howard, asserts that the gallery paid only $750,000 for the painting in 2007 and days later sold it to him for more than five times that price. ''No genuine work of art by de Kooning with a $4 million retail sale value could be purchased in good faith for $750,000,'' the lawyers for Mr. Howard, from Lynn Cahill LLP, state in the papers filed in federal court in Manhattan. Mr. Howard's suit asserts that his painting is one of a number of suspect works by Modernist masters that were supplied to the gallery by a little known Long Island dealer, Glafira Rosales. It states that the landscape, sold as a work painted by de Kooning in 1956-57, was probably created more recently by ''someone affiliated with Rosales.''

In the shadow of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway and just a few yards from the dirt heaps of a dusty construction site, blue and yellow beach umbrellas bloomed. Classic songs like John Lennon's ''Imagine'' floated over an artificial beach stocked with white sand and beach chairs. Smiling teenagers handed out cupcakes and lemonade. And on Friday, after a countdown from 3, dozens of sweaty people jumped into a turquoise pool with views of the Brooklyn Bridge to one side and the Lower Manhattan skyline to the other.

For the filmmaker Peter Jackson, this is not the end of his quest to bring ''The Hobbit'' to the screen, nor the beginning of the end, but maybe - just maybe - it's the end of the beginning: the director has finished filming in New Zealand for his long, long-in-the-works adaptation of that J. R. R. Tolkien novel. In a message posted late Thursday or early Friday, depending on how one measures, on his Facebook page, Mr. Jackson wrote: ''We made it! Shoot day 266 and the end of principal photography on 'The Hobbit.' Thanks to our fantastic cast and crew for getting us this far, and to all of you for your support! Next stop, the cutting room. Oh, and Comic Con.'' Lest it be forgotten how significant an accomplishment this is, the making of ''The Hobbit'' was nearly halted by the bankruptcy of MGM (during which the film lost its original director, Guillermo del Toro); and a labor dispute during which Mr. Jackson threatened to move the production to Eastern Europe. Mr. Jackson also underwent surgery for a perforated ulcer before his cameras finally started rolling in March of last year; that was followed by an explosion on the set and a mixed reception for some early ''Hobbit'' footage that was presented at CinemaCon in April.

Susan Jaffe, a retired dancer with American Ballet Theater, will became dean of the dance school at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts, the arts school said. Ms. Jaffe danced with Ballet Theater for 22 years, retiring as a principal in 2002. Her partners included Mikhail Baryshnikov and Ethan Stiefel, another former dean of the dance school. Ms. Jaffe will resign her position as a ballet mistress at the company, but a spokeswoman said Ballet Theater expected she would continue to choreograph and teach at its Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis School when her schedule allowed. Separately, Ballet Theater announced two promotions on Friday. Hee Seo will become a principal dancer, from soloist, and Alexandre Hammoudi moved from the corps de ballet to soloist. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

9 P.M. (Starz) THE GIRL WITH THE DRAGON TATTOO (2011) Daniel Craig stars as Mikael Blomkvist, a crusading Swedish journalist hired by a wealthy industrialist (Christopher Plummer) to investigate the disappearance of his niece 40 years earlier. Rooney Mara, above, in an Oscar-nominated performance, is Lisbeth Salander, the vulnerable yet ruthlessly competent computer hacker who helps him solve the mystery in this adaptation of the novel by Stieg Larsson, directed by David Fincher. ''She is a marvelous pop-culture character, stranger and more complex than the average superhero and more intriguing than the usual boy wizards and vampire brides,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about Lisbeth, who was first played on film by Noomi Rapace. ''It has been her fate, unfortunately, to make her furious, uninspiring way through a series of plodding and ungainly stories.'' And ''despite the slick intensity of Mr. Fincher's style, his movie is not immune to the same lumbering proceduralism,'' Mr. Scott said, referring to what he described as a flaw in the 2010 Swedish adaptation, directed by Niels Arden Oplev. ''There are waves of brilliantly orchestrated anxiety and confusion but also long stretches of drab, hackneyed exposition that flatten the atmosphere.'' Still, he added, ''Mr. Fincher's impressive skill is evident, even as his ambitions seem to be checked by the limitations of the source material and the imperatives of commercial entertainment.'' The film earned an Oscar for best achievement in film editing. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton interviews E. J. Dionne Jr., the author of ''Our Divided Political Heart,'' about what he sees as contemporary Americans' tendency to favor individualism over community. Lucky Severson travels to Tanzania, where the conversion of Maasai tribal members to Christianity has helped to end female genital mutilation while allowing girls increased access to education.

Yahoo and Facebook agreed on Friday to settle a legal fight over their patent holdings, ending what was shaping up to be one of the nastier court battles in Silicon Valley in recent memory. Under the terms of the pact, the two companies will expand an existing partnership, including a deeper integration of Facebook's tools into Yahoo's content pages.

My Shortcuts column on Saturday, which looked at how the words ''ordinary'' and ''average'' have become derogatory, prompted numerous readers to respond. For the most part, they were glad to think about how we can redefine success and ''being special'' in a country that seems to prize those qualities over everything else. Here is a sampling of their comments: I often have wondered how the world can be in such a mess with all of the ''extraordinary'' people we read about in leadership positions. As you suggest, perhaps they were climbing their mountains for the wrong reasons.

For many people, playing video games in recent years has meant waving their hands in front of a television or swiping a thumb across a smartphone screen. The modern gamer swings an arm to hit a ball or flicks a finger to slice a watermelon in half. It has felt new and different. It looks good in commercials and appeals to the millions who want nothing to do with standard video game controllers, those complicated contraptions covered in buttons and joysticks.

Two authors are writing books about him. Political pundits are murmuring about his future on the national stage. And next week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will hit a new height in his political ascent, with the debut of his very own bobblehead doll. The Tri-City ValleyCats, a minor-league baseball team in Troy, N.Y., near Albany, will give Cuomo bobbleheads to the first 1,500 fans at its game on Monday. The team is calling the evening ''We Love New York Night,'' and Cocca's Hotels, a chain in the capital region, has signed on to sponsor the giveaway. The team released a photograph of the Cuomo bobblehead on Friday, spurring immediate debate on Twitter over whether it looked more like Mr. Cuomo or his brother, the television journalist Chris Cuomo. The ValleyCats, the Class A short-season affiliate of the Houston Astros, will face the Aberdeen IronBirds, an affiliate of the Baltimore Orioles, at 7 p.m. at Joseph L. Bruno Stadium. Tickets are still available.

Parliament refused on Friday to accept the resignation of its leader, Volodymyr M. Lytvyn, and instead adjourned for the summer, leaving uncertain the fate of a contentious bill that would allow local and regional governments to grant official status to Russian and other languages, in addition to Ukrainian. Mr. Lytvyn, the chairman of Parliament, has refused to sign the bill, effectively blocking it from reaching President Viktor F. Yanukovich, who could sign it into law. Instead, Mr. Lytvyn submitted his resignation, challenging the Party of Regions, which holds the majority, to choose a new chairman. Hundreds of people demonstrated against the bill this week, leading to violent clashes with the police. Under the Constitution, Ukrainian is the only official language. But Ukraine, a former Soviet republic, is home to millions of native Russian speakers, particularly in parts of the country that make up Mr. Yanukovich's base of support.

British officials confirmed on Friday that the Serious Fraud Office would pursue an investigation into the manipulation of benchmark interest rates, a process that could result in criminal charges. The agency said earlier this week that it was considering whether to bring criminal charges in the matter, which involves traders at Barclays who were found to have been trying to manipulate rates for their own benefit. The time frame for any potential criminal prosecution is unclear.

While working on the fifth volume of his monumental biography of Lyndon Johnson, Robert A. Caro -- famous both for the size of his books and how long it takes him to write them -- is immersed in another project, too. The new book is not a memoir, exactly, he said in a telephone interview from his summer home on Long Island, but an account of how he came to write the Johnson biography and its predecessor, ''The Power Broker,'' a biography of the developer and city planner Robert Moses. The tone, he said, Is similar to that of his 1998 New Yorker article describing the origins of ''The Power Broker,'' his interviews with Moses and the obstacles he faced. Mr. Caro added that he has an ''understanding'' about the new book with his publisher, Knopf, but no official contract and there is no scheduled publication date.

It’s the fate of being in the middle: a good student but not Ivy caliber, strapped by college costs but not eligible for enough need-based aid. The New York Times analyzed College Board data from colleges and universities that award aid based on academic promise. CAHN--Sadie Jane Effron, 101, of Lantana, Fl and Beacon, NY passed away July 4 peacefully at home Lantana, Fl. Mrs. Cahn was the wife of Dr. Simon Cahn, who predeceased her in 1983. That's the number of cities around the world -- including Seoul, Moscow and Jerusalem -- where the video installation ''The Clock,'' by Christian Marclay, has been screened since its debut in 2010. ''The Clock'' is a 24-hour-long collage of thousands of clips from movies (and some TV shows) -- averaging about four to five each minute -- that refer to time, and the work unfolds in real time. (It drew about 12,000 people to the Paula Cooper Gallery in New York in a monthlong run last year.) Its next stop is the Lincoln Center Festival, where it will be shown at the David Rubenstein Atrium beginning July 13.

RUBINSTEIN--Estelle Ellis, passed away peacefully in her Manhattan home at age 92. She graduated from Hunter College in 1940, and was a leader in launching Seventeen, the first magazine for girls. Later, with husband Sam, she formed the creative marketing firm, Business Image. In her 70s, Ellis created three books: "At Home with Books," "At Home with Art," and "The Booklovers Repair Kit." She served many years on the Board of Directors of the Phillips Van Heusen Corporation. She is survived by son Ellis, his wife Joanna; daughter Nora, her husband Herb Childress; granddaughters Nathalie and Nanna; and great-granddaughter Rebecca. Contributions can be made to Connect to Learn, or Scientists without Borders.
The five most viewed articles at nytimes.com/sports for June 29 to July 6. 1. JOE PATERNO MAY HAVE INFLUENCED

Rowdy Gaines was older than 15-year-old Kathleen Ledecky, the youngest member of the 2012 United States Olympic swim team, when he began competing seriously in the sport. At Auburn, he was a 22-time N.C.A.A. all-American and was chosen over Herschel Walker as the 1981 Southeastern Conference Athlete of the Year. At the 1984 Los Angeles Games, Gaines won three Olympic gold medals, in the 100-meter freestyle and as a member of the 4x100 medley and 4x100 freestyle relays. Gaines, 53 and married with four daughters, sat down at the end of the United States Olympic trials in Omaha after providing color commentary for NBC, a role he will also fill at the London Games. Q.

DAVISSON--Barbara Fischer, 68, passed away peacefully at home in Maine on July 3 following a brave fight with brain cancer. Barbara was magnificent: a woman of grace fun, smart, peppy, stylish, with a gift for transforming space with textiles, art and antiques. Her big heart and understanding of life made her the best possible company, friend, and mentor. Born in Plainfield, NJ to Arthur L. Fischer and Anne Buckle Fischer. Drawn to the sea, she spent youthful summers at Point 'O Woods, Fire Island, and later on Islesboro, Maine. A graduate of Lasell College '64; additional study in Landscape Architecture and Design at the University of California; Royal Kew Gardens and Royal Chelsea Physic Gardens, England; Parsons School of Design; and Institute of Architecture and Urban Studies, New York. Barbara's New York career began at Conde Naste and Glamour Magazine. At Hearst, she repositioned Town & Country to a new lifestyle format. She worked at Harper's Bazaar and Bozell & Jacobs, then founded her interior design firm. In East Hampton, NY on August 15, 1981, Barbara married Indiana native William H. Davisson, a merchant of luxury brands. Careers continued in New York, finding new horizons in California; returning to New York; Portland, Maine; Florence, Italy; and back to Maine. Barbara is survived by her devoted husband William Davisson, brothers James and Arthur L. (Nick) Fischer, Jr., and her beloved Westies, Hamish and Chloe. Donations may be made in Barbara's name to Hospice of Southern Maine and the Portland Museum of Art. Memorial July 24, 10am at St. Lukes in Portland, ME.

We plant villas next to sandstone spires called the Garden of the Gods, and McMansions in Virginia stocked with people who have the world at their fingertips.

While it's been a long time since any of the founding fathers made a personal appearance on the campaign trail, they continue speaking from beyond the grave through the mouths of present-day candidates, weighing in on matters as disparate -- and perhaps unimaginable to them in life -- as health care reform, gay marriage and abortion. Barely an hour after last month's Supreme Court ruling on the Affordable Care Act, Mitt Romney was promising to uphold ''a course that the founders envisioned'' by acting to repeal the law. On other occasions, Mr. Romney has cited America's 18th-century leaders in support of limited government and in opposition to same-sex marriage.

THE annual LATIN ALTERNATIVE MUSIC CONFERENCE returns this week, Wednesday through Saturday. For conference participants it's a strategy session on how to bring music they love to more listeners; for everyone else it's a bounty of music too rarely heard in New York during the rest of the year. The big shows include a Celebrate Brooklyn! concert headlined by Calle 13, the Puerto Rican group that regularly mops up the Latin Grammy Awards. Its smart, socially conscious or raunchy raps arrive in far-reaching pan-American grooves. Ana Tijoux, a Chilean rapper with calmly passionate rhymes about love and war, shares the bill. 6 p.m. Friday, Prospect Park Bandshell, (718) 683-5600; free. There are two SUMMERSTAGE shows in Central Park. On Wednesday, the Spanish rapper Mala Rodríguez shares a lineup with the quirky Ximena Sariñana. And on Saturday the lineup leans toward Mexico and electronics, with the grooves of Kinky and the Latin electropop of 3BallMTY. Both shows start at 3 p.m., midpark at 69th Street, (212) 360-2777; free. Full schedule: latinalternative.com.

(Travel) XTREME WATERPARKS In this series premiere, the first of two new offerings from the Travel Channel that showcase pulse-quickening activities from around the world, viewers are taken to Beach Park in Fortaleza, Brazil, where a water slide called Insano, right, shoots riders down a 14-story drop at speeds reaching 65 miles an hour. Then to the Center of Gravity in Edmonton, Alberta, for a look at the world's tallest indoor bungee jump into water. Another episode follows at 8:30 that showcases Area 47, a water park at the foot of the Austrian Alps, and an enclosed flume slide dubbed the Constrictor at the Wet 'n' Wild in Phoenix. At 9, the series premiere of ''Insane Coaster Wars'' spotlights roller coasters that push the limits of gravity, followed by a second episode at 9:30 focusing on some of the best coasters where riders dangle below the tracks. 9:15 A.M. (TMC) EXIT THROUGH THE GIFT SHOP (2010) This documentary began as a historical account of guerrilla street art recorded over many years by Thierry Guetta, as he followed artists like Shepard Fairey and Invader in Los Angeles. But Mr. Guetta became the unintentional subject of his own movie when the reclusive British artist Banksy decided he would take over editing and production duties. Writing in The New York Times, Jeannette Catsoulis said that the resulting film was ''like Banksy's best work, a trompe l'oeil: a film that looks like a documentary but feels like a monumental con.'' She added: '' 'Exit' could be a new subgenre: the prankumentary. Audiences, however, would be advised simply to enjoy the film on its face -- even if that face is a carefully contrived mask.''

FRANCES--Evan, Our Mom, Evan Frances (Agnew), passed away on June 30th, just shy of her 96th birthday. She came from a small town in Michigan, an only child from a poor family. She never knew her father, for the most part she was raised by aunts and uncles. She was Jewish. The odds were stacked against her from the beginning. She overcame them, and then some. She was born four years before women won the right to vote, two years after WWI began, 48 years before the Civil Rights Act became the law of this land. She lived to see 17 presidents elected, and witnessed her country enter into seven wars, during which more than six-hundred thousand American soldiers and six million innocent Jews lost their lives. She was an unusually bright child and diligent student, received a scholarship to attend the University of Chicago, continued her graduate studies at New York University. The war swept American men to foreign shores, jobs that were not previously available to women suddenly were. She filled one, as a reporter for a New York newspaper. The troops came home, she met our father, Alec, they started a family. Her journalism career blossomed along with her children, Andy, Jimmy and Scott. Her award-filled career as a magazine editor began at Family Weekly, continued at Family Circle and Ladies Home Journal, culminated as editor-in-chief of 1,001 Decorating Ideas. She was a member of The Society of the Silurians and the American Society of Interior Designers. Evan, that is what everyone called her, even her children, was passionate about the world around her. She was an iron lady, righteous and unbending, perhaps to a fault. She stood in Union Square for Ethel Rosenberg's vigil, fought McCarthyism, walked the lines for civil rights, brought us to Washington to protest the war in Vietnam. She instilled in her children the spirit to stand unwavering for one's principles. In turn, we have passed this virtue on to ours. To her end, she could quote verse from Shelley and Yeats. Her greatest gift was her ability to write, she was obsessive about the English language. She never spared us when it came to misusage or misspelling of a word, or proper structuring of a sentence. We are grateful and better for these and all of her lessons. She is survived by us, Andy, Jim and Scott, her grandchildren, Sam, Alec, Sophie and David, and her daughters-in-law, Jane, Cynthia and Patti. Until this weekend we called her Evan. From now on we will call her mom. A memorial will be held on August 22nd at 11am, at The Community Church of New York Unitarian Universalist, 40 East 35th St., NYC.

DRINKING milk is as American as Mom and apple pie. Until not long ago, Americans were encouraged not only by the lobbying group called the American Dairy Association but by parents, doctors and teachers to drink four eight-ounce glasses of milk, ''nature's perfect food,'' every day. That's two pounds! We don't consume two pounds a day of anything else; even our per capita soda consumption is ''only'' a pound a day. Today the Department of Agriculture's recommendation for dairy is a mere three cups daily -- still 1 1/2 pounds by weight -- for every man, woman and child over age 9. This in a country where as many as 50 million people are lactose intolerant, including 90 percent of all Asian-Americans and 75 percent of all African-Americans, Mexican-Americans and Jews. The myplate.gov site helpfully suggests that those people drink lactose-free beverages. (To its credit, it now counts soy milk as ''dairy.'')

VICTORIA, British Columbia, is a city whose former colonial ties to Britain are evident in the neo-Baroque government buildings and countless gardens that dot its landscape. But visitors who trade high tea at the Fairmont Empress Hotel for a stroll around the city will find that it defies easy stereotypes. Exhibit A is Fernwood, a short walk from downtown, home to classic Victoria hallmarks like historic buildings as well as a pirate radio station, a vibrant music scene and local fixtures like a man known for his obsession with blowing bubbles. Since the neighborhood began emerging from decades of blight in the mid-aughts, it has been the best place to explore the city's blossoming alternative culture. ERICA GIES

''YOU can't hold hot glass in your hand and play with it,'' says Tina Oldknow, curator of modern glass at the Corning Museum of Glass in upstate New York. ''You can't have that even casual acquaintance with the material.'' Five years ago, to help foster a more productive relationship between designers and this difficult material, Corning developed the GlassLab, a mobile glassblowing studio that has since made appearances at Design Miami, the Vitra Design Museum and the Cooper-Hewitt. This summer, it's parked near Pershing Hall on Governors Island, where Corning and the Cooper-Hewitt are collaborating on a series of free public glassblowing demonstrations on weekends through July 29. The designers invited to participate are all contributors to the exhibition ''Graphic Design -- Now in Production,'' also on view on Governors Island as part of the Cooper-Hewitt's off-site programming. As in the past, none of them have much, if any, experience with glass. But graphic designers, attests Rob Cassetti, the head of the GlassLab program, are particularly good at pushing the limits of the form. Recently, the graphic designer Peter Buchanan-Smith, who has also worked in three dimensions, put that theory to the test. He brought in a 2D rendering of a glass buoy shaped and colored like an eyeball, and then stood by as three GlassLab gaffers attempted to realize his vision. The result: a brilliantly hued piece of blown glass (above), well over a foot at its longest. ''It's pretty amazing,'' Mr. Buchanan-Smith said. ''These guys are magicians.'' Go to cmog.org. JULIA FELSENTHAL

What compels us to leave home, to travel to other places? The great travel writer Bruce Chatwin described nomadism as an ''inveterate impulse,'' deeply rooted in our species. The relentless movement of the modern world bears this out: our relative prosperity has not turned us into a sedentary species. The World Tourism Organization, an agency of the United Nations, reported nearly a billion tourist arrivals in 2011. Some 200 million people are now living outside their country of birth. This type of massive movement -- the rearrangement, temporary or permanent, of multitudes -- is as fundamental to modern life as the Internet, global trade or any other sociopolitical developments. Certainly, many of our most intractable collective challenges as a society are directly linked to our mobility: urbanization, environmental depletion, scarcity and, of course, immigration. An immigrant is a traveler without a return ticket.

THE Highway Loss Data Institute found in a recent analysis of insurance claims that some crash-avoidance systems were what researchers called ''clear winners,'' while others did not appear to be living up to their promise, the group said on Tuesday. Researchers looked at collision, property damage and injury claims on vehicles from the 2000 to 2011 model years, depending on when an automaker introduced a specific crash-avoidance feature. Analysis began in 2008 and included claim data through August 2011.

My favorite grilling memory of the last couple of years involves a guy in Istanbul who set up shop -- in this case a glass-enclosed grill cart of about 12 square feet -- on a corner I walked past daily. Over a bed of charcoal, he lovingly tended his lamb-onion-pepper-and-tomato kebabs, which were beautiful. What they were not, however, was varied. His customers expected lamb kebabs, and that's what he gave them. He had no choice. But you do. In fact, with this kebab combination generator, a little patience and a few bowls, you can arrange a customizable grilling station where anyone can create a personalized skewer.

An article last Sunday about Alec Baldwin and the attention focused on celebrities' behavior referred incorrectly to Soon-Yi Previn's relationship to Mia Farrow, whose breakup with Woody Allen was caused by his romantic relationship with Ms. Previn. She is Ms. Farrow's daughter, not her stepdaughter. The article also misspelled the name of a credit card endorsed by Mr. Baldwin. It is Capital One, not Capitol One.

BUCKSTEIN--Henry Al (Pappy), age 101, of Boca Raton, FL died July 06, 2012. Contributions can be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County 5360 Linton Boulevard Delray Beach, FL 33484. Services entrusted to Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel Coconut Creek, FL 954-427-6500.

MY career has not been a straight path, which I attribute to my family's penchant for experimenting. My mother was a Girl Scout leader who later worked on political campaigns and then became president of the Ohio Genealogical Society. My father was a civil engineer with an interest in the arts. My sister moved from a business career to the arts. Although I majored in theater at Miami University in Ohio, I chose a business career. I have skills and experiences from several different jobs and industries. After graduating from college in 1981, I completed a management training program at a department store in Ohio, then worked as a buyer for Snyder's department store in Louisville, Ky.
An illustration last Sunday with the Practical Traveler column misstated a Web site. It is SavvyTravel.net, as stated in the column, not SavveyTraveler.net.

MERRIMACK, N.H. - For baseball people, the end of July symbolizes the culmination of a quest. By July 31, the deadline for trades without waivers, general managers will learn if they really can pry Cole Hamels from the Philadelphia Phillies, Zack Greinke from the Milwaukee Brewers or other stars from noncontending teams. A fan here named Scott Mortimer has his own pursuit, with July 31 as the date to watch. That is when the Class AA Erie Seawolves come to Manchester to play the New Hampshire Fisher Cats. The hitting coach for Erie is Jerry Martin, a former outfielder who hit .251 for five teams from 1974 to 1984. Scott Mortimer needs him.

LEVINSON--Robert P.,79, died peacefully on June 12, his sons at his side. Robert was a loving father to Jack (New York) and Jeremy (Milwaukee), grandfather to Simone (Milwaukee), and devoted husband to Helene who died in 2010. He was loved by many family, friends, and colleagues. Born and raised in Rochester, Robert lived mostly in New York. A gathering in his memory will be held this fall in New York (contact Jack: jelevinson@ gmail.com). Donations to the Obama campaign.

As stylish New Yorkers pare down to a basic cotton shirt for the intense heat, a copy of Michelangelo's ''David'' at Ninth Avenue and 14th Street has been slipcovered in stripes. One woman cut the skirt off her designer dress and wore just the top with a bucket-shaped straw hat. An elegant woman (shown next to the statue's leg), on her way to a business meeting, topped her seersucker trousers with a loosely cut cotton shirt. Louise Doktor, top right, a hedge-fund administrative assistant, accessorizes her basic summer oversize cotton shirts with dramatic necklaces. At top left, Melissa Kuba Lederer, a jewelry designer, has her shirts custom made and wears them with jeans. The comfort factor prevails.

I was sitting on the curb watching my 4-year-old son ride his bicycle when I noticed that every time he passed the telephone pole he'd slow down and extend his arm. ''What are you doing?'' I asked. ''Going through the toll,'' he said. He was mimicking what I did at the George Washington Bridge: I'd been too lazy to mount the E-ZPass, so I'd grab it from the glove compartment and hold it out the window, hoping the invisible eye registered our payment.

Most travelers know to get immunizations ahead of time and to pack their prescriptions in carry-ons. A new Web site called Emergencylink.com takes health preparedness one step further by allowing travelers to upload their medical records and designate a contact in their social network who has access to their information in case of emergency. Unlike other paid-plan medical programs, the free service does not arrange treatment or evacuation. Instead, it operates a 24-hour line that emergency medical technicians can call to treat a traveler who is mentally incapacitated. (A traveler's member ID card includes the number.) Emergencylink.com then provides information, including insurance, medications and allergies, and then calls the emergency contact, who can be patched through to E.M.T.'s and reach out to a traveler's family members and hospital if a stay is required.

LONDON -- Scotland, together with England, formalized organized soccer and to this day retains a powerful voice over the laws of the game worldwide. But with the insolvency of Glasgow's most successful club, Rangers F.C., comes an unraveling that threatens the future of the entire pyramid of the country's professional soccer. On Wednesday, the remaining 11 clubs of the Scottish Premier League voted overwhelmingly against allowing a re-formed and rebranded Rangers to play in their league.

PAPA--John. January 20, 1925 - June 24, 2012. John Papa, San Francisco real estate broker, architectural preservationist, patron of the arts, and global-traveler, died at home in his sleep on June 24, 2012. He was born in New Haven, CT, on January 20, 1925, the son of the late John H. and Lucy Merola Papa. As a young man he was active in the family business, Papa & Sons Open Air Market and later as a clothier to Yale students at a local men's clothing store. In 1952 Mr. Papa moved to San Francisco where he pursued a career in real estate and accumulated numerous properties including the historic Selfridge houses, a connected group of six houses designed by the Reid Brothers, located on the southwest corner of California and Pierce streets. His own residence was the Selfridge mansion at 2615 California which Julia Morgan renovated in the 1930s. Mr. Papa was frequently mentioned by the late San Francisco Chronicle columnist, Herb Caen, in his writings about San Francisco's social scene. Mr. Caen also hailed Mr. Papa for his preservation of the Selfridge houses and the creation of the Pierce Street Mews. Mr. Papa was credited with coining the term "Pacific Heights South" as he worked to preserve, restore and revitalize this neighborhood beginning in the 1960s. Mr. Papa often and generously entertained friends, family, and the renowned: HM Taufa'ahau Tupou IV, King of Tonga (1965-2006), Lee Evans, 1968 Olympic Gold Medalist, as well as Hollywood actors, professional musicians, and social, civic and business leaders of San Francisco. Among his distinguished performing arts guests were the great sopranos Leontyne Price and Renata Scotto, prima-ballerina Margot Fonteyn, principal dancers Rudolf Nureyev and Sir Anthony James Dowell, as well as numerous dancers of the American Ballet Theater and the Royal Ballet. An avid traveler, Mr. Papa's journeys took him to all continents. Abroad for six months each year, he spent many winters in Puerto Vallarta, and summers in Europe. He will be most fondly remembered for the many amusing postcards sent and anecdotes brought back. He was predeceased by brother, Stephen J. Papa, sisters Rose Thomas and Mary Avitable, and dearest of friends, Christy MacInnes and Rose Goldstein. He is survived by brother, Arthur Papa of Orange, sister Paula Caruso of North Haven, CT, and numerous (grand) nieces and (grand) nephews, as well as his devoted San Francisco "family." A private celebration will be held following a funeral mass open to the public at St. Dominic's Catholic Church, 2390 Bush Street, San Francisco, Saturday, August 4th, at 12:30pm. www.halstedngray.com

So far, baseball's theme in 2012 has been clear. It's all about pitching. There have been five no-hitters, including two perfect games. APRIL 17 Jamie Moyer, Colorado, at 49 years 151 days, becomes the oldest pitcher in history to win a game when he defeats San Diego.

SITTING proud and pretty on the rarefied stretch of Fifth Avenue quaintly known as Millionaire's Row in the early 20th century -- but ostensibly the province of billionaires only in this one -- an ornate Stanford White-designed mansion that sold for $42 million was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. The 15,225-square-foot limestone showplace at 973 Fifth Avenue, built in the Italian Renaissance palazzo style, had been on the market for a year. It was originally listed at $49 million.

The pictures capture a poignant moment in most children's lives -- their first haircut. Here, young boys from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, perch in the same big barber's chair, newly shorn and relieved to have survived. The pictures come from an archive amassed by Al Criscillo, an immigrant from Naples who for 54 years ran a barbershop on Metropolitan Avenue. Mr. Criscillo began offering a free photo with every first haircut sometime in the 1960s -- family members don't remember exactly when. He would keep a copy for a collage he had in the shop or for storage at home. He continued the practice until he closed the shop in 2005. He died in 2007, at 90.

CARTER--Frederic D.,Jr. Frederic D. Carter Jr., 20 August 1924 30 June 2012 died peacefully, with friends and family, at his home in Millbrook, New York. Born in Hartford, he was raised in Irvington-on-Hudson and Greensboro, VT, the middle of three boys. Fred graduated cum laude from Phillips Exeter Academy, the Yale Class of 45W, spent two years commanding a mine sweeper in the Pacific, completing his education at Harvard Business School '49. As an investment banker, for 39 years he commuted, first from Armonk and then from Bedford Hills, to the United States Trust Company of New York. After 12 years at the Putnam Trust Company in Greenwich, he and Susan, his wife of 55 years, retired to Millbrook. While working in New York City, he spent Thursday evenings singing with the University Glee Club, and until retirement, spent most Saturday afternoon's mowing his lawn. Fred was a "great" fisherman and often fished in the western US. When not fishing he golfed, specializing in hitting from the rough. Over the last seven of his Golden years, he rediscovered his Senior Prom Date and shared her joy of walking on Cannon Beach in Oregon. After retiring and downsizing from four acres to 18, he became treasurer of St. Peter's Church and sang tenor in the choir until the month before he died of liver cancer. Fred is survived by his two children, Frederic (Fred) III and Alice, and two grandchildren, Frederic (Derek) IV and Douglas. He was predeceased by his parents, Frederic D. and Betty W. Carter, his two brothers Charles W. (Bill) and Samuel P.W. (Sam), his wife, Susan Morris, and his partner, Margot (Langdon) Visher. A celebration of Fred's life will be held at 11:00am on Saturday, July 14 at St. Peter's Church, Lithgow, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the Cancer Research Institute, One Exchange Plaza, 55 Broadway, NY 10006.

KAPLAND--Shirley H.,age 90 years. Loving wife of the late Dr. Jack A. Kapland. Devoted mother of Michael Kapland (Kathryn) and Bonnie Postel (Ira). Adored grandmother of Jacquelle Kapland and Geoffrey and Joshua Postel. Cherished great-grandmother of Cecelia and Jillian Postel. Daughter of the late Anna and Harry Stitman, sister of the late Rosalyn Gidan. Graveside services, Thursday, July 5, 2012, 11:30am at Beth David Cemetery. Donations in her memory should be made to the Jewish Museum, 1109 5th Ave., New York, NY 10128.

SOMEBODY at the Paley Center for Media has been having fun rooting through the trash. The trashier stuff in the center's collection, that is. On Thursdays at 6 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays at 2 p.m. throughout July the center is showing what it's calling ''SUMMER 'CAMP,' '' which it describes as ''a compilation of television's most outrageous, campy and head-scratching moments.'' The idea is to create a video version of a mixtape, and this particular mixtape seems intent on proving that alarmist television is rarely a good idea.

FROME--Irving. February 16, 1913, died July 4, 2012. Beloved husband of the late Pauline Frome and loving father to his cherished daughter Karen Lewicki. He is survived by his daughter Karen, son-in-law Richard, granddaughters Robin and Lisa and great-grandchildren Jeremy and Julia.

KINSLOW--Helen. Our dear friend Helen died peacefully at home on May 9, 2012 at age 78. She was buried on May 14, 2012 in Gateway to Heaven Cemetery beside her parents Thomas and Josephine Kinslow. Helen was a devoted daughter and a proud January 1951 graduate of Hunter College High School where she was elected Vice President of her senior class and voted "most indispensable". Helen received a B.S. degree from Cornell University and a Masters degree in Social Work from Case Western Reserve University. She worked in her field at the Community Service Society. Manhattan State Hospital and Bedford Hills prison. Helen is survived by her brother William Kinslow (Pat), her nieces and nephews, her half-sisters Teresa D'Annza and Margaret Nagel. her step-children Lorna Culbert and Marlene Urban, her companion Ted Bekowski and her many friends. Helen faced and handled many difficult challenges during her life courageously. She will be greatly missed for her sweetness, perseverance and generosity. Helen remained "indispensable" until the end to all who knew her. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, July 15, 2012, from 2-4PM in the meeting room at 303 West 66th Street in New York City. Helen loved animals and was a dedicated vegetarian. Donations may be made in her name to the ASPCA at 242 East 92nd Street, NY, NY 10128.

THE Pininfarina Group announced on Tuesday that Sergio Pininfarina, its honorary chairman, who presided over one of the most romanticized eras in Italian automotive design, had died at his home in Turin, Italy. He was 85. The cause of death was not disclosed by the company, but Mr. Pininfarina was known to have been ill in recent years. During his tenure as managing director of the company, the Pininfarina studio produced in the early 1960s what became some of the most valuable sports cars ever, including the Ferrari 250 GT California Spyder and the Ferrari 250 GTO.

In honor of Nora Ephron, who died last month, the Big City Book Club will revisit her early work as a journalist and essayist. In the 1960s and '70s, she wrote for magazines like Rolling Stone, New York and The New Yorker -- pieces collected in the anthologies ''Crazy Salad'' and ''Wallflower at the Orgy.'' We're going to read ''Wallflower'' because it's more readily available, but if you're lucky enough to have an old copy of ''Crazy Salad,'' reread it, too, and weigh in!

RONALD K. BROWN'S engaging mix of West African and Afro-Caribbean dance traditions with a fluid, gestural contemporary style produces movement that engenders a visceral thrill. Like many good choreographers he conveys the idea that perhaps you, with a little more training and fewer inhibitions, could do that too. That most of us couldn't manage the rhythmically complex, liquidly supple movement performed by his superb troupe is all the more reason to head this week to the Joyce Theater, where Mr. Brown will present his company, EVIDENCE, in two programs. On the first is the 1999 ''Gatekeepers,'' and the new ''Everybody at the Table,'' with which Mr. Brown continues his exploration of the music of Stevie Wonder. ''Everybody'' is an extension of ''On Earth Together,'' also set to Wonder songs, which Mr. Brown showed in 2010, and it's likely to offer similar themes of love and compassion. In the second program the company performs ''Walking Out the Dark,'' ''Seeking Healing'' and ''Come Ye'': all compelling odes to the joys -- terrestrial and spiritual -- of dancing. 7:30 p.m. Monday to Wednesday, 8 p.m. Thursday to Friday, 2 and 8 p.m. Saturday, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea,(212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $10 to 49.

THE laws of gravity must not apply at the St. James Theater, where the peppy ''BRING IT ON: THE MUSICAL'' begins performances this week. The show, about cutthroat rivalry among cheerleaders, features high-flying gymnastics in the gasp-inducing choreography by Andy Blankenbuehler (''In the Heights''). The story, which differs from the 2000 movie, revolves around Campbell (Taylor Louderman), a head cheerleader forced out of her wealthy and very white high school thanks to redistricting. When she arrives at the tougher, more diverse Jackson High, Campbell is no longer super popular; perhaps even worse, the school has no cheerleading squad at all. Taylor tries to effect change and love, competition and maturation ensue of course. In addition to Mr. Blankenbuehler, who also directs, the artistic team includes the book writer Jeff Whitty (''Avenue Q''). The music is by Tom Kitt (''Next to Normal'') and Lin-Manuel Miranda (''In the Heights''), and the lyrics are by Mr. Miranda and Amanda Green. The plot of ''Bring It On'' is not exactly momentous -- or entirely unpredictable -- but isn't it the time of year for a buoyant fling anyway? Previews begin Thursday, with the opening set for Aug. 1. 246 West 44th Street, Manhattan; bringitonmusical.com.

I have bipolar disorder and recently recovered from a yearlong mania and depression that required five lengthy hospitalizations (both voluntary and involuntary). When I am sick, I can mount strong and convincing arguments as to why my personal freedom should not be restricted by involuntary commitment. But when I am well, I am relieved that my family and doctors did not, like me, regard the crazy choices of my illness as ''personal freedom.'' CD, New Mexico, posted on nytimes.com

ALTHOUGH 60 years have passed since GRACE KELLY had her first leading role, playing Amy Kane, the prim Quaker wife of an embattled marshal (Gary Cooper) in an Old West town, Kelly remains Hollywood's archetype of ''The Cool Blonde.'' That's the title of BAMcinématek's eight-film retrospective of Kelly's career, which begins on Friday with a weeklong run of Alfred Hitchcock's ''Rear Window'' and continues through July 19. In ''Rear Window'' a mischievous playfulness flashed through her exquisitely demure surface. Hitchcock searched far and wide for another blond star with the same balance of fire and ice and came the closest with Eva Marie Saint in ''North by Northwest.'' The archetype's enduring power is evident in January Jones's sleek Betty Draper Francis in ''Mad Men.'' Besides ''High Noon'' and ''Rear Window'' the series includes ''The Country Girl,'' for which Kelly won an Academy Award, beating out Judy Garland in a famous upset; ''High Society,'' ''Mogambo,'' ''The Swan,'' and her other great Hitchcock collaboration, ''To Catch a Thief.'' Rounding out the series is Henry Hathaway's obscure 1951 documentary-style drama, ''Fourteen Hours,'' in which she made her movie debut playing a tiny role. Tickets and information: (718) 636-4100, bam.org.

Because of an editing error, an article on June 24 about a daughter's struggle to help her mentally ill father misstated one of the conditions he had to fulfill to be released from jail. He had to see a probation officer and complete therapy at a community mental health center, but he did not have to see a psychiatrist every week for a year.

The Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York is such a destination that plenty of guests have swiped a souvenir or two. Now, the hotel has a message for sticky-fingered visitors: give it back and we'll pretend it never happened. The storied hotel has started an amnesty program for items taken before 1960 through Sept. 15 in an effort to bolster its digital archives and its gallery in the main lobby. The Waldorf is seeking items like silverware, ashtrays and linens. The guilty party should return secreted items along with a description, the date of the theft and the guest's recollection of the stay (or meal) that prompted him or her to swipe a memento. Returned items will be displayed on the Waldorf's Facebook page, where followers can vote on which should be displayed in the lobby gallery.

THE Paris couture shows sometimes come off like a wild rampage of creativity slowed only by the odd paralytic wait as seamstresses backstage close that final seam. And then everyone returns to the black hired cars and the beetling traffic on the Rue de Rivoli until the next flash of brilliance. It has been ages since people killed off the hours between shows with a lazy, gracious lunch, a couture tradition. I smiled when a fellow journalist commended the variety of international takeout his co-workers had tasted. Personally, I like the salads at Eric Kayser, a bakery chain that opened a branch near my hotel a couple of years ago. I did manage to go to the Ritz bar this time. It was still the same old Ritz, with the piano player and the stranded-looking tourists clasping their cocktails in a booth as a bit of air came in from the patio. I stayed for one drink.

Travelers peering at hotel mattresses in search of bedbugs should turn their attention elsewhere. A far more diverse set of microscopic critters lodge themselves in a much smaller place in a hotel room: the remote control. A study by microbiologists at the University of Houston, the University of South Carolina and Purdue University found that the remote's crevasses had some of the highest levels of bacterial contamination in hotel rooms.

OPENING on Thursday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, ''YAYOI KUSAMA'' gives contemporary art's reigning queen of obsessive, hallucinatory repetition the full retrospective treatment. Over six decades of making art in two countries (the United States and Japan) and in every conceivable medium, Ms. Kusama, 83, has ensnared viewers in her painted ''Infinity Nets,'' phallic soft-sculpture ''Accumulations'' and psychedelic fields of dots, where they are forced to confront some intense, discomfiting connections between abstraction and anxiety. As is well known in the art world Ms. Kusama has been living, voluntarily, in a mental institution since 1977. Less well known, these days, are her early performances and happenings, made during the 1960s and '70s, while she was sharing a loft with Donald Judd and keeping company with Warhol, Oldenburg and Joseph Cornell. The films and archival material in the Whitney show, which is arriving from the Tate Modern, should change that. Already on view in the lobby gallery, since June 13, is Ms. Kusama's installation ''Fireflies on the Water'' (2002). Owned by the Whitney, this popular piece (which will be familiar to visitors to the 2004 Whitney Biennial) uses water and mirrors to reflect 150 tiny hanging lights into seemingly infinite constellations. Through Sept. 30, (212) 570-3600, whitney.org.

STILLERMAN--Stephen H. The Board of Directors and Staff of Silver Hill Hospital mourn the passing of Steve Stillerman, Chair Emeritus. A devoted friend of the hospital, Steve was a visionary leader, who guided the hospital as Chair from 2003 until 2009 at a pivotal time in the hospital's 81-year history. His supreme generosity and compassion coupled with his steadfast belief in the hospital's mission to provide the best treatment possible for mental illness and addiction has been instrumental in creating an extraordinary place for care. We will remain eternally grateful to Steve for his lasting contribution and extend our deepest condolences to Nancy Stillerman and his daughters Lisa and Nicole, son-in-law Mark Bates, and granddaughter Alexandra. Deann Murphy and Ward Cleary, Co-Chairs, Sig Ackerman, President and Medical Director, and the Board and Staff of Silver Hill Hospital.

TULELAKE, Calif. -- Under a cloud-filled sky, the Japanese-American pilgrims sat on folding chairs facing a vast, flat and dusty landscape whose monotony was broken only by two oddly shaped mountains that rose to the east and west. For the souls of the hundreds buried in a long-vanished cemetery here, a Buddhist minister offered prayers and rang a bell, though its invocation was almost lost as a propeller plane took off from a nearby airfield. Nearly 400 Japanese-Americans journeyed from June 30 to July 3 to this remote corner of California, where 18,789 people of Japanese ancestry were incarcerated during World War II. The turnout was one of the highest ever for the four-day pilgrimage, which occurs every other year around the Fourth of July, organizers said. They surmise that as the number of the camp's survivors dwindles, there is a growing urgency to understand -- and reinterpret -- what has been a hidden subchapter in America's history.

The weekend box office headlines: Spider-Man was solid if not quite superheroic, ''Savages'' surprised, and Katy Perry . . . well, she at least has her day job. ''The Amazing Spider-Man'' (Sony) was an easy No. 1, taking in about $65 million at North American theaters, for a total of $140 million since opening on Tuesday. Comparisons are difficult, but the first ''Transformers'' movie, which opened on the Tuesday before the Fourth of July in 2007, took in about $172 million in its first six days, after adjusting for inflation. Sony called the response to its latest Spider-Man film ''a spectacular success by any measure'' and noted that the movie took in an additional $201.6 million overseas.

CASSANO--Linda Nina, age 62, of New York, NY and Saltaire, NY, passed away after a valiant battle with pancreatic cancer. The beloved wife of James McDonald and mother to Anthony McDonald, Linda was born August 23rd, 1949 to Nina Cassano and William Spadaccini. She attended Mother Cabrini High School and Mahnattanville College and went on to earn her JD from New York Law School and her LLM from NYU. Linda practiced law for 40 years, specializing in securities and regulatory affairs. In addition to her professional life, Linda served on the Board of Trustees of Manhattanville College and as President of the Saltaire, New York Fire Company. Linda was a NASTAR champion snowboarder and active snowboard instructor at Windham Mountain. She is also survived by her loving sister, Victoria, her nephew, Jay Cassano, and thousands upon thousands of friends. The family will receive visitors on Monday July 9th 7-9pm and Tuesday, July 10th 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, (212) 288-3500. A Solemn Mass of the Resurrection will be held at Saint Frances De Sales Church, 135 East 96th Street, New York on Wednesday, July 11th, 2012 at 10:00am.
