Roger Waters projected his message stadium-wide, literally, when he brought his new production of ''The Wall'' to Yankee Stadium on Friday, starting a two-night stand. A white-brick wall, which is both an ideal video screen in concert and the central metaphor of the rock opera he wrote for the 1979 album by Pink Floyd (with additional music by the band's guitarist, David Gilmour), spanned the stadium and towered 40 feet high. The message Mr. Waters hammered home - with images including animated regiments of goose-stepping hammers on the march - was distrust of power and authority in many forms: parents, schools, celebrities, corporations, countries, ideologies. Throughout intermission (as elegiac music played), and at points during the concert, the names and faces of people killed by wars, terrorism and government actions were shown on the wall. Quotations from George Orwell, Franz Kafka and Dwight D. Eisenhower also appeared on it. At one point, animated bombers dropped corporate logos and religious symbols; ''Run Like Hell'' included a WikiLeaks video from an American helicopter firing on Iraqi journalists. Early in the concert, Mr. Waters deplored ''all the victims of state terror all over the world,'' and preached that giving governments, police and soldiers too much power was ''a very steep and slippery slope to tyranny.''

6:05 P.M. (Cinemax) DIE HARD WITH A VENGEANCE (1995) Bruce Willis, left, starring once again as the-down-but-never-out cop John McClane, must stop another terrorist (Jeremy Irons) from destroying a public place. This time, however, Mr. Willis cannot get to the final ''yippee-ki-yay'' without some help from Samuel L. Jackson as Zeus Carver. The film leads its characters (and the viewer) on a dizzying tour of New York City during the mid-90s, from Harlem to Central Park and Wall Street and back up to Tompkins Square Park and the old Yankee Stadium. ''McClane and Zeus are plagued by fake bombs, real bombs and Simon's cadre of killers, not to mention cellular phones that suddenly go dead and really bad traffic on Ninth Avenue,'' Caryn James wrote in The New York Times. The film delivers, she added, ''pure action, with bigger and better explosions and stunts.'' 9:30 A.M. (AMC) RAY (2004) Jamie Foxx, right, won the best actor Oscar for his portrayal of the musician Ray Charles in this biopic directed by Taylor Hackford. A. O. Scott wrote in The Times that Mr. Foxx gave an ''inventive, intuitive and supremely intelligent performance.'' He added: ''He has mastered Charles's leg-swinging gait, his open-mouthed smile and the tilt of his head, as well as the speaking style that could sometimes sound like a form of scat singing. But there is much more than mimicry at work here.''

BAILEY--Robert. The Juilliard School mourns the death of Robert Bailey, member of the School's graduate faculty since 1986 and doctoral committee since 1994. A brilliant scholar and teacher, his presence at Juilliard brought together serious historical studies with performance activities; an approach that now stands as a model for how graduate students are taught at the School. Our condolences go to his family and his many friends. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Jane Gottlieb, Vice President for Library and Information Resources

DEAR DIARY: I rarely if ever wear a wristwatch. When I am walking with friends I often ask what the time is, to my friends' great annoyance. New York City, however, has come to my rescue with the installation of the Muni-Meters. These wonderful boxes appear on every block and contain a window with the current time.

Whether it has been against good Revolution teams (ones with players like Clint Dempsey, Taylor Twellman and Pat Noonan) or bad Revolution teams (which have failed to make the postseason in Major League Soccer the past few years), the Red Bulls have been unable to crack the code in Foxborough, Mass. Now, after Sunday's 2-0 loss at Gillette Stadium, the Red Bulls are winless in Foxborough in 18 games, dating to June 2000.

LEAR--Evelyn. With deep sadness, The Juilliard School recognizes the death of distinguished alumna Evelyn Lear, one of the most admired and respected vocal artists of the twentieth century. With intelligence and artistry, she approached numerous roles and made them her own. She also became a recognized teacher, often in association with her beloved husband Thomas Stewart, a Juilliard graduate as well. We send our deepest condolences to her family. Joseph W. Polisi, President Ara Guzelimian, Provost and Dean Brian Zeger, Artistic Director of Juilliard's Marcus Institute for Vocal Arts
Dear Diary: Third Avenue bus pulled over by frantic man on street. Explains he must retrieve friend's escaped pet bird from roof of bus.

The first goods from the Dreier collection - an array of film-related and other artifacts assembled by Chad Dreier, the longtime executive of the home-building company Ryland Group, and his son Doug - will be auctioned in Los Angeles beginning on July 28. The auction house Profiles in History will run the sale, and some of the collection will be displayed at the Comic-Con International convention this week in San Diego. Among the items are Matthew Broderick's leather jacket from ''Ferris Bueller's Day Off.'' It is tan, gray and black with zippers and rivets, and it even has a tear in back, where Ferris was snagged while running through the bushes. The jacket is expected to go for $20,000 to $30,000, according to the catalog. Other objects include the ''Capt. John Miller'' uniform worn by Tom Hanks in ''Saving Private Ryan'' and Will Ferrell's red suit from ''Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy.'' White leather loafers are included.
Dear Diary: I am a tour guide who was taking a group of eighth graders through Central Park the other day when a magical encounter happened.

It used to be that New York magazine's cheeky blog items expounding on fashion and politicians were accessories to the main attraction - the articles in the flagship magazine. But next month, New York is shifting more attention online. New York Media, which includes the magazine and its Web sites, is investing heavily in its blog The Cut and turning it into what Adam Moss, New York's editor in chief, calls ''a high-end fashion magazine with the scrappiness of a blog.''

SBARRO--Carmela "Mama Sbarro" Of Melville, formerly of Brooklyn. Devoted wife of the Late Gennero. Loving mother of Joseph (Joan), Mario (Nunzia), and Anthony (Victoria). Cherished grandmother of 13 and great-grandmother of 33. Carmela was the Co-founder of Sbarro's Italian Restaurants. She was chosen as One of Six Woman Immigrants for a TV special "Portraits Of Liberty" and she also received and Honnary Doctorate from Johnson & Wales College of Culinary Arts. Funeral Mass, Monday (July 9, 2012) 9:45am at Saint Matthew R.C. Church Dix Hills. Entombment to follow Pinelawn Memorial Park. Funeral services entrusted to Mangano Funeral Home, Inc. - Deer Park, NY. In lieu of flowers, the Sbarro family requests donations to be made to the charity of your choice. www.manganofh.com

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about the actor Andy Griffith misidentified the television anthology series on which he starred in one episode, an adaptation of the novel ''No Time for Sergeants,'' in 1955, before playing the same role in the stage and film versions of the same story. The show was ''The United States Steel Hour,'' not ''Playhouse 90.'' And also because of an editing error, the obituary referred incorrectly to Mr. Griffith's son, Andy Jr. (who died in 1996), and his daughter, Dixie Griffith. They were the children of his first marriage, not his third.

The decree could create a political crisis. He has been waiting to make a decision to prove he is president of a republic. GAMAL EID,a human rights lawyer, on the order by President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt to reconvene the Islamist-led Parliament, which had been dissolved by the military. [A1]

Will Internet companies help or hinder government authorities that try to restrict their citizens from using the Web freely? And will their customers, investors or shareholders care enough to do something about it? That debate was freshly stirred on Thursday as the United Nations Human Rights Council passed a landmark resolution supporting freedom of expression on the Internet. Even China, which filters online content through a firewall, backed the resolution. It affirmed that ''the same rights that people have offline must also be protected online, in particular freedom of expression, which is applicable regardless of frontiers and through any media of one's choice.''

LONDON - The scandal over the manipulation of global interest rates until now has mostly put bankers in the spotlight. But the focus on Monday will turn to the regulators, both on what they did and what they did not do. Paul Tucker, a deputy governor at the Bank of England, will give evidence on whether senior government officials put pressure on Barclays to lower its submissions to the London interbank offered rate, or Libor. Barclays agreed in late June to pay some $450 million to settle accusations from United States and British authorities that its traders and senior executives had manipulated the rate, which underpins trillions of dollars of corporate loans, home mortgages and derivatives around the world.

Dear Diary: I'm a stoop gardener. For six years I bounced around Williamsburg and Greenpoint, Brooklyn, with nary a slab of concrete to call my own. But since last year, when I moved to Crown Heights, I have 12 of them leading up to my door. That spring, my boyfriend and I placed two palms in thick plastic planters along our steps. They cost $5 each, on sale at Lowes. And they were stolen within the week.

Remember when people used to make fun of the way pro golfers dressed in the 1970s? The Sansabelt pants? The loud checks and floppy collars? The canary yellow cardigans? What will they be saying about today's pros in 40 years? Or even 10?

DEUTSCHMEISTER--Jason S.,Attorney at Law. July 6, 2012. The most honest, reliable, loyal and trustworthy man, friend and partner who we had the honor to know and work with for the past 25 years. We love you, Deutschy, and we will miss your counsel and hearing your stories every day. Our deepest sympathies to Jason's family, his wife our dear friend Beth Goldklang, his beautiful daughters Jessica and Chelsea, his beloved brother Gary, his nieces and nephews, brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law and his in-laws Connie and Ed. The Giants have lost their number one fan but we know you will still be rooting for them. Jason, you will be missed. Miriam, Lisa, Lauren, Gina, Maire & Karima Breier Deutschmeister Urban Popper Law Group PLLC.

Robert Nkemdiche, widely considered the top football recruit in the class of 2013, said he would honor his commitment to Clemson even if the Tigers did not offer a scholarship to his good friend and high school teammate, Ryan Carter. Nkemdiche, a 6-foot-5, 260-pound defensive end at Grayson High School in Loganville, Ga., created a stir last week when he told The Atlanta Journal-Constitution that his commitment to Clemson would be a ''done deal'' if Tigers Coach Dabo Swinney offered a scholarship to Carter, a 5-10 defensive back. Nkemdiche, who committed to Clemson in June, told The Journal-Constitution that he might give Mississippi a closer look if Clemson did not offer Carter a scholarship. The Rebels have already offered a scholarship to Carter.

The most important voice in a presidential campaign is that of the candidate. But it is not the only important voice, as President Obama and Mitt Romney recently acknowledged. In the last two weeks, both campaigns have had close advisers increase their day-to-day communications with reporters and various media outlets. It is a recognition that they cannot afford to miss a beat in a rapid-fire media environment fueled by Twitter and cable news programs.
With the House scheduled to vote Wednesday on whether to repeal the health care law, some Republicans worry that constantly rearguing the issue makes them seem out of touch.

WAKSMAN--Byron H.,M.D. A distinguished immunologist who pioneered the field of neuro-immunology, died on Sunday, June 17 in Lexington, Massachusetts. He was 92. Waksman graduated from Swarthmore College in 1940 and from the University of Pennsylvania Medical School in 1943. He went on to an academic career at both Harvard/ Mass General Hospital and at Yale School of Medicine. He began his research career investigating experimental allergic encephalomyelitis, an artificially induced condition resembling multiple sclerosis, and similar inflammatory diseases of the nervous system, which he termed "auto-immune" diseases. Waksman and his students demonstrated the role of the thymus in both immune responses and tissue-specific tolerance. They are also credited with discovering several of the first and most important cytokines and circulating lymphocytes known as T-cells. After retiring from academia, Waksman became vice president for research and medicine at the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, where he streamlined the granting process and improved communication between the board, patients and their families, and the media. One of his greatest achievements was to create a series of yearly workshops that brought together physicians and scientists involved with MS, from basic research to clinical treatments. These workshops and their published summaries successfully promoted cooperative work and moved the field of MS research and treatment forward substantially. Following his second retirement, Waksman taught middle school students at the Salk School of Science in New York, an experience that convinced him of the urgent need to improve science education at the pre-college level. For more than 30 years, Waksman directed the Foundation for Microbiology, established in 1951 by his father, Nobel Laureate Selman Waksman, using patent royalties from the production of streptomycin, the first antibiotic for the treatment of tuberculosis. During his tenure, Waksman focused on improving science communication of every kind. In 1985 he initiated the Science Journalism Program at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, MA, and later created a similar international journalism program (EICOS) at the Max Plank Institute in Munich. He also launched a decade-long K-12 science education initiative training classroom teachers to use hands-on microbiology exercises. Waksman travelled widely both professionally and for pleasure, and he spoke many foreign languages fluently. He was a visiting investigator and/or teacher in France, Britain, Germany, Brazil, Venezuela, and Senegal. From 1961 onward, he served almost continuously on advisory panels of various government agencies, the World Health Organization, and the Rockefeller Foundation, as well as on the editorial boards of scientific journals of immunology. Waksman published more than 350 papers and articles. Waksman's many colleagues, former students, and friends around the world cite his superlative teaching and the open, cooperative, and international atmosphere in his labs as his greatest legacy. Waksman is survived by his wife, Joyce; daughter, Nan Schanbacher; son, Peter; and five grandchildren. Memorial services will take place next summer in Woods Hole.

An article in some editions on Monday about planned changes to one of Manhattan's most dangerous roads, Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, in Harlem, misstated the speed limit on additional signs that have been requested by the transportation committee of Community Board 10. The committee wants more 30-miles-per-hour speed-limit signs, instead of 35-miles-per-hour signs.

Just thinking about my e-mail in-box makes me sad. This month alone, I received more than 6,000 e-mails. That doesn't include spam, notifications or daily deals, either. With all those messages, I have no desire to respond to even a fraction of them. I can just picture my tombstone: Here lies Nick Bilton, who responded to thousands of e-mails a month. May he rest in peace.

SAGE--Lillian, 88, passed away on July 8th in her home in Manhattan. Wife of the late Dr. Maurice Sage, mother of Ann, Malcolm and Martin. She was delighted to be the grandmother of six -- Marissa, Marc, Nick, Richard, Juliet and Jared, and equally thrilled to be the great-grandmother of Lilly and Elizabeth. She was born in The Bronx, grew up in Coney Island, lived through the Depression and the War and saw more of life than she'd ever imagined. Services on Monday, July 9 at 10:00 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

''This is the one,'' said Zenop Tuncer, leading the way to a corner of his car repair and restoration shop, where he had parked a rusty, aged hulk with running boards, an old-fashioned vacuum-tube radio and a history - though maybe not the history he thought. The car is a 1942 Mercedes 320 Cabriolet D. Mr. Tuncer said it ran nicely when it arrived, but the body and the interior needed work, so he had called Mercedes-Benz to order parts. ''As soon as I gave them the VIN number,'' he said, using the abbreviation for vehicle identification number, ''there were a lot of calls from Mercedes: 'That's Hitler's car.'//'' (The 10-digit number in question was actually the car's factory number, or serial number.)

E. L. James has introduced millions of women to the world of sadomasochistic erotica through her ''Fifty Shades'' trilogy. But Anne Rice got there first. Ms. Rice's ''Sleeping Beauty'' trilogy, published in the 1980s under the pen name A. N. Roquelaure, was an underground hit when it was first released. Now, trying to capture some sales from ''Fifty Shades'' readers searching for their next book in the genre, Ms. Rice's publisher will rerelease the novels this week with slick new covers.

Where once cable television was ruled by syndicated reruns and classic movies, now original drama and reality shows dominate networks like TNT, Bravo and the History Channel. Among the top 10 shows last season on these three networks, only one -- ''The Mentalist'' on TNT -- was in syndication. ''The Closer,'' the extremely popular seven-year-old TNT series, begins its final six-episode run Monday night. It leaves with a spinoff in place: ''Major Crimes,'' which stars Mary McDonnell as Captain Sharon Raydor, above left, will have its series premiere on Aug. 13. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Baby boomers may remember the jingle for Riunite, a sparkling wine served chilled, that went ''Riunite on ice. Riunite so nice.'' The TV advertisements that were once ubiquitous have since disappeared into the recesses of 1970s and '80s nostalgia. But the Riunite brand is back, this time chasing digitally adept younger women. Its new slogan: ''Just Chill.''

A boardroom coup at Duke Energy, the nation's largest electric utility, is expected to come under scrutiny on Tuesday when North Carolina regulators question the company's chief executive. James E. Rogers, Duke's chief, has been in a harsh spotlight since last week, when Duke closed its $26 billion merger with Progress Energy, a rival. The transaction, struck 18 months ago, called for Progress's chief executive, William D. Johnson, to run the combined company. But just hours after the deal's completion, the Duke-dominated board ousted Mr. Johnson and put Mr. Rogers in charge.

TANNENBAUM--Harold S. Passed away on July 8, 2012 at the age of 97 in Durham, NC. He was the beloved husband of Justine S. Tannenbaum and the late Jeannette Fuchs Tannenbaum; devoted father of Ira Tannenbaum (Lucretia), Judith Tannenbaum, Rosalind Abram (Adam), and Mark Schaefer (Elizabeth); grandfather of Sarah Sherman (John), Elizabeth and Julia Tannenbaum, Lucas and Evan Schaefer; and Benjamin and Joshua Abram; great-grandfather of Ellie and Jack Sherman. Also survived by sisters Gertrude D. T. Schimmel, and Frances Weinstein. Born in New York City on August 18, 1914, he graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School, City College of New York, and Brooklyn Law School. He enjoyed a long, productive career as President and CEO of Normandy Mfg. Corp., headwear importers. We will miss his unique intelligence, humor, and generosity.

FELDBLUM--Hortense, age 98, born and raised in Houston, Texas, and a graduate of Smith College, died peacefully on July 6 in her Manhattan home. She is survived by three daughters: Barbara, Mary, and Kathy, and three grandchildren: Debbie, Robert and Jerry. A dedicated New York City resident for over 45 years, she was an avid reader, a music lover, a supporter of the Metropolitan Opera and a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. A private celebration of her life will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to New York Presbyterian, Div. of Geriatrics, House Call Program, 525 E. 68th Street, Box 39, New York City 10065.
JESSUP--Sandra U. Departed 15 years ago, but still with me everyday. Jeff
RENFRO--Ed, Illustrator (1924- 2012), died peacefully at home on June 25. Donations may be made in memory of Ed Renfro to: Silvermine Arts Center, 1037 Silvermine Road, New Canaan, CT 06840.

BERKMAN--Yvette, mother of Cathy and Marji, widow of Melvin, sister of Rita Wolfson and the late Ezra Gratz, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on July 8. Born on April 24, 1924, Yvette taught third grade in the Lakeland School District in Westchester County. Following her retirement, she served in the Peace Corps in the Philippines and in Costa Rica. She volunteered at the Holy Apostle Soup Kitchen for more than 15 years until shortly before her death. A graveside service will held on Tuesday, July 10 at 11am at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery.

HOUGHTON--Priscilla Dewey died peacefully at her home in Cohasset, MA, surrounded by her family on July 6, 2012. Priscilla was married to Amory Houghton, Jr. after her first husband, Talbot Dewey died in 1983. Kippy Dewey, Toby Dewey and spouse Susan Morley, and Peter Dewey are her children. Her grandchildren are Jessie Stuart Hollister and husband Richard David Hollister, Daniel Malinowski Stuart and wife Mari Jarvisjarvi, Zachary Blackett Stuart, Jacob Talbot Dewey, Aislinn Abigail Dewey, Chantal Grace Dewey, Alicia Morley Dewey, and Alexander Talbot Dewey. She has four stepchildren and nine step grandchildren. She also has four great grandchildren. A service will be held on Saturday, July 14 at 2pm, in Trinity Church, 206 Clarendon Street, Copley Square, Boston, followed by a reception at the church. In lieu of flowers please send contributions in her honor to Urban Improv, 8 St. John Street, Jamaica Plain, MA., 02130 or donate online at: www.urbanimprov.org.

Mets pitcher R.A. Dickey has the best earned run average, the most victories and the lowest ratio of walks and hits per inning of any starting pitcher on the National League All-Star team. Yet Dickey will not start the All-Star Game on Tuesday night. Tony La Russa, the N.L. manager, chose Matt Cain of the San Francisco Giants to start against Detroit's Justin Verlander of the American League. Cain threw a perfect game with 14 strikeouts last month, and is 9-3 with a 2.62 earned run average. Dickey, who tossed consecutive one-hitters last month, is 12-1 with a 2.40 E.R.A. and a WHIP of 0.933, which leads the league.
An obituary on Saturday about Martin Swig, the founder of the California Mille sports-car rally, misspelled the name of the city in California where he lived. It is Greenbrae, not Greenbray.

FRIEDRICKS--Barbara K.,83, of Sarasota, FL, formerly of Lake Success, NY. Adored wife and best friend of 55 years to Martin B. Friedricks who passed away in 2005. Cherished mother of Linda Halper (Rob), Kenneth Friedricks (Kathy), Bruce Friedricks (Amy). Beloved grandmother (Babsy), to Jeremy Halper (Stacey) and Zach Halper, Emily and Henry Friedricks. Great grandma to Makaela Halper. Dear sister to Alan Kringel (deceased) and Nancy Osserman. Graduate of Wheaton College, Norton, MA. Devoted docent at Mote Marine. Donations may be made to Mote Marine, 1600 Ken Thompson Parkway, Sarasota, FL 34236.

LOS ANGELES - A threatened divorce battle between Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes ended before it really got started, as representatives of the couple announced a settlement of issues between them on Monday. The deal came less than two weeks after Ms. Holmes filed for divorce in New York, seeking sole custody of the couple's 6-year-old daughter, Suri.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Friday about the weekly Billboard album chart, on which Linkin Park's new album, ''Living Things,'' edged out Maroon 5's ''Overexposed'' for the No. 1 spot, reversed the positions in the last 1-2 ranking that was so close, in December. Michael Bublé's ''Christmas'' was No. 1 then, slightly ahead of ''Here and Now'' by Nickelback.

If you live long enough - that is, beyond 50 or 60 - chances are one or more of your joints, probably your knees or hips, will become arthritic. And if pain or stiffness begin to seriously limit your ability to enjoy life and perform routine tasks, chances are you'll consider replacing the troublesome joint. ''People with osteoarthritis are relying more and more heavily on surgery,'' Dr. David T. Felson, a rheumatologist and epidemiologist at Boston University School of Medicine, told me. ''The rate of knee replacement is just skyrocketing, out of proportion to increases in arthritic changes seen on X-rays, and replacement surgery is contributing greatly to the rising costs of Medicare.''

When Nancy Mulhearn learned she had Parkinson's disease seven years ago, she kept the diagnosis mostly to herself, hiding it from friends, colleagues - even, at first, her mother, sister and teenage children. After seven months, she decided she had to tell her family, and they settled into an unspoken agreement not to talk about the disease. She also realized her colleagues already suspected the truth: One asked why she had trouble applying her lipstick. She sometimes could not control her shaking hands.

A chart on Saturday with the Off the Charts column, about some banks' rigging of a benchmark lending rate known as the London interbank offered rate or Libor, misidentified the nationality of one bank that contributes to the setting of Libor. West LB is based in Germany, not Australia. A corrected chart can be found at nytimes.com/economy.

After the failure of the futures brokerage firm MF Global left customers missing more than $1 billion, regulators promised to tighten rules, enhance oversight and crack down on wayward firms. But months later, regulators are scrambling to deal with the collapse of another brokerage firm.

Robinson Cano, who won last year's Home Run Derby, went homerless in 10 swings Monday as fans booed him heavily. Cano was the captain of the A.L. team and did not pick Kansas City's Billy Butler, despite having said that he hoped to take a Royal. ''You know fans,'' Cano said. ''This is for the fans and that's what they want.''

The day has not yet arrived where people can have microchips installed in their bodies that connect them to the Internet, then go haywire and nearly annihilate the human race. But Bryan Singer is happy to hasten that future along, even if it poses risks to the media in which he customarily operates. Mr. Singer, the director of films including ''The Usual Suspects,'' ''X-Men'' and ''Valkyrie,'' is the producer of the new Web series ''H+,'' which will make its debut Aug. 8 on YouTube. Created by John Cabrera and Cosimo De Tommaso, ''H+'' tells a not-so-far-fetched story in which millions of people have communications chips installed in their bodies, and are then wiped out by a virus attacking the chips. Shuttling back and forth in time, ''H+'' follows the survivors of that devastation while exploring the origins of the technology that caused it.

The Off Broadway hit ''Freud's Last Session,'' an imagined debate between Sigmund Freud and C.S. Lewis about God and rational thought, will close on July 22 after two years of performances because of declining ticket sales, the show's lead producer said on Monday. Unlike most Off Broadway straight plays that run for only a few weeks, ''Freud's Last Session''developed such positive word of mouth among audience members that the play transferred last October from its 145-seat auditorium on the Upper West Side to a 199-seat house at New World Stages, a complex in Manhattan's theater district.

A music review on Monday about Roger Waters's production of ''The Wall,'' at Yankee Stadium, misidentified the singer who performed the vocal parts sung by David Gilmour on the Pink Floyd album ''The Wall.'' He is Robbie Wyckoff -- not Dave Kilminster who, as the review noted, plays lead guitar in the live production.
An art entry in the Listings pages on Friday about an exhibition of work by Whitney Claflin at the Thomas Erben Gallery in Manhattan misstated the closing date. It is Friday, not July 28.

It's the ultimate cliché, but it is true: follow the money. For the last several months, American Airlines' new chairman and chief executive, Tom Horton, has been desperately trying to delay merger talks with his former cubicle mate, US Airways' chief executive, Doug Parker. (Mr. Horton and Mr. Parker sat next to each other when they both worked at American in the 1980s.)
THE FACTS Obesity in pregnancy is a growing problem. Nationwide, about one in five expectant mothers is obese, and up to 40 percent of women gain more weight than recommended during pregnancy.

As part of a continuing overhaul of the home mortgage market, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Monday issued proposed rules to bolster fairness and clarity in residential lending, including requiring a good-faith estimate of costs for homebuyers. The proposed rules have two central elements - the loan estimate and the closing disclosure - that would provide would-be homebuyers with a simple accounting of likely payments and fees to prevent costly surprises.

My list of phone contacts reads like many a New York City reporter's, with the representatives of various agencies dutifully noted. But I have proudly held, for years, a shining jewel under the letter B, tucked between Borakove, Ellen, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner's office, and Boyle, Jimmy, a retired president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association. Borgnine, Ernest.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about Las Vegas's new Smith Center for the Performing Arts, which will bring more upscale entertainment to the city, misidentified, in some editions, the person for whom the center is named. He is Fred W. Smith, a retired newspaper executive -- not Frederick W. Smith, the founder of FedEx.

As big banks face the fallout from a global investigation into interest rate manipulation, American and British lawmakers are scrutinizing regulators who failed to take action that might have prevented years of illegal activity. Politicians in both London and Washington are questioning whether regulators allowed banks to report false rates in the run-up to the 2008 financial crisis and afterward. On Monday, Congress stepped into the fray, requesting information about the role of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, according to people close to the matter.

That would not have been enough to serve the 800 or so people who attended a memorial on Monday for the writer and filmmaker Nora Ephron, who made hits like ''Sleepless in Seattle'' and ''When Harry Met Sally.''

Odysseus got homesick. In the first book of ''The Odyssey,'' Homer's epic poem, the Greek hero is said to be ''straining for no more than a glimpse of hearth-smoke drifting up from his own land.'' Thousands of years later, during the Civil War, homesickness (or ''nostalgia'') was viewed as an affliction that could kill soldiers.

NEWTON, Mass. -- Senator John Kerry and Gov. Deval L. Patrick left early. But Representative Nancy Pelosi stayed late - and swayed on the dance floor to ''It's Raining Men.'' Elizabeth Kucinich snapped photographs, as her husband, Dennis, chatted up Representative Steny H. Hoyer by the hors d'oeuvres. And Terrence McNally, the playwright, joined in the hora and a group singalong of ''Low Rider'' by War, with President Obama-themed lyrics written for the occasion.

An obituary last Tuesday about the former NBC president Julian Goodman referred imprecisely to the Fairness Doctrine, which he and executives of other networks pushed to end. While the doctrine, an F.C.C. policy that was eliminated in 1987, did require networks to present contrasting points of view on controversial issues, it did not require that opposing opinions be given ''equal time.'' (The Fairness Doctrine is different from the equal time rule, part of the federal Communications Act, which mandates equal airtime for opposing political candidates.)

Methadone accounted for almost a third of the deaths caused by opioid pain relievers in 2009, even though it was prescribed far less often than other such drugs, government researchers have found. Researchers writing in last week's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report crunched data from the National Vital Statistics System and the Drug Enforcement Administration. The rate of overdose deaths involving methadone in 2009 was more than five times the rate in 1999, they found. The drug accounted for 1.7 percent of the 257 million prescriptions written in 2009 for opioid pain relievers, but it was involved in 31.4 percent of overdose deaths and more than 40 percent of the deaths attributable to use of a single drug.

For New Yorkers who gripe about their cramped living quarters, and there are many, the real estate news announced by the city on Monday should be worthy of note. Confronted with what the city has in mind, such malcontents may feel thankful for what they have.
Seattle's Felix Hernandez threw 114 pitches on Sunday, yet under a new rule, he remains eligible to pitch on Tuesday. ''I'll be ready, because that's my bullpen day,'' Hernandez said.
MORRISON--Theodore P. Born March 8, 1970, died July 9, 2012. He is mourned by his family. There will be no official service. He will be memorialized at a future date by family and friends.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about the recent pilgrimage to the Japanese internment camp Tule Lake in California misspelled the surname of a visitor. She is Mayuko Yamamoto, not Yammato.

The rate of infection with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA, is decreasing nationwide, a study published last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association suggests. In recent years, the drug-resistant bacteria have become a danger in hospitals, schools, gyms and other places. ''Staph is the leading cause of infections in the community, and these can be hard to handle,'' said the report's senior author, Dr. Clinton K. Murray, an infectious disease specialist at the San Antonio Military Medical Center.

A UNIT of a giant agency holding group that usually produces campaigns for clients is undertaking a campaign with itself as the subject. The campaign, which began last month, is on behalf of the Diversified Agency Services division of the Omnicom Group, the world's No. 2 agency holding group behind WPP.

Seventy students were involved in a pattern of smartphone-enabled cheating last month at Stuyvesant High School, New York City officials said Monday, describing an episode that has blemished one of the country's most prestigious public schools. The cheating involved several state exams and was uncovered after a cellphone was confiscated from a 16-year-old junior during a citywide language exam on June 18, according to a city Department of Education investigation.

ROSLEY--Walter D.,passed away on July 7, 2012. He was born on January 29, 1928 in Frankfurt, Germany to George and Martha Rosenberg. He is survived by his brother Alexander Rosenberg and his wife Alice; his children Joan Griffin, Ruth Libin and her husband Jeff, Richard Rosley and his wife Lorena; five grandchildren, one great-grandson, and his long-time companion Adrienne White. A memorial service will be held at noon on July 13, 2012 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY www.riversidememorial mountvernon.com

Mothers face a significantly increased risk of death in the years following the death of a child, a new analysis has found. Using federal Census Bureau data, researchers tracked information on 69,224 mothers ages 20 to 50 over nine years. Mortality for the entire group was low, about 1.2 percent.

The author Douglas Brinkley and the actor Johnny Depp are teaming up to edit ''House of Earth,'' a previously unpublished novel by the folk singer Woody Guthrie that will be released next spring. Mr. Brinkley said in a telephone interview that the book would appear from ''a major New York publisher,'' but declined to specify which one before the deal was completed. The manuscript, which Guthrie finished in 1947, follows a West Texas couple who, in their effort to build adobe homes as protection against treacherous weather, fight against banks and lumber companies.
BENIZEAU--Ernestine. The Bronx County Family Court Bar Association records with sorrow the death of its beloved member.

8 P.M. (IFC) THE PRESTIGE (2006) Rival magicians (Hugh Jackman and Christian Bale) in 19th-century London compete not only to see who is the greater trickster but also who can win the affection of their beautiful assistant (Scarlett Johansson, above with Mr. Jackman). Directed by Christopher Nolan and based on the novel by Christopher Priest, the movie also manages to weave a bit of reality into the mysticism with the inclusion of the inventor Nikola Tesla (David Bowie, in an inspired supporting turn). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film ''a triumph of gimmickry, a movie generous enough with its showmanship and sleight of hand to quiet the temptation to grumble about its lack of substance.'' He added: ''Maybe, in the end, it all makes sense. Or maybe convincing you that it does is just the last and cleverest of this movie's many sleights of hand.'' 6 P.M. (Showtime) THE SCHOOL OF ROCK (2003) Jack Black, below, stars as Dewey Finn, a broke musician who impersonates his friend to land a substitute teaching gig, in this comedy directed by Richard Linklater. When he discovers that his students possess some raw musical talent, he jumps at the chance to instill in them some good old-fashioned rock 'n' roll skill. Joan Cusack plays the well-intentioned yet tightly wound principal. Writing in The Times, Stephen Holden compared Mr. Black to other kings of comedy: ''Not since Jim Carrey twitched, mugged and leered his way to the head of the class has a comic actor stirred up such a gleeful furor on the screen. And not since John Belushi has one used the anarchic roar of rock as a conceptual platform.''

A coalition of about a dozen environmental groups is preparing to file a lawsuit as early as Tuesday seeking greater protections as Shell prepares to begin drilling exploratory wells off the North Slope of Alaska this summer, spokesmen for the groups said. The groups - including Earthjustice, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Sierra Club, Oceana and the National Audubon Society - will challenge the Interior Department's approval of Shell's plans for responding to a potential spill.

Reggie Jackson, who threw out the first pitch before the Home Run Derby on Monday, emphasized that his absence from the Yankees last weekend in Boston was not punitive. ''There is no ban, no suspension,'' Jackson said.

9:43 a.m. | Updated Gabriel García Márquez, the Colombian novelist and Nobel laureate, has dementia and is no longer writing, his younger brother, Jaime, has said. The Telegraph of London reported that in a lecture to students in Cartagena, Jaime García Márquez told the audience that Gabriel, who is 85, ''is doing well physically, but he has been suffering from dementia for a long time.'' The author often calls him to ask basic questions, Jaime García Márquez said, adding: ''He has problems with his memory. Sometimes I cry because I feel like I'm losing him.''

As Rick Santorum embarks Tuesday on his first tour of Iowa since his painstaking, 99-county campaign for the state's Republican presidential caucuses, an interview offered hints at what will not be, what might have been and what could be in the future. What will not be: Evidently, Mr. Santorum is not on the list of Mitt Romney's potential running mates - or even one of his key surrogates.

The All-Star Game break, though not at the exact midpoint of the season, has traditionally been the dividing line at which players and teams size up how the season is going. It is a time for projection as well. Reggie Jackson's 37 home runs in 1969 had people dreaming of 70 (he finished with 47), and Juan Gonzalez's 101 runs batted in in 1998 had the name Hack Wilson on the tip of everyone's tongue. (Gonzalez ended with 157, short of Wilson's 191 in 1930.)

4:19 p.m. | Updated WellPoint agreed on Monday to buy Amerigroup in a deal valued at $4.9 billion in cash, as one of the country's biggest health insurers seeks to take advantage of an expansion of health care coverage instituted by the Obama administration.

CAMPBELL PURCHASE The Campbell Soup Company said on Monday that it will buy the food company Bolthouse Farms from the private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners for $1.55 billion in cash. It is the largest deal in Campbell Soup's history and will bolster the company's healthy offerings as sales of soup slow. Bolthouse's products include fresh carrots and premium beverages, as well as refrigerated salad dressing. It also packages carrots for various private label brands.

ASPEN, Colo. -- Last week, physicists around the world were glued to computers at very odd hours (I was at a 1 a.m. physics ''party'' here with a large projection screen and dozens of colleagues) to watch live as scientists at the Large Hadron Collider, outside Geneva, announced that they had apparently found one of the most important missing pieces of the jigsaw puzzle that is nature. The ''Higgs particle,'' proposed almost 50 years ago to allow for consistency between theoretical predictions and experimental observations in elementary particle physics, appears to have been discovered -- even as the detailed nature of the discovery allows room for even more exotic revelations that may be just around the corner.

RUBINSTEIN--Selma, age 90, passed away on July 8, 2012 in Columbus, OH, where she has lived since leaving her longtime home in Queens, NY. She is survived by her husband Bernard; children, Jessica Rubinstein (Michael Mercier), Henry Rubinstein and Shira Rubinstein (Eric Schechtman); grandsons, Andrew Hollweck (Bomi Kim) and Aaron Mercier, and two granddaughters, Min and Bea Hollweck. Donations to the Alzheimer's Foundation and Hadassah.
BORGNINE--Ernest. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Ernest Borgnine. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

Tom Dettweiler makes his living miles down. He helped find the Titanic. After that, his teams located a lost submarine heavy with gold. In all, he has cast light on dozens of vanished ships. Mr. Dettweiler has now turned from recovering lost treasures to prospecting for natural ones that litter the seabed: craggy deposits rich in gold and silver, copper and cobalt, lead and zinc. A new understanding of marine geology has led to the discovery of hundreds of these unexpected ore bodies, known as massive sulfides because of their sulfurous nature.

GOODMAN--Ethel B. The Independent Family Aid Association mourns the loss of its esteemed member and financial secretary, Ethel Goodman. She was a gracious and selfless woman who will be missed by all. Services Wednesday, July 11th, 11:30am at Sinai Chapels. Mitchel Freedman President, IFAA

An article on Sunday about Las Vegas's new Smith Center for the Performing Arts, which will bring more upscale entertainment to the city, misidentified the building that most influenced the planners of the Smith Center. It is the Nancy Lee and Perry R. Bass Performance Hall in Fort Worth -- not the Nancy Lee and Perry R. Bass Concert Hall at the University of Texas at Austin.

JOFFE--Julie Schuelke, (86), of White Plains passed peacefully at home on July 6, 2012 from pulmonary fibrosis. Raised in Ohio and Austin, Texas, she earned her MSW at Columbia University. Through her professional, volunteer, and philanthropic efforts, Julie dedicated her life to the social welfare of others. Administrator and therapist at White Plains Hospital Department of Psychiatry from 1966 until her retirement in 1992, she continued in private practice specializing in psychoanalysis and psychotherapy. A long-time resident of Irvington and White Plains, Julie is predeceased by her husband Lester L. Joffe. She is survived by her children Barbara, Lee, Paul, and Elyzabeth Smiles and six grandchildren, all of whom will miss her grace, elegance, and sense of fun.

YOGURT on the run usually means a frosty swirl in a cone or a cup. But a couple of new places are challenging that approach. Two companies are opening storefronts featuring fresh, not frozen, yogurt. The first one, the Yogurt Culture Company, opened Monday at 125 Park Avenue (41st Street). It's a new subsidiary of Dannon, long one of the top yogurt companies in the United States.

The video is called ''Seven Minutes of Terror,'' and describes, with the suspense and cinematography of a movie preview, what will happen next month when a one-ton spacecraft launched in November smacks into Mars. ''We've got literally seven minutes to get from the top of the atmosphere to the surface of Mars, going from 13,000 miles an hour to zero,'' Tom Rivellini, a NASA engineer, tells the camera with a grim face and deadpan delivery. ''If any one thing doesn't work just right, it's game over.''

As they often do, Andrew Rausa and a few friends spent the evening of July 4 lounging barefoot on the front stoop of a friend's brownstone home in Brooklyn and enjoying a few beers. Escaping the indoor heat, Mr. Rausa and two friends sipped cans of Brooklyn Summer Ale; his girlfriend held an unopened bottle of a blueberry ale. When an unmarked police car pulled up and two officers got out, Mr. Rausa and his friends worried that the charcoal grill that was set up nearby had gotten them in trouble.

GLEASON--Genevieve, 96, of Manhattan, New York, passed away peacefully at Mary Manning Walsh Home on Monday, July 9, 2012. Wife of actor, Jackie Gleason, Genevieve was a devoted mother and grandmother, a devout Catholic, and a generous advocate of personal charity. Dedicated to programs of the aged and infirmed, she was a daily communicant and longtime volunteer at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Midtown Manhattan. Genevieve was a contributor and founding member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, a supporter of the American Red Cross, a member of the Association of Ladies of Charity, a generous devotee of Marymount School of New York, from which both her daughters graduated, and a supporter of the Redemptorist Brothers and Fathers in their world wide mission work. She was a founding member of the National Law Enforcement Officers Memorial Fund and Museum inspired by the events of September 11, 2001. Genevieve was received into the Franciscan order of Lay Province of St. Mary in 1982 and was granted the rank of Lady in the Knightly Order of the Holy Sepulcher of Jerusalem in 1991 by the authority of the Holy Father, Pope John Paul II. She is survived by her two daughters, Geraldine Chutuk and Linda King; son-in-law, Robert King; grandchildren, Jennifer Miller, Jason Patric, Jordan Miller and Mark Chutuk; and great-grandchildren Caitlin Chutuk, Alison Chutuk and Jack Brodie Miller. Family to receive friends at Frank E. Campbell - The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st), Thursday 6-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Patrick's Cathedral - Lady Chapel, Friday 10am. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

Perhaps the most surprising aspect of the Libor scandal is how familiar it seems. Sure, for some of the world's leading banks to try to manipulate one of the most important interest rates in contemporary finance is clearly egregious. But is that worse than packaging billions of dollars worth of dubious mortgages into a bond and having it stamped with a Triple-A rating to sell to some dupe down the road while betting against it? Or how about forging documents on an industrial scale to foreclose fraudulently on countless homeowners? The misconduct of the financial industry no longer surprises most Americans. Only about one in five has much trust in banks, according to Gallup polls, about half the level in 2007. And it's not just banks that are frowned upon. Trust in big business overall is declining. Sixty-two percent of Americans believe corruption is widespread across corporate America. According to Transparency International, an anticorruption watchdog, nearly three in four Americans believe that corruption has increased over the last three years.

Since it opened in 2003, the Bedford Cheese Shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has evolved from a stand in a funky mini-mall to a well-stocked store. Now it has added an even bigger store, near Union Square in Manhattan. A classroom within the shop is called the Homestead because, as Charlotte Kamin, an owner, said, ''we wanted to convey the homeyness of what we do.'' But make no mistake. Despite the brown paper labels on some of the artisanal local goods they sell (in addition to about 300 cheeses and fine domestic cured meats, and a sandwich of the day), this is a classy, sophisticated operation, more sleek than rustic, with 10 more feet of cheese and meat displays than in Brooklyn, and four additional feet for olives and pickles. There are also three cold rooms, with varying temperatures and humidity, for affinage.

Willie Nelson, Neil Young, John Mellencamp and Dave Matthews will be among the performers this year at the annual Farm Aid benefit concert, which will be held in Hersheypark Stadium in Hershey, Pa., on Sept. 22. Farm Aid has been held nearly every year since 1985 and has raised more than $40 million to help family farmers remain on their land. The event drew about 16,000 people last year in Kansas City, Kan. Its Farmer Resource Hotline network is now online and helps farmers find alternate sources of credit or specialized training.

As the article correctly noted, Detroit won with a game-ending single, not with a home run.

(Travel) ADAM RICHMAN'S BEST SANDWICH IN AMERICA The search for the greatest sandwich ever made continues in Seattle, where Mr. Richman, above, uses his own BITE scale (B=Bread, I=Interior, T=Taste, E=Eating Experience) on the oxtail sandwich from the Italian charcuterie Salumi. He then goes on a hoagie hunt in Portland, Ore., that includes Bunk Sandwiches' pork belly Cubano. (IFC) CHE (2008) Benicio Del Toro plays Che Guevara, the Argentine doctor turned revolutionary, in this biopic from Steven Soderbergh, which clocks in at four and a half hours. Part 1, ''The Argentine,'' follows Guevara from 1956 to '58, when he met the Cuban exile Fidel Castro (Demián Bichir) and waged a guerrilla campaign against the government of Fulgencio Batista. At 11:30 a.m., Part 2, the more sobering ''Guerrilla,'' follows Guevara's star-crossed attempt to ignite a popular uprising in Bolivia. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called Mr. Del Toro's performance ''technically flawless'' and infused with ''the full and considerable measure of his own charisma.'' He added: ''As history, though, 'Che' is finally not epic but romance. It takes great care to be true to the factual record, but it is, nonetheless, a fairy tale.''

A&E STAKE BUYBACK Comcast said on Tuesday that its NBC Universal subsidiary had agreed to sell its 15.8 percent stake in A&E Television Networks for $3 billion. A&E will most likely buy back the stake with a cash payment, although it may also opt to pay with cash and a note. The money for the transaction will be provided by its remaining owners, the Walt Disney Company and the Hearst Corporation. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

RALEIGH, N.C. - An accumulation of concerns caused Duke Energy's board to lose confidence in its chief executive, leading to his ouster just hours after completing a $32 billion merger with Progress Energy, according to testimony Tuesday by the man who replaced him. Johnson, the Progress chief, who was to run the company.

As unemployment climbed and tax revenue fell, the city of Baltimore laid off employees and cut services in the midst of the financial crisis. Its leaders now say the city's troubles were aggravated by bankers' manipulation of a key interest rate linked to hundreds of millions of dollars the city had borrowed. Baltimore has been leading a battle in Manhattan federal court against the banks that determine the interest rate, the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, which serves as a benchmark for global borrowing and stands at the center of the latest banking scandal. Now cities, states and municipal agencies nationwide, including Massachusetts, Nassau County on Long Island, and California's public pension system, are looking at whether they suffered similar losses and are weighing legal action.

7:17 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO - Google and the Federal Trade Commission are near a $22.5 million settlement agreement related to charges that Google bypassed privacy settings in Apple's Safari browser to show advertisements, according to a person briefed on the proposed settlement. The $22.5 million fine would be the largest privacy-related settlement in F.T.C. history. It comes as the commission investigates Google for antitrust violations and cracks down on privacy missteps by tech companies, including Google, which last year agreed to pay for any future privacy blunders as part of a separate F.T.C. settlement.

Robert de La Rochefoucauld belonged to one of the oldest families of the French nobility, whose members included François de La Rochefoucauld, the author of a classic 17th-century book of maxims. For 30 years he was the mayor of Ouzouer-sur-Trézée, an idyllic canal town in the Loire Valley, and he used the aristocratic title of count. But he is best remembered as a courageous and celebrated saboteur who fought for the honor of France in World War II as a secret agent with the British.

BAILEY--Robert. How can our world continue without this unique friend, who charmed us and instructed us in every aspect of life and art? His joie de vivre and grace were always an inspiration. He combined a love of the most serious aspects of Western civilization with a delight in the silly and the absurd. Robert was not only an unparalleled scholar and musician, but also an art collector of rare discrimination. He taught us to cherish the richness and beauty of things, whether musical sounds, the grain of language, or the shades and composition of a painting; and he taught us to savor life. As a teacher and mentor he changed all our lives, and we shall never forget the generosity of his spirit. Carolyn Abbate Joseph Clark Marcia Lazer Bruce and Angelika Livie

Bush said on Tuesday that ''it's never too late'' for Mitt Romney to take a leadership role in the immigration debate, but he acknowledged Republicans were outflanked by President Obama's election-year decision to allow hundreds of illegal immigrants to remain in the country without fear of deportation. USA Today has turned to the digital world for its new editor in chief. The paper announced Tuesday that David Callaway, the editor of the financial news Web site MarketWatch, would take over the paper later this month. Mr. Callaway, who graduated from Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism, has worked at MarketWatch for more than a decade. He has also been a financial columnist for The Boston Herald and a securities reporter at Bloomberg.

Guy Vaknin started making vegetarian sushi two years ago, when he was working for Esprit Events, his family's kosher catering company. But he thought his colorful creations might appeal to a broader audience, so he has opened a simple storefront, where the sushi is made to order in rolls, individual pieces, rice paper wraps and salads. Except for the occasional egg, most of his bright, well-seasoned sushi is vegan. He uses a six-grain mixture or black rice as the base and fills the rolls with vegetables, fruits, herbs, spices and tofu. Various sauces, like white miso and chile mango, come alongside.

Symphony Space has announced that its next season of events, which begins on Sept. 24, will includes a new series, John Cage's ''How to Get Started.'' The three events, which each pair a musician with an author, are based on a 1989 performance in which Mr. Cage spoke extemporaneously on 10 topics. Each of his short speeches was looped back by sound engineers, creating, according to the Symphony Space Web site, a ''multilayered 'thought performance.' '' The pairings in the new series are Oscar Hijuelos and Arturo O'Farrill on Nov. 1; the brothers Wallace and Allen Shawn on Nov. 15; and Robert Pinsky and John Wesley Harding on Dec. 13.

ROSLEY--Walter D.,passed away on July 7, 2012. He was born on January 29, 1928 in Frankfurt, Germany to George and Martha Rosenberg. He is survived by his brother Alexander Rosenberg and his wife Alice; his children Joan Griffin, Ruth Libin and her husband Jeff, Richard Rosley and his wife Lorena; five grandchildren, one great-grandson, and his long-time companion Adrienne White. A memorial service will be held at noon on July 13, 2012 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY www.riversidememorial mountvernon.com

REITMAN--Alan. The American Civil Liberties Union mourns the passing of one of our great champions. Starting in 1949, Alan served the organization for 40 years with the highest distinction, rising to become associate executive director. Alan was at the forefront in the ACLU's battles against McCarthyism, segregation and ensuring free speech in times of war. We continued to benefit from his wisdom after retirement, when he served as a consultant for many years. Alan Reitman will be sorely missed by all who value a true guardian of our liberties.

LONDON - During his tenure as Barclays chief executive, Robert E. Diamond Jr. spoke passionately about creating a strong culture of integrity and trust, a common philosophy that would breed success at the big British Bank. In a speech last year, he emphasized that the ''evidence of culture is how people behave when no one is watching.'' But now Mr. Diamond, who stepped down last week, faces criticism about his leadership as Barclays deals with fallout from a scandal involving interest rate manipulation.

An article on Monday about Valiant Entertainment, a comic book publisher with movie aspirations, using information from the company, erroneously included two prominent Hollywood business figures among the members of Valiant's board. Tom Sherak, the departing president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, and Sidney Ganis, a past academy president and Columbia Pictures executive, have only given Valiant informal advice on occasion.

How important is the singer Ricky Martin to the box-office success of the Broadway revival of ''Evita,'' in which he stars as the musical's narrator, Che? And how much pressure is on the show's producers to find a major star to replace Mr. Martin when his contract ends in early January? Just look at last week's ticket sales for ''Evita'' without Mr. Martin, who was on vacation: The show grossed $643,663, a little more than half as much as the previous week's gross of $1,191,200. It was the first week that ''Evita'' had grossed less than $1 million since performances began in March. (The production's other stars, Elena Roger as Eva and Michael Cerveris as Perón, were in the show last week.) By comparison, the overall gross for Broadway shows last week was down about 6 percent from the week before; musicals and plays took in a total of $22.4 million.

A report in the ArtsBeat column on Thursday about France's celebration of the 300th anniversary of the birth of Jean-Jacques Rousseau omitted the word ''Modern'' from the title of a book by Elisabeth Badinter, who in an essay commented on Rousseau's view of women. James H. Lee enlisted in the new 43rd Alabama Infantry in the spring of 1862. A man either poor enough or transient enough to have eluded the census taker two years earlier, Lee openly admitted that it was money, in the form of regular pay and a $50 bounty (akin to a signing bonus), that finally convinced him to rally to the colors. Writing from camp near Mobile, Ala., a few weeks later, he already regretted his decision. “We have not drawed one red cent,” he wrote his wife, “and from what I hear among the boys they havent more than one third of them ever drawed half of there bounty yet.”

A new color made an emphatic appearance on the runways for fall: oxblood. A deep red with hints of brown -- not quite burgundy, not quite scarlet -- it's darkly moody and flattering to almost anyone. There were oxblood leather coats and skirts at Alexander Wang; dresses and jackets and pants at Jason Wu, Peter Som, Yigal Azrouël; boots at Rag & Bone. And as a trend, the color has acquired a real-life jump-start on the red carpet: Elizabeth Banks (near left) chose an embroidered dress from the Alexander McQueen prefall collection for a premiere; Chloë Grace Moretz (far left) wore a McQ dress from the fall runway at another; and Emma Stone (center) chose a regal Rochas for her ''Spider-Man'' tour. As the fall collections roll into stores, think about investing in an oxblood leather skirt (from Miu Miu, say, or 10 Crosby). For accessories, any Céline obsessive already has her eyes peeled for an envelope-shape shoulder-strap bag in the must-have color.

KRIEGEL--I. Stanley, beloved 101 year-old Patriarch and Brooklyn Booster. For 72 years, the devoted husband of his beautiful Charlotte, who predeceased him by four years, and with whom he fully shared all of life's joys and struggles. Inseparable, they filled all their days together with an abundance of love and generosity, family and faith, culture and service. They married at Temple Beth Elohim where Stanley served as President and a trustee for 77 years. They savored every offering of the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM) where he was Senior Trustee after 44 years. He was a Founding Trustee of the Brooklyn Philharmonic and Kingsbay YMHA, also it's President. For his manifold communal services, from selling bonds during WW II to the Brooklyn Public Library Board, they often called him "Mr. Brooklyn." A proud graduate of NYU School of Commerce in the auspicious class of '29, and President of the NYU Club. Expert business advisor and CPA, he became the region's leader in the automotive industry. Charlotte and Stanley feasted on opera, theater and music, food and travel. They are survived by their children Myra and her husband Matthew Zuckerbraun and Jay and his wife Kathryn McAuliffe, five grandchildren, Hope, Stuart, Abby, Isabel and Connor, and spouses Bill, Sharon, Ken and Trevor, three step-grandchildren, Jevon, Caitlin and Tessa, and 10 great-grandchildren (one en route). Funeral will be Friday July 13 at 9:30 at Temple Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place (Eighth Avenue), Brooklyn. Contributions welcome to Development Dept, BAM, 30 Lafayette Street, Brooklyn, NY 11217, or Temple Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, NY 11215. Shiva on Friday July 13 from 2-5pm at Jay and Kathryn's at 139 Spring Street, NY (at Wooster St); and Sunday July 15 from 4-8pm at Myra and Matthew's at 190 Argyle Road (Albermarle and Beverly), Brooklyn.

TRAUB--Marvin. We are deeply saddened by the death of our former CEO and great friend Marvin Traub. The part of his legacy we will treasure the most will be the lives he touched at Bloomingdale's. Marvin took great pride in all of those that he mentored. Blessed with enormous energy, he will always be remembered for his passion and devotion to the store for the last 62 years. We will miss him and what he gave and continued to give us until his final days. We express our sincere sympathy to his beloved wife Lee and the entire Traub family. Michael Gould, Chairman & CEO Tony Spring, President & COO The Bloomingdale's Family

This week on the pop charts Chris Brown scored his second No. 1 album, an Amazon promotion spurred a wave of older releases back to the Top 10 and Carly Rae Jepsen's ubiquitous ''Call Me Maybe'' remains the top song. Mr. Brown's latest, ''Fortune'' (RCA), opened at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, with 135,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It is his second No. 1, although this album's first-week sales were significantly lower than those of his last chart-topper, ''F.A.M.E.,'' which opened at No. 1 last year with 270,000 sales.

WASHINGTON -- With the economy having slowed in recent weeks, business leaders and policy makers are growing concerned that the tax increases and government spending cuts set to take effect at year's end have already begun to cause companies to hold back on hiring and investments. Economists say the magnitude of the effect remains unclear and the fiscal uncertainty is probably not the economy's main problem, but is instead one of several factors -- along with Europe's troubles, the spike in oil prices this spring and a continuing hangover from the housing bubble -- restraining growth.

Brace yourself for a polka-dot explosion. Yayoi Kusama, the Japanese artist who was a central figure in the New York avantgarde scene in the 1960s, when she staged Body Festivals around the city in which she painted naked participants with polka dots, is celebrating the arrival of a career retrospective at the Whitney on Thursday and a collaboration with Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton. As with its artist collaborations with Takashi Murakami and Richard Prince, Vuitton does not do things halfway. On Tuesday, a pop-up opens at its SoHo store (six others will roll out globally), exuberantly done up in (what else?) dots and Ms. Kusama's tentaclelike ''nerves'' motif. Seeking to be a larger presence in the living rooms of media-consuming Americans, Western Digital recently expanded its product line, which had consisted primarily of storage drives, to offer routers. The routers are intended not only to connect devices throughout the home to the Internet, but also to create a wireless home network for the high-speed delivery of content.

After the financial crisis, regulators vowed to overhaul supervision of the nation's largest banks. As part of that effort, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in mid-2011 replaced virtually all of its roughly 40 examiners at JPMorgan Chase to bolster the team's expertise and prevent regulators from forming cozy ties with executives, according to several current and former government officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

An article on Wednesday about an immigration initiative by Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago that challenges Obama administration enforcement policies referred incorrectly to the status of a federal fingerprinting program, known as Secure Communities, in Illinois and Alabama. Those are the only two states where the program has been implemented in some jurisdictions but not statewide; it is not the case that those are the only two states where the program has not been put into effect at all.

STURIM--Allan, on July 11, 2012. Loving husband and father, proud grandfather. Skilled lawyer, avid golfer. Never passed a divot without replacing it. Services Thursday, 10am at Riverside Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

LANE--Mary Elizabeth "Susie" (Suehs), wife of the late Peter A. Lane, Sr., died Tuesday, July 10, 2012. Born on August 10, 1926 in Yonkers, she was the only child of Erwin Alfred and Mary Elizabeth (Rice) Suehs. Mary grew up in Great Neck and Elmira. She graduated from Great Neck High School in 1943. She received her BS/RN from Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in 1948. Mary did graduate work in public health at Columbia University and worked for many years as a public health nurse in Simsbury. She was predeceased by her daughter Christine. She is survived by her daughter, Barbara, two sons, Peter (Barbara Bornemeier) and Michael, two grandchildren, Jack and Elizabeth, and her "nearest and dearest" cousins, Joseph and Mary Elizabeth (Gaiser) Belloma and family. Funeral mass on Friday at St Mary's Church, Simsbury. Donations to The McLean Foundation, 75 Great Pond Road Simsbury, CT. Vincent Funeral Home, Simsbury CT in charge of the services.
Unidentified gunmen stormed a compound in the eastern city of Lahore in an attack that revived concerns about a fresh wave of terrorist strikes, officials said.

Because of an editing error, a report on the Currents page last Thursday about a furniture sale through July 31 at Kartell, a Manhattan store, miscalculated the discounted price of the Masters chair by Philippe Starck. It is $215, not $206.

Regulators are examining JPMorgan Chase's sales tactics, after claims that the nation's largest bank pushed its own mutual funds over competitors' investments. Authorities are responding to current and former JPMorgan financial advisers who said they had felt pressure to sell the bank's products even when cheaper or better performing options were available.

The Deal Professor column on Wednesday, about the soccer team Manchester United's public offering in the United States, misstated the year that the Sarbanes-Oxley Act was enacted. It was 2002, not 2001.

This year marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Gordon Parks, the renowned photographer, writer and filmmaker. Beginning Thursday, the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in New York is commemorating the centennial with an exhibition of 100 of his images from six decades, several on public display for the first time. The exhibition, called ''Gordon Parks: 100 Moments,'' includes some of Mr. Parks's more famous work, including ''American Gothic, Washington, D.C.,'' which depicts a black cleaning woman standing in front of an American flag, a broom in one hand and a mop in the background. The photographs getting a new airing are of children in Harlem in the 1940s, before Mr. Parks, who was born on Nov. 30, 1912, became famous. He died in 2006 at 93 and lived in New York for many years. The free exhibition, at 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, in Harlem, continues through Dec. 1. The International Center of Photography in Manhattan is also offering an exhibition of Mr. Parks's work.

Aereo, the service backed by Barry Diller, can keep streaming for now. A federal judge on Wednesday denied a temporary injunction sought by television broadcasters that would have shut down Aereo, a start-up that streams local TV stations' signals to customers over the Internet without the explicit permission of the stations.

An article on Wednesday about a dramatic NASA video that is drawing attention to the expected landing of the Curiosity rover on Mars next month misstated the time the capsule carrying the rover is predicted to enter the Martian atmosphere. It is 1:11 a.m. Eastern time on Aug. 6 -- not 12:11 a.m.

It started with a single jingle, imploring New Yorkers to call Carmel Car and Limousine Service at ''six, six, six/six, six, sixty-six.'' That was never going to sit well with a company called Dial 7.

The country music star Luke Bryan is not as country strong as some fans may have hoped. Mr. Bryan sang the national anthem before Major League Baseball's All-Star Game in Kansas City, Mo., on Tuesday night, and could be seen glancing down at his hand during the performance. Turns out he was borrowing a cheat sheet method long favored by middle-schoolers everywhere: he had some of the lyrics written on his palm. ''I had a few keys words written down to insure myself that I wouldn't mess up,'' he posted on Twitter on Wednesday, saying he wanted to explain his performance. ''I just wanted to do my best. I promise it was from the heart.''
The Boîte column last Thursday, about the club Bantam, misidentified a promoter there. She is Nicollette Santos, not Nicolette Sheridan.

Much has been said of John McEnroe's skills as a tennis analyst during the two weeks of Wimbledon, and little of it is hyperbole. He's arguably the best analyst in any sport. Meanwhile, Jimmy Connors, McEnroe's former playing rival and his partner and foil in the BBC's acrimonious Wimbledon booth for three years, took to social media to share his analysis of the tournament. The ironyshould not be lost on anyone. For if Jimmy Connors is known for something (besides, perhaps, the best return of serve in tennis history), it is that he has never been the most sociable guy in the room. And that may be an understatement.

IS ''The Big Bang Theory'' more risqué than ''Three's Company'' was? Can we equate the machinations of ''Game of Thrones'' with those of ''Dallas''? I have happy memories of watching television with my parents, and I have realized that unless I'm in the kitchen laughing while my family watches ''Phineas and Ferb,'' television is not something we share. Which matters very little, unless you feel you're missing something, like I do. Of course, the way we watch television has changed dramatically. If we think ''The Big Bang Theory'' is inappropriate, we can hook younger viewers up to their own dose of Disney without leaving the sofa.

There are a fair number of clever straps available for your digital S.L.R. camera, but sometimes the last thing you want to be carrying is yet another strap. The $80 Peak Design Capture is a quick-release camera mount that can be attached to a belt or any strap - like the one on your backpack or handbag - so your camera is always accessible, not swaying and not getting tangled.

An article last Thursday about pairs of siblings who are succeeding in New York misidentified the instrument played by Jack Antonoff, one of the siblings, in the band Fun. It is the guitar, not the bass. The article also misstated the title formerly held by Sylvana Ward Durrett, another of the siblings, at Vogue. She was the accessories editor, not the beauty editor. And the article misspelled, at one point, the name of a restaurant opened by Chris and Heather Tierney, another pair of siblings. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, it is Pulqueria, not Pulquera.

He will be remembered as an inspired costume designer and for the five magnificent productions he gave us. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and friends.
