As moguls descended on Sun Valley on Tuesday for Allen & Company's annual gathering, they were greeted by a giant plume of smoke. Fanned by wind, wildfires in southern Idaho had spawned a huge cloud, obscuring the area's verdant hills and creating a mess on the runways. Commercial and private jets were delayed. Many circled Friedman Memorial Airport, waiting for their turn to land. And about a dozen private jets were diverted to the airport in Twin Falls -- an hour and a half drive from the resort.

O'BRIEN--Florence (Sos). We at Congregation B'nai Yisrael mourn the loss of Florence Sos O'Brien. We shall miss her warm friendship. Lawrence C. Fox, President, Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz, Rabbi Seth M. Limmer, Cantor Hayley Kobilinsky

The Paul Taylor Dance Company will return to Lincoln Center for a second season next year, its executive director said on Monday. The company will perform at the David H. Koch Theater from March 5 to 24, said the official, John Tomlinson. With money scarce, it still plans to perform to recorded scores instead of live music, he said. ''We are struggling with the live music issue,'' he said. ''We have not given up on it, but it is a cash issue. We have yet to find the numbers to make that happen.'' Last season's performances without live music drew objections from the musicians' union. Mr. Tomlinson said the run would include new works; Mr. Taylor's ''Sacre du Printemps (The Rehearsal),'' based on the Stravinsky composition that is marking the 100th year since its premiere; and a discounted ticket evening of two 25-year-old Taylor pieces, ''Speaking in Tongues'' and ''Brandenburgs.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Adidas shell toes are getting another outing, another chance to ''Walk This Way'': the surviving members of Run-DMC, the pioneering hip-hop group, will reunite to perform at the Fun Fun Fun Fest in Austin, Tex., this fall, organizers announced. The group went into retirement after the death of its D.J., Jam Master Jay, who was murdered in 2002. (The case was never solved.) In the decade since they last performed together, one member, Rev Run - born Joseph Simmons - has been a best-selling author, with ''Take Back Your Family: A Challenge to America's Parents,'' and the star of an MTV reality show, ''Run's House.''

Windows 7 includes a panel of the most-used settings for running a presentation or demonstration from a laptop. The Windows Mobility Center screen includes controls for the computer's audio volume, screen brightness, battery status, wireless antenna, external display and other settings adjusted frequently on traveling laptops. (Some versions of Windows 7 have fewer settings available.) To open the Windows Mobility Center with a keyboard shortcut, just press the Windows logo key and the X key. You can also go to the Start menu, open Control Panel, select Mobile PC (or Hardware and Sound) and then click on Windows Mobility Center. Microsoft has more information on using the controls at bit.ly/QXAGVL. A version of Windows Mobility Center is also available in Windows Vista.

FREEMAN--Vera, 88, passed away peacefully at home on July 10th. A loving wife to the late Andrew, wonderful mother of George and grandmother of Jennifer and Griffith, she was born in Budapest, survived the War, and then began a new life in New York City. She started working almost immediately, becoming an import manager of fine papers for Andrews/Nelson/Whitehead and later Boise Cascade, and was recognized as an expert in handmade fine arts papers. She had a powerful intellect, a huge curiosity of the world around her, was an avid reader, lover of classical music and enthusiastic traveler, and was a strong source of support and strength to friends and family. Memorial service at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, Madison and 81st, on Thursday, July 19 at 4pm.

Furby is back. After 14 years and a lengthy hibernation, Hasbro is reviving one of its most famous toys for this fall, with new technology, a hefty price tag ($60) and an app connection. This Furby is more huggable, with soft fur that hides touch sensors, and more expressive, with rubbery ears that twitch and a pair of backlit LCD eyes with mechanical eyelids that blink, look around or respond to the sounds picked up by Furby's onboard microphone.

7:30 P.M. (Showtime) THE HELP (2011) Skeeter (Emma Stone), an aspiring writer from a prominent family in early 1960s Mississippi, causes an uproar in her community when she interviews black female servants in this adaptation of the Kathryn Stockett novel, directed and written by Tate Taylor. Viola Davis earned a best actress Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Aibileen, a maid who has raised several of the town's white babies. Octavia Spencer (above right, with Ms. Davis) won for best supporting actress as Aibileen's best friend, Minny, who endures soul-killing work for Hilly (Bryce Dallas Howard), a housewife who believes in white superiority. And Cicely Tyson is Constantine, the woman who raised Skeeter -- and who inspires her former charge's journey of discovery. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called this best picture nominee a ''big, ole slab of honey-glazed hokum.'' The movie's ''vision of a divided America that while consistently insulting and sometimes even terrifying, is rarely grotesque, despite Hilly's best (worst) segregationist efforts,'' she added. ''Inside all these different homes, black and white women tend to the urgent matters of everyday life, like the care and feeding of children. And while every so often the roar of the outside world steals in like thunder, Mr. Taylor makes sure it doesn't rattle the china or your soul.'' 8 P.M. (HBO) SOMETHING BORROWED (2011) Ginnifer Goodwin stars as Rachel, a New York lawyer who imagines herself a wallflower until, on her 30th birthday, she finally ends up in bed with her longtime crush, Dex (Colin Egglesfield). Kate Hudson is Darcy, a brassy blond bombshell and Rachel's lifelong best friend -- and the woman Dex happens to be engaged to. ''The contrast between Darcy and Rachel is a bit overdrawn, but it should have given the conflict between them at least a hint of comic snap,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The Times about this film, adapted by Luke Greenfield from the novel by Emily Giffin. ''And the premise should have been a surefire recipe for farce, especially when everyone piles into a summer share in the Hamptons.'' Why this film ''should be so cautious and tepid,'' Mr. Scott said, ''is a puzzle.''

8:44 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES - There was a sobering prelude to Comic-Con International, which kicks off Wednesday night with a preview evening at the San Diego Convention Center: a devotee of the ''Twilight'' series was killed by a car on Tuesday while lining up for a Thursday movie panel. According to the Web site U-T San Diego, which cited a police sergeant, the woman was killed in a crosswalk walking against a red light. The site, that of The San Diego Union-Tribune newspaper, said she was 53 years old.

If you are thinking about buying a new laptop, stop thinking and do it. At least that's what the algorithms at Decide.com say to do. Decide.com is a Web site created by artificial intelligence experts that tracks millions of price changes on consumer electronics and appliances and uses algorithms to to predict when buyers are most likely to get a deal. The site claims 77 percent accuracy since its inception in June 2011.

''The mother garden is back,'' said Takeo Lee Wong, a sometime actor whose main role these days is as the gardener of West 105th Street in Manhattan. His ''mother garden'' is a small jungle of plants in pots and planters in front of the five-story walk-up building at 319 West 105th Street where he lives. Mr. Wong turned this concrete expanse - about the size of a parking space - into a plant paradise over the past decade, only to have it stripped of the plants by his landlord two summers ago.

LONDON - Robert E. Diamond Jr., the former chief of Barclays who resigned because of a scandal involving interest rate manipulation, defended his testimony to a British parliamentary committee as lawmakers called more senior officials to appear. Late Tuesday, Mr. Diamond responded to criticism from British politicians that he had not been completely forthcoming last week at a hearing on the Barclays case.

At Paire.us, a new online jewelry store, you can buy coveted baubles straight from the runway, which, often as not, are next to impossible to track down. The founders, Lissa Hussian and Dominique Marano, friends who met working at Donna Karan, will tell you that finding an item of jewelry that walks down the runway is akin to scoring a must-have catwalk garment. Right now, you'll find pieces from Jean Paul Gaultier, Andrew Gn, and Vionnet as well as technicolor rings and bangles from the Bibhu Mohapatra x Gemma Redux spring collaboration. Later this month, find the pretty star cluster hair accessories from Rodarte's fall show and the Fenton for Prabal Gurung steer-skull pieces, like this seductively menacing cuff, $995. ''It's about making a statement,'' Ms. Marano said. ''That doesn't have to mean being all done up. You can put on a piece of jewelry and still feel very much in the fashion forefront.''

An article on Tuesday about a genetic test that very accurately predicts the outcome of patients with ocular melanoma misspelled the name of a class of drugs that are being tested against a cancer of white blood cells and perhaps could be used to slow the spread of ocular melanoma. The drugs are histone deacetylase inhibitors, not histone deacylase inhibitors. The article also left the incorrect impression that valproic acid is unrelated to that class. Valproic acid, an older drug used to treat epilepsy and other disorders, subsequently was found to be a histone deacetylase inhibitor.

SO you've finally made it to the Big City, and all you can afford is a mini-apartment. Such is the situation outlined this week by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg when he announced a competition to design a building of so-called ''micro-units,'' no bigger than 300 square feet, presumably tailor-made for single adults, childless couples or really, really good friends. Building such a micro-pad is only half the battle, of course. After the paint dries, you still have to furnish it. But despair not: while you may be living in an area smaller than your average motel room, some experts say outfitting such tiny surroundings can actually be good for your soul.

Tourists staying at the W Times Square Hotel might get a lesson in 20th-century New York club culture on Monday night. The hotel bar, which occupies a 1918 theater building at Broadway and 47th Street, is the location for a screening of ''It's a Jackie Thing,'' Charles Atlas's 1999 documentary about the gender-bending party Jackie 60 that ran for most of the 1990s in the meatpacking district. Why the W? In the early '90s the building was home to Club USA, a megaclub designed by Jean Paul Gaultier and run by Peter Gatien, the former New York nightlife impresario who also owned the Limelight, the Tunnel and the Palladium. Club USA, whose décor played on the theme of a gritty, bygone Times Square, was filled on many nights with club kids and drag queens. Its Sunday-night party, Bump, was popular with gay men. The club closed in 1994, and W turned it into a hotel in 2001.

A report in the Inside Art column on Friday about the display of the paintings ''Nymphs and Satyr'' by William-Adolphe Bouguereau and ''Springtime'' by Pierre Auguste Cot at the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- the first time the paintings have been together since 1882 -- referred imprecisely to the closure for renovations of the Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., which lent ''Nymphs and Satyr'' to the Met. While the Clark museum building is in fact closed, the permanent collection is on display at the institute's Manton Research Center.

DENIS--Raphael J.,was born June 5th, 1934 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti to Stephen and Emma Denis. He was one of seven children, and was educated at the Lycee Tousaint l'Overture. He was a dedicated bookbinder, painter, master of carpentry, and family man. His artwork is part of public and private collections internationally, and has also been exhibited across the globe. He also mentored and tutored several artists including Jocelyne Telson. Raphael died peacefully and of natural causes shortly after his 78th birthday, on Saturday July 7th, 2012. He departed from his studio/art gallery at home in Brooklyn, NY, in the arms of his wife. He is survived by his wife Violette, his sisters Bernadette, Stephanie, and his brothers Marcelle, and Camille, his two daughters Rachel, Pascale, his daughter in law Denise, his grandchildren Sarah, Yoseph and Richard, as well as many nephews, nieces, cousins, in-laws, friends and associates.

The new Green Goblin has materialized. Robert Cuccioli will take on the role of the villain (and his alter ego, Norman Osborn) in ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark'' on Broadway, representatives for the show announced. Mr. Cuccioli, a Tony nominee for ''Jekyll and Hyde'' - in which he also played dual roles - will replace Patrick Page, who originated the part, stuck with it through the show's lengthy development process and was rewarded with expanded stage time after the character tested well with audiences. He will depart Aug. 5 and Mr. Cuccioli will begin performances Aug. 7.

A headline in some editions on June 30 with an article about the halting of part of a Bloomberg administration plan to close and reopen 24 schools described the official who made the decision incorrectly. As the article correctly noted, the official is an arbitrator, not a mediator.

LIVINGSTON--Dr. Patricia, 87, died on Tuesday, July 10th. Dr. Livingston was born in St. Paul, Minnesota and was a graduate of the University of Minnesota. She received a Ph.D. in rehabilitation counseling from New York University, where she was Professor of Rehabilitation Counseling Studies. Dr. Livingston was a leader in the development and member of the Board of the International Center for the Disabled. An active volunteer of the Carl Schurz Park Association for many years, she was instrumental in getting New York's first dog litters laws passed. She leaves her husband of fifty-four years, Dr. Arthur Livingston. Viewing will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave (81st), Friday July 13th, 2-5pm, 7-9pm. Funeral services will be private for family members. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the International Center for the Disabled.

A single company purchased more than 50,000 Hewlett-Packard computers last year, buying in bulk to shave millions of dollars off its costs. But it was not General Electric, Procter & Gamble or another large, multinational conglomerate with the muscle to dictate prices to suppliers. Rather, the big buyer was the Blackstone Group, a private equity firm.

An essay on Tuesday about the significance of physicists' discovery of a particle thought to be the Higgs boson described the physicist Victor F. Weisskopf incorrectly. Dr. Weisskopf was, from 1961 to 1965, the director of CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, which was established in 1954; he was not the center's first director.

TRAUB--Marvin, died peacefully at home on July 11. He was 87. He and his wife Lee were married for 63 cloudless years. He leaves behind his devoted children, Andrew, James and Margaret and his grandchildren, Rebecca, Rachel, Abigail and Alexander. As chairman and chief executive of Bloomingdale's, Marvin was one of the great merchants and retailers of his day, widely admired, honored and copied. But what was perhaps more remarkable is that he achieved his extraordinary success without ever making an enemy or speaking ill of a rival. He was an unfailingly gracious and generous man who didn't have a mean bone in his body. He was optimistic to a fault, and a font of enthusiasm. His favorite word was "marvelous." Marvin was born in New York City and graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School. He enlisted in the Army, and was wounded during action outside Metz. His doctors feared that he would never walk again, but after more than a year of intense therapy, Marvin regained full mobility and never walked with a limp. He was awarded the Purple Heart and three Bronze Battle Stars, and was later given the keys to the city of Metz. After graduating from Harvard in 1947, Marvin enrolled at Harvard Business School and graduated in the famous class of 1949. He met Lee, a student of modern dance and a Smith College student, in 1947, and they married on September 2, 1948. He went to work at Bloomingdale's and rose rapidly up the executive ladder, becoming CEO in 1978. Under his tenure, Bloomingdale's became a cultural mecca; he helped turn retailing into a form of theatre and entertainment. One of the hallmarks of Marvin's career was mentoring many executives who went on to become department store CEOs, as well as hiring, supporting and promoting many women executives. Retiring from Bloomingdale's at age 66, Marvin was ready for another career. For the next 21 years, he ran Marvin Traub Associates, working with many of the designers he had known for so many years as well as retailers and developers all over the world. Marvin loved his life; and "working," for him, was another word for "living." Marvin was deeply involved with a wide range of charities and institutions, including Harvard, where he and Lee sponsored scholarships for middle-income students. He and Lee were the center of each other's lives. Marvin was terrifically proud of everything his children accomplished. He was a loving and attentive father-in-law to Lois Traub, Elizabeth Easton and Phyllis Dicker. He considered almost everyone he ever met a friend--and the feeling was mutual. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Marvin and Lee Traub Flexible Financial Aid Fund at Harvard, or to Pin Down Bladder Cancer. A funeral service will be held at Central Synagogue at 10am on Sunday, July 15.

The actress Kristin Chenoweth was released from the hospital after she was injured Wednesday during the filming of the CBS series ''The Good Wife.'' In a statement on Thursday, Jill Fritzo, a publicist for Ms. Chenoweth, said: ''Kristin has been released from the hospital and is home recovering. She thanks everyone for their prayers and well wishes.''

A group of doctors and women's rights advocates challenged Arizona's new abortion limits in a federal lawsuit on Thursday, claiming that they violate the Constitution and pose a threat to women's health. The law, set to take effect on Aug. 2, prohibits abortions once 20 weeks have passed since a woman's last missed period, which is about 18 weeks after fertilization. This is the earliest deadline set by any state and is weeks earlier than the threshold set by the Supreme Court.

GRALLA--Milton. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, friend, philanthropist, of Boca Raton, FL passed away on July 11, 2012. He was 84 years old. Born in 1928, middle son of Jewish immigrants from Poland. Graduated 1948 (English, journalism) from City College of New York. Newspaper/magazine career started as sports stringer for New York Times. Worked for Tulsa World, before establishing business magazine company with brother, Lawrence Gralla. Company expanded into Gralla Publications which had 19 magazines and a national exposition division before being sold in 1983 to United Newspapers (London), an international publishing firm. Active life-long in philanthropy and Jewish educational progress in the United States, Israel and Former Soviet Union. Served on boards of directors of Boys Town Jerusalem, Yeshiva University, UJA-Federation (NY City), World ORT, Jewish Telegraphic Agency, JEWISH WEEK newspaper, Solomon Schechter School and Y/JCC of Bergen County (NJ), and Be'er Hagolah School, ORT schools to Former Soviet Union as founder (with wife Shirley) of new school in Odessa and then chairperson of "Regeneration" campaign to build or expand similar schools in numerous FSU cities. Sponsored and helped conduct seminars in Moscow for executives of revitalized Jewish community weeklies. Became chairman of Salute to Israel parade in New York City in 1994. With wife Shirley sponsored "Freedom Flight" of 250 Russian Jewish immigrants to new homeland in Israel. "It was emotional and memorable beyond description," Milt recollected. In 1998 founded Gralla Fellows Program at Brandeis University for journalists in early/middle stages of careers. Helped bring music to Boca Raton FL through financial and business support of the Palm Beach Pops and the Sunshine Pops. With Adriane Berg co-authored "How Good Guys Grow Rich" which explained Good Guy attitude that living to enrich others without seeking rewards would bring financial rewards and personal satisfaction. Ran as Independent for Congress in his NJ district in 1974 and gained considerable support. Numerous awards included Ellis Island Medal (to first-generation or second-generation Americans who have made distinguished contributions to U.S. society), and Doctorate of Humane Letters from Yeshiva University (1991). Residence in Boca Raton (FL). Wife Shirley (Edelson) Gralla, married in 1950. Children M/Ms Edward Gralla, M/Ms Todd Galinko, M/Ms Dennis Gralla. Six Grandchildren. Donations in Milton's name can be made to any of the following institutions: Brandeis University, Mailstop 122, Waltham MA 02453 - Attn: Nancy Winship, Senior VP of Institutional Advancement; For Milton Gralla Endowed Scholarship for a Journalism Student, 781-736-4003 or Jewish Home in Rockleigh, 10 Link Drive, Rockleigh, NJ 07647 - Attn: Chuck Berkowitz, Executive Director, 201-784-1414 or Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture, 50 Broadway 34th Floor, New York, NY 10004 - Attn: Dr. Jerome Hochbaum, 212-425-6606.

''American Idol'' faces another upheaval in its on-camera lineup with the announcement on Thursday that Steven Tyler is stepping down as one of the show's three judges. The change comes after a season of sharply depressed ratings for ''Idol,'' which had ridden a wave of popularity to the top of the prime-time television ratings over the last decade. The Fox network issued a statement from Mr. Tyler, the longtime lead singer of the rock band Aerosmith, in which he said he was going back to full-time work with the band.

After petitions and official presentations failed to save the wooden Coney Island Boardwalk, several advocacy groups and outspoken residents filed a lawsuit this week to stop New York City from tearing up a five-block section and replacing it with concrete and plastic. Beyond the destruction a historical gem, these groups say, there are serious safety concerns - including improper drainage - that have already arisen in sections renovated with concrete. The lawsuit, dated on Tuesday and filed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, claims that the parks department did not subject its plans to the necessary state and city environmental review.

As the Sbarro pizzeria chain spread from Brooklyn to malls and airports around the world, her name adorned the menus and stretched across the entrances. But Mama Sbarro herself still stood behind the counter of the original Sbarro's salumeria in Bensonhurst, serving chicken parmigiana and cheesecake in high heels as she had done since 1956. The original Italian deli has been closed for 10 years, shut down when Carmela Sbarro, who died Saturday at age 90, was no longer able to run the kitchen. Nothing on the stretch of 17th Avenue where it stood hints at its past. The salumeria is now a Japanese shabu-shabu restaurant; across the street are a Polish deli and a Spanish restaurant. Asian families now fill many of the brick row houses nearby.

Melillo, Harvey Lichtenstein, and Alan Fishman

TRAUB--Marvin. We are deeply saddened by the death of our former CEO and great friend Marvin Traub. The part of his legacy we will treasure the most will be the lives he touched at Bloomingdale's. Marvin took great pride in all of those that he mentored. Blessed with enormous energy, he will always be remembered for his passion and devotion to the store for the last 62 years. We will miss him and what he gave and continued to give us until his final days. We express our sincere sympathy to his beloved wife Lee and the entire Traub family. Michael Gould, Chairman & CEO Tony Spring, President & COO The Bloomingdale's Family

The International Olympic Committee confirmed Thursday that Saudi Arabia would send two female athletes to compete in this summer's London Games, which means that, for the first time, every participating country will have a female athlete. The I.O.C. said Saudi Arabia, a monarchy with severe restrictions on women in daily life, would send Sarah Attar, an 800-meter runner, and Wodjan Ali Seraj Abdulrahim Shahrkhani, who competes in judo.

9 P.M. (Showtime) GOD BLESS OZZY OSBOURNE (2011) The way Keith Richards of the Rolling Stones remembers it in his autobiography, ''Life,'' Mr. Osbourne, above, consumed more drugs and alcohol in the 1980s than even he did. This documentary by Mike Fleiss and Mike Piscitelli chronicles the life and times of Mr. Osbourne, from his working-class English background and his success as the frontman for the heavy-metal band Black Sabbath through his struggle with substance abuse. It even addresses the report that Mr. Osbourne once bit off the head of a live bat during a performance. (Yes, he did.) Mr. Osbourne's son, Jack, is an executive producer. 8:30 A.M. (USA) DUPLICITY (2009) She -- Julia Roberts as the long-legged Claire, standing in a garden in a flowery dress, looking bored -- is C.I.A. He -- Clive Owen as Ray, on whom a suit becomes a brazenly sexy uniform -- is MI6. Five years after meeting over frozen drinks at a barbecue and ending up in bed, they decide to abandon their respective governments and go to work on opposite sides of the beauty-products industry, with puffed-up executives portrayed by Paul Giamatti and Tom Wilkinson. ''It's a caper movie, a love story,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film, written and directed by Tony Gilroy, ''an extra-dry corporate satire. However you describe it, 'Duplicity' is superior entertainment, the most elegantly pleasurable movie of its kind to come around in a very long time.''

Diane Lane will star as a fading Hollywood heroine in Tennessee Williams's ''Sweet Bird of Youth'' at the Goodman Theater in Chicago, the theater announced on Wednesday. Finn Wittrock will play opposite her as the gigolo Chance Wayne in a production directed by David Cromer (''Our Town''). Mr. Cromer was earlier set to direct the play on Broadway, with Nicole Kidman and James Franco to star, but that production never materialized. He is making his directorial debut at the Goodman.

An obituary on Tuesday about Martin Pakledinaz, who designed the costumes for numerous theater, opera and dance productions, including the recent revival of ''Anything Goes,'' misidentified the actor who played the part of Moonface Martin in the original Broadway production of that show, which opened in 1934. The actor was Victor Moore, not Bert Lahr. (Mr. Lahr played the role in a 1954 television adaptation.)

KRIEGEL--I. Stanley, beloved 101 year-old Patriarch and Brooklyn Booster. For 72 years, the devoted husband of his beautiful Charlotte, who predeceased him by four years, and with whom he fully shared all of life's joys and struggles. Inseparable, they filled all their days together with an abundance of love and generosity, family and faith, culture and service. They married at Temple Beth Elohim where Stanley served as President and a trustee for 77 years. They savored every offering of the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM) where he was Senior Trustee after 44 years. He was a Founding Trustee of the Brooklyn Philharmonic and Kingsbay YMHA, also it's President. For his manifold communal services, from selling bonds during WW II to the Brooklyn Public Library Board, they often called him "Mr. Brooklyn." A proud graduate of NYU School of Commerce in the auspicious class of '29, and President of the NYU Club. Expert business advisor and CPA, he became the region's leader in the automotive industry. Charlotte and Stanley feasted on opera, theater and music, food and travel. They are survived by their children Myra and her husband Matthew Zuckerbraun and Jay and his wife Kathryn McAuliffe, five grandchildren, Hope, Stuart, Abby, Isabel and Connor, and spouses Bill, Sharon, Ken and Trevor, three step-grandchildren, Jevon, Caitlin and Tessa, and 10 great-grandchildren (one en route). Funeral will be Friday July 13 at 9:30 at Temple Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place (Eighth Avenue), Brooklyn. Contributions welcome to Development Dept, BAM, 30 Lafayette Street, Brooklyn, NY 11217, or Temple Beth Elohim, 274 Garfield Place, Brooklyn, NY 11215. Shiva on Friday July 13 from 2-5pm at Jay and Kathryn's at 139 Spring Street, NY (at Wooster St); and Sunday July 15 from 4-8pm at Myra and Matthew's at 190 Argyle Road (Albermarle and Beverly), Brooklyn.

The City Room column in some editions on Saturday, about the opening of a pool in Brooklyn Bridge Park in Brooklyn Heights, misidentified the neighborhood of Clarissa Wertman, who was at the pool with a friend. She is from Crown Heights -- not Prospect Heights, where her friend lives.

An obituary on Feb. 26 about Dmitri Nabokov, the son and literary executor of Vladimir Nabokov, misstated the date of his death. It was Thursday, Feb. 23 -- not Wednesday, Feb. 22. (Though his death was announced in the United States on Feb. 22, he died in Switzerland, where it was already Feb. 23.) The error recently came to the attention of Times editors during the preparation of an essay about Mr. Nabokov that will appear in the Book Review on Sunday, July 22.

VOGELMAN--Dr. Joseph H.,on July 11th at the age of 91. Loving husband to Norma. Devoted father to Jeffrey, Leslie, and Linda. Cherished grandfather of seven and brother to Regina. Services will be held today, 11:30am at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

FREEMAN--Vera, 88, passed away peacefully at home on July 10th. A loving wife to the late Andrew, wonderful mother of George and grandmother of Jennifer and Griffith, she was born in Budapest, survived the War, and then began a new life in New York City. She started working almost immediately, becoming an import manager of fine papers for Andrews/Nelson/Whitehead and later Boise Cascade, and was recognized as an expert in handmade fine arts papers. She had a powerful intellect, a huge curiosity of the world around her, was an avid reader, lover of classical music and enthusiastic traveler, and was a strong source of support and strength to friends and family. Memorial service at Frank Campbell Funeral Home, Madison and 81st, on Thursday, July 19 at 4pm.

BOSTON -- Jill Stein, presumptive nominee of the Green Party, is probably the only candidate on the campaign trail who spends an hour a day cooking her own organic meals -- and who was, not too long ago, the lead singer of a folksy rock band.But the differences do not end there. When Ms. Stein is introduced on the trail as ''Jill Stein for president,'' she is also very likely the only candidate to be asked, ''For president of what?''

A picture caption on Wednesday with a news analysis article about new austerity measures for Spain referred incorrectly in some copies to the economy minister, Luis de Guindos, who was shown talking to reporters. He is the official who had said at one point that a sales tax increase was off limits this year; he is not the official who was scheduled to announce the new measures on Wednesday. (That was done by the prime minister, Mariano Rajoy.)

Before Jack Mubiru, a father of the skateboarding scene in Uganda, could build a half-pipe in his native Kampala in 2006, he had to avoid paying a construction fee, so he fabricated a story about building a private enclosure for a pet crocodile. Most local officials -- and neighborhood residents -- had never heard of skateboarding. Six years later, the sport has spread from the skate park to the streets, attracting children as young as 5 and adult women. Its profile is growing throughout eastern Africa, with skate parks built or planned in neighboring Kenya and Tanzania. Proponents of skateboarding say it gives participants a welcome leisure activity in countries where there are few other options. ''There is not much else for younger people to do,'' Mubiru says. ''So many people want to skateboard.'' Members of the Uganda Skateboard Union in 2006: 5

LIVINGSTON--Dr. Patricia, 87, died on Tuesday, July 10th. Dr. Livingston was born in St. Paul, Minnesota and was a graduate of the University of Minnesota. She received a Ph.D. in rehabilitation counseling from New York University, where she was Professor of Rehabilitation Counseling Studies. Dr. Livingston was a leader in the development and member of the Board of the International Center for the Disabled. An active volunteer of the Carl Schurz Park Association for many years, she was instrumental in getting New York's first dog litters laws passed. She leaves her husband of fifty-four years, Dr. Arthur Livingston. Viewing will be at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave (81st), Friday July 13th, 2-5pm, 7-9pm. Funeral services will be private for family members. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the International Center for the Disabled.

Pluto is still not a planet, but it does boast an impressive entourage. Astronomers said Wednesday that they had spotted a fifth moon orbiting Pluto, which they already knew had four. The discovery, made with the Hubble Space Telescope, gives Pluto more moons than Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars combined.

An article on Thursday about the 10th stage of the Tour de France, which included the Grand Colombier pass in the Jura Mountains, misstated the winning time of Thomas Voeckler. It was 4 hours 46 minutes 26 seconds, not 4:05:26. The error was repeated in some copies in a picture caption. The article also misidentified the river that the Grand Colombier overlooks. It is the Rhone, not the Rhine.

An article on June 27 about allegations that dozens of Stuyvesant High School students cheated on exams by using text messaging misstated the type of test being taken on June 18 when a student's cellphone was confiscated, revealing messages that suggested students had been sharing information about state Regents exams. It was during a city language exam, not a state Regents language exam. (Regents exams no longer include testing on foreign languages.)

TRAUB--Marvin S. Marvin was a splendid human being. He was a brilliant retailer who took Bloomingdale's from a mediocre, run-of-the-mill store and developed it into one of the most dynamic and exciting retailers in the world. But more importantly, he was a magnificent husband and father, who raised three wonderful children; Peggy, Jimmy, and Andy; and had many close friends and a personal life which was warm and intense. He and Lee maintained a great romance that lasted all his life. Marvin was kind and intelligent with a great passion for life. Dalia and I will miss our dear friend very much. Larry
ROLLER--Mildred. H.B. Mom. Wish you were here. Forever in my heart. Love, Cheryl

A few years after he directed ''The Warriors'' and a few years before he made ''Brewster's Millions,'' Walter Hill directed ''48 Hrs.,'' the 1982 action-buddy comedy that starred Nick Nolte and Eddie Murphy as unlikely partners working a murder case. Now, 30 years later, Mr. Hill is turning his attention to a different, equally unlikely project about another famously mismatched pair. The Aldrich Company announced that Mr. Hill would direct a remake of ''Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?'', the 1962 thriller directed and produced by Robert Aldrich and which starred Bette Davis and Joan Crawford. In the original film, adapted from Henry Farrell's novel, Davis played Baby Jane Hudson, a onetime vaudeville star who resents the attention shone on her older sister, the movie star Blanche (Crawford). Years after the spotlight has faded, Blanche has been paralyzed by a car accident, and Jane, now her caretaker, torments her sister emotionally (while serving her the occasional rat for a meal) and obsesses over her own show-biz comeback.

We mourn the passing of our friend and colleague Ronald Sell, lifelong member of the American Symphony Orchestra, distinguished French Horn player, and for decades our personnel manager. Few have rivaled his love of music and loyalty to his colleagues. He will be missed throughout New York. Leon Botstein Danny Goldberg Lynne Meloccaro Oliver Inteeworn Irene Zedlacher

TRAUB--Marvin. It has been an honor to have Marvin as our friend and business associate. He was always there for everyone regardless of time or distance. Our love to Lee and his family. Barbara D. & Arnold L. Cohen

Colin Marshall, who played a central role in transforming British Airways from a widely disparaged, deficit-ridden government-run entity into one of the world's most profitable airlines in the 1980s, died on July 5 in London. He was 78. The cause was cancer, said Tony Cocklin, a spokesman for the family.
SAN FRANCISCO -- Another month, another major security breach. Yahoo confirmed Thursday that about 400,000 user names and passwords to Yahoo and other companies were stolen on Wednesday.

PROWLER--Robert Hudes. January 3, 1923-July 10, 2012, was born in Brooklyn and attended James Madison High School and St. John's University. After serving on Okinawa in World War II he worked for many years on Madison Avenue and lived in Malverne, NY. Bob edited the Malverne Times community newspaper, was treasurer of the Malverne Historical Society, fed the homeless in a Long Beach shelter and was on the board of Amnesty International's local Chapter. He had a sharp but gentle wit and in moments could turn you into a friend for life. He is survived by wife Joan, sons Gilbert (Mindy) and David (Simone Perez), grandchildren Brienna, Alyssa, and Joey and mourned by many friends and family. The Memorial will be Sunday, July 22 at 10am at the Malverne Funeral Home, 330 Hempstead Avenue, Malverne, NY.
TRAUB--Marvin. You were the best boss I ever had. I loved working for you and I loved working for your mother. The Fashion Industry will miss you. Susan Rudin

The New York premiere of Christopher Wheeldon's ''3 Movements and 4 Repeats'' performed by Fang-Yi Sheu & Artists, from Taiwan; the United States premiere of ''Deseo Y Conciencia'' by María Pagés Compañía of Spain; and a world premiere from Ka Leo O Laka I Ka Hikina O Ka La of Hawaii are among the highlights of the ninth annual Fall for Dance Festival at New York City Center. This year's festival will run Sept. 27 to Oct. 13 and has been expanded to 12 nights of dance with all tickets at $15. The festival will feature 20 companies in 5 programs. (Programs 1 through 3 will be performed twice; programs 4 and 5 will be performed three times.) Also on the lineup: BalletBoyz, from London; LDP-Laboratory Dance Project of Seoul, South Korea; Moiseyev Dance Company of Moscow; and Nan Jombang from Jakarta, Indonesia. Juilliard Dance will perform a work by Pam Tanowitz, and Ballet West, Pacific Northwest Ballet, Jodi Melnick and Shantala Shivalingappa are also scheduled to appear. Tickets go on sale Sept. 9 at 11 a.m.

MAY--Bernard J.,(Bernie), passed away peacefully on July 6, 2012 following a struggle with tonsil cancer. He was 68. Born in Brooklyn, raised in Queens, he returned to New York, the city he loved, as an adult. He was a 1961 graduate of Bayside High School, and in 1965 graduated from Miami University in Oxford, OH. He served from 1965 through 1967 in the Peace Corps as a secondary school teacher in rural Thailand. He returned to attend Clark University, Worcester, MA for graduate studies in Geography and embarked on a long corporate career, largely in Real Estate. After 25 years, he retired in 2007 from Merrill Lynch as a Director of Real Estate Risk Management. He is survived by his beloved wife of 44 years, Suzanne (Lutz) and his loving son, Christopher, 36, of Denver. Other survivors include cousins Marjorie Sullivan O'Brien, Monica Ericsson Jonson and Ann-Christen Ericsson. A Memorial Service will be held at All Souls Unitarian Church. Contributions in Bernie's memory can be made to the Star Island Corporation, Portsmouth, NH or the Carl Schurz Park Conservancy, New York, NY.

An article on Thursday about uncertainties surrounding a package of tax increases and spending cuts scheduled to take effect in 2013 if Congress does not act misstated, in some copies, part of the budgetary effect of such inaction. The government would gain -- not forfeit -- $399 billion in tax revenue.

It might be nearly midsummer but in the Hamptons things are just getting started. The Watermill Center on Long Island is gearing up for the July 28 opening of its show ''Mike Kelley: 1954-2012.'' The exhibition, which is devoted to the Detroit-born artist who committed suicide earlier this year, has been organized by Harald Falckenberg, an expert and collector of Mr. Kelley's work. It is being presented in collaboration with the Luma Foundation, a nonprofit based in Switzerland that has supported other Kelley projects. The show, which runs through Sept. 16, will fill the center's entire south wing and include early punk soundtracks, experimental videos and several of the artist's later works from the ''Kandor'' project, which deals with the town of Kandor, on the planet Krypton from which the child Kal-El escaped to Earth, where he became Superman. On view will be cardboard models and banners from Mr. Kelley's ''Kandor-Conn 2000'' installation; seven large-scale projections from 2007; one of the bottled cityscapes of ''Kandor,'' also from 2007; and Mr. Kelley's last performance video, ''Vice Anglais,'' from 2011.

The Le Thor Journal article on Wednesday, about a small museum in southern France dedicated to the memory of President John F. Kennedy's press secretary, Pierre Salinger, whose French roots ran deep and who spent his last years in Le Thor, referred imprecisely to the origin of Mr. Salinger's brief stint as a Democratic United States senator from California in 1964. While Mr. Salinger was appointed to fill a vacant Senate seat during the administration of President Lyndon B. Johnson, the appointment itself was made by California's governor at the time, Edmund G. Brown, not by Mr. Johnson.

When Timothy F. Geithner ran the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, he acknowledged fundamental problems with the process for setting key interest rates in the midst of the 2008 financial crisis, according to documents provided to The New York Times. Mr. Geithner, who is now the United States Treasury secretary, questioned the integrity of the benchmark as reports surfaced that Barclays and other big banks were misrepresenting the rates. In 2008, Barclays had several conversations with New York Fed officials about the matter.

The authorities in central Hunan Province determined that a veteran dissident who was found dead in his hospital room last month took his own life, a news service reported.
Sir John Sawers shared the forecast with a gathering of civil servants last week, according to a British newspaper.

Nathan Tinkler, an Australian coal tycoon, is leading a $5.4 billion bid for Whitehaven Coal, at a time when falling coal prices have weighed on profits in the industry. The group offered to take Whitehaven private for 5.20 Australian dollars ($5.29) a share. The bid is a 51 percent premium above Friday's closing price, the coal mining company said on Friday. The bidding group said it had received support from roughly 48.3 percent of Whitehaven's shares, according to the company. Mr. Tinkler controls more than 20 percent of the company. The offer comes a month after Mr. Tinkler initially approached the company. On Friday, Whitehaven said Mr. Tinkler's group had been given four weeks to conduct due diligence exclusively.

An article last Saturday about a lawyer for the owner of a boat that capsized off Long Island on the Fourth of July, killing three children, who said the boat was not necessarily overloaded, erroneously applied a formula often used to determine a boat's capacity. The calculation -- a boat's length in feet times its width, divided by 15 -- is used for boats under 20 feet. The capsized boat, the Kandi Won, was 34 feet. (As the article noted, when that calculation is used for the Kandi Won, its capacity is 27 -- the number of people on it when it capsized.)

The French flavor at Red Bull Arena became a little more savory Friday when the Red Bulls acquired the dynamic Sebastien Le Toux from the Vancouver Whitecaps for Dane Richards and what Major League Soccer calls allocation money. Add Le Toux, 28, a native of Mont-Saint-Aignan France, to the star striker Thierry Henry and the coming Trophee des Champion game between Lyon and Montpellier at the stadium in Harrison, N.J., on July 28. (Le Toux is also a dead ringer for the club's striker Kenny Cooper.)

SONDHEIMER--Ruth Grunebaum, on July 12. Mourning the loss of our grandmother. Great-grandmother of Olivia, Stella, Juliette, Clara, Ilana, Jeremy and Daniel. Blessed to have passed peacefully at 97. Shiva 3-8pm Sunday-Wednesday, 300 Central Park West. Douglas, Rodney, Jamie Propp

KOTITE--Antoinette L. Toni Kotite passed away peacefully at her home in Manhattan on July 12 surrounded by her children. She was the beloved wife of the late Albert Kotite. Loving mother of Edward, Sonny, Peter, Deborah and Toni and adoring grandmother of Edward, Elizabeth, P.J., Christopher, Caroline, Harry, Topper, John and Aaron. Loving, giving, kind, sweet and compassionate do not begin to describe her. She lived her life for her family and touched all who knew her. Her family and friends will miss her but will carry her truly beautiful spirit with them always.
International UNESCO TO GIVE PRIZE

While Fox would surely love a world in which the stars of ''Glee'' stay forever young (and remain forever in high school), that sort of thing happens only in comic books. But for four issues, the warbling youngsters of the New Directions glee choir can know what it's like to never grow old and have their major life dilemmas turn out consistently swell when they meet Archie Andrews and his Riverdale pals in a forthcoming comic-book series. On Monday Archie Comics said that it would publish a four-part story called ''Archie Meets Glee,'' in which characters like Archie, Betty, Veronica and Jughead mix it up with the students of ''Glee.'' The series, which will run next year in the publisher's ''Archie'' series, will be illustrated by Dan Parent and written by Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa, a ''Glee'' writer and producer who has also written for many comic-book series and contributed to the book of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.''

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the discovery of a fifth moon orbiting Pluto quoted incorrectly from a comment by Dean Burnett, a British neuroscientist and stand-up comic. In commenting on the discovery, Mr. Burnett said, ''Good on Pluto, I say'' -- not ''Good one Pluto, I say.''

A prominent futures-industry executive was arrested on Friday after confessing to embezzling from clients and defrauding banks over nearly two decades. Russell Wasendorf Sr., the chief executive of the futures brokerage firm Peregrine Financial Group, admitted that he stole more than $100 million from his customers, prosecutors say. The formal charges, brought by federal prosecutors in Iowa, accuse him of lying to government regulators.

An article in the Square Feet pages on June 27 about the redevelopment of buildings at the former headquarters of 3M in St. Paul, Minn., misstated the given name of the architect who designed the executive office building. He is Albert Kahn, not Alfred.

JACOBSON--Naomi "Red" Skutelsky, left this world on Tuesday to join Bob, the love of her life. She will be missed by her children Sarah (Eddie), Mimi (Skip), Alan (Hoang) her grandchildren Matthew, Ashlie, Andrew, Jonathan and Alyssa, and her many nieces and nephews. Services will be Sunday, July 15th, 2:30pm at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre.

It is beginning to look like ''Extreme Makeover: 'American Idol' Edition.'' One day after Steven Tyler announced that he was leaving ''American Idol,'' the blockbuster singing competition on Fox,Jennifer Lopez said on Friday that she too would exit the show, television's biggest of the past decade.

STRAUSS--Armar A.,age 81, passed away suddenly from coronary complications on July 2nd at his home in Pacific Palisades, California. Two of his dearest friends were with him at the time. Everyone who met Armar-a wise and caring physician, loyal friend, and generous donor to liberal causes and those in need-could not help being touched by his concern for their own well-being. His generosity, ready laugh and good counsel will be hugely missed. He is survived by sister Lydia ("Witty"), brother Chris and daughter Irit. Dr Strauss had long insisted that no service be held for him; only that his ashes be carried back to Japan and interred alongside those of his late beloved wife, Umeko.

BAILEY--Robert. The NYU Department of Music notes the passing of its long-time colleague, Robert Bailey, The Carroll and Milton Petrie Professor of Music Emeritus in the Faculty of Arts and Science. He was a distinguished scholar and teacher, whose students hold important positions in major American universities and opera houses, whose writings have profoundly shaped the discourse of musicology. His like does not come along often in each generation.

TRAUB--Marvin. The Martha Graham Center mourns the passing of Marvin Traub- the Center's friend and benefactor, and husband of our Chairman Emerita, Lee. Judith Schlosser, Inger Witter, LaRue Allen, Janet Eilber
ROBBINS--Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep abiding interest in and love for each of us. Sheila

GUTTMAN--William M.,of Palm Beach, FL, and New York, NY, died on July 13, 2012. He is survived by his wife Susan, his daughters Jennifer Guttman Schlau and Catherine Guttman-McCabe, and four grandchildren; Steven, Alexa, Anna, and Abigail. Born April 15, 1941, in Manhattan, he grew up on Long Island. He was the General Counsel and a senior executive of Time Inc., where he was responsible for all domestic and internal legal affairs of Time and its worldwide divisions and subsidiaries. He served as the chief executive officer of the Palm Beach Civic Association from 1997 to 2005. He also served on the Town of Palm Beach Charter Review Commission from 1997 to 1999, as Chairman of the Palm Beach Planning and Zoning Commission, and on the Board of Directors of the Palm Beach Fellowship of Christians and Jews, the Citizens Association of Palm Beach and the Graham-Eckes Palm Beach Academy Foundation. In 2005, he was presented with the Anti-Defamation League's Distinguished Community Service Award for promoting harmony and understanding in Palm Beach, and in 2006, he received the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce's Pride of Palm Beach Award. A former adjunct professor at Pace University Law School in White Plains, NY and Columbia University Business School, he received both his undergraduate and law degrees from Columbia with honors. He lived with gusto, wit, and passion. His memory will remain indelible with andhis indomitable spirit carried on by his family, friends, and any who knew him. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NY, NY on July 15, 2012 at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be sent to Columbia University Medical Center, 100 Haven Avenue, Suite 29D, NY, NY 10032-2626.

Ulugbek Kodirov, a 22-year-old Uzbek man who moved to the United States planning to study medicine in New York, but ended up working in a suburban Alabama mall, was sentenced to more than 15 years in prison on Friday for plotting to kill President Obama on behalf of a jihadist group in Uzbekistan. As The Associated Press reports, Mr. Kodirov's lawyer, Lance Bell, blamed the Internet for radicalizing the young man, who moved to Alabama after giving up on a plan to get a medical degree at Columbia University because his English was not good enough. ''I'm not calling him a victim,'' Mr. Bell said, ''but he's a victim to a degree of social media.''

It's hard to imagine the writings of Charles Bukowski, the dyspeptic poet of drink and loneliness, being set to a jaunty musical theater score. (Five, six, seven, eight - ''Some people never go crazy. What truly horrible lives they must lead'' - and jazz hands, chorus!) That is, unless you're Joanne Gordon, the artistic director of the California Repertory Company in Long Beach. Ms. Gordon conceived of and will direct ''B.S.: Bukowski.Sondheim,'' a new theatrical work that fuses Mr. Bukowksi's poetry with the music and lyrics of Stephen Sondheim. After a workshop it will have its premiere later this year, with the blessing of the Bukowski estate and Mr. Sondheim himself.

MALONE--J. Robert. 87, died July 8, 2012 at his home in Vero Beach. A native of Philadelphia, PA, Mr. Malone attended West Catholic High School for Boys, Villanova University, and the Harvard Business School, where he received a Master's Degree in Business Administration. After serving in the United States Navy during World War II, Mr. Malone received his license as a Certified Public Accountant. In 1947, Mr. Malone joined Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., later KPMG, where he served as the Managing Partner of the Rochester, New York, and Cleveland, Ohio offices before returning to his native Philadelphia to manage the firm's office there. Throughout his career, Mr. Malone was active in professional and civic organizations including the Civic Music Association of Rochester, Chairman of the Board of the Trustees Catholic Family Center of Rochester, Member of the Greater Cleveland Growth Association, the Board of Overseers for the Dental School of the University of Pennsylvania and the Board of Directors of the Greater Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce. Upon retiring in 1983, Mr. Malone divided his time between Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania and Vero Beach, Florida while continuing to be active in various capacities including service on the Board of the John's Island Property Owner's Association and the Board of General Accident Insurance. An avid golfer, Mr. Malone was a member of Philadelphia Country Club and a former member of the John's Island Club, and of the Bent Pine Golf Club. Active in various Catholic charitable organizations, Mr. Malone was invested as a Knight of Malta in 1979. At his death, he was a member of Holy Cross Catholic Church in Vero Beach. Survivors include his wife of sixty-three years Margaret Grant Malone of Vero Beach; his daughter, Margaret Ann Malone of Columbus, Ohio; his son and daughter-in-law, James Robert Malone, Jr.and Anne P. Malone of Ambler, Pennsylvania; his brother, Msgr. Richard Kevin Malone of Upper Darby, Pennsylvania and two grandchildren, Scott J. Malone, and Tara A. Malone. Mr. Malone was predeceased by his brother, John L. Malone, and his sister, Ritanne M. Devine. Memorial contributions may be made to Order of Malta, American Association, P.O. Box 10023, Uniondale, NY 11555-0023. Services: A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:30am, July 24, 2012 at St. John Vianney Catholic Church, Gladwyne, Pennsylvania. Interment will be in Calvary Cemetery, West Conshohocken, Pennsylvania. In addition, a Memorial Service will be held at Holy Cross Catholic Church, Vero Beach later in the fall. Services by Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory Vero Beach. An online guestbook is available at: www.strunkfuneralhome.com.
5:37 p.m. | Updated Wells Fargo reported its 10th consecutive quarter of earnings growth, propelled by a booming business originating and refinancing mortgages.

Prepaid debit cards and their various fees have been getting a lot of scrutiny lately from consumer advocates and regulators. Now, prepaid utility accounts are on watchdogs' radar, too. With a traditional credit-based home utility account, you use power to cool and light your home, and then receive a bill for what you owe. (In some states, if you have poor credit or you are a new customer, you must pay a security deposit to obtain an account.)

In the first comprehensive review of the government's programs for treating post-traumatic stress disorder in service members and veterans, a panel of experts recommended on Friday that the Defense Department and the Department of Veterans Affairs expand access to services, particularly for people in rural areas, in the National Guard or Reserves, or in combat zones. The report, by the Institute of Medicine, also concluded that the two departments need to improve their assessment of how well their many treatment programs work, as well as find better ways of coordinating care that can begin overseas and then continue on bases or in small towns across the country.

Just as criticism of Mitt Romney's time at Bain Capital hit a fever pitch, the lead headline on The Drudge Report trumpeted a shocker: Condoleezza Rice was the ''front-runner'' to be his vice-presidential nominee. Ms. Rice, a former secretary of state and national security adviser who is now a professor at Stanford, has said repeatedly that she is not interested in joining the ticket.
KRIEGEL--Stanley. The Brooklyn Philharmonic family mourns the passing of our friend and founding board member. We all are the better for knowing Stanley and will miss him greatly.

An article on June 30 about the anticipated victory of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, in Mexico's presidential election after 12 years out of power quoted incorrectly from a comment by the Mexican historian Enrique Krauze about the 71 years that the autocratic, and often corrupt, PRI had ruled the country. He called that era the ''imperial presidency,'' not the ''imperial democracy.''

All Tomorrow's Parties is moving again, this time to Manhattan. The event -- a connoisseur's rock festival from Britain that popularized the model of a full lineup programmed by a guest musician -- has bounced around the area a bit in its attempts to establish a New York branch. For three years it was at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N.Y., and last year it moved to Asbury Park, N.J., in part because Kutsher's -- often called the last of the Borscht Belt resorts -- was in too poor a condition to continue, the organizers said. But attendance at both places was also disappointing.
CHAVIS--Sidney. Shelter Rock Tennis Club mourns his loss and extends sympathy to his family.

8 P.M. (HBO) IN TIME (2011) The director Andrew Niccol (''Gattaca'') imagines a future in which everyone stops aging at 25, after which a glowing green digital clock on the left forearm starts counting down 365 days and stops for good when those days run out -- unless people buy more time. Justin Timberlake plays Will, who has managed to add three years to his life, only to watch the cost of breathing keep going up. Matt Bomer is Henry Hamilton, a rich 105-year-old stranger who transfers a century to Will, thus ending his own life. Amanda Seyfried, above with Mr. Timberlake, is Sylvia, a babe whose father (Vincent Kartheiser, of ''Mad Men'') helps control the global time market. And Cillian Murphy is the head of the policelike Timekeepers, who blame Will for Henry's death. ''There's plenty to enjoy about that genre standard, which, with the help of the cinematographer Roger Deakins (shooting in digital), Mr. Niccol transforms into a neonoir gaudily washed in green and gold,'' Manohla Dargis wrote of what she called ''a couple-on-the-run flick'' in The New York Times. ''But then the characters open their mouths and start going on about minutes and hours, clocks and watches, and their time running out and not having enough time, and where's my time, don't waste my time, that time will get you killed, brother can you spare some time because, well, I'm all out.'' 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Tim O'Brien examines charges that some federal prosecutors have wrongfully withheld material evidence from defense lawyers.

LONDON - Long renowned as the center of global money flows, deal making and - above all - discretion, London's financial center has become a hub to a different form of activity of late: financial scandal and behavior beyond the pale. Rogue traders working out of the London offices of the American International Group, UBS and JPMorgan Chase have rung up billions of dollars of losses in recent years. Attempts to manipulate an important interest rate - the London interbank offered rate, or Libor - originated on the trading floors of some of the biggest and oldest banks in London, like Barclays. Government officials on both sides of the Atlantic are now investigating how many other big banks joined in.

COLIN--Justin Stanford, born, December 31, 1924; died July 12, 2012 in Santa Fe, NM. U.S. Army Air Corps 1943-46; Harvard College, A.B., cum laude, 1949; Yale Law School, LL.B., 1952. Prestigious career at U.S. Department of Justice; general partner, Lazard Freres, and senior partner, Colin, Hochstin Co., a brokerage firm he co-founded in 1971. Chairman of the Board, American Ballet Theater, 1974-78. Survived by his wife, Mary Lee Potter Colin; children Laura Colin Klein and Ann Colin Herbst (from a previous marriage); Emily, Justin, and Nicholas Colin; and four grandchildren.

KATZ--Jody Elyachar, 58, of Westchester, NY and Sarasota, FL, who is survived by her beloved parents, Ralph and Alice Elyachar of Scarsdale, NY passed away on Tuesday, July 3, 2012. While in her 30's was employed by Gourmet Magazine as assistant to the chief editor in charge of travel and entertainment. Jody is also survived by her husband, Richard A. Katz, Esq. who is employed by Elyachar Properties LLC as Co-Senior Managing Member, together with her first cousin, Jonathan R. Elyachar of New York City, who serves in the same capacity for the Family Firm. Jody is further survived by her beloved uncle Daniel Elyachar and her beloved aunt Ruth Turner. In addition, she is survived by her sister and brother-in-law Dana and Peter Stahl of Katonah, NY, a sister-in-law, Andrea Elyachar of Overland Park, Kansas, a niece and three nephews, and several first cousins, in addition to her beloved King Charles Cavalier, Mazel. A private service for friends and family was held on Friday July 6, 2012 in Westchester. Anyone wishing to make a donation in Jody's memory should do so to the Humane Society in their respective local area. Thanks is given to the staff and doctors at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. A special thanks is given to Dr. Seth Feldheimer and Dr. Mark B. Stoopler for their individual care and concern given to Jody during her illness.

For 164 years, the granite block marked ''Mexico'' lay mostly undisturbed in the historic Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn. Wooden plaques placed to commemorate the men buried around it had rotted away. A low-hanging tree grew above it. With its circular rough patch, iron urn and cryptic inscription, the block was a mystery to the cemetery workers who came across it several years ago. It took some searching through cemetery archives for the cemetery historian, Jeff Richman, to determine that 10 men - 8 veterans of the Mexican-American War and 2 who brought their bodies back to New York in 1848 - were buried around the granite block.

PAKLEDINAZ--Martin. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of the distinguished costume designer Martin Pakledinaz. At the Met he designed costumes for new productions of Lucia di Lammermoor, Rodelinda, Iphigenie en Tauride, and the Met and Juilliard co-production of The Bartered Bride. The company will miss not only his talents but his warm collaborative spirit. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

TRAUB--Marvin. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Joyce Theater are deeply saddened by the passing of Marvin Traub. A devoted friend of The Joyce Theater and lover of dance, his presence will be missed in our theater. Our condolences to his dear wife, Lee.

An article on Friday about a lawsuit challenging Arizona's new abortion limits, set to take effect on Aug. 2, misstated the point at which the 20-week count begins before an abortion is prohibited by the new law. It is prohibited once 20 weeks have passed since a woman's last menstrual period, not since her last missed period.

Kerry Kennedy, the former wife of Gov.Andrew M. Cuomo, was arrested and charged with driving while impaired by drugs on Friday morning after she collided with a tractor-trailer in Westchester County and left the accident scene, the State Police said. Ms. Kennedy, through a spokesman, denied the charge.

A bad weather-related air travel experience I had recently prompted me to research ways to mitigate the damage caused by storms when traveling. As with my post last week about obtaining good seats, this sort of thing is second nature to those who fly often for business. But for those who may be rusty, it's time to bone up on travel tactics ahead of summer vacation season. The background: After a weekend in New York City last month, I had some meetings on Monday before I was scheduled to fly home from La Guardia Airport. But a storm blew in, and I received an e-mail from my airline saying my 7 p.m. flight was delayed by two hours. That would mean I'd miss my connection in Atlanta and wouldn't get home (to Arkansas) that night.

MobiTV Inc., the maker of software that lets smartphone users watch live television, withdrew its plans for an initial public offering, citing ''unfavorable market conditions.'' The California-based company, which filed for a $75 million offering in August, requested in a letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission Friday that the filing be withdrawn immediately. MobiTV has never turned a profit, according to regulatory filings, recording a net loss of $11.8 million last year even as revenue rose 27 percent to $85.1 million. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

SONDHEIMER--Ruth. A lovely lady. Our condolences to Eve and Ernest, to Doug, Rod and James. Morris, Marni and Adrienne

Say you see an advertisement boasting that new replacement windows can save you ''up to'' 47 percent on your home heating and cooling bills. Would you then expect that the new windows would save you, personally, almost half of what you've been paying for energy costs? If your answer is yes, you may be guilty of wishful thinking - perhaps not surprising, given the heat wave that has gripped much of the country. And you have some company. The Federal Trade Commission recently commissioned a test that found that many consumers apparently dismiss the ''up to'' qualifier, and believe the product will save them the maximum possible amount.
METZ--Charles E.,September 11, 1942 - July 4, 2012. Renowned scientist and educator in radiological imaging science. Beloved father and friend. Services August 27, 2012 University of Chicago.

With the demotion of Rangers to the third division of Scotland's domestic league system Friday, many have speculated - to a precise and reasonable degree - that Scottish soccer, as an ecosystem for professional sports, will cease to exist. That revenue will dry up, the television companies will walk away and the fans will no longer feel the allure of just one Glaswegian giant in town each year. And they may be right. Celtic and Rangers, famously (and sometimes infamously) known as the Old Firm, not only represent two clubs, a city, or even a sporting culture, but an industry that has been running through thick and thin for the best part of 124 years that now finds itself with little time to get back on its feet.

A pop music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a Guthrie family reunion celebrating the 100th anniversary of Woody Guthrie's birth, at Central Park Summerstage on Sunday, misspelled the given name of one of Arlo Guthrie's daughters. She is Cathy Guthrie, not Carthy.

The cover article this weekend about travel advice from frequent travelers in Silicon Valley refers incompletely to the legal issues surrounding one such tip, by the author Tim Ferriss, who discussed packing a starter pistol and declaring it at check-in as a way to insure that a checked bag is not lost. While Transportation Security Administration rules allow such items if properly declared and locked, some local jurisdictions, including New York City, have stricter rules. (A spokesman for the New York Police Department said starter pistols are illegal without a permit.)

GLASGALL--Elaine Lasser Meyer, 87, passed away Thursday, July 12, in her Palm Beach home. An avid bridge player and high-heel wearer, Elaine was a beloved wife to the late Horace "Eddie" Meyer and the late Hyman Glasgall, and sister to the late Kenneth Lasser. She was a loving mother to Douglas and his late wife Jill, and the late Brett and his wife Patricia and also a caring and generous grandmother to Sara, Damon, and Elizabeth Meyer, and Emily Jacobs and husband Daniel - and an affectionate "great-grandmother" to the four-legged Isabella. Elaine had an unceasing desire to see every corner of the world, and her eyes would light up when she spoke of her journeys. She always returned bearing gifts and stories. A graveside service will be Sunday, 11:30am. at Mount Pleasant Cemetery.

Before the Library of America releases its two-volume collection ''American Science Fiction: Nine Classic Novels of the 1950s'' later this year it's preparing to take its own step into the future: on Tuesday, it will launch an online companion for the books, offering additional background and commentaries on the novels in the collection, as well as audio and video content and social-media interactivity. The Library of America, which made the announcement on Friday, said it was the first time it had offered these kinds of digital enhancements for one of its publications. Among the bonus materials it said would be found starting Tuesday at the companion site, www.loa.org/sciencefiction, are the ''Change War'' short stories of Fritz Leiber (whose novel ''The Big Time'' is included in the print collection); original book covers from the 1950s; film and radio adaptations; and appreciations by writers like Neil Gaiman, William Gibson, Connie Willis, Peter Straub and Michael Dirda. The online companion is curated by Gary K. Wolfe, who also edited the ''American Science Fiction'' collection.

Feinstein's, the popular high-end supper club at the Loews Regency Hotel in Manhattan, will close on Dec. 31 after 13 years. Beginning at the first of the year, the hotel will undergo an extensive renovation, hotel management said Friday.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn. - Brendan Hansen was in the middle of an interview at a pre-Olympics swimming camp Thursday when a scene a few yards away caught his eye. His 17-year-old teammate, Missy Franklin, spotted her father, Dick, who was visiting from Colorado, and ran into his embrace. Watching them hug, Hansen said, ''That's awesome.'' Hansen's wife, Martha, is expecting the couple's first child later this year. It thrills Hansen to know that no matter how he fares in London, he can count on 2012 being a watershed year.

AN unusual duplex co-op at 88 Central Park West, reconfigured in 2007 to capture treetop and cityscape vistas to the north and west, sold for $19.5 million and was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records. Located in the Brentmore -- an address whose residents past and present have included Robert De Niro, Sting, Laurie Tisch, Celeste Holm, and, almost, Matthew Broderick and Sarah Jessica Parker -- the fully renovated 6,000-square-foot apartment offers five bedrooms, five and a half bathrooms and staff quarters, and is accompanied by a formidable $11,205 monthly maintenance fee. The light-filled living spaces are concentrated on the eighth floor, with the bedrooms and a 30-by-20-foot family room on the ninth. Oversized windows distinguish both floors.

COLIN--Justin Stanford, born, December 31, 1924; died July 12, 2012 in Santa Fe, NM. U.S. Army Air Corps 1943-46; Harvard College, A.B., cum laude, 1949; Yale Law School, LL.B., 1952. Prestigious career at U.S. Department of Justice; general partner, Lazard Freres, and senior partner, Colin, Hochstin Co., a brokerage firm he co-founded in 1971. Chairman of the Board, American Ballet Theater, 1974-78. Survived by his wife, Mary Lee Potter Colin; children Laura Colin Klein and Ann Colin Herbst (from a previous marriage); Emily, Justin, and Nicholas Colin; and four grandchildren.

SMUKLER--Joseph. The Board of Trustees and the staff of the National Museum of American Jewish History, Philadelphia, mourn the passing of our cherished Trustee. Joe was an extraordinary community leader who generously supported many causes in deed and in action. His contributions to the Museum are but one reflection of his commitment to the history and the future of American Jewry. Joe will be profoundly missed by all who had the privilege to work with him. We will forever be grateful for his enduring legacy. Heartfelt condolences to our beloved Connie and the family. May his memory be a blessing. Ivy L. Barsky, Director & CEO Philip M. Darivoff & Ron Rubin, Co-Chairmen

A report last Sunday about the marriage of Atia Abawi and Conor Powell misstated the middle initial of the bridegroom's father. He is John M. Powell, not John R.. The report also misidentified the Virginia law firm where the bridegroom's father was a partner before retiring. It is Powell & Cheyney in Vienna -- not Gabeler, Battocchi & Powell in Fairfax.

McCALL--James Wilson James Wilson McCall, of Hillsborough, California, on July 13, 2012, after a courageous struggle with cancer. Jim was the beloved husband of Jennifer Jordan McCall; devoted father of Peter Lewis Livingston McCall and Andrew James McCall; stepfather of Caroline Debevoise Clark and Hillary Sage Clark; son of Lewis Livingston McCall, Jr. and Dixann Wilson McCall; and brother of Mary Margaret McCall. Jim was knowledgeable in many subjects from sports, to history, politics, photography, music and Formula 1 racing. Jim was an avid reader, particularly of American history and international relations. Jim was always fun to be with. An entertaining conversationalist, Jim's wit and humor will be deeply missed. His family and friends admired him greatly for his insight and sensitivity, and for his thoughtfulness, modesty and courage. Jim set an example with his intellectual curiosity, dynamic yet gentlemanly manner and high moral character. He was a trusted advisor to many, and a loyal friend. Jim especially enjoyed advising his four children, and was proud that all four of them attended Princeton University. Jim took special pride in his sons and their accomplishments, both in sports and academics. Born in Norman, Oklahoma March 10, 1953, Jim graduated from the University of Oklahoma in 1974 with a B.A. in Letters with Honors, in History, Philosophy and English. Jim completed his undergraduate degree in five semesters, was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and was a Rhodes Scholar nominee from the State of Oklahoma. Jim earned a J.D. from the University of Oklahoma in 1977, where he was a member of the Law Review. In 1974 Jim attended Oxford University as a Scholarship Resident at University College in Economics. Jim earned his M.B.A. in 1984 from Harvard Business School and served as a member of the Faculty Judicial Review Board. Jim's work experience included McKinsey, Goldman Sachs and Security Pacific/Bank of America Venture Capital Group. Jim joined Intel Corporation in Santa Clara, California in 1997 where he remained to the present. He became an Assistant Treasurer for Mergers, Acquisitions & Strategic Investments and Managing Director, Digital Enterprise and Digital Home for Intel Capital Corporation, the venture capital arm of Intel. Jim was a talented athlete and sports enthusiast throughout his life. As a thirteen-year-old, Jim shot even par in a golf tournament; in high school he played football, golf and ran track, holding the State of Oklahoma record for the 220- and 440-yard dash. At the University of Oklahoma Jim played golf and followed professional baseball. Jim's love of golf stayed with him throughout his life. Jim was a member of the San Francisco Golf Club and Burlingame Country Club, San Francisco, the Merion Golf Club, Ardmore, Pennsylvania and The Creek Club, Locust Valley, New York. Jim's family and friends loved to play golf with him, not only because of his entertaining and friendly manner, but also because of his shot-making finesse. Jim gently offered tips to those who requested them, and was always a patient teacher. Jim was keenly devoted to his family and to the memory of his predecessors. Jim was a proud member of The Society of the Cincinnati, whose members are descendants of the Officers who served in General George Washington's Revolutionary Army. He belonged to The Society of Colonial Wars, The General Society Sons of the American Revolution, The Order of St. John of Jerusalem, the General Society of the War of 1812, the Order of Indian Wars of the United States, and the Aztec Club of 1847 Military Society of the Mexican War. Jim's warmth, enthusiasm, and intellect will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, July 17, 2012 at 4:00 p.m. at First Presbyterian Church of Burlingame, 1500 Easton Drive, Burlingame, CA 94010. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Cancer Center, Stanford University Medical Center, 875 Blake Wilbur Drive, Stanford, CA 94305, ATTN: Dr. Sandy Srinivas for research in kidney cancer.

NISANTASI is Istanbul's trendiest shopping district, as well as the birthplace of the Nobel Prize-winning author Orhan Pamuk. And Abdi Ipekci Caddesi is its most glamorous street, though, like much of Mr. Pamuk's work, it has a dark side. It is named after Abdi Ipekci, a Turkish journalist assassinated here in 1979 by Mehmet Agca, who later tried to kill Pope John Paul II; a memorial marks the spot where Mr. Ipekci was gunned down. Today, though, Istanbul's fashion set flocks to the international names on the street, including Prada, Cartier and Louis Vuitton. In recent years, many high-end local designers have set up shop in alleys off the main street -- perfect destinations for shoppers tired of tacky tourist trinkets. KAVITHA RAO
