GARCIA--Anthony J.,passed away July 12, 2012. Anthony was the son of Fulgence and Josephine (Marraro) Garcia. He was born in New York City, NY on July 31, 1946. Anthony attended Marquette University from 1963-1965. He served in the U.S. Army from 1965 to 1967. Anthony was proprietor of Med Com Consultants for many years. He was currently employed as senior account director for Pharm Methods in Trevose Pa. Anthony loved people, theater, and was a collector of classic movies and books. Anthony is survived by his son Brandon J. Garcia (Jennifer), his sister Louise A. Freed (Richard), nephews Thomas, Michael, and Anthony Strouse, nieces Teresa Cannon, Kristina Carlton, as well as their children. As per Anthony's request the funeral will be private. Friends will be notified of a memorial service at a later date. Donation's may be made to the American Cancer Society.

The story of Alex White and his involvement in the Kathryn Johnston incident underscores a history of questionable behavior from the city's police force. As an Atlanta native, I think of the raid on the Atlanta Eagle nightclub, where patrons were illegally detained, and of the visiting college professor, Felipe Fernández-Armesto, who was manhandled and then incarcerated after being stopped for jaywalking in the downtown area. It is unfortunate that an international city with aspirations for education, business and the arts will not address the issue of an undisciplined and overly aggressive police force that includes corrupt individuals. Cities like Atlanta should open themselves to scrutiny and exhibit the will to right problems within the system. CAMERON KENNEDY, Atlanta

An article in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section last Sunday, about real estate investment trusts, misstated the rating that Citi Investment Research gave to one REIT, Community Office Properties. It was a sell rating, not a buy. The article also misidentified the owner of the Empire State Building. It is Empire State Building Associates L.L.C., not ESB Trust.

GETMAN--Kendall G.,of Edgehill in Stamford, CT on July 10, 2012. Born October 17, 1915 in Cortland, NY to Arthur and Fredella Babcock Getman, raised in Albany, NY, graduate of Alfred University. He served in the US Army from 1942-1945, and raised his family in Darien, CT, where he was an active member of the Noroton Presbyterian Church for 65 years. Kendall was an acquisitions editor for science textbooks at Wiley & Sons, then Holt, Reinhart & Winston until retirement in 1980. He was a loving husband to Deborah Brennemann Getman (1915-1999) for 58 years, and father of two loving daughters, Barbara Getman Mack of Weld, ME and Ann Getman of Cambridge, MA. A Memorial Service will be held at Noroton Presbyterian Chapel, Darien on Tuesday, July 31, 2011 at 11:00am.
HARRISON TUDOR $1,699,000

MACKENZIE--Thayer Mills, of Washington, DC, died on June 24, 2012. He was born in New York on January 19, 1922 and attended Milton Academy, Harvard College and received his MD at Johns Hopkins. In 1953 he married Carolyn Suratt who survives him.

GUTTMAN--William M.,of Palm Beach, FL, and New York, NY, died on July 13, 2012. He is survived by his wife Susan, his daughters Jennifer Guttman Schlau and Catherine Guttman-McCabe, and four grandchildren; Steven, Alexa, Anna, and Abigail. Born April 15, 1941, in Manhattan, he grew up on Long Island. He was the General Counsel and a senior executive of Time Inc., where he was responsible for all domestic and internal legal affairs of Time and its worldwide divisions and subsidiaries. He served as the chief executive officer of the Palm Beach Civic Association from 1997 to 2005. He also served on the Town of Palm Beach Charter Review Commission from 1997 to 1999, as Chairman of the Palm Beach Planning and Zoning Commission, and on the Board of Directors of the Palm Beach Fellowship of Christians and Jews, the Citizens Association of Palm Beach and the Graham-Eckes Palm Beach Academy Foundation. In 2005, he was presented with the Anti-Defamation League's Distinguished Community Service Award for promoting harmony and understanding in Palm Beach, and in 2006, he received the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce's Pride of Palm Beach Award. A former adjunct professor at Pace University Law School in White Plains, NY and Columbia University Business School, he received both his undergraduate and law degrees from Columbia with honors. He lived with gusto, wit, and passion. His memory will remain indelible with andhis indomitable spirit carried on by his family, friends, and any who knew him. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NY, NY on July 15, 2012 at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations can be sent to Columbia University Medical Center, 100 Haven Avenue, Suite 29D, NY, NY 10032-2626.

An article on June 17 about Hillary Rodham Clinton misspelled the surname of a foreign-service officer who wrote an article mentioned by Clinton. He is Aaron D. Snipe, not Snipes. It also misstated which round of the United States-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue Clinton attended this year. It was the fourth round, not the third.

GILMARTIN--Christina Kelley, of Milton, MA. Pioneering scholar of Chinese women's history at Northeastern University. Memorial Service at First Parish, 535 Canton Avenue, Milton MA, Thursday, July 19th, at 7pm.

HEYER--Ethel Friedman, 88, passed away peacefully at her home on July 7. For 40 years she was the devoted wife of Harold K. Heyer. An elegant lady, a devoted mother and proud grandmother, she is survived by her sons, Steven and Andrew (Mindy) and grandchildren James, William, Peter, Kate, Harris and David. Ethel was born in Livingston Manor, NY and attended Syracuse University, prior to making her permanent residence in New York. She will be remembered with love. A private service was held on July 9. Donations to Disabled American Veterans (DAV.org) will be welcomed.

An article last Sunday about the organic foods industry misstated the name of one such brand owned by Hain Celestial. It is Health Valley, not Healthy Valley. The article also erroneously included one company among independent businesses acquired by big corporations by 2002, when regulations for the organic industry were put in place. Honest Tea did not cease to become independent until 2011 when Coca-Cola completed a years-long acquisition of it. And the article misspelled the name of a substance approved for use in organic foods. It is docosahexaenoic acid algae oil, not docosahexzenoic.

WHEN Sara Cedar Miller became the official photographer of Central Park in 1984, the work of the Central Park Conservancy, the nonprofit group created to maintain and run the park, had barely begun. Belvedere Castle, which had been boarded up and covered with graffiti, was newly restored, along with the Dairy and Sheep Meadow. ''There were 800 acres to go,'' Ms. Miller recalled. ''It was in pretty rough shape.'' Since then, she has documented an overhaul that has attracted international notice and reclaimed Central Park as the lungs of the city, the people's backyard and a tourist destination. The conservancy has raised hundreds of millions of dollars from residents, corporations and foundations, and has restored bridges and buildings, gardens and lawns, fountains and monuments. Ms. Miller's photographs are on view through Aug. 4 at the Leica Gallery, at 670 Broadway, in a show called ''Transforming Central Park: A Celebration of the Central Park Conservancy.''
TRITEL--Liz Daichman, died after a sudden illness in New Haven, CT on June 20, 2012. Family and friends will greatly miss her warmth, generosity, wisdom and wit.

FOR Carol Channing, ''the safest place in the world to be is center stage.'' And that's where she was determined to stand from childhood when, delivering The Christian Science Monitor to San Francisco theaters with her mother, Ms. Channing realized she was ''walking on hallowed ground.'' In ''CAROL CHANNING: LARGER THAN LIFE,'' Monday at 6:30 p.m. on Showtime, the filmmaker Dori Berinstein worships at the altar of the theatrical funny girl, now 91, who soared to stardom in 1949 as the diamond-loving Lorelei Lee in ''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes'' and performed her signature role, the widowed matchmaker Dolly Levi, which she originated in the Broadway hit ''Hello, Dolly!,'' more than 5,000 times. The documentary also chronicles the genesis of the public persona -- a madcap human bobblehead doll with saucer eyes fringed in fake lashes, outsized lips and a megawatt smile, and that voice, somewhere between Betty Boop and a fog horn -- that spawned a thousand imitators. ''You're the best Carol Channing I've ever seen,'' a stranger once told her, assuming she was a drag queen, before asking who she really was. ''A truck driver from Toledo,'' came Ms. Channing's reply.
INTERLAKEN HUNTING LODGE $799,000
METZ--Charles E.,September 11, 1942 - July 4, 2012. Renowned scientist and educator in radiological imaging science. Beloved father and friend. Services August 27, 2012 University of Chicago.

As night falls, I watch from the window as flashes from Tuskar Rock Lighthouse become visible. It does its two flashes and then stops as though to take a breath. Until I was 12 and my family stopped coming to this remote place on the coast of Ireland in the summer, I watched the lighthouse too, from a different window not far from here. Every day now as I walk down to the strand I pass the house we lived in then. Someone else is there now, but no matter what happens, the room that I can almost peer into from the lane remains my parents' bedroom, with the iron bed and the cement floor. I suppose it must seem smaller now that I am bigger. And the smell of clover in the field before the cliff is the same smell, although it must be different clover. Maybe the smell is similar and not the same, but because I am trying all day to dream that world of 1967 into existence, it is sometimes closer now than it ever was.

Five states had multiple representatives on the United States roster for last Sunday's All-Star Futures Game in Kansas City. The first four were not surprising: California, Florida, Texas and Georgia. The fifth state was Connecticut. Matt Barnes, a Red Sox pitching prospect, and Mike Olt, a Rangers infield prospect, grew up there and stayed for college, at the University of Connecticut. Olt was drafted 49th over all in 2010, and Barnes 19th over all last year.

SALVATORE FERRAGAMO and the label's cool 1970s-style logo are vintage-store staples: few insoles are as recognizable as the one that lines the brand's shoes, and even fewer shoes feel as stylish and nostalgic, still. Knowing this, the Italian house recently consulted with its archives in Palazzo Spini Feroni in order to reintroduce a select group of crocodile kitten heels with its prefall collection. ''What I want to create is accessories and garments that will never lose their allure,'' says Ferragamo's creative director, Massimiliano Giornetti. ''What really can be defined as 'classic' will never lose an intrinsic message of modernity,'' he says. So spare them the arrivedercis, please. Salvatore Ferragamo green crocodile kitten heels, $4,500. At select Salvatore Ferragamo boutiques; (800) 628-8916. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

RENE--Denise. The Josef and Anni Albers Foundation acknowledges with sadness the death of our beloved friend Denise Rene. At age ninety-nine, she died as she lived: with courage and grace. She was unique among art dealers in the courage with which she defended the artistic approach about which she was most passionate. She helped introduce the vision of Arp, Le Corbusier, Anni Albers, and Josef Albers to the French public in her two galleries in Paris, and, when she had a gallery in New York, was the first to present the work of many European geometric abstractionists in the United States. She was a splendid and loyal friend, and a woman of profound human insight. She hosted a meeting of the Resistance, with Sartre attending, in 1943 in the middle of Paris, determining that no one would suspect such an event in her gallery on the rue La Boetie because the neighborhood was so heavily occupied by German soldiers; she never lost her bravery or panache. We loved her deeply. Nicholas Fox Weber, Executive Director; his wife Katharine and daughters Lucy and Charlotte; Brenda Danilowitz, Chief Curator

BAILEY--Robert. The NYU Department of Music notes the passing of its long-time colleague, Robert Bailey, The Carroll and Milton Petrie Professor of Music Emeritus in the Faculty of Arts and Science. He was a distinguished scholar and teacher, whose students hold important positions in major American universities and opera houses, whose writings have profoundly shaped the discourse of musicology. His like does not come along often in each generation.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Julie Bosman with notes from the field and Greg Cowles with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. BY THE BOOK An expanded version of our interview with Dave Eggers, the author of ''A Hologram for the King.''

IN 1980 the director Francis Ford Coppola -- having weathered the logistical ordeal of shooting ''Apocalypse Now'' in the Philippines -- was ready for a change. His next project, '' ONE FROM THE HEART'' (1982), playing Sunday at the Museum of the Moving Image as part of its indispensable See It Big! series, was a complete reversal: a deliriously fantastical confection, evoking MGM musicals and reveling in studio artifice. The production designer Dean Tavoularis recreated a glittering Las Vegas Strip; the brilliant Vittorio Storaro (''The Conformist'') was the cinematographer; Kenny Ortega (''High School Musical'') choreographed dance sequences; Tom Waits sang with Crystal Gayleon the soundtrack and composed the lush, Oscar-nominated score. The story -- a working-class couple (Teri Garr and Frederic Forrest) bicker and separate (naturally, it's Independence Day), then reconsider -- may be thin. But Ms. Garr, Raul Julia (as a dashing Latin lover) and Nastassja Kinski (as a beguiling circus acrobat) are in top form. Audiences stayed away, evidently not in a romantic mood. Don't make the same mistake. Catch this gem on a screen worthy of its scale. 3 p.m., 36-01 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens; (718)777-6888, movingimage.us.
EAST VILLAGE CO-OP $1,300,000

AT least since 1998, when the United States Olympic Committee first approached sportswear companies to liven up the look of its team, American athletes have worn ceremonial outfits that were manufactured in places far from home. For a decade, almost everything they wore to represent the United States at the opening and closing ceremonies was actually being designed and produced in Canada, by the sportswear company Roots, until the American company Ralph Lauren won those rights in 2008. But an ABC News report this week that pointed out that the Ralph Lauren uniforms the athletes will wear in London, for the ceremonies on July 27, are made in China has prompted an unusual degree of outrage, at least in Congress. Senator Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader, said on Thursday, ''I think they should take all the uniforms, put them in a big pile and burn them and start all over again.''

In last Sunday's Big City column, ''New Frontier for Tourists: Your Home,'' Ginia Bellafante wrote about a new service that lets visitors rent high-end houses and apartments when their regular occupants are elsewhere. Readers responded to that column and to the cover article, ''He Takes the Village,'' Rebecca Flint Marx's profile of Ben Shaoul, a controversial landlord and real estate developer particularly active in the East Village, on NYTimes.com. A selection of their comments is below. Yes, riding the No. 6 at rush hour ... but not going to work. Taking a drawing class because, as all know, that is what we do when we first arrive in town. A town house in the West Village or a loft in TriBeCa, but two examples of affluent life in the big town. I love the tourists, save those who seem to walk five in a row somewhere on Broadway in the 40s. I love them spending their money, shopping at local businesses and getting out of here. But please spare me that any of the above is ''experiential'' New York living. It's great that people can afford such accommodations, but if they go home telling people they came here and lived like one, they'll be lying.

NATHANSON--Sylvie. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Sylvie Nathanson, our devoted long-time member and generous benefactor of the Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School. To her daughter Nadine Dugue and the family our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

In December 1944, Albert Camus, then editor of Combat, the main newspaper of the French Resistance, made Jean-Paul Sartre an offer he couldn't refuse: the job of American correspondent. Sartre, who had long dreamed about the United States, was delighted to get out of post-Liberation Paris. Camus himself would make the trip soon after, only to return with a characteristically different set of political, philosophical and personal impressions. Both would be kept under close surveillance by the F.B.I., who naturally suspected all philosophers of being subversives. In some sense, existentialism was going home. Twentieth-century French philosophy was not immune to the metaphysical turmoil of the United States at the end of the 19th century. More significantly, both Camus and Sartre had borrowed from 20th-century writers like Faulkner, Hemingway and Dos Passos -- and, of course, from the films of Humphrey Bogart. Camus, in particular, cultivated the trench coat with the upturned collar.

Survived by long time companion, John McCollum, Scottsdale; brother Ian, London; and countless friends with whom, given a choice, he would now be indulging his love of music, theater, books and witty conversation. Iechyd da!

BIANCHI--Richard, "Dick". A prolific Production Designer/Art Director for television and film, died at his home in Connecticut on June 30th. The cause was Multiple Myeloma. He was 84 years old. Born in Somerville, MA, he graduated from Arlington High School, and pursued an interest in art to the Massachusetts College of Art and Design, graduating with a BFA in 1950. After teaching for two months in Concord, NH, he went to Korea with the 45th Infantry Division, and went on to work in Military Government. On the G.I. Bill, he attended Tufts University, graduating with a Master's of Education in Arts and Sciences. Art won over education and, thanks to a mentor in the Tufts Theater Department, he went on to the Yale School of Drama. He graduated with an MFA in 1957, becoming a member of the United Scenic Artists Union that same year. Other than erasing Uncle Wethbee's drawings and weather reports from a board used on air the night before, little is known about his first job at NBC, including the game show "Haggis Baggis". Over the next ten years, he designed many Off-Broadway plays, as well as countless television commercials. One of his last being Cora's Country Store for Maxwell House Coffee, with Margaret Hamilton. In 1969, he designed his first feature film "Puzzle of a Downfall Child", with Faye Dunaway, followed by "Voices" with Amy Irving, and was the New York Art Director for Lady Liberty, with Sophia Loren. Some of his movies for TV were "Skokie", with Danny Kaye, "The Deadliest Season", with Michael Moriarty, and two Kojak Specials, with Telly Savalis. His series for television included "The Bloodhound Gang", three episodes for the CBS series "The American Parade", "Nurse", with Michael Learned and "The Equalizer", with Edward Woodward. During a break in that show's third season, he was asked to do a pilot for CBS called "Law and Order". Two years later, it began shooting for NBC, which he designed for the next six years. His love of opera took him to San Francisco to design Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro", and his love of painting found him on the coast of Maine for a month every year in the summer. As work kept interrupting these interludes, he finally built a year-round cottage by the sea on an island near Boothbay Harbor. He is survived by his brother and sister-in-law Robert and Erika Bianchi, a niece, Jane Bianchi, and his wife, Maeve McGuire. Gifts may be made in his name to The Massachusetts College of Art and Design, 621 Huntington Ave., Boston, MA 02115, or The Yale School of Drama P. O. Box 208244, New Haven, CT., 06520.
KRIEGEL--Stanley. The Brooklyn Philharmonic family mourns the passing of our friend and founding board member. We all are the better for knowing Stanley and will miss him greatly.

TRAUB--Marvin, died peacefully at home on July 11. He was 87. He and his wife Lee were married for 63 cloudless years. He leaves behind his devoted children, Andrew, James and Margaret and his grandchildren, Rebecca, Rachel, Abigail and Alexander. As chairman and chief executive of Bloomingdale's, Marvin was one of the great merchants and retailers of his day, widely admired, honored and copied. But what was perhaps more remarkable is that he achieved his extraordinary success without ever making an enemy or speaking ill of a rival. He was an unfailingly gracious and generous man who didn't have a mean bone in his body. He was optimistic to a fault, and a font of enthusiasm. His favorite word was "marvelous." Marvin was born in New York City and graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School. He enlisted in the Army, and was wounded during action outside Metz. His doctors feared that he would never walk again, but after more than a year of intense therapy, Marvin regained full mobility and never walked with a limp. He was awarded the Purple Heart and three Bronze Battle Stars, and was later given the keys to the city of Metz. After graduating from Harvard in 1947, Marvin enrolled at Harvard Business School and graduated in the famous class of 1949. He met Lee, a student of modern dance and a Smith College student, in 1947, and they married on September 2, 1948. He went to work at Bloomingdale's and rose rapidly up the executive ladder, becoming CEO in 1978. Under his tenure, Bloomingdale's became a cultural mecca; he helped turn retailing into a form of theatre and entertainment. One of the hallmarks of Marvin's career was mentoring many executives who went on to become department store CEOs, as well as hiring, supporting and promoting many women executives. Retiring from Bloomingdale's at age 66, Marvin was ready for another career. For the next 21 years, he ran Marvin Traub Associates, working with many of the designers he had known for so many years as well as retailers and developers all over the world. Marvin loved his life; and "working," for him, was another word for "living." Marvin was deeply involved with a wide range of charities and institutions, including Harvard, where he and Lee sponsored scholarships for middle-income students. He and Lee were the center of each other's lives. Marvin was terrifically proud of everything his children accomplished. He was a loving and attentive father-in-law to Lois Traub, Elizabeth Easton and Phyllis Dicker. He considered almost everyone he ever met a friend--and the feeling was mutual. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Marvin and Lee Traub Flexible Financial Aid Fund at Harvard, or to Pin Down Bladder Cancer. A funeral service will be held at Central Synagogue at 10am on Sunday, July 15.

A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the Paris Opera Ballet, which has been performing in the United States this summer, misidentified the woman shown dancing with Stéphane Bullion in ''Orpheus and Eurydice.'' She is Marie-Agnès Gillot, not Alice Renavand, who is also a member of the ballet.

As regulators ramp up their global investigation into the manipulation of interest rates, the Justice Department has identified potential criminal wrongdoing by big banks and individuals at the center of the scandal. The department's criminal division is building cases against several financial institutions and their employees, including traders at Barclays, the British bank, according to government officials close to the case who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the investigation is continuing. The authorities expect to file charges against at least one bank later this year, one of the officials said.

The news reports, quick to make the cover of almost every tabloid, had a familiar ring: The marriage of Tom Cruise to a high-profile actress was coming to an end with a startling swiftness. But there was a decided difference this time around. Last time, in 2001, Tom Cruise suddenly announced that his 10-year marriage to Nicole Kidman was over, apparently catching her by surprise. This time it was Mr. Cruise, shooting a movie in Iceland and about to celebrate his 50th birthday, who was caught unaware when Katie Holmes announced that she was ending their five-year marriage. A look back at two Mrs. Cruises. STUART EMMRICH

THE inevitable response to the increasing number of blogs and Web sites that fetishize home design is the onslaught of those dedicated to yanking the vintage Berber rug out from underneath the entire enterprise. Take Catalog Living, the comedian Molly Erdman's ''glimpse into the exciting world of the people living in your catalogs.'' The people to which the title refers are Gary and Elaine, an imaginary couple who dutifully carry on their day-to-day existence in the overstyled pages of West Elm and Pottery Barn, right down to the strategically -- or more to the point, incomprehensibly -- placed buckets of starfish, gargantuan balls of twine and faux vintage wire bird cages stuffed full of books. ''Catalog Living at Its Most Absurd'' ($18, Plume Original), out this month, follows Gary and Elaine on all-new adventures in domestic ridiculousness. (''Half past Z!? Elaine, I asked you to tell me when it was quarter to Y!'' reads the caption for the photo above.) Not all is bliss, of course. When it comes to the taxidermied elephant, Elaine puts her foot down. ''Yes Gary, another brilliant installation in your 'literal metaphors' series,'' she says. ''Now get that thing back to the zoo before my book club arrives.'' ALIX BROWNE

GOODMAN--Roger B. Beloved father of Peter and David, father-in-law of Debbie, grandfather of Leo and Stephen. Friday, at Atria Assisted Living in Plainview, NY. He lived a long, rich, full life. He was married for 61 years to the former Laura Rosenblum, a teacher, school librarian, and just as high-spirited. She died in 2003. He retired in 1972 as chairman of the English Department of Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, and spent the rest of his years writing poetry, trying various odd ventures, enjoying himself and making everyone around him smile and laugh. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he attended Townsend Harris Hall and the City College of New York, where he earned bachelors and masters degrees in English. He served in World War II as an officer in the field artillery and then as a teacher. Recalled during the Korean War, he was a member of the ROTC faculty at CCNY. He loved the arts, literature and the theater especially. He was a founder of the Roundabout Theater Company, and appeared in their earliest productions. He was profoundly enamored of Shakespeare, especially "Hamlet," though he thought the Bard treated Richard III unfairly. The family is sitting shiva Sunday, July 15, at Peter Goodman's home in Syosset. There will be a Memorial Service 11am Monday, July 16, at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64th St., New York. Contributions in lieu of flowers, may be sent to Stuyvesant High School Alumni Association P.O. Box 3531 New York, NY 10008-3531, in memory of Roger B. Goodman, for the English Department.

JUST as the name implies, ''People Who Work Here,'' on view at David Zwirner in Chelsea through Aug. 10, is a group show featuring the work of 16 of the gallery's staff members (pictured below), from the facilities assistant to the inventory manager. ''There is a long tradition of great artists working as art handlers,'' said David Zwirner, citing Jason Rhodes, Damien Hirst and Rirkrit Tiravanija. Mr. Zwirner has long wanted to do a show curated from within the gallery's ranks and believed that they had reached a critical mass of talent. ''I'm just glad I didn't have to pick,'' he said. Those honors went to Chris Rawson and James Morrill, the founders of Rawson Projects in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Mr. Rawson is the archivist for Zwirner, and Mr. Morrill does the gallery's books. While the two did not have a specific aesthetic agenda, they insist that the show was not curated democratically. They set up an open call to the staff for submissions, and only artists with a rigorous working practice could apply. The work cuts across all media, from sound and video to painting and photography, and yet it all ultimately hangs together. And what's more, the two had a large and professional staff at their disposal. ''That has been amazing,'' Mr. Morrill said. 519 West 19th Street. ALIX BROWNE

RADWANER--Irving, age 87, of Riverdale, NY. Passed away peacefully on July 13. Beloved husband of 63 years to Muriel, father to Valerie and Bradley, grandfather to David, Daniel, Jonathan, Joshua, Jake and Rachel. He loved life and his family greatly. We love, miss you very much. Bradley and Risa Radwaner Steven and Valerie Virany

ARCOMANO--Cathryn Buckley, beloved wife of Nicholas, died on June 27. Cathryn was an International artist who lived and worked in Manhattan. She had solo exhibitions in the United States, England, Italy, The Netherlands, Switzerland and Hong Kong. Her paintings were acquired by museums and corporations, including the Brooklyn Museum, Newark Museum, Everson Museum, Gannett Co., Nordstrom, Pfizer, and the Skadden Arps Law Firm. She is represented by the Adamson Gallery in Washington, D.C. She was born in Troy, New York on November 20, 1923, daughter of Catherine Looby and Timothy J. Buckley. Shortly thereafter, her parents moved to the Buckley Ancestral Home Altmar, New York. She was a 1946 graduate of the college of Saint Rose in Albany, NY. Her yearbook described her as "pensive, dreamy...an artist's artist...clever, poetic Cathy". In 1945, she lived in Mexico City and studied art at the University of Mexico. On October 7, 1961, she married Nicholas Arcomano, a New York copyright attorney, at The Lady Chapel in St. Patrick's Cathedral. They celebrated their 50th anniversary at the cathedral last year. After her marriage, she attended the New School in New York City and was awarded the first prize for painting in 1974. In 2010, she and her husband established the Cathryn Buckley Arcomano Lectureship Series in contemporary art at the College of Saint Rose. Sister Wendy Beckett, art critic, and contemplative nun, described Cathryn's work as "strong and delicate...mysterious and subtle...and beautiful" and to those who knew her, it describes Cathryn. A review in "Der Bund" in 2000 praised the "silent magic" of her paintings. A private funeral mass and burial took place on July 3 in Gloversville, New York. Donations in Cathryn's memory may be made to The Breadline for the Poor, The Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West 31st, New York, NY 10001, or The Cathryn B. Arcomano Lectureship, The College of Saint Rose, 432 Western Ave., Albany, NY 12203.

The Big City column last Sunday about visitors to New York City who stay in houses and apartments while the regular occupants are elsewhere referred imprecisely to a 2011 state law aimed at dismantling illegal hotels and certain short-term rentals. While occupants can legally rent out their residences, there are some restrictions; it is not the case that ''you are not breaking the law if you rent out a place you actually live in.''

A report on July 1 about the marriage of Tamara Klajn and John Paul Schnapper-Casteras misstated the venue in which the bridegroom's father, Eric Schnapper, has argued civil rights cases, pro bono. It was before the United States Supreme Court, not in Seattle.

GIVE YOUNG THE GIANT a break. The name is goofy, and not helped by the long nomenclature shadows cast by more successful bands like Foster the People and Cage the Elephant. Its performance at the 2011 MTV Movie Awards was a bit -- shall we say? -- unfocused. It was something like watching icebergs shear off into the sea with a huge splash, a combination of wow and oh dear. In 2010 Young the Giant released its self-titled debut album (on Roadrunner), and it's been oozing along under its own steam, every now and again squeezing out a single -- a couple, like ''Cough Syrup,'' sticky and great -- slowly earning its keep. But the truth is this: Of bands with that absurd name structure, of newish major-label rock bands, of bands who crib shamelessly from the mopers of the late 1980s and early 1990s, Young the Giant is one of the finest. The Smiths and the Cure bubble up through this band's slick, downcast arrangements, which at their most polished recall the Killers, and at their most scuffed, suggest the Walkmen with a bigger budget. And obstacles be damned, it's working: the group's built enough momentum to headline SummerStage. Maybe it can finally get around to being a critic's darling now. 6:30 p.m. Monday, Rumsey Playfield, Central Park, midpark at 70th Street, (212) 360-2777, summerstage.org; sold out.

Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Brooke Boertzel and Shay Lurie misspelled the bridegroom's surname as Laurie in several instances.
BUCH--J. Fredric, 91, beloved father, friend, died July 11, 2012 after a full and interesting life. We will miss him.

CRANE--David L. Age 90, of West Palm Beach FL, and recently of Dalton MA, passed away on July 6, 2012. Son of Aaron and Hannah Cohen, David was a native New Yorker. Often regaling his children with Runyonesque tales of his West Side childhood, he witnessed the building of the George Washington Bridge and he played street baseball with neighborhood boys. Babe Ruth tossed an occasional ball with them. Always a rascal, David once happened upon New York City Police routing a gang; he stayed to watch the firefight. However, he neglected to mention this to his parents who later saw a newspaper photo of the raid; young David was perched just outside of the line of fire. David attended the University of Illinois and served in the US Army during WWII. He co-founded Timpson, Kramer and Crane, a successful food brokerage business in the mid-60s. A lifelong Republican, he was surrounded by a family of staunch Democrats, providing fodder for his love of boisterous political argument. Above all else, David valued family, friends and a good party. When his final illness robbed him of his voice, he joined in a raucous dinner by whispering a joke to one of his daughters line by line so that she could broadcast it to the clan. His beloved wife, Carol, his daughters, Susan Crane (Terry Etapa), Andrea Crane-Rabe, and Nancy Crane (Tom Butler), his brother Gerald (Joan), his grandsons Eric and Dan Rabe (Paula), and numerous nephews and nieces survive him. When asked what he wanted his obituary to say David retorted: "Tell anyone who owes me money to send it to Carol."

Subscribers have to pay at least $195 a year to get Andrew Harper's Hideaway Report, a monthly newsletter that reviews luxury hotels and resorts. Now the famously discerning Mr. Harper is giving away some of his tips, in a new iPad app. Andrew Harper's Paris, available at iTunes.com, covers restaurants, shops and attractions as well as hotels. Eschewing the model of most guidebooks, which survey the travel landscape more comprehensively, the app is, according to a welcome letter, ''a selective and personal guide'' to the city.

In honor of Nora Ephron, who died last month, the Big City Book Club will revisit her early work as a journalist and essayist. In the 1960s and '70s, she wrote for magazines like Rolling Stone, New York and The New Yorker -- pieces collected in the anthologies ''Crazy Salad'' and ''Wallflower at the Orgy.'' We're going to read ''Wallflower'' because it's more readily available, but if you're lucky enough to have an old copy of ''Crazy Salad,'' reread it, too, and weigh in!

VEIT--Henri Charles, 87, of Hadlyme, CT, died on June 23, 2012. Harry was born in Paris, France. The son of Russell Charles Veit and Emilienne Bompard Veit, Grandson of well-known 19th-20th century painter Maurice Bompard. Harry served in the US Navy during WWII and was Princeton class of '46. He worked for US Steel in Lima Peru and London and later as chief librarian of the Brooklyn, New York Public Library. Harry was predeceased by sister Mary V. Kane and is survived by brothers Richard B. Veit of San Rafael, CA and Alexander E. Veit of Grasse, France. Funeral Services are private but donations may be made in his memory to the Lyme Public Library, 482 Hamburg Rd., Lyme, CT 06371. Fulton-Theroux Funeral Home, Old Lyme is assisting with the services.

Hyper-parenting has many pitfalls. Overprotected and overpraised children may develop an inflated sense of entitlement. Parents who obsess about every detail and orchestrate their children's ''résumés'' may run themselves ragged while their own identities and relationships wither. But are involved parents creating spoiled Peter and Priscilla Pans who refuse to grow up? Or are parents and youths simply trying to navigate new obstacles that make the route to adulthood more circuitous?
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel visits the remote Lofoten Islands, above the Arctic Circle (above), where he encounters perpetual daylight, whale steaks and plenty of friendly Norwegians.

Dots are covering the facade of the Louis Vuitton Fifth Avenue store, which in collaboration with the 83-year-old artist Yayoi Kusama, top right, created windows and merchandise being sold in the shop covered in her signature dots. In conjunction with the store's unveiling last Tuesday, the Whitney Museum of American Art previewed its retrospective of the Japanese artist. Passers-by stopped at a window to photograph a lifelike wax model of the diminutive artist, who often placed herself in her art. This last spring, the fashion designer Rei Kawakubo showed clothes with huge dots.

RADWANER--Irving. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death on Friday, July 13 of Irving Radwaner, beloved father of our friend and partner Valerie E. Radwaner. We express our deepest sympathies to Valerie and to all members of the family.
